HEADLINE: Bitter Harvest

BYLINE: By David Kusnet; David Kusnet, a visiting fellow at the Economic Policy Institute, was chief speechwriter for President Clinton from 1992 to 1994.

 BODY:

WITH THESE HANDS
 The Hidden World of Migrant Farmworkers Today.
 By Daniel Rothenberg.
 Illustrated. 334 pp. New York:
 Harcourt Brace & Company. $28. 
 When it comes to the farm workers' plight, the union organizer Ernesto Galarza once said that the nation's conscience "flickered and died down like a firefly." Daniel Rothenberg's "With These Hands" seeks to reawaken the public concern that once burned bright.
From a century ago, when California growers hired Asian immigrants to harvest their crops, the fruits and vegetables Americans eat have been picked by social and economic outcasts. Over the years, farm owners turned to poor whites (including Depression-era refugees from the Dust Bowl who were disparagingly called Okies), poor blacks and generations of immigrants from Mexico and, more recently, the Caribbean. Always, these workers have trekked across the countryside following the harvest, living in ramshackle housing, suffering from low wages and no benefits and enjoying few of the essentials most people take for granted, from clean drinking water to toilets on their work sites.
Yet efforts to improve conditions for farm workers seem to emerge only every 30 years. During the 1930's and 40's, agricultural and cannery workers conducted ambitious but ultimately unsuccessful organizing campaigns. Thirty years later the United Farm Workers, under the charismatic leadership of Cesar Chavez, organized some 80,000 members, building a base that has since eroded. In both eras, farm workers were supported by Americans whose consciences had been stirred by novels and news reports, from John Steinbeck's "Grapes of Wrath" to Edward R. Murrow's "Harvest of Shame."
Appearing just as farm workers are striving to rebuild their union, Rothenberg's book should play a modest but useful part in exposing the underground economy that produces much of our food. Approximately 1.5 million seasonal farm workers -- almost half of them migrants -- work intermittently for an average of $6,500 a year. Murrow and Steinbeck would have recognized the abuses that Rothenberg reports: piecework that pays less than the minimum wage, workers housed in chicken coops and herded across the countryside by unscrupulous labor contractors, work camps in the rural South where poor blacks are confined in conditions recalling sharecropping and slavery.
A former legal services aide in Florida's farm country, Rothenberg conducted over 250 interviews with farm workers, contractors, growers, government investigators and union organizers, and his most moving passages are those where people relate their own stories in their own words. Often, there's plain-spoken poetry amid the poverty and pain. A contractor who was once a farm worker says she tells her daughter, "I was never a child." A migrant laborer recalls that he began drinking "to feel better, so as not to think so much."
This is oral history at its best, but "With These Hands" displays the genre's weaknesses as well as its strengths. Rothenberg's treatment of the larger context for the farm workers' plight is sketchy and repetitive, and the book would have benefited from greater explanation and analysis.
Rothenberg could have done more to emphasize the extent to which farm workers have been marginalized by design. In 1935, Congress excluded them from the National Labor Relations Act, which guaranteed most workers the right to organize. From 1942 through 1964, the "bracero" program admitted more than four million guest workers, providing agribusiness with a steady supply of low-wage labor and isolating these workers from the mainstream economy.
If there is an implicit message to this worthwhile survey of America's most exploited workers, it is that somehow their isolation must end. But in the face of employer opposition, episodic public concern, ineffective Government regulation and even attempts in Congress to revive the bracero program, this effort will not be easy.

HEADLINE: Sparring for Liberty

BYLINE: By Pauline Maier; Pauline Maier's latest book is "American Scripture: Making the Declaration of Independence."

 BODY:

THE STORY OF AMERICAN FREEDOM
 By Eric Foner.
 Illustrated. 422 pp. New York:
 W. W. Norton & Company. $27.95. 
 Most Americans understand the history of their freedom in an uncomplicated way: the Founding Fathers laid down principles of American liberty that their descendants have been applying ever since, steadily "augmenting the happiness and value of life to all people of all colors everywhere," as Abraham Lincoln put it.
Eric Foner disagrees. "The story of American freedom," he says, "is not simply a saga of a fixed set of rights to which one group after another has gained access," but "a tale of debates, disagreements and struggles" with lots of bumps and wrong turns along the way. Moreover, American freedom itself is "not a single idea" but a "complex of values" that have changed over time, taking on meanings unknown to Jefferson and his contemporaries. Yet freedom, he says, provides a unifying thread for our national experience.
Foner, the DeWitt Clinton Professor of History at Columbia University, presents "The Story of American Freedom" as an answer to those who say that the study of our history has become "so fragmented and trivialized that it is no longer possible to view American society whole." But an account of the American past using freedom as an "organizing theme" needs to be written in "new ways," he says, showing how the "universalities" of our political culture were constructed so that they benefited some Americans and excluded others, and how freedom as we know it is a product of protracted struggles by those who were once excluded -- particularly workers, women and racial minorities -- to win access to its blessings.
The book's strongest claim to distinction lies, however, not in its approach but in its succinct, information-packed, wonderfully readable account of the twists and turns in 20th-century American history, which claims about a quarter of the book's chronological range but over half its basic text. In little more than 200 pages, Foner traces the development of American freedom through a time that saw a fundamental reconsideration of the relationship between liberty and the state, the "birth of civil liberties," dramatic changes in the status of women, a substantial dismantling of institutionalized racism and the arrival of multiculturalism. He covers that story capaciously, explaining critical economic, social, political and legal developments, and he draws on a large cast of characters, from Samuel Gompers and W. E. B. Du Bois through Margaret Sanger and Franklin Roosevelt to Friedrich A. Hayek, Milton Friedman and Ronald Reagan, all of whose places in the narrative are briefly but usefully described. That makes "The Story of American Freedom" an excellent choice for serious readers tired of pretending they know more about contemporary history than they do but unwilling to plow through a library of books to solve the problem.
Foner summarizes earlier periods of American history, upon which much of his previous writing focused, with far less detail. Only one of 13 chapters examines the "birth of American freedom" in Britain and in colonial and revolutionary America, although a second addresses the issue of slavery in the early republic. During the American Revolution, he says, colonists abandoned narrow claims to "British freedom" and adopted instead the "language of natural rights and universal liberty." American citizenship was nonetheless confined to whites: as the nation's first Attorney General, Edmund Randolph, put it, slaves were not "constituent members of our society."
The obvious inconsistency between the country's public commitment to human freedom and its system of black chattel slavery did, however, produce a late-18th-century emancipation movement, which was confined to the Northern states and a set of slaveholders in the upper South who voluntarily freed their slaves. As a result, the United States acquired a community of free blacks who became the nation's most ardent critics of slavery and, with white abolitionist allies, advocates of a genuinely universal, color-blind American liberty. Their opponents also saw themselves as defenders of liberty, which for them centered upon the sanctity of property rights, including property in men.
With the Union victory in the Civil War, the "abolitionist vision" triumphed and "liberty became a universal principle" that crossed racial lines to the benefit of not just blacks but all Americans. "Slavery" quickly became a powerful metaphor for those seeking the "emancipation" of workers or women. However, the full impact of the war's outcome was felt, Foner says, only in the 20th century, when the Supreme Court began using the 14th Amendment (1868), which prohibited states from abridging "the privileges and immunities of citizens" or denying them "the equal protection of the law," to force general compliance with the Bill of Rights. That document finally became what it had never been before, a powerful guarantee of civil liberties against violations by not just the Federal Government but also the states and, beginning in the 1930's, private organizations as well.
In addition, the Civil War brought a shift "from antebellum anti-institutionalism . . . to a state-centered vision" of reform that, again, would be fully realized only much later, after overcoming a powerful movement in the opposite direction. In the late 19th century, "classical liberals" committed to limited government and laissez-faire economics used the 14th Amendment not to protect black rights, its original purpose, but to promote "the unfettered operations of the capitalist marketplace." The "fetters" they opposed included laws regulating working conditions and collective bargaining, which some employers described as "an infringement of personal liberty and a menace to the institutions of a free people." Industrial workers, who needed unions to acquire bargaining power comparable to that of their employers, had a different notion of liberty.
So did sociologists like Lester Ward, who argued that in the modern world "individual freedom can only come through social regulation." Under the influence of 20th-century writers like Herbert Croly and, above all, in the hands of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, "liberalism" was redefined as a commitment to "an activist, socially conscious state" that worked for civil rights and racial equality as well as economic democracy. Or was governmental "planning for freedom" an oxymoron, as the influential Austrian-born British economist Friedrich Hayek argued in 1944, since "planning leads to dictatorship"?
Similar disagreements weave through the story of 20th-century freedom. Did the maternalist welfare legislation of the early 20th century promote women's freedom or institutional gender inequality? Was the black power movement of the 1960's a step toward or away from the integrated, egalitarian society that most civil rights workers hoped to establish? Anomalies and contradictions also proliferated, particularly in wartime. The American struggle to "make the world safe for democracy" in World War I let loose an orgy of repression and racial violence at home. In World War II, the United States again fought for freedom but violated the civil liberties of those West Coast Japanese-Americans who were herded into internment camps. The nation's cold war campaign against Soviet "slavery" made some of the greatest tyrants part of the "free world" and led to extraordinary violations of Americans' right of free speech in the name of anti-Communism.
No separate conclusion summarizes the meaning of the story. Foner reveals his political sympathies only in the closing paragraphs of an even-handed final chapter on contemporary "conservative freedom" and in occasional judgments within the text, like his endorsement of the 1962 Port Huron statement of student radicals as having been written in "the language of Jefferson and Emerson, of Garrison, Debs and Dewey." Or does the whole structure of the book reflect his politics? "The Story of American Freedom" is perhaps less an example of "new ways" to study the past than a familiar left-wing approach to American history. The left, it is often said, dwells on conflict, contradictions and the "underside" of American history, while the right seeks out consensus and achievement, the stuff of celebration. Conflict and consensus, however, go together, since it's difficult to have a really good fight without shared premises.
The question here is whether there have been more enduring conceptions of American freedom than Foner allows. Consider, for example, the beliefs he attributes to early-20th-century immigrants who considered the United States a "land of freedom" because here men were "equal before the law, could worship as they pleased, enjoyed economic opportunity" and were free from "oppressive social hierarchies." Each item on that list had roots in the Revolutionary era, when the meaning and practical implications of freedom were already the subject of intense debate. In fact, the persistence of both ideals and conflict is not surprising. Principles remain separate only in the abstract; when applied to real life, they have a tendency to interfere with one another, raising issues of balance and choice. Abstract principles of liberty are also notorious for undermining practices that the first asserters of those principles consider beyond criticism, inspiring new divisions over new causes.
Anxious to avoid reading history backwards, Foner underplays the revolutionary origins of American ideas of freedom, but the characters in his story did not. They continually cited what "those who won our independence believed" to support their positions or to criticize those of others. Devotion to a shared (if continually reinterpreted) 18th-century tradition gave some bounds to Americans' debates over the meaning of liberty and suggests that what Foner describes as novel developments were often understood as efforts to eliminate hypocrisy by reconciling practice with principle, or to adapt older ideals to novel situations. "Reconstruction represented less a fulfillment of the Revolution's principles," he says, "than a radical repudiation of the nation's actual practice for the previous seven decades." Couldn't it be both?
In the end, however, it's hard to disagree with either Foner's assertion that the specific content of American freedom has changed -- George Washington, after all, lost little sleep over gay rights -- or his description of the process by which those changes occurred. Dissent is the way American freedom has been defined, extended and, indeed, kept alive far longer than the founders thought possible. The greatest danger to liberty lies, as Justice Brandeis said, in an "inert people" -- in a silent, self-absorbed citizenry that doesn't care enough to join the argument.

LENGTH: 2235 words

HEADLINE: A Quiet Quarter and its Crown Jewel

BYLINE: By ANN PRINGLE-HARRIS; ANN PRINGLE-HARRIS visits Paris regularly.

 BODY:
JUST as there are New Yorkers who don't know the wonders of Brooklyn and the Bronx, so there are Parisians who know nothing of the 19th arrondissement, a district with an eventful history, colorful neighborhoods and -- its crown jewel -- Les Buttes-Chaumont, one of Paris's loveliest parks.
Situated at the northeastern edge of the city, the 19th became a part of Paris proper through the annexation in 1860 of the village of La Villette and the Commune of Belleville. Both territories -- Belleville being rough and hilly and La Villette flat with rich sources of water -- were, in pre-Revolutionary France, stopping points where a fee had to be paid to the king before wine and produce were permitted to pass into the city. All of that ended during Napoleon's time, but not before enterprising citizens had scaled fortified walls and dug underground passageways in order to move goods into Paris without paying the hated fees. 
 A couple of hundred years ago there were fertile grain fields on the plain of La Villette and vineyards on the hills of Buttes-Chaumont. But Buttes-Chaumont's principal source of wealth during the late 18th and early 19th centuries was quarrying. One part of the district was named, and is still called, the Quartier d'Amerique because so much of the gypsum quarried there was sent to America. Local legend has it that gypsum from the quarter was used in the foundation of the White House.
By the mid-19th century, quarrying in the quarter had largely ended, and the former quarrying sites had become a haunt for vagabonds and derelicts, as well as a source of noxious emanations from local dumping grounds. It was an unfortunate comedown for a formerly prosperous working-class neighborhood, but there was a happy ending. The city planners, chief among them Baron Georges Eugene Haussmann, the genius behind Paris's grand boulevards and its urban vistas, decided to create a new park. At the time, the aim was to sanitize the district. Clean air, open spaces, hygienic conditions -- these were what the park was to give to the city's residents.
From the beginning, though, the 62-acre park had a magic about it, a magic that artists in particular recognized. At its opening in 1867, its heights and vistas were compared to the stanzas of a beautiful poem. In the early 1920's, the writer Louis Aragon, night-prowling with his fellow surrealist Andre Breton, wrote that the very name Buttes-Chaumont evoked a "mirage" that held them "spellbound."
Finding this mirage not only real but also open at night, Aragon proclaimed it "an oasis in a sinister working-class neighborhood," a "mad eyrie which sprang from the head of an architect influenced alike by . . . Jean-Jacques Rousseau and by the economic conditions of Parisian life." In his book "Le Paysan de Paris," Aragon develops within the framework of this night visit to Buttes-Chaumont his theories of the fluid intermingling of nature, art, fantasy and the unfettered imagination.
In none of my exploratory walks in June through the Buttes-Chaumont district did I find a sinister working-class neighborhood. I found instead the mix of residential and commercial streets common to outlying arrondissements, with dwellings that ranged from handsome turn-of-the-century apartment-house blocks to cottage-size houses whose small gardens open onto cobblestoned alleyways just about wide enough for one car. Some are ivy-covered, some have trellised rose gardens or wisteria arbors; all have the charm of the country in an urban venue.
To stroll through some of these mews -- they are called Villas -- walk along the Rue du General Brunet, the Rue de Mouzaia and the Rue Miguel-Hidalgo, near the Botzaris entrance to the park, and you will find at least a dozen of them. The neighborhood is part of the Quartier d'Amerique, but the street names have various associations. The Villas Emile-Loubet, Sadi-Carnot and Felix-Faure are named for former presidents of the French Republic. Mouzaia commemorates a conflict between the French and Muslim forces of Algeria in 1839. Joined to one another in a Y shape in 1889, the Rues Liberte, Egalite and Fraternite commemorate a centennial that needs no identification.
Venturing into other neighborhoods that border the park, a guide to the 19th arrondissement tucked under my arm, I came upon St.-Serge, a Russian Orthodox Church at 93 Rue de Crimee. The building was acquired by the Orthodox Church during the influx of Russian emigres to Paris after the First World War and the Russian Revolution. When I arrived, in the early evening, a young man was retouching the splendid painted wood porch and double staircase leading up to the sanctuary. Inside, I was dazzled by the iconostasis of gold-haloed saints, by richly painted walls and ceiling and windows with a folk art feeling in bright blue, red, green and yellow. There was also a lovely harmonic hum whose source I couldn't find until I moved toward the altar and saw on my left a trio of men who obviously formed a choir. I had happily stumbled upon a vespers service.
On the same property, an institute of theology was established in 1925. Courses are taught in French and Russian, and graduates have gone on to become priests, bishops and monks in many parts of the world.
The prime attraction of the 19th arrondissement, of course, is the Parc des Buttes-Chaumont. It is at once wild and sequestered, yet is served by four Metro stops; a refuge from buses and street noise that is nevertheless bound on all sides by residential and commercial avenues to which the park's several gates give easy access. Step into the park and you get a sense of having strayed into one of those picturesque landscapes dear to the hearts of 19th-century romantics -- yet the city's muffled hum remains a reassuring presence. You aren't lost, you've simply been temporarily spirited away.
Part of the ambitious plan behind the park was to conserve some of the towering gypsum deposits remaining on the site and convert them into the natural-seeming precipices that visitors climb today. Indeed, the entire plan for the park was to take what nature provided and elevate it into art. Engineering and landscaping the site under Haussmann's supervision, Adolphe Alphand and Jean-Pierre Barillet-Deschamps constructed a three-tiered cascade from on-site rocks and gypsum, troughs for flowing rivulets of water and paths that lead strollers upward to fresh breezes and glorious views.
The park is shaped somewhat like a crescent that has been widened and squared off at one end. Near its center is a lake, and in the middle of the lake is an island, accessible by two bridges. One stands 88 feet above ground level, a noteworthy height in a low-profile city, and promptly acquired the nickname le pont des suicides. Today, a guard rail protects against leaps or falls.
On my first visit to Buttes-Chaumont I took a leisurely walk around the lake, wondering how to reach the belvedere and its small Greek-style temple. Since I could see people up there, I knew there must be steps, and a waiter from a nearby restaurant showed me where they were. I dutifully climbed the 84 stone steps to the belvedere and the 12 cement steps leading to the top of the temple, looked around and instantly forgot about soreness of muscle and shortness of breath. To my left were the domes of Sacre Coeur, dark silhouettes against an azure-blue sky. From that vantage point, the park seemed round and so did the city, and I stood at the very center of it.
As its planners intended, Buttes-Chaumont combines natural beauty and human ingenuity. In the grotto, once a major quarry site, water crashes from a height of about 100 feet over rocks both real and artificial -- a wall of water dropping into a pool below. If you stand in the grotto and close your eyes, you can easily imagine yourself in a cool, deep cavern, your skin freshened by a light spray from the falling water. Glancing up, you see stalactites that look the way stalactites should look -- but they are of cement. Similarly, running your hand over the rough-barked branches that fence in some walking paths, you realize that you are fingering Art Nouveau branches fashioned from cement. The seemingly artless alpine look of the park, its hills and valleys, actually took several years of hard labor to create; the natural terrain was just a starting point.
The original buildings that remain in the park -- chalet-style guardhouses at the gated entrances and some rustic-looking refreshment stands -- enhance this illusion of a mountain village at the edge of Paris. So does the open-air Theatre Anatole just inside the park entrance at the Place Armand-Carrel. If you are in Paris any time from April through October, you can see Grand-Guignol puppet performances under a striped tent on weekends and school holidays when the weather permits. On the day I visited, children between the ages of about 3 and 10 were lined up awaiting the 3 o'clock performance of "Les Fantomes du Chateau." Wandering inadvertently into a space reserved for unescorted youngsters, I was politely shown to a back bench, where I enjoyed the audience as much as the show. The children screamed directions at the puppet actors, shouted their answers to questions from the stage, laughed at the stupid, greedy servant and giggled nervously at the white-sheeted phantom. They gave new meaning to the term interactive theater. And this kind of theater has a bonus for apprentices in the language: the plots are simple, the words follow the action, and the diction is loud and clear.
IF a shrug is the correct Gallic response to today's fitness craze, Buttes-Chaumont residents haven't caught on. On early-evening visits to the park (the place easily becomes habit-forming) I regularly saw runners exchanging sweaty handshakes and arranging their next meeting. I saw groups doing calisthenics, and serious walkers along with those who were strolling with their children or exercising their pets. Signs at the entrance to the park announced races for various age groups.
The 19th arrondissement doesn't specialize in lavish restaurants, but visitors needn't go hungry. There are pleasant neighborhood bistros and, in the park, stands that sell crepes, waffles, ice cream, snacks and cold drinks. The Weber Cafe, on the Allee de la Cascade, serves teas, drinks and light meals, and the Pavillon du Lac has two pretty lakeside terraces where food and drinks are served, when the weather permits, from breakfast through lunch and up till 7 P.M. For formal dining, the Pavillon Puebla, just inside the park entrance near the Bolivar Metro stop, is popular. It serves Catalan cuisine in an attractive Second Empire setting, but the place to dine in fair weather is its two outdoor terraces, shaded and inviting with their umbrellas and greenery. Atmosphere is part of the charm here, but the food is good. I enjoyed my baked calamari in shellfish sauce with saffron rice and a gateau de riz (I'd call it rice pudding) with orange confit sauce.
If it's a quick drink or caffeine fix you have in mind, head for the Place Rhin-et-Danube, a 10- or 15-minute walk east from the park on Rue Miguel-Hidalgo. Named for battles fought in Germany near the end of World War II, in which the French First Army took part, the place brings into focus bits of the district's past. In its center, a statue of a powerful woman striding along with a sheaf of wheat under her arm symbolizes the area's agricultural history but also the quarry workers who later brought prosperity to the quarter. Facing the statue is Le Cafe Parisien, with its small, companionable terrace and supercharged coffee. It's a neighborhood favorite whose decor -- old hollywood movie posters -- befits its location in the Quartier d'Amerique of Les Buttes-Chaumont.
 
A poet's park
Buttes-Chaumont and Botzaris are the closest Metro stops to the park; Bolivar and Laumiere are within walking distance.
The park is open from 6:45 A.M. to 9 P.M. in winter, 6:45 A.M. to 11 P.M. in summer.
 
Exploring
 Information on guided visits in English may be obtained through the Paris Tourist Bureau, (33-1) 49.52.53.54, 127 Avenue des Champs-Elysees.
Travelers who know some French will find an excellent walker's guide to the park, with information about the surrounding district and suggested itineraries at the visitors center of the 19th Arrondissement Mairie, (33-1) 44.52.28.80, 5-7 Place Armand Carrel.
"Le Guide du Promeneur: 19th Arrondissement" by Elisabeth Philipp (Editions Parigramme), a walker's guide in French, is available at F.N.A.C. stores ($16.35).
 The Theatre Anatole, (33-1) 43.98.10.95, is just inside the entrance to the park at the Place
Armand-Carrel. Grand Guignol puppet performances are given Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays and school holidays from April to October (when the weather permits) at 3 and 6:30 P.M. and at 4 P.M. in July and August.
 
Where to Eat
Le Pavillon Puebla, (33-1) 42.08.92.62, near the angle of the park where the Rue Botzaris and the Rue Simon Bolivar meet, serves lunch and dinner every day except Sundays, Mondays and holidays. Three-course meals without wine start at about $35.
Le Cafe Parisien, (33-1) 42.06.02.75, 2 Place Rhin-et-Danube, serves drinks, sandwiches and salads until 2 A.M. every day except Sunday; an espresso costs about $1.75 ($1.10 at the bar).

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN?;
Hawaii

BYLINE: By JOCELYN FUJII; JOCELYN FUJII lives in Honolulu.

 BODY:
When leaf-peeping northeasterners begin retiring their binoculars for the year, Hawaii residents start dusting theirs off. November opens the unofficial season of rubbernecking, a time when migrating whales and big-wave riders turn the ocean into the site of the islands' favorite spectator sports.
Unlike the economy and the weather, the humpback whales can be counted on. They return in late November and stay until April or May, breaching, spouting, mating and calving spectacularly in the island waters that serve as their refuge from the icy ones they have left behind in Alaska. As for surfing, winter is its zenith, a time when "pray for surf" is the prevailing mantra and waves aren't big unless they're 15 feet or higher. On the north shore of Oahu, the coastline becomes theater: no wave is too large for the world's most daring and accomplished surfers, who look like specks in the winter swell. 
 These attractions are free, a considerable plus in a state reeling with economic woes. The disappearance of Japanese investment and the decline in tourism have come on the heels of widespread plantation shutdowns, calling upon the adaptive spirit of Hawaii's people.
Attractive rates in hotel, air fare and travel packages can be found in November and the first three weeks of December. In this shoulder season (high season begins around Christmas and lasts until mid-April), the islands are less crowded and the weather, as in late spring, is at its best, averaging in the mid-70's -- although several degrees warmer on the Kona-Kohala coast.
With events from "The Nutcracker" to the Hawaii International Film Festival, culture addicts, like surfers and luau aficionados, have a full plate in the weeks to come.
 
Events
Josef Albers, Sol Lewitt, Andy Warhol, Jasper Johns, Frank Stella, Richard Diebenkorn, Roy Lichtenstein and Claes Oldenburg are among the 40 artists represented in "First Decade: Highlights from the Contemporary Museum's Collection," opening Friday and running through Jan. 3 at the Contemporary Museum, 2411 Makiki Heights Drive, Honolulu. Robert Motherwell's "Elegy With Rice Paper and Blue," from his series "Elegies to the Spanish Republic," is among the works not previously shown here. The museum is set in a garden in the hills overlooking the city. Open Tuesday to Sunday, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Admission: $5. (808) 526-0232.
In Hilo, on the Big Island, the film critic Roger Ebert and Nadia Tass, an Australian director, will help reopen the historic Palace Theater, where Ms. Tass's film "Amy" will be shown on Nov. 13, 38 Haili Street at 6:30 P.M. as part of the Hawaii International Film Festival. More than 150 films will be shown from Nov. 6 to 19 throughout the Islands. Renovation of the 73-year-old neo-classical theater is not complete, but this will be the first screening of films there since 1982. Admission is $10 for the "Amy" premiere, otherwise $5; (808) 528-4433 or (800) 752-8193.
A storm in the Aleutians would be great news for big-wave riders and spectators hoping for epic El Nino-generated surf at this year's Vans G-Shock Triple Crown of Surfing Series, from Nov. 5 through Dec. 20 at Haleiwa Beach, Sunset, and Pipeline on Oahu's North Shore. Top professional surfers will compete for $1 million in men's and women's events. Free admission; (808) 637-6376 for daily recorded information.
The grape, the cowboy and good food are the topics at Mauna Kea Resort's annual Winter Wine Escape, Nov. 12 to 14 at 62-100 Mauna Kea Beach Drive, and at Hapuna Beach Prince Hotel, 62-100 Kaunaoa Beach Drive, on the Big Island's Kohala Coast. Mainland and Hawaii chefs and nearly 70 vintners present tastings and feasts. In this Year of the Paniolo honoring the Hawaiian cowboy, the Parker Ranch in Waimea will be one of the sites. Admission: $25 to $125; accommodations packages available; (800) 882-6060.
Ballet Hawaii will present "The Nutcracker" Dec. 18 to 20 at the Blaisdell Concert Hall, 777 Ward Avenue, with guest artists from the American Ballet Theater. Admission: $15 to $35; (808) 591-2211.
 
Sightseeing
Good timing, powerful binoculars and quick reflexes (to pull over if you're driving, or to drop whatever you're doing if you're not) are useful when humpbacks appear, most reliably along the west and south Maui shoreline. Favorable vantage points along the west shore include Pap awai Point, McGregor Point scenic overlook, Launiupoko State Wayside and Wahikuli State Wayside; on the south shore, Wailea Beach Park and the dining rooms of the deluxe Wailea resorts. On Oahu, Makapuu Point, Waikiki and the Kaena Point Trail on the leeward coastline can be center stage. The Pacific Whale Foundation, 101 North Kihei Road, supports its research with daily whale-watching cruises beginning Dec. 1 on Maui, $22 to $31; (800) 942-5311.
At the Maui Ocean Center, a new five-acre marine park at 192 Maalaea Road, life-size whale models are part of the 60 exhibits. Jaws drop during shark feeding and in the 54-foot walk-through tunnel aquarium. Admission: $17.50, $12 for children; open daily 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., (808) 270-7000.
Sections of a 22.5-mile network of ditches, flumes and tunnels built in 1906 to irrigate sugar plantations have been transformed into an easy, meandering waterway for kayaking. Guides with the Kohala Mountain Kayak Cruise explain the region's history while gliding in the narrow outdoor flumes that traverse rain forest and stands of wild ginger. Headquarters are in Hawi, at the junction of Highways 270 and 250. Cost for the 75-minute paddle: $75, $55 ages 5 to 18; (808) 889-6922.
The Old Lahaina Luau on Maui -- in moving to a larger oceanfront site, 1251 Front Street in Lahaina six months ago -- has reinvented itself authentically in a genre rife with cliche. At sunset, guests sit at tables or on lauhala fiber mats on the ground in front of a grass-mound stage. The program offers intelligent narration and excellent ancient hula (the absence of fire dancing is noted but not lamented). There are no watered-down mai tais and, like the atmosphere, the food is authentic Hawaiian, and delicious. Admission: $65, $30 for children; (808) 667-1998.
On Oahu, Pearl Harbor's newest resident, the 887-foot Missouri, where Gen. Douglas MacArthur accepted Japan's surrender, is being scrubbed, buffed and prepared for its opening in January as a national memorial and museum. It is moored near the Arizona, sunk during the Pearl Harbor attack. Guided tours will be $14; (808) 545-2263.
 
Where to Stay
The new Waimea Brewing Company, at Waimea Plantation Cottages, 9400 Kaumualii Highway, Waimea, may seem out of character in a retro-historic plantation village, but in the dusty, dry plains of this west Kauai town, there's something to be said for cold beer. The 48 authentic plantation cottages from the early 1900's were moved from a nearby plantation and faithfully restored and equipped with verandas and full kitchens. For those heading for the Waimea Canyon and Kokee State Park, this is the last hostelry before the 4,000-foot ascent. Rates: $170 to $500; (808) 338-1625, fax (808) 338-2338.
On the Hana coast in east Maui, a three-hour drive from Kahului Airport, the once musty Heavenly Hana Inn, 4155 Hana Highway, reopened in June behind its signature bamboo gate as a sleek, stunning Japanese-style hostelry of three suites under one roof but each with separate entrance. Lush gardens surround the studio and suites and the grand dining room, featuring exotic woods and impressive craftsmanship. Rates: $100 to $235; (808) 248-8442.
Shipman House Bed and Breakfast Inn, 131 Kaiulani Street, Hilo, on the Big Island, won the 1998 Historic Preservation Award from the Historic Hawaii Foundation. It recently completed the renovation of its conservatory, which will serve as the meeting room in this 100-year-old Victorian mansion. Rates in the three rooms and a guest cottage with two units are $130 to $150; (800) 627-8447, fax (808) 934-8002.
Budget: Scarcely a year old, the Old Wailuku Inn at Ulupono, 2199 Kahookele Street, Wailuku, helps make central Maui a viable destination on this shoreline-crazy island. Situated near Iao Valley, the Hawaii Nature Center, a block of antiques shops, and mom-and-pop restaurants, this two-story, seven-room inn, built in 1924, is filled with vintage Hawaiiana. Notable features include the original ohia and eucalyptus floors. Rates: $120 to $180; (808) 244-5897, fax (808) 242-9600.
Luxury: With lava from an 1801 flow as its foundation, it was no surprise that Hualalai Resort, Kaahumanu Highway, Kaupulehu, Kona, on the Big Island, which contains the 243-room Four Seasons Resort Hualalai, has added hot stone therapy to its spa offerings. Smooth stream rocks are heated and placed on massage points. The low-rise, bungalow-style resort's educational programs for guests, including celestial navigation, are firmly anchored in Hawaiian culture. Room-car or room-breakfast packages are available for $390 to $930; (808) 325-8000, fax (808) 325-8100.
With all 191 guest rooms and three suites fully renovated last fall, Kapalua Bay Hotel, 1 Bay Drive, Kapalua, Maui, has awakened from a long slumber. Eco-tourists love the hiking and environmental progams of the Kapalua Nature Society, based in this quietly luxurious resort. Rates from $275; (800) 367-8000, fax (808) 669-4694.
 
Where to Eat
Those expecting attitude at the newly opened Neiman Marcus restaurant, Mariposa, 1450 Ala Moana Boulevard, Honolulu, will be pleasantly surprised -- efforts to integrate casualness with fine dining have succeeded. Lanai seating offers great views of park and beach, and the American and regional menu highlights local ingredients. The excellent wine list (38 by the glass) has good prices. Dinner for two with wine, about $80; (808) 951-3420.
Hoku's at the Kahala Mandarin Oriental Hotel, 5000 Kahala Avenue, Honolulu, has a new culinary team: executive chef Markus Greiner, formerly of the Regent Hotel in Hong Kong, and executive sous-chef Wayne Hirabayashi, fomerly of the Halekulani Hotel. They have been luring new diners to the elegant ocean-view dining room, and keeping the faithful, with favorites like grilled misoyaki vegetables with taro gnocchi and deep-fried whole island fish. Dinner for two with wine, $130; (808) 739-8777.
It has been a stellar lobster season on the north shore of Kauai, where Roadrunner Bakery and Cafe, 2430 Oka Street, Kilauea, also features organic local vegetables, 30 types of chilies, and pork, fish and free-range chicken. Lobster fajitas ($16.95) and tacos prove that lobsters can be fresh, good and cheap. Dinner for two (bring your own wine) is about $35; (808) 828-8226.
Sansei Seafood Restaurant and Sushi Bar, 115 Bay Drive, Kapalua, Maui, has turned the formerly moribund Kapalua Shops into a culinary hot spot. Dishes include Asian rock shrimp cake, shrimp-nori ravioli and tradition-defying sushi with tangy sauces and unorthodox pairings. Dinner for two with sake, about $50; (808) 669-6286.
In whale-watching territory on the south shore, Nick's Fishmarket Maui opened two months ago in the striking Kea Lani Hotel, 4100 Wailea Alanui, Wailea. Fresh seafood includes succulent Tristan lobster and elegant snapper in several preparations. Dinner for two with wine, about $120; (808) 879-7224.

HEADLINE: A Winter Haven for Birds And Frontier Historians

BYLINE: By ROB NIXON; ROB NIXON is the author of "Dreambirds," about ostriches and desert places, to be published by Doubleday/Anchor in England in the spring.

 BODY:
BOB MILES, an Arizona Game and Fish agent, peered at his watch and announced with the authority of an air-traffic controller: "They should be taking off in a few minutes. It's almost 7:15." I was standing with a group of 20 other visitors on the edge of Willcox Playa, a 50-square-mile dead lake in southeast Arizona. We were waiting for first light and the first cranes.
Meanwhile, in the predawn frost, my toes were threatening to secede. Somewhere out there, 10,000 sandhill cranes had spent the last 12 hours standing in two inches of icy water. I asked Bob about crane frostbite. "Ah," he explained, "cranes have a shunt system that allows them to shut off the blood to their feet." That's an advantage they enjoy over their coyote enemies: "Coyotes don't like to get their feet wet." 
 The light began to turn pinky yellow above the Chiricahuas, which rise to over 9,000 feet near the Arizona-New Mexico border. On cue, the 7:15 cranes took to the air, cruising low overhead, long necks stretched forward, seven-foot wings spread wide. I could almost feel the draft from their wings as they passed, thousands of them, kar-r-r-r-o-o-o, kar-r-r-r-o-o-o-ing above us, all rolling their r's like Scots.
I had traveled to southeast Arizona for Wings Over Willcox, a three-day festival held each January to celebrate the region's remarkable natural and human history. Eight hundred visitors were in attendance. The cranes (which leave in March for Alaska, Canada and Siberia, returning in October) are the festival's principal attraction. But participants can choose from 18 half- or whole-day guided tours, focusing on everything from the area's bird life to its geology and frontier past.
Willcox itself, nine miles to the north, is an unassuming, raw-boned Western town of about 3,500. Founded in 1880 as a construction camp for the Southern Pacific Railroad, Willcox was soon shipping more cattle than any town in America, according to the Chamber of Commerce. But times have changed. The local economy now blends the old West with the new, relying on cattle, ecotourism, pistachios, hydroponic tomatoes, onions, a prison and, for their exotic leather, ostriches.
The town's being in the heart of Cochise County, about 80 miles east of Tucson, is its main appeal. Willcox is a place of confluence. It rests in the 100-mile-long Sulphur Springs Valley and is flanked by four ranges. On either side stretch two great deserts: the Sonoran and the more elevated Chihuahuan. These valley, desert and mountain corridors link Willcox to Mexico and give the local fauna and flora a subtropical dimension. They also create ideal circumstances for the cranes to congregate.
During my visit, I stayed at Muleshoe Ranch Preserve in preference to Willcox's chain motels. The Arizona Nature Conservancy, jointly with two Federal agencies, owns and operates Muleshoe, where accommodations consist of four renovated adobe casitas and (my choice) a two-room stone cabin beside a hot springs wash.
I have seldom been in a place so comfortable yet exquisitely remote. The nearest public telephone and store were back in Willcox, 30 juddery dirt miles to the east. But the tradeoff was considerable. During my time at Muleshoe, I didn't encounter another guest.
In a state where trees are as scarce as water, Muleshoe exudes abundance. Willows, Arizona sycamores, cottonwoods and scrub oaks line a latticework of streams. The growth attracts plants, birds and subtropical animals associated with Mexico. One morning, while wandering the dry washes, I disturbed a dozen javelina, 60-pound wild pigs. I stood quietly while they snuffled past, clicking their heels as they went.
Muleshoe's special allure is its two willow-shaded hot tubs -- simple galvanized-iron tanks that hold 115-degree water from the springs on the property. Their history goes back to 1875, when a rheumatic New Yorker, Dr. Glendys King, staked out a 160-acre homestead claim around the Muleshoe springs. Dr. King was shot in a boundary dispute before he could realize his fantasy of converting the property into a healing spa.
But when the cattle baron Henry Clay Hooker bought it in 1884, he started a newspaper trumpeting the miraculous powers of his springs. As enticements, Mr. Hooker added a croquet lawn, tennis courts and billiard tables. He buttonholed travelers alighting from the Willcox train and promised them quick cures for their pimples and dyspepsia.
In the closing years of the 19th century, Hooker's Hot Springs buzzed with 400 visitors each summer. But Western spoilers -- stagecoach robbers, rustlers, droughts and flash floods -- ruined Mr. Hooker's dream of turning Muleshoe into a badlands rendition of Baden-Baden in Germany.
As a birder, I was attracted first to Cochise County's ornithological riches: 500 bird types -- including 15 varieties of wintering hawks. I soon found equal pleasure, however, in the varied landscape and human history.
Around Willcox, frontier history gusts up from every gulch and gully. This is Geronimo, Buffalo soldier, Butterfield Trail and Wyatt Earp country. Behind the 19th-century Apache wars and the O.K. Corral shootout stands an older history of Mexican gold panners, 16th-century Spanish conquistadors, and Mogollon Indians. And behind them all stand the Clovis people, who inhabited the region at the end of the last ice age, preying on the mammoths, bison and camels that roamed Willcox Playa long before the cranes arrived.
I went to see some Clovis flint tools at the Amerind Foundation, 24 miles southwest of Willcox. Amerind is one of my favorite museums, almost as much for its location as for its stunning displays of American Indian cultures and histories. The foundation's Spanish Colonial Revival buildings -- miles from any other human habitation -- are humbled by the massive boulder formations of the surrounding Texas Canyon.
I have a fondness for experiencing history outdoors, so I took a trip offered through Wings Over Willcox to Fort Bowie, led by a National Park Service volunteer. Between 1862 and 1886, Fort Bowie served as the nerve center for United States military campaigns against the Chiricahua Apaches led first by Cochise and then Geronimo. The fort and Apache Pass are 36 miles east of Willcox, the last two on a washboarded dirt road. From there, we had to walk a hilly mile and a half to the ruins, passing through superb high desert country.
A recent notice at the trail head warned of several close encounters with mountain lions and advised visitors to carry a stick and not walk alone. The sign ended with the laconic reminder: "If attacked, remember to fight back aggressively." I made a mental note. Later, I learned from park rangers that chances of such an attack are slim but that turning your back and running is more dangerous than facing the animal.
Even in the absence of mountain lions, it was easy to see why Apache Pass gained a reputation as the most unnerving station on the 2,800-mile Butterfield Overland stage route, from St. Louis to San Francisco. With my eyes, I could follow bits of the old trail route. It threaded through ravines, meandering dry washes, rocky overhangs and sudden bends. This must have been formidable terrain for anyone to hold.
Fort Bowie's story is punctuated by kidnappings, ambushes, hangings, torture and decapitations, with unsteady truces in between. But like so much Western history, it is essentially the story of a water war -- the battle for Apache Spring.
En route to the fort ruins, our party passed the spring, a frail pool overhung with Arizona walnut trees. A quail covey was sipping there and flew off, clucking, as we approached. At this dry point in the year, the pool held no more water than would fill a few bathtubs. But the trickling spring flows incessantly, and so became a hallowed spot for the Apaches and a coveted one for white travelers crossing the desert.
The details in the landscape are deeply moving: the unimposing spring; the bleached gravestone marking the burial of Little Robe, Geronimo's son; the spot where four Apaches were hanged and their bodies dangled for four months. To the north stands the mountain where Geronimo had a vision that no soldier would ever kill him.
The National Park Service has discreetly laid out educational signs along the trail. Occasional small plaques mark historical sites and identify plants like barrel cactus, agave, Spanish bayonet and jumping cholla in this landscape of spears and thorns -- just enough quiet pointers to set the imagination on course.
The trail ends at the fort ruins, adobe stumps that resemble stained, uneven molars -- something like Capt. Thomas Roberts's false teeth, which were on display at the museum overlooking the fort. Captain Roberts (whose detachment was ambushed by Apaches in 1862) recorded in his diary that one night pack rats had carried off his dentures, which he'd left beside his bed. A hundred years later, archeologists reclaimed them from the rats and the ruins. They knew the dentures belonged to Captain Roberts because he'd received a bullet wound through the mouth that had left them distinctively rearranged.
From the fort, we could see the remnants of an old gold stamp mill. Far below, a Southern Pacific train sped toward New Mexico across the desert. A glossy raven was mobbing two golden eagles overhead, their wing-tips flaring against the sun.
A few days later, I drove deeper into the Chiricahuas, the most spectacular of the region's mountains. It was a bright, 70-degree January day, so I rolled down the car windows as I headed east. The rising road led me through scrub desert, then grassland, then up into pinon pine and juniper woodlands and on into fir and spruce. Just 40 miles from Willcox, I reached an elevation of 7,000 feet. Higher still, I would have entered alpine tundra. It felt otherworldly up there, as if I had driven in one hour from Mexico to Canada.
I had entered the sky islands, the lush border mountains that have enabled pioneering fauna and flora to venture north from the Mexican Sierra Madres. The human history resounded, too. I followed a foot trail through the rhyolite badlands, which for four centuries served as the Apaches' stronghold. That era ended with Geronimo's capture in 1886 and the tribe's deportation from this place -- which they called the Land of the Standing-Up Rocks -- to swampy Florida. The chilly air swirling around the Chiricahua peaks added to the ghosted feeling of the place.
On my final night in Cochise County, I paid a midnight visit to the Muleshoe hot tubs. I stripped down and sank into the solitude, thinking there aren't many places in America that feel more isolated today than a century ago. My mind raced ahead to the world awaiting me: icy streets, honking Broadway taxis. One breath and they were gone. What remained was the hooting of a great horned owl in a cottonwood, veined against a bright, star-crowded sky.
 
Where stagecoaches once stopped
Tucson's is the nearest airport to Willcox. For the 80-mile drive along Interstate 10 from Tucson to Willcox, I rented a car from Hertz, but all the major rental companies have outlets in Tucson.
 
Where to Stay
Muleshoe Ranch, on 48,120 acres owned and operated by the Nature Conservancy and the United States Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Managagement, is 30 miles northwest of Willcox. The five casitas, furnished with simple Southwestern elegance, cost $70 to $100 a night, double occupancy. They have private baths and kitchens; there is no restaurant and the closest shopping is in Willcox. Closed June, July and August. The hot tubs are for overnight guests only; phone and fax (520) 586-7072.
Triangle T Guest Ranch, Post Office Box 218, Dragoon, Ariz. 85609, is 23 miles southwest of Willcox, in the Texas Canyon area. The nine cabins -- all private baths, one with a kitchen -- cost $50 to $75 double occupancy. The restaurant serves sandwiches and meals ($12.95 and less); (520) 586-7533.
Chiricahua Foothills Bed-and-Breakfast, Dos Cabezas Route, Box 6310, Willcox, Ariz. 85643, is 35 miles east of town, on a working ranch by the national monument. The six rooms cost $65 a night, double occupancy, full breakfast included; (520) 824-3632.
 
Where to Eat
Restaurants in Willcox are modest and mostly routine. Rodney's, (520) 384-5180, a hole in the wall on North Railroad Avenue, offers hearty food (catfish, burritos, steak and shrimp, gumbo) for under $10. You can enjoy a meal at tables on the sidewalk or the back patio gazing out across the range. Open for lunch and dinner; closed Monday.
Other options include Solarium Dining Room and Hopi Room Lounge (steaks, seafood, Italian and Southwestern dishes, averaging $45 a couple for dinner, with drinks) at the Best Western Plaza Inn, on Rex Allen Drive; (520) 384-3556.
Also on the drive is the Plaza Restaurant, (520) 384-3819, which is open 24 hours and offers Mexican dishes, steaks and a salad bar. Dinner for two with a drink is about $20.
 
What to Do
The sixth annual Wings Over Willcox festival will be Jan. 15 to 17. Registration forms and tour schedules are available from the Willcox Chamber of Commerce and Agriculture, 1500 North Circle I Road, Willcox, Ariz. 85643; (800) 200-2272. Tours are first come, first served; they cost $15 to $40.
Chiricahua National Monument, (520) 824-3560, off Highways 186 and 181, 37 miles southeast of Willcox, has a scenic drive with commanding views of landmark peaks and desert valleys. Hiking trails range from a quarter mile to nine miles round trip. Park entrance costs $6, and the 25 campsites cost $8 a night. The visitors center is open 8 A.M. to 5 P.M.
Fort Bowie National Historic Site, (520) 847-2500, is at Apache Pass, 36 miles east of Willcox. The cavalry fort's ruins and the adjoining museum are open 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily except Christmas. Free.
Amerind Foundation Museum, Post Office Box 400, Dragoon, Ariz. 85609, (520) 586-3666, offers exhibits of archeological and Indian history. Admission: $3; ages 12 to 18, $2. Open daily September through May, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.; in summer, Wednesday through Sunday, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.

HEADLINE: The Post-Khomeini Generation

BYLINE: By Elaine Sciolino; Elaine Sciolino, a senior writer for The New York Times, is working on a book about Iran. Her last article for the magazine, "The Chanel Under the Chador," was about the power women of Iran.

 BODY:
In February, Iran's revolution will turn 20 years old. And among the country's many problems, what troubles Iran's clerical leaders the most is that they are losing -- or have already lost -- the generation that has come of age since then.
Sixty-five percent of Iran's population is under the age of 25. Many of them have no particular love or hatred for the late Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlevi or even for Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the cleric who led the revolution. Universities are so crowded that only 1 in 10 applicants get in. With jobs scarce, young people must defer marriage because they cannot afford a proper wedding and a place to live. Despite episodic easing of some restrictions, socializing with members of the opposite sex, holding hands in public, listening to certain kinds of music, watching foreign television and of course, drinking alcohol, are forbidden. 
 "The younger generation has no attachment, no feeling for the revolution," says Sadeq Ziba-Kalam, a political scientist who was imprisoned by the Shah's regime. "When I teach the revolution, many of my students just look out the window and watch the clock. They say: 'What about us? You had your revolution and your war. What's in it for us?' And I can't tell them the answer."
With the election of Mohammed Khatami as President last year, many young people -- who can vote at age 16 -- hoped they had found the answer, responding enthusiastically to his call for the rule of law and the creation of a civil society. Khatami celebrated the one-year anniversary of his election on May 23 with a passionate speech at Teheran University in which he pleaded for "patience and tolerance" while the Government strives to create the university slots and jobs young Iranians are demanding. But more than a year after being sworn in, he has yet to deliver.
In the following pages, the voices of six young people capture the restlessness and longing of a generation. They come from different backgrounds, yet they all express a strong love of their country. While not rebelling outright, they reject the stern restrictions of the Islamic Republic and demand more freedom and prosperity. And they all hope for better relations with the Western world, and with the United States in particular.
 
Jaffar Azadi, 28, Singer
By morning a taxi driver in Tabriz, by afternoon an auto mechanic, Jaffar Azadi lives for the night. That's when he does his best imitation of his hero, Dariush, the popular Iranian-born singer who now lives in Los Angeles
In Iran, where many popular songs are banned, singing is a high-risk occupation. It's always advisable to carry a little cash to placate the Komiteh, the official morality police, should they happen to crash the wedding party you're working. And sometimes, even that's not enough.
"Of course I've been arrested," Azadi says matter-of-factly, sitting in a lace-curtained ice cream parlor. "Many times I've had to sign papers promising I wouldn't commit the crime of singing again. Usually they want to lash me because I'm the lead singer. But one of the members of our group is 45. And since he's older, we send him to be lashed. We hope they'll lash him less."
Azadi lives with his parents in a modest house with a satellite dish that picks up foreign channels like CNN and the BBC. Although he doesn't pray like his father, he is considered a good son, particularly after he agreed to marry a cousin chosen for him by the family.
Even though they have signed their marriage contract and recited the Koranic marriage verses, the couple do not live together. That will have to wait until they have a formal wedding, which they cannot afford.
Azadi says he voted in last year's elections because that was the only way he could get his identity card stamped to make him eligible for food ration coupons.
So far, his choice, Khatami, has been a disappointment. "Young people in Iran are very confused," he says. "We have no money and no amusement. I haven't seen America but I have heard only good things about it, that you have freedom and an easy life there. Like we hear how it was in the Shah's time -- a free-and-easy life. We loved the Shah. But we don't like this regime. This is not true Islam. They don't live the things they demand we do. I wish we could go back to those days. If only there could be a disco.
"That's what Dariush is good for. He understands sadness, depression."
And then, Azadi sings a song Dariush made famous years ago:
The year of 2000
The year of silence and escape
The year of running away and
patience
The season of the dead-end street
The dark age of 2000.
 
Samira Makhmalbaf, 18, Film Director
From the age of 4, Samira Makhmalbaf knew she wanted to direct films. Unlike most young Iranians, however, she actually had a chance of doing it. She is the daughter of Mohsen Makhmalbaf, the celebrated Iranian filmmaker, and spent much of her childhood on location.
Last year, after watching a television news report about two retarded sisters whose beggar father locked them at home for years, Makhmalbaf borrowed her father's camera and some of his precious film (the distribution of film is controlled by the Government). Within the year, she turned out "The Apple," a feature-length movie about the struggles a social worker endured in trying to free the girls from their confinement.
"The film is about every society but about Iran too," says Makhmalbaf. "People are not free to say what they want here. They think a woman is a second-class human being. They tell you from the time you're a child that you can't do certain jobs because you are a girl."
With her slim pants and T-shirt, three-inch platform sandals, heavy black eyeliner and long ponytail, Makhmalbaf doesn't look much like a female role model for the Islamic Republic. But when her film was shown during the Cannes film festival this year, she wore a head scarf -- tied fashionably behind her neck.
"You get used to it," Makhmalbaf says about the scarf over tea and melon in the headquarters of her father's film company in central Teheran. "The head scarf is a law. Even when I am outside the country, I obey my Islamic law because I want to come back to Iran. There's another thing. It's sort of like my national dress."
Makhmalbaf cannot explain why she voted for Khatami. "Why did I? Why did I?" she asks, flustered. "I beg you not to ask me about political things. I'm only 18. How can I care about everything?"
She has no feel for the revolution and despises the propaganda films shown repeatedly on television about Iran's eight-year war with Iraq. "Revolution is a kind of suicide," she says. "You just kill yourself."
I ask her what kind of film she would make about her own future. "With 'Apple,' I drew these children out of their locked room. 'Apple' drew me out of the country too. Now I can see the world."
 
Leila, 20, Beautician
Leila, an assistant at an upscale beauty salon in Teheran, is a captivating beauty, with thick, braided, thigh-length black hair, a chiseled profile and a slender frame. But you'll just have to take my word for it. She comes from a poor, ultrareligious family and her father, a school security guard, forbids her being photographed, even if she is swathed from head to toe in the black chador she always wears on the street.
Leila doesn't understand the reasons for the revolution, or why she had to chant "Death to America" every day in elementary school. But she knows she wants freedom.
But what does freedom mean for someone like Leila, a deeply religious young woman who prays five times a day? It's the freedom to walk on the streets without the morality police telling her how to dress. "I always wear a chador," she says. "But when some stranger comes up to me and says, 'Lady, fix your head covering,' it hurts. Because inside I know I am very religious. Who is he to insinuate that I'm not?"
 
Sorajedin Mirdamadi, 25, Journalist
In 1988, when Sorajedin Mirdamadi was 15, he ran away from his home in the northeastern city of Mashad and signed up as a martyrdom-seeking volunteer in the horrific war against Iraq. By the time his parents were told what he had done, he was well into basic training.
When it came to the fighting, Mirdamadi was lucky, in a manner of speaking. He was badly wounded before he could join the hundreds of thousands of young Iranians who died in the war. He needed several operations, and still suffers pain from the shrapnel embedded in his body.
He doesn't like to talk much about the war. "I loved the Imam," he says of Khomeini, "and followed whatever he said, so from the time I was a small boy
I prepared myself to go to war." But then, he admits, "It wasn't a very good end, was it?"
After getting a university degree in theology and philosophy, Mirdamadi took a newspaper job in Teheran. With a salary of $170 a month, he lives rent-free in a commune run by a student organization called the Office for Fostering Unity. The group -- which takes its intellectual inspiration from some of the same people who seized the American Embassy in Teheran 19 years ago -- preaches an Islamic-socialist message of distribution of wealth and empowerment of the masses. In fact, some of the decades-old bookcases, tables, chairs and file cabinets in the commune were salvaged from the Embassy.
Mirdamadi, who describes himself as left-wing, believes that backward-thinking clerics have distorted the true meaning of the revolution by abandoning the commitment to the poor, promoting the business interests of big bazaar merchants and giving Iran's current spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, too much political power.
"In culture and politics the clerics are backward," says Mirdamadi,
a small, thin man with dark circles under his eyes. "It's a kind of totalitarianism. They believe that all the power is in their hands."
The son and grandson of clerics, Mirdamadi is a little confused about his future. He says he wants to become a cleric, but in the next breath says he wants to travel the world -- not the normal aspiration of an Iranian cleric. "I lead a kind of university life," he says. "I have no apartment, no car, no girlfriend. I eat very simply -- maybe like the Indians in America did. I never think about getting married or having children, only following my political goals. But I would love to visit America. It's important for a political person to do that."
 
Leila Chamankhah, 22, Student
As far as her parents know, Leila Chamankhah, a graduate student in political science, is living in a dormitory at Tarrbiat Modaress University. They are a wealthy but very conservative couple who presumably would frown on her current full-time residence -- their two-bedroom pied-a-terre in Teheran -- which they think she is using only for studying in the daytime.
Chamankhah likes to wear T-shirts and blue jeans, but she would never go outdoors without a maghnaeh, a cowl-like hood, and a long coat. She has never traveled outside Iran, worn makeup or kissed a boy. Living in the apartment is her way of rebelling, just as she has rejected every man her father has brought home for her to marry since she was 16.
"In our society, going to university is a highway to get away from the customs at home," says Chamankhah in her parents' apartment. "My father believes that women were created to obey men."
Like many young Iranians, Chamankhah calls the 23d of May -- the day Khatami was elected President -- a defining moment. "The 23d of May is when all the efforts of the right wing failed, when they proved they had lost the generation of the revolution," she says. "Khatami is everything the right wing is not. He shows respect for the youth. He is a cleric, but he has been able to adapt himself to the modern world. Even if Khatami is overthrown, his ideas will outlast him."
Chamankhah wants to study in England, then return to Iran to teach and write. "My dream is to inspire students in a country in which Khatami has made permanent changes: political freedom, the creation of political parties, a better economy, relations with all countries, especially America."
Fiery sermons against foreign cultures and the evils of America no longer have the power to inspire, she says. Because the Iranian revolution went too far in Islamicizing the country, she adds, even religious people have turned against institutionalized religion.
"When the regime started acting too religious, people wanted to separate themselves from it," she says. "Prayer should be a personal not a political thing. My mother used to pray at the mosque, but now she says her prayers at home." In her own generation, she says, "religion is fading. We have an expression: whatever we have woven becomes threads instead of cloth. The Islamic regime has failed to win the loyalty of the children of the revolution.'
 
Arash Shamsai, 20, and Mehrab, 19, Entrepreneurs
One day, when he was 16, Arash Shamsai went into his bedroom, locked the door and took an overdose of sleeping pills. He had only recently returned to Iran with his family from Sweden, and the adjustment from the freewheeling life of Malmo was too much to bear.
"I was really angry," he recalls, speaking in fluent English. "All my friends in Sweden kept calling and telling me to come back. In Iran, I had no friends. I couldn't speak Persian very well. I had really long hair and everyone thought I was gay or something."
Shamsai's mother found him unconscious and rushed him to the hospital. "It wasn't time for me to die," he says.
Over time, Shamsai made friends at the private international high school he attended in Teheran. He wants to go to college but has failed the entrance exam two years in a row.
Because he has not done his two years of compulsory military service -- and, under Iran's convoluted rules, is not eligible to pay the $16,000 fee to buy his way out of it -- he must live outside the system. He cannot leave the country to study abroad, get a job with a corporation or get married. But he refuses to serve.
"You lose two years of your life as a soldier," says Shamsai. "The government gets drivers, bus collectors, guards for embassies, toilet cleaners, airport workers, all for free."
So Shamsai and Mehrab, his best friend, lead an underground life. With financing from their fathers, they have rented a tiny office in central Teheran and with one personal computer have set up a business. The two of them make pirated copies of mostly American music and films on CD's and sell them on the black market.
"My parents are well off, so I could sit home and just get money from my Mom and Dad," says Shamsai, who, like most single young people in Iran, still lives at home with his parents. "But I want to get my own money, to be independent."
Born in 1978, nine months before Ayatollah Khomeini returned to Iran, Shamsai says he doesn't know why there was a revolution or a war with Iraq. He can't remember what Khatami's first name is, but voted for him because "he looked good."
"It's summer and it's hot and I don't want to go out with these pants I'm wearing," he says over dinner at a popular open-air Italian restaurant called Sorrento. "I want to go out in shorts. But it's banned. I came here last night with my parents, and they talked about how much they loved coming here before the revolution, having beer and wine to drink as they sat outside and ate a good meal. Why can't it be like that now?"
Shamsai may copy American music and films for a living, but he has no desire to escape from Iran and move to the United States. He has two heroes, he says: his father and Ali Daei, the star of Iran's soccer team.
"If you ask me my dream, it's to be free like they are in other countries. If I could say whatever I wanted to say, go wherever I wanted to go, go to university, have fun, that would be great. I want things to be better -- here -- in my own country."

HEADLINE: Typical;
The Likes and Dislikes of Today's Everyfamily

BYLINE: By David Wallis 

 BODY:
When Americans go to the polls on Tuesday, don't expect seismic shifts -- or even loud noises. Things are comfy right now, and even with background worries about the economy, the Zeitgeist seems to be: We like where we are. Pass the microbrew. As surveys indicate, middle America is more upscale than it used to be -- liberal socially, conservative economically. In the following data stream, moderation reigns, strikingly so, perhaps explaining why Bill Clinton and his poll-tested policies have stayed popular during this Presidential annus horribilis.
 
* The typical American family -- a white married couple with 1.89 children -- lives in a house it owns and has a pet, most often a mixed-breed dog or a nothing-special domestic short-hair cat.
* Favorite sport utility vehicle: the Ford Explorer.
 
* Most couples consider good sex vital to a marriage's success, but have sex about once a week -- for an average of 39 minutes.
 
* Given $1,000 to invest, 73 percent of respondents in a recent survey would still bet on stocks.
 
* The Top 10 things recently ranked by Americans as in: jeans, the Internet, female athletes, gourmet coffee, kids, alternative medicine, ethnic food, angels and volunteerism.
 
* Growth of red-wine sales in the U.S. from 1991 to 1997: 151 percent.
 
* Growth of Internet usage since 1995: 167 percent.
 
* Almost everybody -- 99 percent -- thinks the Government wastes a portion of their tax dollars.
 
* Most doubt that they will be able to afford health care in the next 10 years.
 
* Most believe contraceptives should be covered by health insurance, even if premiums rise slightly.
 
* A majority of Americans now dress casually for work everyday.
 
* Seven of 10 want stricter gun-control laws and oppose repealing the assault-weapons ban.
 
* The number of Americans who have tried cappuccino, latte or another espresso-based product grew by 34 percent from 1997 to 1998.
 
* Seventy-six percent of Americans oppose a constitutional amendment outlawing abortion.
 
* Sixty percent of all U.S. households carry credit-card debt. Average balance: $7,000.
 
* Three of four families still eat together regularly, but the dinner hour is speedy -- 30 minutes or less.
 
* A majority of Americans, of all races, support mending not ending affirmative action.
 
* Most Americans (80 percent) support President Clinton's plan to lower the average class size in public schools.
 
* More than 90 percent feel safe in their neighborhoods.
 
* The average American family generates more than 2,500 pounds of garbage each year; 76 percent recycle cans, bottles or paper.
 
* Nearly two-thirds don't find the air nearly clean enough -- and want Uncle Sam to do something about it.
 
* Two-thirds want to restrict human cloning.
 
* Favorite pizza topping: pepperoni.
 
* Eight of 10 adults agree that the Social Security system faces serious problems requiring Congress' immediate attention.
 
* Two-thirds favor allowing homosexuals to serve in the military.
 
* Sixty-three percent think a sexual encounter between a powerful man and a less-powerful woman at the office does not automatically constitute sexual harassment.
 
* Favorite actress: Meg Ryan and Helen Hunt (tie).
 
* Favorite airline for long-distance flights among frequent fliers: T.W.A.
 
* Ninety percent own dental floss, but most neglect to use it every day.
 
* Americans, by a 2-to-1 margin, oppose bilingual education; most people would agree to carry a national identity card if that deterred illegal immigration.
 
* Most people agree with the statement, "The United States Constitution is important to me," but more than half don't know that there are 100 senators. More American teen-agers can name the Three Stooges than the three branches of the Federal Government.
 
* An overwhelming majority believe in God (and most believe in the devil, too), belong to a church and pray silently at least once a day.
 
* Favorite style of eggs: scrambled.
 
* Most voters want TV and radio networks to provide political candidates with free air time.
 
* A majority believe the government should ban smoking in public places like stores and restaurants.
 
* Favorite sneakers: Nike.

HEADLINE: Mail-Order High for Students on the Go

BYLINE: By David M. Herszenhorn 

 BODY:
After bouncing in and out of so many schools in Europe, Africa and the United States that he can't remember all their names, Simone S. Liverani found himself in Kolokani, a town in Mali, the west African country where his mother worked for a company drilling water wells. There was no diplomatic or international school anywhere nearby, so he tried a local high school.
 Mr. Liverani (pictured at right), an Italian who also speaks English and understands some French, had been told classes would be taught in French, but most teachers spoke Bambara, the native language. "This was the last straw," he said. "It was a mess." 
 An official at the United States consulate suggested the Independent Study High School, based at the University of Nebraska in Lincoln. Founded in 1929 as a correspondence program to educate rural Nebraskans, the school has one of only a few fully accredited distance-education programs offering high school diplomas; other well-known programs include the North Dakota Division of Independent Study in Fargo and Texas Tech University Distance Learning in Lubbock.
 They offer an option for the children of diplomats and missionaries, or those
 who can't or don't want to go to a schoolhouse every day. Among young athletes and actors who have studied through Nebraska are Michelle Kwan, the Olympic silver medalist, and Lisa Bonet, a star of "The Cosby Show."
 While most students take courses to fill gaps in their school records, some 3,400 students have received diplomas from Nebraska since 1968. With the emergence of home schooling as a viable choice for teen-agers, enrollment has increased almost 50 percent in the last decade, according to James E. Schiefelbein, the Nebraska school's principal. Today there are some 5,000 students at any given time, representing more than 130 countries.
 Joining the new wave in distance education, the school has begun offering on-line courses and is developing a complete on-line, four-year curriculum with the help of a $15 million grant from the Federal Department of Education. For now, students must take a mix of Web and correspondence courses to meet diploma requirements, which are 40 courses, or 200 course hours.
 A course can be completed in as little as five weeks of intensive study, or stretched out for as long as a year. Assignments are submitted by mail, fax or e-mail to 9 permanent teachers, who grade them with help from 10 to 15 part-timers. When written examinations are required, a proctor approved by the school administers the tests.
 "Our kids do very, very well post- secondary," Mr. Schiefelbein said. "They are not dependent on somebody to tell them what to do and when, so they have a little bit of an advantage on their peers because they have become more self-disciplined workers."
 The school designed a program for Mr. Liverani, now 28, that allowed him to finish his diploma requirements in a year and a half. From his remote home, he sent assignments by mail, and they were graded and returned that way. "They managed to make you feel that you were part of a school," said Mr. Liverani, who worked this past summer in New York City as an intern at The Economist and is hoping for a journalism job in Europe. "I sent in a lot of material, and it would be corrected. They would write a lot. That was important because it was a continuous relationship."
 Allison Rizzuto, of Omaha (right), an Independent Study graduate, remembers getting a big box of experiments in the mail for physical science class. "It's kind of funny, because you are in the kitchen with a bunsen burner and you have to do all these experiments by yourself," she said.
 Ms. Rizzuto, worried that attending a traditional school until 3 P.M. would derail her career, had convinced her parents to let her take correspondence courses so she could sing in a folk-pop group with her three older sisters.
 She studied from 8 A.M. to noon for four years, spending afternoons practicing or touring the county and state fair circuit. In May her group, Mulberry Lane, named for the street the sisters grew up on, released a debut CD, "Don't Cry -- Til You Get to the Car," which they recorded themselves in their home studio.
 "I learned to be self-motivated," said Ms. Rizzuto, now 22. "In correspondence school, every textbook you get, you have to finish the whole thing. You read every page of the book." DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
