HEADLINE: The Final Refrains of 'Dixie'

BYLINE: By Kevin Sack; Kevin Sack is the Atlanta bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: Oxford, Miss.

 BODY:
Not so long ago, it would have been considered an act of cultural treason: Allison Grisham, a white sorority sister at the University of Mississippi, stood onstage at Fulton Chapel and explained to a hushed crowd why it was so important for students and alumni at football games to stop waving the Confederate battle flag and singing "Dixie."
 Standing beside her good friend Jada Love, who is black, Ms. Grisham told a forum sponsored by President Clinton's advisory board on race that she understood that many students regarded the rituals as a demonstration of school spirit, inherited from red-sweatered parents on family pilgrimages to Oxford. 
 But, she argued, those days have passed.
 "The need of the university to be welcoming to all students far outweighs the perceived tradition of the controversial flag and song," she declared.
 The crowd's ovation, the most enthusiastic of that March night, accelerated quickly to a crescendo, no one applauding more admiringly than Chancellor Robert C. Khayat, the man who has made it his mission to change the hidebound image of Ole Miss. With Ms. Grisham and Ms. Love side by side, here was the embodiment of the university of his aspirations, a place where a fresh breeze of civility might finally cut through the fog of stale tear gas and defiance.
 Still, the old Ole Miss lingered in the audience. Before long, a man from DeSoto County, Bryant Walker, rose to declare, "It's my freedom to fly that flag." He then suggested that the university was suppressing its symbols only to recruit black football players. "I'll tell you one thing," Mr. Walker concluded, "before it comes to me losing a flag that I believe in, I'll lose football games."
 The Faulknerian tension between past and present never eases for long at Ole Miss, a university that sent its sons off to war in 1861 and then waged a civil rights battle of its own a century later.
 The cemetery behind the basketball arena holds hundreds of Confederate dead from the days when classrooms were converted into hospital wards for the wounded from Shiloh. Nearby, the columned administration building, known as the Lyceum, is still pocked with bullet holes from the riot that greeted the court-ordered arrival of the first black student, James H. Meredith, in 1962.
 Many white Mississippians have long venerated the University of Mississippi as sacred space. But nationally, because of its violent resistance to desegregation and the suppression of academic freedom that followed it, the school has been regarded by many as a place where scholarship seemed secondary to the preservation of a bygone culture.
 Since taking office three years ago, Dr. Khayat (pronounced KI-yat) has shown fierce determination to change all that. In a turnabout worthy of Nixon to China, Dr. Khayat, a former Ole Miss student, football hero and law professor, has effectively staked his legacy on recasting the school's image by aggressively confronting its shortcomings, both real and perceived.
 It is no accident that Dr. Khayat, 60, explains his goal for Ole Miss as a dual one: "To be -- and to be perceived as -- a great public university." Image, Dr. Khayat understands, is a university's most precious asset. When it gleams like a gilded dome, a school sells itself effortlessly, whether its reputation is deserved or not. Conversely, when a school's image is tarnished, it is doubly hard to attract top students, star faculty, alumni support and research grants, no matter how outdated the perception.
In the academy, perhaps more than in any other realm, perception often lags reality by decades. And nowhere has that phenomenon been more crippling than at Ole Miss, which has struggled for decades to claw its way out of the disastrous public relations hole it dug for itself in the early 1960's.
 "Ole Miss is not the national repository of racial guilt," Dr. Khayat said, "and we are not the last bastion of the Confederacy. We lived through the Civil War and we lived through the civil rights movement, and the university was significant in each of those. But this is 1998. We are a fully integrated, open, caring, nurturing, vital community, and I am ready for the rest of the country to understand that that's where we are."
 This, of course, is why Dr. Khayat invited the President's advisory board to Oxford in the first place, to demonstrate that it was now possible to have an open conversation about race at Ole Miss. But that evening, like other recent events, also made it clear that change does not come without challenge in a place where history resonates so strongly. Last year, for instance, when Dr. Khayat broached even the possibility of examining the university's remaining Old South symbols, including the flag, he received hate mail so virulent that the university tightened security around his house.
 Still, in this, the university's sesquicentennial year, there are signs of progress. Most visibly, and perhaps most remarkably, the Confederate flags have virtually disappeared from Vaught-Hemingway Stadium on football Saturdays, the result of repeated efforts by the administration, the coaches and the student government. Grandstands that once swirled with Rebel flags, even as dozens of black players took the field, are now largely an impressionist blur of red-and-white pompoms.
 Less evident, but perhaps more significant in the long term, are Dr. Khayat's notable fund-raising successes and the gradual improvement in the university's persistently mediocre academic standing. But even with the improvement, Ole Miss remains well behind other Southern universities in critical areas, like faculty salaries, research grants and number of library volumes. Yet its forward momentum, however tentative, may prove the best cure for the university's reputation as a static, backward-looking place.
 "Chancellor Khayat's great goal is to free the University of Mississippi from these negative images," said David G. Sansing, an Ole Miss historian and the author of the university's sesquicentennial history. "And he feels that if you can maximize the positive images of this institution, the negative images will take care of themselves."
 To most of the 255 colleges and universities with chapters of Phi Beta Kappa, the honor society's presence on campus is so taken for granted that it hardly merits mention. That is what makes its absence so hurtful -- humiliating, really -- to the handful of flagship universities where the quality of undergraduate liberal arts education is not deemed high enough to rate membership in the club.
 Dr. Khayat has made it his obsession to win a Phi Beta Kappa chapter for Ole Miss, which shares its ignominy with the universities of Alaska, Montana and Nevada. Success, he said, would help Ole Miss overcome an inferiority complex that he said seems native to all Mississippians. "As our self-perception changes," he said, "then the external perception will change as well."
 When Phi Beta Kappa denied the University of Mississippi's membership application in the mid-80's, it cited the school's substandard libraries and laboratories and its inability to attract and challenge the brightest students.
 But that was then. Although the honor society's officials will not formally visit the campus until next spring, its executive secretary, Douglas W. Foard, already offers a complimentary assessment. "In all cases, images lag," he said, "and there's still a lot of that old mint julep image left. But my sense is that it's a much improved academic institution, that it's no longer a Southern party school, that it's a much more serious place for students to study and for faculty to do research and teach."
 Phi Beta Kappa's judgment will provide only one gauge of progress. With other yardsticks, the university's standing depends on whether it is measured against its past or against its peers. Compared with the Ole Miss of a decade ago, it is a more diverse, more selective and more rigorous school. But compared with the prestigious state schools that Dr. Khayat hopes to compete with someday, like the universities of Michigan, North Carolina, Texas and Virginia, it has a distance to travel.
 Research funding at Ole Miss, for instance, has grown to $20.5 million this year, from $13 million in 1989. But that sum pales when compared with other flagship schools: the University of Georgia, for example, reports $209 million in annual research funds.
 In each of the last three years, Ole Miss has broken its previous record for the average A.C.T. score of its entering freshmen. This year, that score has increased to 23.44 (out of a possible 36), from 22.21 in 1990. Its scores now are comparable to those reported by the University of Alabama, the University of Arkansas and Louisiana State University, but are well behind those of other Southern schools, like the University of Florida and the University of North Carolina. And faculty members complain that many students are ill prepared, particularly in their writing and analytical skills, shortcomings they attribute to the poor quality of Mississippi's public schools.
 In a state that is 36 percent black, the number of black students is only 11.4 percent of the total enrollment of 10,731 students, but that represents an increase of nearly 50 percent in the last 10 years. A new honors college has helped to attract bright students of all races who might not otherwise have considered Ole Miss.
 One of them, Markeeva A. Morgan, a black sophomore from Strayhorn, Miss., said he chose Ole Miss over Harvard and the University of California because of its nurturing environment. "Looking at pure academics," he said, "I don't think I could justifiably compare Ole Miss to the other two. But when I compared the personal atmosphere as well as the intellectual rigor, there was no comparison. I was determined to go to a university where I wasn't a number. There's a genuine interest in the administration and the professors to see a student excel."
 Like students at many colleges, those at Ole Miss tend to segregate in dining halls and at parties. But a new biracial group of university students is addressing questions of race and diversity, and students have also formed a foundation to raise $150,000 to commission a civil rights memorial for the campus. They have raised about a third of that sum in three years.
 Perhaps the most challenging issue remains the recruitment of black faculty, currently 6 percent of the total. The school's respected Center for the Study of Southern Culture, for all its research on the blues and other aspects of African-American heritage, has never employed a black professor. Natashia S. Gregoire, a black senior who is editor of the student newspaper, said she had yet to take a class taught by a black faculty member.
 But Ole Miss still has done better than many of its peers. And one of its faculty appointments speaks volumes in symbolism. Donald R. Cole, one of seven black students who were expelled after a racial protest in Fulton Chapel in 1970, is now the associate dean of the graduate school.
 Clearly, though, the university's image has hindered recruitment of black faculty, just as it has limited its appeal to black athletes. Tommy Tuberville, the football coach, and Rod Barnes, the basketball coach, maintain that they lose recruits because rivals play the race card against Ole Miss. Dr. Cole said the same holds true in the competition for black professors.
 "With faculty that are highly sought," he said, "other universities will use our past against us. I often think about whether we can get on the fast track out, or do we just throw up our hands and say it's hopeless."
 Janice W. Murray, a black New Yorker, remembers the puzzled looks she got last year when she decided to leave Yale to become chairman of the art department at Ole Miss. "People would say, 'What's wrong with you? Are you running away from something?' " she said with a chuckle.
 But after a year, Ms. Murray is charmed by Faulkner's hometown, with its endearing courthouse square. She likes her colleagues and admires her students and their manners. "I probably heard more 'thank you's' in the first week here than I heard in 10 years," she said.
 And she quickly became captivated by the university's history. She fell hard for the story of the University Greys, a company of young students who marched off to protect the Confederacy in 1861, only 13 years after the university opened its doors. Almost all were killed or wounded, many during Pickett's charge at Gettysburg.
 As she told the tale over dinner in a crowded restaurant one night this fall, she began dabbing her eyes with her napkin. "They almost all died," she said.
 That a black woman could shed tears over Confederate dead seems incongruous on a campus whose history has so mirrored the racial conflicts of the South. By the 1950's, even as integrationist movements were gaining strength elsewhere, the imagery of the Lost Cause had been thoroughly woven into the fabric of the university, according to Dr. Sansing. It had adopted the nickname Ole Miss, a phrase once used by slaves to refer to the mistress of the plantation. Its athletic teams bore the name Rebels, as they still do today. Its hallowed shrines included the Confederate cemetery, a monument to the Confederate dead and a stained-glass window that paid tribute to the Greys.
 In 1948, the same year that the segregationist Dixiecrats revived the use of the Confederate flag, the Ole Miss band began to play "Dixie" and unfurl an enormous battle flag as part of its halftime routine. In 1950, students inaugurated "Dixie Week," which featured a ceremonial reading of the Ordinance of Secession and the auctioning of cheerleaders as slaves.
 Then, in the autumn of 1962, under Federal court order, Mr. Meredith became the first black student to enroll at the University of Mississippi. His arrival on campus was greeted with a riot that became a seminal moment in the civil rights movement, prompting President Kennedy to send in nearly 30,000 Federal troops. The rioting left two people dead, hundreds injured and hundreds more arrested.
 Making matters worse, the desegregation of the campus was followed by intermittent purges of faculty members judged to be too liberal on race. An exhibition by Ray Kerciu, an art professor, was ordered removed after complaints that his paintings degraded the Confederate flag. Robert Farley, a law school dean who was considered an integrationist, was forced to retire. James Silver, a prominent historian, left under fire after arguing that Mississippi had become a totalitarian society.
 In 1983, as black students and faculty became more integrated into campus life, the university officially dissociated itself from the Rebel flag, meaning that it would no longer be carried
 by cheerleaders or sold in university bookstores. But some students and fans continued to wave the flag in the stands and to display it proudly in the Grove, the lovely oak-filled green where lavish pregame picnics are held. And each time the university seemed poised to move forward, some embarrassing event always managed to pull it back.
 In 1988, for instance, the first black fraternity house being built on Fraternity Row was torched in an unsolved case of arson. (White fraternities helped raise the money needed to rebuild.) A year later, some white fraternity pledges kidnapped a white upperclassman and left him naked at Rust College, a predominantly black school nearby, with racial epithets scrawled on his chest. After the incident, the fraternity was disbanded, and a number of students were disciplined.
 If anyone can make the case that Ole Miss must change, the university's loyalists say, it is Robert Khayat. He is, after all, one of them.
Born in Moss Point near the Mississippi coast, Dr. Khayat was an all-conference baseball player at Ole Miss. He also led the nation in scoring as the football team's place-kicker in 1958 and 1959, and then played for the Washington Redskins for four years. He returned to Ole Miss for law school, then later taught and served as associate dean there. As a professor, he earned a reputation for prescience when he returned an examination to a student named John Grisham with the comment, "Although you missed most of the legal issues, you have a real talent for fiction."
 As chancellor, he exudes the courtliness and amiability of a small-town lawyer. He picks up litter on morning jogs through the campus and brakes his Jeep to chat with students. Freshmen get the sweats when his secretary summons them to his office, only to discover that he simply wants to see how they are enjoying the place. He has personally made 30 recruiting trips to predominantly black high schools.
 Alumni have responded enthusiastically to his vision for the school. Not accounting for inflation, he has raised more money during his tenure than all of his predecessors combined, according to school records. The university's endowment has nearly doubled to $204 million. Large private gifts have financed the honors college, an international studies institute and salary increases for liberal arts professors. The compact campus is bustling with construction, including the $20 million first phase of a new performing arts center.
 Dr. Khayat has attacked the university's image as a party school by pushing fraternity and sorority rush from the first week of fall term to the sixth week. He has insisted that the university library remain open 24 hours a day and has redesigned course schedules so that more students have classes on Fridays, undercutting their tendency to begin weekends on Thursday nights.
 After deciding to attack his university's image problem when he took over in 1995, Dr. Khayat turned for help to Harold Burson, an Ole Miss alumnus and the chairman of Burson-Marstellar, the world's largest public relations firm.
 "Robert called me up and said, 'We're going after a Phi Beta Kappa chapter,' Mr. Burson said, 'and I'm just concerned that the one thing that could knock us down is the perception that we're a racist school.' He said, 'I'd really like to change that, but I'm not sure how to go about it.' "
 They decided to start with a national opinion survey, but in announcing it last year, both Mr. Khayat and Mr. Burson made it clear that the assessment might raise questions about the university's remaining Old South symbols, including the continued use of the Confederate flag, the name Ole Miss, the nickname Rebels, campus street names, like Confederate Drive, and the white-haired mascot, Colonel Reb.
 A backlash swelled quickly. Students formed groups dedicated to the preservation of Ole Miss traditions. Letter writers, egged on by the Sons of Confederate Veterans, scorched Dr. Khayat in Mississippi newspapers and in messages sent to the university.
 It quickly became apparent that Dr. Khayat would have to moderate his approach to avoid a self-immolating firestorm.
 At the same time, somewhat surprisingly, in Mr. Burson's survey relatively few people raised the issue of the symbols at all, and race relations was mentioned even less frequently as a liability than the university's reputation as a party school. The larger problem, Mr. Burson asserted, was not that Ole Miss had a negative image, but that it had little image at all.
 Dr. Khayat used Mr. Burson's findings to downplay the need to move aggressively against the symbols. It fell to the student government to pass a resolution last fall encouraging students to leave their Confederate flags at home on game days. The athletic department helped by banning flag sticks in the stadium because they posed a safety hazard. (Banning the flag, it was thought, would violate free-speech protections.)
 For the most part, the flags have disappeared. But a small number of students have responded by outfitting themselves in Confederate-flag skirts on game days. And a few alumni still place statuettes of Robert E. Lee on their brunch tables in the Grove, a bastion that remains so white on football Saturdays that some black students and faculty refuse to traverse it.
 Some faculty members criticize Dr. Khayat for backing away from a confrontation over the symbols after gauging the resistance.
 "The feeling of many faculty here was that he raised the issue in dramatic fashion, and that was important," said Charles Reagan Wilson, the director of the Center for the Study of Southern Culture. "But he got so much criticism from people outside the university, these neo-Confederates out there, that he really felt the force of that."
 But others, including some black professors, say Dr. Khayat had wisely concluded that his other ambitions for Ole Miss would be threatened by a fight to the death over the university's symbols, and that such a confrontation might harm the university's image more than improve it.
 "You can't be a lightning rod if you want to stay," said Ms. Murray, the art department chairman. "And if you've got goals for this place, you've got to be here."

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 8; Column 4; Education Life Supplement 

LENGTH: 415 words

HEADLINE: BLACKBOARD: JOB MARKET;
Package Deal For College

BYLINE: By Stephanie Gutmann 

 BODY:
In these boom times, with part-time jobs going begging in the service economy, college students can afford to be picky. That's why United Parcel Service in Louisville, Ky., the company's busiest package-processing hub, began its own version of the G.I. Bill this fall: free tuition at three local colleges -- the University of Louisville, Jefferson Community College and Jefferson Technical College -- in exchange for a semester-by-semester commitment to work 20 hours a week on U.P.S.'s most-difficult-to-fill shift: midnight to 3 A.M.
 And it's grueling, hefting boxes onto conveyor belts or into trucks in the middle of the night. But people like Michael Hayes, 20, formerly of Flatwood, Ky., were so elated by the prospect of free tuition that they moved to Louisville to take jobs. He now lifts 25 large (up to 150 pounds) packages a minute. 
 Mr. Hayes is one of 850 employees -- 650 new ones lured by free college and 200 company veterans -- who started school this semester at what is being called Metropolitan College; 150 young people are on a waiting list, and U.P.S. expects to eventually put 2,000 employees a year through school.
 "We had an inkling we could get more students if we could get a college to offer classes on a schedule that was conducive to working in the middle of the night," says Ken Shapiro, a U.P.S. spokesman, "and we were ready to offer some kind of incentive to get people in the door."
 The unusual deal developed when U.P.S. started talking about expanding its plant, hiring more workers and, if necessary, moving to find them -- maybe out of state. At stake were about 21,000 U.P.S. jobs. After learning of the company's staffing needs, the city offered to pay 50 percent of the tuition in the program, as well as provide the usual please-don't-leave tax breaks. (Tuition ranges from $800 to $8,040 a year, depending on a student's residency status, the school and the course load.)
 To insure that there are appropriate schedules for these special students, who need to sleep during the day, the three schools added a total of 78 classes in the hours of 5 to 10 P.M.
 U.P.S. and the city are also constructing a dormitory (it won't be free) with special soundproofing, heavy blinds and more classrooms, and offering shuttle bus service between the job, the dormitory and classes.
 The idea, said John Kinney, director of Metropolitan College, is to "develop a group who can function with an altered circadian rhythm." S.G.

GRAPHIC: Photos: In exchange for free tuition, Michael Hayes hefts boxes on the U.P.S. night shift, top. (John Rott for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1368 words

HEADLINE: Uncommon Stories of Common People

BYLINE: By KENNETH BEST 

 BODY:
THE story behind Diane Smith's weekly series on television station WTNH developing into a book is the kind of upbeat tale of Connecticut Yankee ingenuity that Ms. Smith would report herself, if she could.
The 160-page book, "Positively Connecticut," published in October by the Globe Pequot Press of Old Saybrook, includes 70 stories and lots of photographs from the nearly 600 feature reports Ms. Smith has done over the past 15 years on subjects ranging from a horseshoe league in Deep River to a blind canoeist in Bethel. 
 Ms. Smith's "Positively Connecticut" reports, which air each Monday evening on News Channel 8, are unabashedly inspired by the late Charles Kurault, the CBS correspondent whose "On the Road" series took him across the United States in search of uncommon stories about common people.
"He was sort of a role model to me," Ms. Smith said. "He could make you care about this guy in North Carolina who carves whistles to call his pigs in with. I don't ever expect to be as good a writer as he was, but I'd like to think that I always try to concentrate on the story behind the story -- What motivates this person? Why do they have this passion? Why do they have this dream?"
For many years as she spoke before community groups, Ms. Smith would be asked if she planned to put her own stories into a book. Two years ago, following a speech at the Madison Beach Club, the question surfaced again from a woman who said she had recently moved to Connecticut.
"I answered the question by saying I thought it would be complicated to do a book because the television station owned the material, it was copyrighted and I wasn't sure if they'd be interested in doing it," Ms. Smith recalled. "A couple of people sitting next to me laughed and one of them tapped me on the shoulder and said, 'Obviously you haven't met your new general manager's wife.' "
That was Valerie Yaggi, whose husband, Hank Yaggi, was the newly arrived general manager of News Channel 8. He thought that publishing a "Positively Connecticut" book would be a good way to celebrate the 50th anniversary of WTNH in 1998.
Ms. Smith began the process of selecting stories by taking boxes of videotapes from the station's archives to her Fairfield County home (along with various playback machines, since video technology has changed over the 15 years).
"There were stories that immediately jumped out that I knew had to be in there," she said. "Some stories got eliminated because there were too many in one category, like historic places. Then I took a map, hung it up on the wall and put pins in it for where all the stories originated, because I really wanted to say something about all of Connecticut. So we started looking at stories that had to go because there were too many from one area."
As Ms. Smith was working to narrow the story selection, her husband, Thomas Woodruff, began to work out the technical challenges. An economist and former professor at Cornell with long experience with personal computers, Mr. Woodruff first sought to ease the process of transcribing the original tapes using voice conversion software.
But the multiple voices on each story, along with natural, ambient sounds which were integral to the reports, resulted in limited success. Ms. Smith had to transcribe the tapes herself, and in the process started to update the stories.
"It refamiliarized me with the people and then I just sat down and started calling," she said. "If I couldn't find them, I could call someone in the town and ask if they remembered so-and-so, who did such-and-such. Somebody always could find them. It actually turned out to be a lot of fun. Most of the people were still doing what they were doing when I did my story."
Ultimately, Ms. Smith said, she reworked almost all of each story, adding descriptions to replace the visual images, while trying to keep the flavor of the narrative.
To illustrate "Positively Connecticut," the publisher originally had the thought to use still photographs of the people and places in the stories. However Ms. Smith wanted to keep the "authentic feeling of what it was like on the air." That meant trying capture video images for use in a print publication, a process that has not been done very successfully in color because of the technical differences between video and print technology.
Mr. Woodruff took on the technical challenge. He worked with Globe Pequot's technical staff, graphics software manufacturers and WTNH technical staff. Eventually more than 300 color video images accompanied the still photography opening each section of the book.
"Video images don't contain as rich a bed of information as print films on a still image," Mr. Woodruff said. "We used a two-step process. We froze images on videotape to get the largest images possible and then played with the color density and contrast to find the best characteristics of image and sharpness. I probably need a new pair of glasses now."
The collaborative process used in preparing the book is consistent with that used to report the weekly stories for television, Ms. Smith said. The video photographers she has worked with over the years receive warm acknowledgment from her in the beginning of the book.
"It's sort of been serial monogamy. I've had a few guys for a long period of time and then in the interim I've had a mix of guys," Ms. Smith said. "When photographers came up with great ideas for a story, I asked them to shoot it with me, which is why there are so many names. When I work consistently with a photographer I don't think of them as just the picture guy. I depend on them to talk to me about the story and ask if they think it's a good story. How would it work out? What kind of music would be good? That's one of the reasons I got into TV. I had been in radio and it was so solitary to me. I like having a partner to bounce things off of."
Her current partner on the "Positively Connecticut" series is Ken Melech, who also worked closely with Mr. Woodruff on the book.
"I get a lot of creative freedom to shoot and edit the pieces as I see them," he said. "This was another growth opportunity. I never worked with publishing before."
There were two stories that Ms. Smith knew from the start would be in the book.
One was a report about a group of retired workers from Sikorsky Aircraft in Stratford who volunteered to restore the Excambian, a flying boat used during World War II to carry V.I.P.s. Ms. Smith originally reported the story in 1987 and returned more than 10 years later to see the completed project, which is now on display at the New England Air Museum in Windsor Locks.
"It's unusual in this business to have the opportunity to stick around long enough to see something from beginning to end. That made it very special to me," Ms. Smith said. "Plus the idea that these people would come back to work -- practically full time -- and that they loved what they did."
The other story is about Eric Hultgren of Westport, known as the Toyman, who after losing his wife to cancer and then battling the disease himself channeled his energy into crafting wooden toys for children being treated at Bridgeport Hospital. She revisited Mr. Hultgren to see how he reacted to all the publicity he received.
"His story gave me the feeling that one of the things about Connecticut is that we have these pockets of extreme wealth and poverty," she said. "This was a story that crossed those borders. Not that Eric is a terribly wealthy man, but he lives in Westport, one of the gold coast towns, and his heart went out to the kids in Bridgeport. And while not every kid in Bridgeport Hospital is a poor kid, a lot of them are."
Ms. Smith will continue to anchor two newscasts each weekday and prepare a new "Positively Connecticut" segment each week while juggling a promotional schedule of book, charity events and media interviews. Facing the opposite end of a microphone will be a new experience for her.
"I am a little worried about it," she said. "My family teases me that I never have a conversation, it's always an interview. I figure what I'll probably end up doing is turn it around and interview the person interviewing me."

HEADLINE: Q&A/Karen Pollard;
Public-Private Gains at New Waterbury Mall

BYLINE: By CHARLES D. TIMLIN 

 BODY:
FOR years, the drive past Waterbury on Interstate 84 was marred by the decrepit and decaying Scovill Manufacturing plant, where brass products once were made. Then Homart Inc., of Minneapolis, bought the site, proposing a mall. General Growth Properties Inc. of Chicago, in turn, bought out Homart in December of 1995. Last September, aided by $36 million in state and Federal funds, it completed the $160 million, 1.1 million-square-foot Brass Mills Center Mall and Commons on the site.
Karen Pollard, a Waterbury resident who had been in the shopping center business, was one of those who had once winced at the eyesore of the 87-acre site. Now, she is very committed to it, as general manager of the Brass Mills Center, which has been widely hailed as a model for how businesses can work with cities in urban renewal. The mall is expected to generate tax revenues of $3 million to $5 million for Waterbury. 
 Ms. Pollard recently discussed the evolution of the project, its influences in the greater Waterbury community and its long-term prospects. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. What does the general manager of a mall do?
A. It's kind of similar to being the mayor of a small town. Day-to-day operations -- facilities management, security, landscaping, engineering, marketing, public relations, advertising, promotional events. Also rent collections and billing. And because this is a public-private partnership, I am very, very involved in the community as well.
No two of my days are even remotely similar. If you need structure or to be able to schedule your time, then forget it. You have to be very flexible, very crisis driven.
Q. How did you become involved with this particular mall?
A. Since I lived in Waterbury and was in this business, I was asked to give the original developers, Homart, a tour of the property. I was asked by some people in Waterbury to be on the Downtown Economic Development Committee. A big part of what we did was to analyze what the city and community felt the mall should be like and what kind of requirements we felt should be met. Eventually, General Growth Properties asked me to work for them.
Q. What did the committee want to see in the mall?
A. They wanted a quality project that would incorporate some of the history and some of the architectural elements of what had been here in the Scovill site. They wanted to make sure that we didn't wall ourselves off. They wanted something that would flow to the downtown as opposed to creating a wall that would keep people from going downtown.
Q. Has more business been generated for downtown Waterbury?
A. Since we opened, people from the suburbs who did not ordinarily feel comfortable or safe coming to Waterbury now come on a regular basis -- to the Seven Angels Theater, for instance, which is adjacent to us, or to downtown restaurants.
However, the downtown has not yet put together their plan for revitalization. There are three elements: the Palace Theater area, the downtown area and the East Main Street area. Committees are working on each and I work with those committees.
The Governor is looking into giving us anywhere between $50 million and $100 million to work on these projects. But because there is no plan in place, nothing has yet changed in terms of more restaurants, more retails, more reasons for someone to go there. As a matter of fact, when the mall opened a number of the retails closed and came into the mall. So it's really hard to say that we are or are not having a major impact.
Q. Clearly, then, this mall is part of a plan to revitalize the businesses of Waterbury and by extension the quality of life for its citizens.
A. This was the catalyst to jumpstart the rejuvenation of the city. We are in essence the gateway to Waterbury. We're visible from the highway. Waterbury actually is a neat little city. We have some beautiful art and architecture, a fantastic symphony, a performing arts theater, a ballet.
Q. Not too far away from here you have the Danbury Fair Mall, the Meriden Square Mall, the West Farms Mall. Why another mall?
A. We had no critical mass of retail here, in an area with 340,000 people in a 10-mile mile radius. And with couples working, everybody running around, you have to drive the kids everywhere, people don't have half a day anymore to do the shopping. It used to take me 30 or 40 minutes to drive to a critical mass of retailers. I always felt that we needed a mall nearby.
Q. Hoyts Cinema built a 12-screen complex in this mall. How crucial was it to the plan?
A. It was very important. Fifteen years ago, 30 percent of a mall's business was viewed as ready to wear, women's apparel. Now women's apparel is under 20 percent of a mall's business. So we had to find a niche for growth. Because downtowns have deteriorated, malls have emerged as the environment where people can go, a destination above and beyond the shopping experience. And that's dining and entertainment.
We really concentrate on sit-down restaurants. We have Ruby Tuesday's, Bertucci's, in December we will be opening Trout Brook Brew Pub from Hartford. And then the theater and these restaurants play off each other.
We also own the 200,000-square-foot Commons adjacent to the mall. And there we have a Chili's, a Barnes and Noble, and a Shaw's will open there, and TGI Friday's is coming.
Q. What interest does a Chicago company have in Waterbury?
A. We have a $160 million investment to protect here. How much success and growth this mall will enjoy will be directly related to Waterbury's growth and prosperity.
Q. When the mall opened there was talk of state employment organizations, like Connecticut Works and Work Force Connection, working with the shops to hire the unemployed and disadvantaged. How successful have those programs been?
A. Fantastic. The Connecticut Works program put together a committee. They started it in absolutely the right attitude and approach. They brought in me and the managers of the department stores and said, "We want to know how to help you stock your stores with employees. What do you need? What kind of training can we provide?" They had a job bank of, I think, somewhere around 9,000 people. A lot of people were hired.
Q. Time magazine recently ran a cover story, "Kiss Your Mall Goodbye!" on the growth of Internet shopping. Could the Internet make malls obsolete?
Q. I don't think that a computer can ever take the place of the experience. People look for things to do with whatever spare time they have, and when you offer them an enjoyable environment, the experience is something people want. And the modern mall has food, it has theaters, and we host all kinds of community programs.
Q. How can the mall use the Internet?
A. As a marketing tool. Stores can advertise their products as well as daily or weekly specials. The Internet could actually help us draw more people to the mall.
Q. This mall has been celebrated for its public-private partnership. Has it led to any other collaborations in and around Waterbury?
A. Of any community I have worked with, and I have worked in a lot, I have never, ever seen a community more willing to spend not just money but time and energy to ensure its success in every way.
The Naugatuck Valley Development Corporation, the city agency which administered the $36 million in state and Federal money for cleanup, appointed the Design Review Committee. It's composed of residents, architects, engineers, and others. We could not build anything, we couldn't do landscaping, we could do nothing without their approval. The committee still exists. And they stuck to their guns -- we don't have a Golden Arches, for instance. It's been a remarkable relationship.
The Chamber of Commerce and many local economic development constituencies are meeting regularly to build consensus for renewal. The city just built a new courthouse, there are plans for new office buildings, and some of the hotels are getting remodeled. All of that is because of what happened here. You need something to bring people in, that suggests you can turn around what was an eyesore.
Q. As the Brass Mill Center nears its first birthday, how successful has it been in financial terms?
A. We average about 22,000 people a day. We had originally projected doing around $290-300 per square foot in our first year. An average mall does about $230. We have done over $350 a foot in our first year. And we're only about 80 percent occupied right now. This project has been a success in almost every way.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Karen Pollard, general manager, at the almost-one-year-old Brass Mills Center Mall and Commons. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WORKING;
The Cameo Appearance

BYLINE: By MICHELLE COTTLE; Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer.

 BODY:

Q. As if meetings didn't already dominate my workday, my company often organizes food- and drink-filled social events in the evening. A shy person, I find these after-work gatherings exhausting, yet realize that failing to attend could hurt my career. Any survival tips?
 
A. Ah, forced bonding with co-workers. Is there any less natural form of socializing known to mankind? Who really wants to let their hair down in front of the boss, or the office lecher, or that boor in the adjoining cubicle who eavesdrops on phone calls? But don't despair. While shunning such schmooze-fests would indeed be ill-advised, no one says you have to hang out all night with these people. You need to learn the sanity-saving art of the tactical strike: Get in, get around and get out. 
 "She's right that she has to attend, but she doesn't have to stay long," said Ronna Lichtenberg, author of "Work Would be Great if It Weren't for the People" (Hyperion, 1998). The key, Ms. Lichtenberg said, is to get more mileage out of the time you do spend at the event. Rather than hiding in a corner for hours, nursing your glass of Merlot, you should grit your teeth and do a swift round of flesh-pressing. "Go and work the crowds really heartily," she counseled. "Spend time with as many people as possible and look as cheerful as possible."
Those 15 minutes or so of super-schmoozing may be taxing, but once you've made your presence felt, you are then free to flee. "The face time is important," said Ginny Rehberg, a consultant with Drake Beam Morin in Boston who specializes in workplace politics and career issues. "Ten minutes and you're out of there. But people think you were there longer because they remember seeing you."
When you feel certain that you have kissed enough cheeks and laughed at enough jokes, check your watch and explain that you, most regrettably, have another commitment. No one need know that the commitment may consist of Chinese take-out and reruns of "E.R." Or perhaps you need to spend time with a significant other or a child -- or a cocker spaniel that needs to be walked.
Yes, the reasons may be terribly superficial. But, hey, so are too many office social events. "So much of what's going on when people are asking you to socialize has to do with the appearance of being part of a team," Ms. Rehberg said. By making an effort to chat with co-workers before disappearing, she said, you send out the reassuring message that you consider yourself one of them.
Distasteful though it may be, participating in office-bonding sessions will earn you not only valuable points, but also the right to bow out of an occasional gathering. If you can predict which events are likely to be particularly odious (cocktail parties, as opposed to breakfast meetings; birthday lunches versus picnics), save up your attendance chits and skip the one or two events a month that are guaranteed to make your flesh crawl.
 
Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer. Each week, she will respond to readers' questions about career and workplace issues. Send them by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

HEADLINE: Russian Champions on the Stamford Ice

BYLINE: By DOMINIC MARIANI 

 BODY:
AMONG the victims of the recent economic collapse in Russia have been public buildings, left in decline as more urgent problems clamor for fixes. One of those is the Yubileiny Palace of Sports ice rink in St. Petersburg, where the reigning Olympic gold and silver medal-winning pairs of skaters trained.
So what did Oksana Kazakova and her partner, Artur Dmitriev, (gold medal) and Elena Berezhnaya and Anton Sikharulidze (silver medal) do to train for coming events? 
 They came to America, specifically to the Stamford Twin Rinks, as the guests of Fairfield County families whose children also skate at Twin Rinks. "I have always had luck, and I am lucky that we were invited here," said their coach, Tamara Moskvina, who along with her husband, Igor Moskvin, is known for the St. Petersburg style of skating. "It was cheaper and easier to come here than for us to train in Moscow."
The group and its choreographer are armed with three-year visas and are training largely for competitions to be held in the United States.
Frank and Emily Cassella, the directors of skating for the Stamford Twin Rinks, extended the invitation to the Russians and also arranged for the local families to be hosts for them. Mr. Cassella is a former national champion and the couple has been teaching skaters for 20 years.
"The experience has been great for our students," Ms. Cassella said of the Russians' appearance. "We've got about 200 kids who are getting the chance to see and be around Olympic champions."
"Most lower and middle level coaches in Russia have already left for good," Mr. Cassella pointed out. "There has been an explosion of interest in skating and ice sports here that has coincided with the poor economic situation over there."
The entire Russian contingent speaks laudable English which they've studied and practiced during their many tours here. Last year they spent nearly three months on American soil -- and ice.
At the Twin Rinks in Stamford, the skating practices are open and free to the public, although seating is limited to about 300. The American Olympians Tara Lipinski and Nicole Bobek have also trained there, as well as Surya Bonaly, the French women's champion.
But it is the Russians who have dominated pairs skating for the last generation, winning every Olympic gold medal since 1964. And Mr. Dmitriev is the first male to have won it twice.
Underscoring the Russian depth in the sport, the Olympic silver medalists beat the gold medal pair at the most recent world championships.
Or, as Ms. Moskvina puts it, "The currency may change, the rink may need repair, but the quality of the Russian skating always remains the same."
When asked by Barbara Innamorati of Westport, with whom Ms. Kazakova stayed for a couple of weeks, why the Russians are so pre-eminent, Ms. Moskvina indicated that it was a complex blend of tradition, coaching, attitude, social and financial conditions and a deep-grained knowledge of the sport.
"Remember also that under the Soviet system everyone could skate because it was free," she said. "We had access and became dedicated, and since we were a closed society we worked hard at what we had without distractions."
How do the Connecticut families feel about having the Russians in their homes?
"It has been absolutely delightful," said Ms. Innamorati, a manager in mergers and acquisitions with Xerox. "The kids seem to be benefiting just by their being around."
Her son, Daniel, began skating outside at Longshore Park last winter and liked it so much he signed up for a program at Twin Rinks in May with the Ukrainian coach Victor Baryshevtev.
Maomi Anderson of Wilton, vice president of the Springdale Skating Club (based at the Twin Rinks), is the hostess for Elena Berezhnaya and the group's choreographer, Alexander Matveev, who just recently arrived. Her daughter, Gwen, has been skating with the Cassellas for five years.
Ms. Berezhnaya "has become part of the family. Not only does she give Gwen skating tips, she even helps with her Spanish homework," Ms. Anderson said.
"Oksana, Elena and I went to Brighton Beach grocery shopping last week and that was a lot of fun because everyone speaks Russian there. Elena then made us a delicious chicken borscht."
Howard Eison and his wife, Randy, of Weston, were hosts of Mr. Dmitriev and Mr. Sikharulidze. The Eison children, Kaile, 10, and Daniel, 12, are both pair skaters.
"Having Olympic champions living in our home is just like having a dream come true for our kids," Mr. Eison said. "They've always worked hard at skating, but I've noticed they're even more inspired with Artur and Anton around. And the cultural interchange has been enlightening."
The Russian coaches have been staying with Marlyn Gladieux of New Canaan, whose daughter Amanda, 11, also skates in Stamford.
"This is an experience we'll cherish for years," she said. "They can stay as long as they like."
Igor Moskvin was a Soviet pairs champion In the mid-50's and first coached, then married Tamara, who finished fourth in the 1968 Olympics and coached gold and silver medalists in 1984, a silver medalist in 1988, a gold and silver in 1992, a silver in the odd year 1994 and a gold and silver again this past winter in Nagano, Japan.
Tamara Moskvina often puts pairs of skaters together. If they have the right chemistry to work with each other, she becomes their coach, trainer, teacher, manager, agent and counselor.
"Believe me, you have to become a psychological counselor, almost like a marriage counselor," she said. "You almost have to hypnotize the couple to continue working toward the specific goal of becoming a champion. One thing I am for sure is a good diplomat."
Ms. Moskvina is one of six people from the various skating disciplines to be appointed to the Coaches Commission of the International Skating Union. She earns a living through a combination of government stipend, fees for various competitions and prize money. (The skaters can earn money through union-sanctioned events, but retain amateur status.)
According to the coach, skaters typically start as early as the age of 5 and she usually comes into the picture when they're anywhere from 15 to 17. "I look for complements in height, weight, technique, body look an a certain psychological sympathy between the two skaters," she explained.
Pairs skaters typically train for two sessions daily. They spend three hours on the ice and two hours off, working on the interwoven network of elements like music, costumes, ballet, conditioning and performing that are demanded on the world championship level.
In exchange for ice time at Twin Rinks, Ms. Moskvina and Mr. Moskvin and the skaters have volunteered to offer pointers to promising American skaters like Kyota Ina and John Zimmerman, who both moved to Stamford recently to take advantage of the Russian training, as well as to give advice to the host families' children.
"We want to be grateful guests and share our knowledge," Ms. Moskvina said.
As Mr. Zimmerman sees it, "There's nothing like skating with and against the best in the world. And getting the chance to work with Tamara is priceless."
The fact that Elena Berezhnaya is even skating is a near miracle. In 1995, while practicing camel spins with her then-partner in Latvia, she suffered a life-threatening injury when his blade accidentally smashed into her skull. She was hospitalized for two operations and lost her ability to speak and to write.
Though told she would need six months to recuperate and that she might not ever skate again, she was back on the ice in three months and working with Mr. Sikharulidze toward the world title they won this year.
Like the others she is uncertain about what the future will bring for her country. "Right now we all just wait and see what happens," she said. "Maybe we can go back to our country, maybe it's better to stay here. We don't yet know."
After repeatedly demonstrating to Ms. Ina and Mr. Zimmerman how to make a certain spin-throw, Mr. Sikharulidze was asked if he wasn't afraid of giving away too many secrets.
"No, we don't have any secrets," he said. "Once we perform in public everything we do is open to all. If you can do it better, then you are the champion."
Mr. Dmitriev, a three-time Olympic medal winner, likes the quality of the ice in Stamford, intimating that it is better than the Yubileiny Palace rink at its best.
"We will have to go back home sometime early next year, for a rest, to make new costumes and to get some new ideas," he said. "But we have a lot or work here. We have a 10-week tour, a month off, then another 10-week tour.
"It's a good job," he shrugged, "but a job."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In / Great Neck Estates, L.I.;
Elegance With a Protected Tranquillity

BYLINE: By VIVIEN KELLERMAN 

 BODY:
HALF the roads in Great Neck Estates are laid out to resemble an English garden, gently curving and lined with gnarled old trees. And landscaped islands help to create a relaxing maze of streets that never seem to end.
Many of the homes in this village hugging Little Neck Bay and the Queens border are massive Tudors, colonials and Mediterraneans. F. Scott Fitzgerald lived in Great Neck Estates with his wife, Zelda, and is reputed to have written a short story there that eventually became "The Great Gatsby." One home was designed by Stanford White, another by Frank Lloyd Wright. Even beyond the oldest part of the village, in areas where long-line ranches dominate, the community suggests elegance and calm. 
 "Residents here take great pride in the tranquillity of the village, and are fierce about protecting it," said Mayor Lawrence Nadel.
 The village has laws barring the felling of trees without a permit or taking up too much of the property in building or expanding houses, said Mr. Nadel. It was also the first community on Long Island to curtail the use of power blowers in the summer.
Residents of Great Neck Estates enjoy the protection of a 13-member police force, have the use of a five-acre park, marina, swimming pool and tennis courts. Their children attend a highly regarded school system. Shopping is easy along the village's northeastern border, Middle Neck Road, where about 70 stores provide 10 percent of the village's tax base.
Single-family homes in the village range from about $350,000 for a three-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath colonial on about one-quarter acre to more than $1 million, said David Lurie, owner-broker of Lurie Realty Company in next-door Great Neck. A typical high-end house would be a two-and-a-half-story contemporary, with five bedrooms and four-and-a-half baths on half an acre.
Most houses were built in the 20's and 30's. About 25 percent of the houses were built after World War II and range in price from $800,000 to $900,000, said Mr. Lurie.
Mr. Lurie said that except for spot building of some subdivided lots, there is no new construction in the village. But many people are renovating, he said.
The 67-unit Kenwood Gardens, built in 1927 and advertised as a co-op with luxurious apartments, cost $1.5 million to construct, or $14 million in today's dollars. Two-bedroom units now sell for about $200,000, three-bedrooms for about $250,000, said Mr. Lurie.
During the 1930's, he said, the basement of the building housed servants who worked for the apartment owners. Small cubicles serving as bed chambers ran the length of the building and servants shared a communal kitchen and bath. The basement is now used for storage.
Mr. Lurie said the market was quite strong in Great Neck Estates, despite the high prices of the homes.
HOWARD WEITZMAN, who served as Mayor from 1989 to 1995, said that he discovered Great Neck Estates in 1977 when his first child, Cathy, now 26, was getting ready to attend school.
"I looked all over Nassau County and decided after really researching that what I was looking for, I would find in Great Neck Estates," said Mr. Weitzman. "It's as close as you can get to living near the city and still be in the suburbs. It's close to everything."
He and his wife, Susan, a landscape designer with a home office, raised their three children in the village. And, said Mr. Weitzman, as they expected, the school district provided them with the best education.
"All of my children got into the best colleges," he said.
The 5,900-student Great Neck Union Free School District, which serves the 12 Great Neck Peninsula communities and part of New Hyde Park, has one Early Childhood Center, four K-5 elementary schools, two middle schools and two high schools, said Schools Superintendent William Shine.
Between 1970 and 1982, when enrollment declined, five schools were closed. But the buildings are still in use -- one for adult-education programs, another for citizenship and literacy programs, a third for a center for the elderly and after-school program, the fourth for a joint program with Manhasset to provide pre-kindergarten to economically deprived children and the fifth as an alternative high school.
The district's kindergarten program consists of classes with no more than 20 pupils attending four half-days and a week. One day a week they stay for the full day.
Last June, 96 percent of the district's 462 graduates of its North High School and South High School went on to higher education. There were four Merit Scholarship finalists and three winners. Four students were semifinalists in the Westinghouse Science Competition and three were finalists.
One student, Michael McNabb, a senior at North High, was selected as a United States Presidential Scholar, an honor that goes to up to 141 graduating seniors in the nation each year. Selection is based on achievement in academic and artistic endeavors, leadership and involvement in the community.
The high schools offer 21 advanced placement courses, including separate courses on Vergil and Latin literature; there are at least two computers in every elementary school classroom, with a goal of five, and a dedicated cable channel is used for after-school programs and a technology course.
The five-acre Waterfront Park on Little Neck Bay has a stone promenade where residents can view the Manhattan skyline in the distance. The park has an Olympic-sized pool and a kiddie pool, which is open Memorial Day through Labor Day. Residents pay $200 for a family season pass.
There are seven tennis courts, three of them enclosed. Family passes for outdoor tennis are $120 a full year. Indoor passes range from $600 to $1,300, depending on days and times. The village marina offers a boat launching service at $500 a season and free mooring. A baseball field, soccer field, basketball and handball court, playground and benches complete the picture. To use the park residents need a parking sticker, available free of charge at Village Hall.
The village also has two wetland preserves -- the Nature Preserve with a walking trail and Pond Park -- with a total of about four acres.
IN the summer, a day camp for village children aged 4 to 6 offers swimming lessons, arts and crafts, dancing and sports at no cost. Fifty children were enrolled in the camp last summer, said Mayor Nadel, in a village of only 2,811 people, indicating that many young families are moving in.
Residents have 11 village restaurants to choose from on Middle Neck Road. Among them, La Pizzeria, a kosher pizzeria, Tortilla Grill, for Tex-Mex food, Shishkabob Palace for Middle Eastern, two Chinese and several Italian restaurants, among them Navona, where the comedian Alan King, a resident of nearby Kings Point has a special table, according to Mayor Nadel.
The earliest settlers in the Great Neck Estates area were the Matinecock Indians who lived along the shore. Around 1625, the tribal leaders sold their lands to a representative of Charles I of England, Lord William Alexander Sterling, a poet and statesman, for about 11 cents an acre. The land was then sold to 50 patentees. In 1630, Richard Thorne, a farmer, purchased the property that became the village. The Thorne family held the property until 1909.
For most of its early history, farming was the primary source of income and the community remained sparsely settled. In 1862, the Long Island Rail Road began service to neighboring Great Neck, cutting the time to the city from seven and a half hours to a little more than an hour.
By the time the village was incorporated in 1911, it had 15 houses and 60 residents. Among the celebrities who moved into the village in the 20's, besides the Fitzgeralds, were Ring Lardner, Fanny Brice and Ed Wynn.
In 1939, the Soundview Golf Course was sold to private developers, who began building after World War II. The former golf course area represents about 25 percent of the village.
Ilsa Kagen, the village historian and former president of the Great Neck Estates Civic Association, moved into Great Neck Estates in 1960. She said she and her late husband, Richard, a tax lawyer, had chosen the community after learning about the school district's fine reputation. Her daughter, Mici, a lawyer, who was educated in the district, is a Harvard graduate.
"It's a very convenient village," she said. "We're not that far from stores, we have the pool, tennis courts, marina. And it's just plain gorgeous. It's just wonderful to be living here."

 DESIGN FOR LIVING: In 1909, an international contest was held offering a $10,000 prize for the best design of what is now known as Great Neck Estates. The contest -- sponsored by Richard McKnight, an Englishman who had purchased 600 acres from the Thorne family, which had owned the property since 1630 -- was won by C. E. Bartlett, a well-known English landscape architect. The winning plan called for a clover-leaf design for the village, which was incorporated two years later. Ilsa Kagen, the village historian, said vistors often complain that they can't find their way around. "I can't think of a better place to get lost in," she said.

HEADLINE: In the Region / Westchester;
Two Soaring Proposals for Low-Scale New Rochelle

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
THINGS are definitely looking up for this city on Long Island Sound as it considers two proposals that have nothing in common, except their height. At more than 200 feet, they would be the tallest structures in the city.
On Wednesday, the City Council is to consider whether to allow Avalon Bay Communities, a Real Estate Investment Trust based in Alexandria, Va., to build a 280-foot-tall, 24-story luxury rental as part its long-awaited Avalon on the Sound project, which is expected to eventually comprise 1,000 apartments in three separate buildings. 
 Also on the table will be another, more unusual proposal for a 220-foot free-fall ride called Space Shot, which the developer Louis Cappelli wants to build atop NewRoc City, the three-story entertainment/retail center now rising in the city's downtown.
These two new proposals are the latest additions to projects that have been in the pipeline for years. Advocates of the projects say that they will be catalysts for this city's economic revival, especially for its deteriorating downtown.
The 375,000-square-foot NewRoc City, which is expected to open next summer, will comprise a 20-screen movie theater, the county's first IMAX large-screen movie theater, twin ice skating rinks, a supermarket, health club, restaurant and hotel.
Avalon on the Sound, which still has to receive its final approvals, is expected to start construction in the spring and take about 18 months to complete the first phase, according to Fred Harris, vice president for development for Avalon.
Prior to submitting its latest plan for a 24-story building, Avalon had already received approvals to build 1,000 apartments in three 14-story buildings. Then last month, the developer resubmitted plans calling for the taller building, which would have a total of 408 one-, two- and three-bedroom apartments.
The 24-story building would constitute the first phase of the project, according to Mr. Harris. At this time, the second and third phases will probably be the two 14-story buildings, as originally planned, "but we're not really thinking about too much about the other phases yet," Mr. Harris said, adding that "we want to build the first building and then see what happens."
Of the two new proposals, Avalon's appears the most likely to come to fruition, according to Joseph Madonna, the city's Commissioner of Development. "I think there's a lot of support for it," he said. "It's actually a more exciting and aesthetically pleasing building than the first one they proposed."
Due to the building's extra height, the City Council would have to pass an amendment to the city's comprehensive plan, said Mr. Madonna. The planning board would thenhave to approve a revised site plan, he explained.
"I don't think the impacts are that different from the former proposal," said Anthony Carbone, chairman of the Planning Board. "I don't expect a lot of controversy." The reason for changing the building's height was to "capitalize on the views," according to Mr. Harris. "We also wanted to create a more luxurious building, the kind of high rise you'd see in Manhattan," he said. The new plan, he added, also "represents our confidence in the market now for luxury rentals."
The L-shaped building will occupy a site near the Metro-North train station and will tower over a city comprised mostly of single-family homes, and several much smaller apartment buildings. Designed by Beyer Blinder Belle, of Manhattan, the brick-and-limestone building will take maximum advantage of its sight lines, said Karen Thomas, project architect.
"The east side of the building will look out on the Long Island Sound and the west will have views of New York City's skyline," Ms. Thomas said. And all apartments will have bay windows and a large percentage will have balconies.
Half of the 408 apartments will be one-bedrooms, the balance two- and three-bedrooms. "The top three floors will be penthouses," Ms. Thomas said. "They will be set back from the top, as in steps. Each will have large paved terraces and, perhaps, floor-to-ceiling windows." The interior designs are still being worked out.
Atop a 200-car parking garage, there will be a swimming pool, clubhouse and rooftop terrace, with landscaping and sitting areas. The ground floor of the apartment building will also include a small retail component.
Avalon now has two luxury rentals under construction in the county, a 227-unit project in Mamaroneck and one with 110 units in Bronxville. Although rents at the New Rochelle building have not yet been established, they should be in line with those in the other projects, Mr. Harris said. In Bronxville, for example, one bedrooms start at $1,700 and three bedrooms at $$3,600.
While Avalon's latest proposal was expected by the city, Mr. Madonna said, the plans for the Space Shot seem to have come completely out of the blue. "People are concerned about this one because this city is not a resort town," Mr. Madonna said. "As far as adding it to an entertainment and shopping center in the heart of the city, I'm not sure it will go with everything else."
MR. CAPPELLI, a general partner with Cappelli Development Company, of Valhalla, who is a partner in NewRoc City, said that he recently had held a meeting to explain his proposal to the community, and only around 15 people showed up.
"I think that's encouraging because usually only the people who oppose a project show up at meetings," Mr. Cappelli said. "By the time the meeting was over, only one person was still against it."
When the Space Shot proposal goes before the planning board, "it will be judged on its merits the same as any other proposal," said Mr. Carbone. One of his major concerns, however, is the potential noise. "I heard that the machine is relatively quiet since it uses compressed air," he said, "but what about the screaming?"
The proposed ride would sit atop the three-story center. Twelve people would be strapped into seats outside a tower. They would be rocketed into the air and then dropped 180 feet, temporarily escaping gravity and floating above their seats.
Construction of the ride, more than 50 versions of which have been built in 18 countries, is expected to cost $2.5 million. Mr. Cappelli said he was willing to build it on a trial basis for three years. "If the city doesn't like it after that time, I can take it down.
"I think it's the perfect complement to an entertainment center," Mr. Cappelli said. "I'm not trying to create an amusement park. This is meant to continue the experience people get from the movies and the IMAX theater. I don't want people to just go to the movies and then go home."
Mr. Cappelli added that traditionally it had been hard to get people to "go vertical" in a center of this kind. "If people go up the escalator just out of curiosity, the ride will be worth it," he said.

HEADLINE: An Election, Yes, But Congressional Races, Not Really;
Challenger Making Money an Issue

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
IT bothers Congressman Forbes that his Democratic opponent, Mr. Holst, a Suffolk County legislator, is bringing up contributions Mr. Forbes received from tobacco companies.
Mr. Forbes, 46, a Republican, would rather dwell on his efforts to clean up Brookhaven National Laboratory, combat breast cancer, expand the Wertheim National Wildlife Refuge, create a new Federal land preserve near the old Grumman plant in Calverton, ban toxic dumping in Long Island Sound and bring a new veterans health clinic to his eastern Long Island district. 
"I have no idea how much or how little I got from them," said Mr. Forbes, referring to figures showing he received $19,800 from the tobacco industry during his two terms. "I don't vote according to that measure."
Mr. Holst, 46, a lawyer, said the contribution was one of many from political action committees that had enriched Forbes campaigns. "I don't want that kind of money," he said.
People close to Mr. Forbes said Mr. Holst need not worry. His low-budget, uphill fight to unseat Mr. Forbes wouldn't attract outside money from anywhere, they said.
But Mr. Holst, for whom public education and economic development are the highest priorities, said he senses upset in a district that has elected Democrats before. "He is vulnerable with women," Mr. Holst said. "He hasn't made any inroads on issues such as domestic violence and he is radically anti-choice on abortion." Mr. Holst describes himself as pro-choice.
Mr. Forbes, also the Conservative, Independence and Right-to-Life candidate in the race, knows it's a swing district and names one predecessor, Democrat Otis G. Pike of Riverhead, as his role model. Mr. Forbes said last week he will spend about $700,000 to defeat Mr. Holst. "You take nothing for granted," he said.
Mr. Forbes said he had delivered on promises to "restore fiscal integrity in Washington" by joining the House Republican leadership in budget-cutting and in reforms that replaced welfare with workfare.
But, he said, his record also showed he was "not afraid to break with the Republican leadership."
In January 1997, Mr. Forbes was one of nine Republicans who opposed the re-election of Newt Gingrich as House speaker because of his admission of ethics violations. Last July, he also opposed the leadership by voting for a campaign finance reform bill.
For all that, Mr. Holst said, Mr. Forbes was still in lock-step with the leadership on most issues. Mr. Forbes's support for an open-ended Presidential impeachment inquiry, Mr. Holst said, "sets the stage for another two years of personal attacks on President Clinton."
Mr. Forbes said he would "wait and be thoughtful" before making a judgment on whether Mr. Clinton should be impeached. "All of us are weary of this and want it to be brought to a quick conclusion," he said.
