HEADLINE: Negative Rate For Savings In September

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
United States manufacturing was weaker last month than at any time in more than two and a half years, and consumers saw their incomes weaken in September as the savings rate turned negative for the first time in 40 years.
The National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index fell to 48.3 in October from 49.4 in September -- the lowest reading since 47.3 in March 1996. The index has hovered just below 50 since June, a sign of a decline in manufacturing and slower economic growth over all. 
 Personal income growth slowed in September, rising two-tenths of a percent -- half the previous month's gain -- as spending rose, Commerce Department figures showed. September's savings rate fell to minus two-tenths of a percent. That is the first time the statistics have showed people spent more than they earned since the Government began tracking savings monthly in 1959. The only times the savings rate was negative for a year was during the Great Depression.
Today's reports suggest falling exports and weaker consumer confidence were slowing the economy and suggested subdued growth in the months ahead. "Manufacturing is still in deep trouble," said Astrid Adolfson, an economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York. Consumers, meantime, "just aren't saving," and they cannot live beyond their means for long, said Kevin Flanagan, an economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York.
While manufacturing is slowing, builders are still reporting growth. Construction spending rose four-tenths of a percent in September after showing no change in August, Commerce Department figures showed. Construction, especially of single-family homes, had been a mainstay of the economy all year.
And the factory decline had not yet pushed the United States toward a recession, analysts said. A reading below 50 in the purchasers' index means the number of manufacturers who said business deteriorated was greater than the number of those saying it improved. Still, only when the index falls below 43.6 for a time does it generally signal a contraction in the broader economy, officials of the purchasers' association said.
The association's production index, a gauge of current output, fell to 52.6 in October from 53.4 during September. The new orders index, a gauge of current demand, fell to 45.7 in October from 50.1 during September. The export orders index, a gauge of Asian and other international demand, fell to 42 in October from 45.8 during September.
The association's price index showed little change, holding close to the lowest reading in half a decade. Its index of prices paid edged up slightly, to 35.8 in October from 34.4 during September, the lowest since July 1949.
Businesses are bracing for a slowdown. Facing a potential inventory buildup, the Ford Motor Company, the world's No. 2 auto maker, will shut down a Missouri car plant for three weeks and an Ohio van factory for one week beginning today, idling 4,000 workers. Citing declining exports and pressures from imports, the LTV Steel Corporation said on Thursday that it would idle 40 percent of its Cleveland steel operation for one week and furlough 320 workers.
The Commerce Department's income and spending report, meantime, suggested consumers' buying could slow. Spending rose five-tenths of a percent in September, following a revised four-tenths of a percent rise in August. The two-tenths of a percent increase in incomes was the weakest since a drop in April 1997 and followed a four-tenths of a percent increase in August.

HEADLINE: Tower Realty Says Crescent Cancels Deal

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Crescent Real Estate Equities Company, an investment trust controlled by the billionaire Richard E. Rainwater, and the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation have called off their $734 million joint purchase of the New York office developer Tower Realty Trust, Tower said yesterday.
Tower said it considered the move a "willful breach of the merger agreement" and filed a lawsuit against Crescent and Reckson in New York State Supreme Court for at least $75 million in damages. 
 Speculation had increased in recent months that the transaction would not be completed after Crescent, which is based in Fort Worth, backed out of least $2 billion in other acquisitions amid a decline in its stock price and dwindling financing available for real estate.
"Regrettably, Tower Realty Trust is the latest victim of Crescent's desperate attempts to unwind many of its financial obligations in light of current market conditions," Tower said in a statement.
Officials at Crescent, Reckson and Tower were not immediately available for comment. Tower did not say why Crescent and Reckson had called off the purchase.
Tower shares fell 11 percent yesterday, dropping $2.3125, to $17.9375. Crescent was unchanged at $25.0625, and Reckson rose 18.75 cents, to $22.875.
Officials at Crescent, where Mr. Rainwater is the chairman and founder, said in recent interviews that with real estate values coming down, they wanted to conserve their capital, which would allow them to buy properties at better prices than earlier this year.
Analysts have called the agreement between Crescent and Reckson legally "airtight," with neither able to walk away without stiff monetary penalties.
In recent interviews Reckson officials said they were still committed to buying Tower, and some analysts and investors expect the company to find a new partner.
"We'll probably see this deal come back in one form or another," said James Grissett, a Tower shareholder who heads Parthenon Group, a real estate securities money management firm .
In July, Crescent and Reckson teamed up in a 50-50 venture to buy Tower for $454 million, or $24 a share, cash and $280 million in assumed debt. All three companies are real estate investment trusts, or REIT's.
Reckson, which is based in Melville, N.Y., is Long Island's biggest commercial property landlord. Crescent, one of the nation's largest real estate companies, has stakes in everything from office buildings to psychiatric hospitals and residential developments.
The purchase was to give Crescent and Reckson an entree into the New York office market. Tower owns 24 office buildings with 4.6 million square feet of space in New York, Phoenix and Tucson, Ariz., and Orlando, Fla. About two-thirds of Tower's revenue comes from its New York office properties.
Since the agreement was announced, REIT stocks have tumbled on concern about a slowing economy and increased development. Crescent shares are down 35 percent this year, while Reckson is down 11 percent.
Other recent transactions Crescent has walked away from include the $1.7 billion purchase of the Las Vegas gambling company Station Casinos Inc. and the acquisition of $456 million of office buildings from the Prudential Insurance Company of America. Station has filed a lawsuit against Crescent seeking $400 million in damages.
Investors said Crescent's decision to walk away from these agreements might give the company a negative reputation among sellers, shutting it out of the market for desirable properties that become available.
"They have an evolving credibility problem," Mr. Grissett said. "Probably the only way they can get deals going forward is as a buyer or lender of last resort."

HEADLINE: Albright Will Visit Jakarta This Month

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright will visit Indonesia later this month for the first time since the downfall of President Suharto, who was an American ally for several decades, the State Department said today.
Ms. Albright, who will be in Asia this month for the annual Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, will also visit Thailand for meetings with Thai leaders, the State Department said. 
 Indonesia, Thailand and Malaysia have been hard hit by the Asian financial crisis, which began with the collapse of the Thai currency in July 1997.
The crisis spread to Indonesia, where rioting and mass protests forced Mr. Suharto to resign on May 21. He was replaced by Vice President B. J. Habibie, but unrest and economic distress have continued.
In recent speeches, Ms. Albright has advocated that Asian governments follow policies of free trade, market economics, democratization and respect for human rights.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Up 114.05 as Stocks Gain for Fourth Straight Session

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices continued to plow ahead yesterday as investors gained more confidence that the days and weeks of instability that were the norm from mid-July until late September are over.
"Everything is good right now, for now," one stock trader said. 
 "There is a continued belief the Fed will ease interest rates again," he added. "Foreign markets are stable. There is not a lot of new supply because there are not any deals. And mutual-fund inflows continue."
Once again, equities turned in a broad-based advance. The Dow Jones industrial average yesterday rose 114.05 points, or 1.33 percent, to 8,706.15.
It was the fourth consecutive session to end with a gain for the blue-chip gauge and the first time it has closed above 8,700 points since Aug. 18. For the year, the Dow is up slightly more than 10 percent.
Among broader market measures, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 12.93 points, or 1.18 percent, to 1,111.60. The Nasdaq composite index rose 29.52 points, or 1.67 percent, to 1,800.91. And the Russell 2000 index of small-company stocks gained 8.66 points, or 2.3 percent, to 386.82.
For the second consecutive session, investors bought stocks despite a sharp rise in market interest rates.
Rates rose on all manner of Treasury securities yesterday. The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell by more than a point, and the yield rose to 5.25 percent, its highest level in six weeks.
Analysts said the recent selloff in the Government debt market was a sign that investors were increasingly confident that conditions no longer warranted the safety of Treasury notes and bonds.
"By and large, the Treasury bond market got way ahead of itself in terms of being a flight-to-quality haven," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management. "Now, money is redistributing itself among all financial markets. If people start getting nervous again, it may reverse."
Mr. Fine said that developments over the last week had slightly altered what had been a near-unanimous view in the credit markets that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates again later this month.
In the stock market, however, that view is still widely if not universally held. Moreover, there is little doubt that the Fed's decision to cut rates in late September and again last month has been vitally significant to the stock market's rally.
"The key thing is that we now have financial leadership worldwide, led by the Fed," said Jack Shaughnessy, chief investment strategist at Advest Inc. in Boston.
In a weekly letter sent to clients yesterday, analysts at International Strategy and Investment noted that concerns about the world financial crisis prompted 17 central banks, including the Fed, to cut interest rates last month. Six countries that lowered rates are European, and those cuts have helped reinvigorate stock markets on the Continent.
Most European markets posted strong gains yesterday, with indexes in Britain, France and Germany all rising by more than 1 percent.
Michael Clark, head of United States stock trading at Credit Suisse First Boston, said that American equities had benefited from what has been happening in Europe.
The Western European markets, he said, "are picking up steam as we move toward the end of the year and the birth of the European monetary union. That has given support to all industrialized country markets."
Worries that a global economic downturn would hurt companies that rely on overseas sales for a big part of their profits helped to lower share prices of many multinational companies through the last six weeks of the summer. Those concerns have abated somewhat, and the stocks are beginning to rebound.
Yesterday Coca-Cola, which relies on foreign sales for more than 75 percent of its profits, was the Dow's best-performing issue. Coke rose 3 7/16 a share, to 71. Boeing, another Dow stock, gained 3 3/4, to 41 5/16.
A third Dow component, Citigroup, fell 7/8 a share, to 46 1/8, after James Dimon, co-chief of its investment banking unit and the presumed heir apparent to Sanford I. Weill, Citigroup's co-chairman, abruptly announced his resignation.
Takeover stocks were big gainers yesterday.
Sofamor Danek Group, a surgical equipment maker, rose 8 1/2 a share, to 110 1/8, after it agreed to be acquired by Medtronic Inc., one of the world's biggest manufacturers of pacemakers, in a stock deal valued at $3.6 billion, or $115 a share. Medtronic shares rose 1 9/16 , to 66 9/16.
Boole & Babbage Inc. gained 3 1/2, to 30 1/8, after BMC Software Inc., a leading maker of software to manage programs on computer networks, agreed to buy the company for about $900 million in stock, or $32.44 a share, based on Friday's closing prices. BMC shares fell 2, to 46 1/16.
Among other Nasdaq stocks, Intel rose 2 5/8 a share, to 91 13/16 . And Cisco Systems, which is expected to report its third-quarter results tomorrow, gained 1 11/16, to 64 11/16.

HEADLINE: Good Times Mean Hard Sell for the Military

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WALDORF, Md., Oct. 29

 BODY:
Christopher Thompson was a prime target for the two older men roaming the St. Charles Towne Center mall today dressed in black uniforms. He was young. He looked fit. He was in the mall in the middle of the morning.
"You play sports?" Mr. Thompson was asked by way of introduction. More importantly, Keith L. Dixon wondered, had Mr. Thompson ever considered enlisting in the Navy? 
 Petty Officer Dixon and his fellow recruiter got little more than a shrug from Mr. Thompson, 19, a response all too familiar these days.
Recruiting young men and women into the nation's all-volunteer military has never been easy, but the military now faces a crisis in recruiting that has been building for some time and, many commanders fear, could very well get worse.
The Pentagon has announced that the Army and the Navy have each failed to reach their goals in signing up new recruits for the fiscal year that just ended. It was the first time since the draft ended in 1973 that the Navy had fallen short, and it did so disastrously, enlisting 12 percent fewer recruits than its goal of 55,300.
The Pentagon attributes its difficulties to many things. The economy is thriving. The unemployment rate is at its lowest since the days of the draft. Young people are more likely than ever to go straight to college after graduating from high school -- nearly 70 percent now, compared with less than half just a decade ago.
But many officials believe the armed services face a deeper problem and one more difficult to overcome. The military, simply put, no longer looms very large in young people's lives and families.
"More people are into just having fun," said Mr. Thompson, who recently moved to Maryland from Charlotte, N.C.
The sharp drawdown of personnel that followed the end of the cold war -- and the collapse of the nation's only overarching enemy -- has left the military as small as it has been since right after World War II. With 1.4 million soldiers, sailors, airmen and marines on active duty, the military is 40 percent the size it was at the peak of the Vietnam War in 1968.
That has meant a steady decline in the number of veterans in the population and in the number of those the recruiters call "influencers," the relatives, friends, teachers or others with military service who often inspire young people to sign up.
Mr. Thompson's generation -- the teen-agers and 20-somethings born after 1973 -- is the first whose fathers never had to face conscription.
"I can remember, when I was a little kid growing up, all I heard about was the military service of my parents," said Adm. Barbara E. McGann, the Navy's two-star commander in charge of recruiting. "Both my parents served. And you do grow up hearing these stories and being curious about what military service would be all about.
"I mean that's gone forever," Admiral McGann added.
The recruiting difficulties have led to shortages of enlisted personnel in the field, raising concerns about the "readiness" of the armed forces to fight -- and win -- a war.
Since Navy recruits almost always go straight to sea after basic training, the Navy's shortfall has contributed disproportionately to shortages of enlisted sailors in the fleet. Navy ships, on average, now set sail with only 90 percent of a full crew.
The Army missed its goal to recruit 72,600 soldiers by 1 percent, but it fell far shorter in enlisting recruits for harder-to-fill specialities.
The Air Force and Marines, both smaller forces with more specialized appeals, met their goals for the last fiscal year, though, in the Air Force's case, only after speeding up the start dates of those who signed up but decided to wait to enter the service.
The Pentagon is scrambling to address the shortfalls. The $1.1 billion that Congress approved for military readiness two weeks ago included $113 million to aid recruiting, including an increase in enlistment bonuses for areas hit hardest by recruiting woes.
The cost of recruiting has risen. Without the infusion of new money, it now costs, on average, $7,187 per recruit, including advertising, enlistment bonuses and money for college. At the end of the cold war in 1989, each recruit cost $5,460, in dollars adjusted for inflation.
The Navy and the Army have hired hundreds of new recruiters, and they have flooded television with ads they hope will reach youths.
In mid-October, the Army began broadcasting new commercials. The jolting advertisements mix staccato Nike-like images and pulsating music. "Are you ready to make real noise?" one of them asks.
"It's still 'Be all that you can be,' but we took the experience the Army can offer and packaged it in a more contemporary fashion," said Lieut. Col. James P. Sullivan, the Army's chief of marketing and advertising.
In a few weeks, the Navy will broadcast its first "infomercial" on cable, touting the service in a medium more often used to sell beauty products and financial investments.
"This generation watches cable late into the evening," Admiral McGann said.
The Admiral and other Pentagon officials express optimism that a redoubled effort will fix any serious recruiting problems before they endanger the services.
But others argue that recruiting will thrive only when more chronic problems are addressed. In a memorandum sent to every Army general on Oct. 7, the Army Chief of Staff, Gen. Dennis J. Reimer, warned that the perceived gap between civilian and military pay and benefits and the high pace of Army operations would continue to hurt recruiting until the situation was addressed.
The memorandum cited the lament of an Army recruiting sergeant in Ohio, who summarized the problem like this: "We are asking today's youth to leave home, deploy at a moment's notice and give his life for his country for the same pay as a fry cook."
All of which makes recruiters like Petty Officer Dixon more important than ever. He works out of a small office along Highway 301 in Waldorf, about 25 miles southeast of Washington. The office and another in Lexington Park handle recruiting in most of rural southern Maryland.
An 18-year veteran, Petty Officer Dixon has spent the last two and a half years trying to sell prospective recruits on the Navy.
He scours the high schools and recreation centers, but also improvises. He once left his business card in each sneaker in the mall's shoe store and, surprising even himself, received a call from a prospect, who a week later was on his way to a Navy boot camp.
In the last two years, he has been the second best recruiter in a region that stretches from northern Virginia to New Jersey, but it was always a struggle, he said.
"There's a real lack of interest," he said, cheerful nonetheless, as he cruised the mall, which, he explained, is crawling with prospects.
In a way, the Navy is a victim of its own success.
Like the other services, the Navy has increased the quality of its recruits by requiring a high school diploma and above-average scores on aptitude tests. The Navy also turns down anyone with physical or mental defects, or a history of drug use. Those standards, the Navy estimates, eliminate two-thirds of the pool; more often than not those are the ones who volunteer.
"Most of the people who walk into the office have something wrong with them," said Petty Officer Benny J. Granillo, a 10-year veteran who works mostly from Lexington Park.
That is why recruiters rely more on contacts they cultivate. At the mall, for example, Petty Officers Dixon and Granillo each went to check up on prospects, like Patricia Overstreet, 19, who signed up to be a medical corpsman but wanted to wait until after Christmas to start.
Since the mall has a ban on soliciting, recruiters approach prospects like Mr. Thompson indirectly. In this case, they chatted a bit about basketball and high school, learning that Mr. Thompson was waiting for his girlfriend to get off from her job at a store. Petty Officer Dixon invited him to join a basketball game on Saturday. "No strings attached," he said, handing him a card.
After leaving Mr. Thompson, Petty Officer Dixon asked, "Do you know what the problem with that guy is?"
He and Petty Officer Granillo answered in tandem, "The girlfriend."
"He might be interested, but the girlfriend won't want him to leave," Petty Officer Dixon explained. Then he made a note to himself to drop by the store every now and then and see how the relationship was going.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Tours West Coast to Whip Voters Into a Poll-Going Frenzy

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 2

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore ended his long and labored campaign season today with a long and laboring day on the West Coast, joining major Democratic candidates for a rally in Sacramento, Calif., and along a four-stop, 130-mile bus tour through western Washington.
In the final hours before the elections, Mr. Gore delivered a fiery speech at every event, each generally focused on urging Democrats to vote on Tuesday. As he raised his voice to an assemblage of 800 noisy, card-waving partisans in Sacramento to start the day: "The enthusiasm level in this room is very high. You have to translate that into a very high turnout tomorrow. I know you are determined to do that." 
 For Democrats across the country, the stakes are unusually high, measured against predicted losses for the party in the House, the Senate and Governors' mansions, in part because of the eleventh-hour Republican strategy to make President Clinton's involvement in a sex scandal a major campaign issue.
Mr. Gore and the candidates who accompanied him today countered by stressing issues that Democrats have made the hallmarks of their fall campaigning -- education, health care, economic progress and environmental protections -- while taking steady swipes at Speaker Newt Gingrich and the right wing of the Republican Party.
After his remarks at a park in Olympia, the Washington state capital, Mr. Gore took the additional step of calling aside Jay Inslee, a former House Democrat who is trying to regain a seat this year, to acknowledge his efforts as the first Democrat anywhere to air a television commercial criticizing Republicans who made the sex scandal a campaign issue.
Mr. Gore told reporters that Mr. Inslee was the first "to sound the trumpet and say, 'Hey, wait a minute, this election ought to be about the future of the American people and not about investigating President Clinton.' He's taken that message to the people, and the people have responded by saying, 'That is right.' "
In his speech, Mr. Gore reprised a favorite laugh-line when he told the crowd of several thousand: "The Republican party in 1998 is in such disarray that the right hand doesn't know what the far right hand is doing."
At the University of Washington at Tacoma, Mr. Gore seemed to contradict the disarray joke by saying Republicans were "united in their hatred for President Clinton and their fondness for personal attacks and negative advertisements."
But Mr. Gore repeated the joke, anyway.
For Mr. Gore, as well, the stakes in the elections are elevated, in that all his recent campaign appearances -- more than 100 events in 26 states since late August -- have also been designed to help solidify his political base for a Presidential run in 2000.
But aside from a smattering of "Gore 2000" signs along the way today and a reference to him by Art Torres, the state Democratic Party chairman, as "the next President of the United States," most references to the future were limited to the next 24 hours.
Aides to Mr. Gore said that part of the political calculation for ending the campaign with a two-day trip that began on Sunday in New York and Wisconsin was to provide a final boost for four candidates caught in Senate races that remained too close to call: Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, Senator Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin, Senator Barbara Boxer of California and Senator Patty Murray of Washington. Ms. Murray accompanied the Vice President on each stop today.
The Republicans hold a majority of 55 seats in the Senate and hope to add several more. But the Vice President had generous words for almost any Democrat running, including the entire statewide Democratic slate in California and most of the Democratic House candidates in Washington State, including the two challengers who have the best chance of winning: Mr. Inslee, who is in an even race with Representative Rick White, and Brian Baird, who is seeking to succeed Representative Linda Smith, the Republican who is challenging Senator Murray.

HEADLINE: Boston Leading a Renewal of Old Northern Cities

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Boston, of course, would never do anything so uncouth as to boom.
But consider: Big cranes are in such demand here that builders have been looking for them as far west as the Mississippi. Architects are in short supply. Downtown commercial real estate has the lowest vacancy rate of any city center in the country, local monitors say, and the highest average rents, topping even San Francisco's and Manhattan's. Hotel rooms are often so impossible to get that reservation clerks might as well be Cabots or Lodges, for all the airs they put on. 
 Consider, too, that for the first time in more than five years new office towers are going up in downtown Boston, with one planned to rise higher than the landmark Prudential Center. Warnings of the dreaded "Manhattanization" of downtown can again be heard.
And this: Boston, its face already changing strikingly as the $11 billion construction project known as the Big Dig sinks the city's unsightly main highway underground, is embarking on a project so monumental that it has been compared to the landfill creation of the graceful Back Bay section a century ago. The project is the development of a 1,000-acre seaport district in South Boston, the last great chunk of convenient empty land on the water. (Water that was once the filthiest urban harbor in the country and is now, thanks to a nearly complete $4 billion cleanup, possibly the cleanest.)
The city, said the Boston Redevelopment Authority director, Thomas N. O'Brien, using the local vernacular, "is wicked hot."
For some, it is too hot. In legendary working-class neighborhoods like the Italian North End and traditionally Irish South Boston, the costs of buying and renting apartments have nearly doubled in the last two years, as the white collar has invaded and some blue collars have been squeezed out. And advocates for the poorest Bostonians worry about still-greater crowding and displacement.
But overall, Boston's resurgence is seen by many urban experts as spearheading a hopeful trend among aging northern cities that have experienced decades of decay. Planners talk about an "urban surge" or "comeback cities," spurred by factors as varied as plummeting crime rates, a strong national economy, a return of empty-nesters to walkable lives and the disdain that many young, educated professionals feel for the suburbs they grew up in.
They qualify carefully. The greatest population and employment growth is still occurring in the suburbs and "exurbs," farther out, and many urban cores continue to crumble, losing people and jobs. Many parents still spurn urban school systems. And of course it is the sunny cities like Atlanta, Phoenix and Las Vegas that are booming loudest.
But from Chicago to Cleveland to Pittsburgh to Baltimore, experts in urban affairs also note mounting signs of a willingness -- even eagerness -- to live and work and play in once-shunned downtowns and centers, and of both a public and private willingness to invest there.
"I think the traditional downtowns or older cities are now being kind of re-imagined by people," said Alex Krieger, chairman of the department of urban planning and design at Harvard University. "Instead of places where you get blue-collar jobs, which is the midcentury view of the city, they're being re-assimilated in the consciousness of Americans as places of culture, leisure, entertainment, bar-hopping and service-sector jobs."
"This is one of the most interesting changes in turn-of-the-century American society," he said. "There's this amazing shift from the city as a place where you live because you can't afford to live anywhere else to a place where you go to have fun."
And among resurging Eastern and Midwestern cities, some urban-affairs experts say, Boston seems to be coming back the best, helped by huge public projects but also by being the right place at the right time in the strong economy.
 
After a Hard Fall, A Welcome Bounce
In a way, such a high-stepping comeback seems only fair. Boston, the 20th most-populous city in the United States, with nearly 600,000 people, suffered disproportionately in the last recession. In the 1980's, New England hit the worst economic times any region had since the Depression. Speculative overbuilding in and around Boston in the mid-80's resulted, by the end of the decade, in despair.
It took until last year to regain all the recession jobs lost and sop up the extra office space. But now, history seems to be smiling again on an intellectual and cultural peacock of a town that calls itself the Hub and the Athens of America. In a traditional toast, Boston is also called the Home of the Bean and the Cod; but now, at just the right time, it is more of a home to the bit and the doc -- a capital of financial services, medicine and high technology, all fields that have particularly thrived in this thriving economy.
That economic diversity should help cushion Boston from financial shocks like this summer's stock market "correction," said Mayor Thomas M. Menino, the first Italian-American in to hold that office in Boston and a nuts-and-bolts kind of guy whose business-friendly approach has helped fuel the city's growth.
"Boston depends on four different economies -- academia, health care, mutual funds and tourism," he said, speaking in his cavernous City Hall office. "Most cities depend on one segment of the economy."
Lately, economic uncertainty has led to tighter credit for commercial real estate deals here, and economists predict a slowing of the city's growth. They also warn of an impending labor shortage, particularly of skilled workers. At the same time, they point to the striking breadth of Boston's non-boom.
In the Italian North End, for example, Nancy Caruso, a pillar of the dense, sauce-scented neighborhood who has lived there for 50 years, said she got cards and letters almost every day asking whether she would consider selling her small building. Buildings bought by speculators in the 1980's for $200,000 would now bring perhaps $600,000, she said.
"Within the last two years," she said, "it's started to boom again, and last year it was very booming, and this year, it's just gone crazy," to the point that Italian families who had moved to the suburbs and want to come back find they cannot afford it.
The North End situation, though nice for owners, also illustrates the great downside of the city's current vigor. Boston housing has long been some of the most expensive in the nation, but the soaring prices lately have been squeezing poorer residents, particularly new immigrants, ever harder.
"Every neighborhood in Boston has very strong pressures in its residential market," said Mr. O'Brien, of the Boston Redevelopment Authority.
Real estate brokers say that in South Boston, the heavily Irish enclave that gained ill-fame for its opposition to school busing in the 1970's, rents have shot up perhaps 70 percent in the last 18 months; and in the traditional triple-deckers that have usually housed a family on each floor, the population is changing.
"What's happening is that the families that have lived here for so long are really becoming displaced," said Mike Foley, regional vice president for Jack Conway and Company Realtors. Apartments that once housed single families are being shared by individuals bringing in multiple incomes. "We're renting to three or four individuals who can pay $500 a piece," Mr. Foley said. "Two years ago, you might have been getting $800 for those same apartments. The marketplace has increased so drastically that South Boston families can't afford these rents."
Among Boston's poorest, the economic energy has helped some. Marc Germain, a social worker in the Dorchester section, said, "It's easier to get a lot of young people -- who are traditionally unable to get into the labor market -- jobs."
But it has also hurt, said Charlotte Kahn, director of the Boston Foundation's Persistent Poverty Project. With the city's high cost of living, she said, "for people on fixed incomes or minimum wage, it has always been tough, and in this kind of boom environment, it becomes that much tougher. And when you factor in welfare reform, which is due to start in December, nobody knows what that's really going to mean for people."
"We're already seeing an increase in homelessness," she said.
Boston's growth also creates problems for those in the path of development -- like George Hagerty, an artist in the historic Fenway Studios building near the chi-chi boutiques of Newbury Street. He protests that his light will be ruined if plans go forward for a neighboring skyscraper over the Massachusetts Turnpike, and that in times like these, sometimes "people get squished."
"We could either succeed or fail very badly at changing the face of Boston," he warned.
 
Economic Changes, Yes, but Social, Too
The burst in Boston's civic energy, some city leaders say, seems to come not only from economic forces but from social changes as well, changes in a city so known for paralyzing political fights that the former Governor of Massachusetts William Weld recently said Boston had boomed "in spite of itself."
For well over three decades, for example, an elite, rather secretive group called the Vault, founded in 1959 mainly by Yankee bankers and businessmen to help create a "New Boston" in the dismal post-war years, was seen as a leading force in shaping the city. That group imploded about two years ago and is officially defunct.
Now, said Ira Jackson, an executive vice president at Bankboston, a broader, more open, more inclusive group of business, labor, neighborhood and political leaders has formed a loose coalition, with more of a friendly, collaborative, "getting-it-done" approach to everything from crime to education.
Take Boston's push to have the Democratic National Convention in 2000. Boston has never been host of the convention, Mr. Jackson noted, in part because it could not get its act together to compete for it. This time it is in the running. When Democratic scouts came around, they visited the city's tallest building, the blue-mirrored John Hancock tower, and took the popular new Duck Tours in amphibious vehicles on the Charles River and around town.
"The notion you could get business guys to sit down with labor and community leaders and the Republican governor and the Democratic Speaker and everybody at a big lovefest at the top of the Hancock or at 7 o'clock in the morning at Filene's Basement!" Mr. Jackson exclaimed. "Or taking a Duck Tour with delegates and driving the thing onto the floor of the Fleet Center! All those things happened. It couldn't have happened in Boston ever before."
The new model for city development, said Thomas Piper, an urban-planning research scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is the way Boston is approaching the gargantuan development of the new seaport district, which is expected to take decades to complete.
The area, which already includes the World Trade Center exhibition complex, the just-opened $220-million Federal courthouse and the just-opened Seaport Hotel, was the subject of a special town-meeting type of conference in May, and the city's plan for it is now absorbing widespread comment from neighborhood defenders and the Boston Society of Architects, among others. Interested residents can even check out a three-dimensional seaport plan on the Internet.
"It's a challenge to the imagination," Mr. Piper said, comparing the project's scale to the development of Battery Park City in Manhattan. The seaport can also be seen, Mr. Piper said, as the shape of the urban future: a project made possible by an environmental cleanup and offering enticing recreational spots, serving pedestrians well and reflecting the ideas and desires of the public.
Lively debate is also already under way about what to do with the empty 27-acre swath that will be left over the sunken highway, the Central Artery.
 
Building From Ground, And Beneath, Up
Boston has recovered and then some, but not all by itself, all acknowledge. It has been blessed by $17 billion in infrastructure investments, including a $1 billion renovation of Logan International Airport. Some of the investment was brought home by long-serving and powerful Congressmen and some was provided by a wealthy state that makes its capital here. The seaport district will have a subway line and turnpike exits once the Big Dig is completed, for example, and the North End is red-hot in part because it will no longer be cut off from the rest of the city by the Central Artery.
"Boston is exceptional" in its comeback, said Alan Altshuler, a professor of urban planning at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government and a skeptic about the talk of a general urban resurgence. "There's been massive infrastructure investment focused here."
Other skeptics would agree, pointing out that the concentration of poverty in many cities has continued to rise. They also note that, while there are many projections of a coming urban population influx, not even fashionable centers like Denver and Portland, Ore., have seen much population growth in the 1990's compared with that in the suburbs. That cities are doing better is undeniable, they say, but at best that means a new stability, not a full-fledged renaissance.
A recent survey of cities by the Brookings Institution and the Fanny Mae Foundation projected, for example, that the downtown population of Cleveland would grow by 228 percent by the year 2010, while Denver's would grow by 165 percent and Columbus, Ohio's, by 53 percent.
Harvard's Professor Krieger, like other urban enthusiasts, sees the half-full glass:
"The point is that, thought about most broadly, there is substantial reinvestment in the cores of our cities," he said, "and that is quite different from a generation or two ago in America, or even a decade ago."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Union Official Expects No Games Before January

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
On the day before the season was supposed to start, Billy Hunter, the executive director of the National Basketball Players Association, said yesterday that no agreement was imminent in the labor impasse and that he thought the season would not begin until next year.
Hunter's remarks dispelled any notion that the team owners and the players were headed toward a settlement any time soon, despite long, intensive bargaining sessions last week. 
 "My gut tells me that in January we could be playing," he said in a conference call with reporters. "I would anticipate the season would start around the first part of January."
Russ Granik, deputy commissioner of the National Basketball Association, said he agreed with Hunter that an agreement was not close.
Hunter's declaration came after representatives of the owners and players met for about two and a half hours at a Manhattan law firm. Union officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the divide was over the mechanics of an escrow system proposed by the owners.
The plan would have been put into effect after two or three years of employing a luxury-tax system to curb salaries. In those escrow plan years, the sides would determine at the end of each season how much revenue was devoted to player salaries. If a target number was exceeded, part of the escrow money would be returned and distributed to all 29 teams. It was unclear how far apart the sides were.
Hunter said that he was trying to stop recent news media speculation that an agreement would be reached as early as this week. "I don't know where that information came from, but I can indicate that I don't see any possibility at all of reaching an agreement this week, and I can't say how soon it will be," he said.
Before the disagreement on how the escrow system should be put in place, the biggest stumbling block was what revenue percentages should be after the system had been in place for a few years. The players are asking for 60 percent; the owners are offering 50.
No talks are scheduled until tomorrow, when N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern, Granik and the league lawyers will meet with Hunter, the union president Patrick Ewing and their legal team. Hunter said an earlier plan to have full negotiating teams present was scrapped, but he did entertain the possibility of such a bargaining session by the end of the week if the two sides could hash out their differences.
Hunter said that yesterday was used to iron out some of the mechanics for calculating salary caps and other issues. "There was little or no progress," he said.
"We obviously think we're much further apart than we were a week ago on economic issues," Hunter said. "My optimism last Tuesday was over the fact that we were meeting, and I felt the owners and the league were somewhat anxious. But for whatever reason, they've become a little more entrenched and we may have taken a step back today."
In a statement, Granik said last night: "Nothing has changed from last week. The union agreed that the N.B.A. had the right to reopen the contract if player compensation reached 52 percent. The percentage we paid to players last year soared to 57 percent and the players' best offer so far is that they be paid 60 percent. We agree with Mr. Hunter that we are not close."
Under a normal schedule, players would have gone through their last practices yesterday before openers around the country tonight.
The 194 games in November have been canceled. If there is no settlement this week, then the first week of December will be canceled. Granik had said that every week an agreement was not signed basically meant another week would be canceled.
Meanwhile, fans of professional basketball are split over who is more justified in the labor dispute, according to the latest nationwide New York Times/CBS News Poll. The players are supported by 36 percent of fans, while 29 percent side with the owners, according to the poll. Nine percent said neither side was more in the right, and 25 percent didn't have an opinion.
Male fans are evenly divided: 32 percent support the players and 34 percent endorse the owners' position. Female fans' sentiment was more inclined to be with the players: among the women interested in professional basketball, 41 percent sided with the players and 24 percent supported the owners.
The telephone poll was conducted Oct. 21-25 with 1,118 adults, 39 percent of whom said they were very or somewhat interested in professional basketball. The margin of sampling error for basketball fans in the poll is plus or minus 5 percentage points.

Taped Gates Testimony Shown at Microsoft Trial
In two hours of videotaped questioning shown at the Microsoft antitrust trial, William H. Gates, the chairman of the company, professed ignorance of several key charges in the Government's suit, including allegations that he was involved in plans to bully competitors like Apple Computer and Netscape Communications to step back from Internet software markets that Microsoft sought to dominate. 
 When presented with electronic mail messages he had written, he often said he did not recognize the messages or recall the discussions surrounding them, prompting, at times, even the presiding judge to chuckle and shake his head. Page A1.
 
Impasse at Federal Express A top executive at Federal Express warned that the company was on the verge of losing several large customers during the peak holiday season because of a threatened strike by its pilots. The disclosure came after the latest round of negotiations between the company and the Fedex Pilots Association broke down late Friday. C2.
 
Danone Buys U.S. Bottler
Groupe Danone announced that it was buying Aqua Penn Spring Water for $112 million, or $13 a share, which sent Aqua Penn's shares up 30 percent. The move gives Groupe Danone of Paris access to three spring-water sources in Florida, California and Pennsylvania in addition to the Utah and Quebec springs it now uses for its Dannon brand of bottled water, which is distributed nationwide. It also links Danone for the first time to big customers like McDonald's, where Aqua Penn sells bottled water in some areas, and doubles the company's production capacity in the United States. C4.
 
F.D.A. Approves Sangstat Drug
Sangstat Medical said the Food and Drug Administration had approved its immune-suppressant drug, Sangcya, for preventing organ rejection in transplant patients, and for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and psoriasis. Sangstat said it would introduce the drug within a month and would be priced 20 percent below an equivalent drug, Neoral, which is made by Novartis. C9.
 
New Signs of Economic Weakness
The latest evidence of slower economic growth showed that United States manufacturing was weaker last month than at any time in more than two and a half years and that consumer income weakened in September as the savings rate turned negative for the first time in 40 years. C2.
 
Tower Realty Sale Collapses
Crescent Real Estate Equities, an investment trust controlled by the billionaire Richard E. Rainwater, and Reckson Associates Realty have called off their $734 million joint purchase of the New York office developer Tower Realty Trust, Tower said. C4.
 
Philips to Close Factories
Royal Philips Electronics, the Dutch manufacturing giant, said it would close up to one-third of its plants by 2002 to create a leaner company and adapt to a difficult world economy. The announcement, while troubling for the Philips work force of 256,000, seemed to be welcomed by investors. Shares of Philips rose 9 percent in Amsterdam. On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Philips jumped $4.5625, to $59.8125. C4.
 
Update at London Exchange
The London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange, under pressure to make its trading system faster and cheaper, announced a sweeping reorganization intended to cut its operating costs in half by the end of next year. C4.
 
The National Association of Securities Dealers, parent of Nasdaq, completed its merger with the American Stock Exchange. C10.
 
New York City and state officials are close to a deal to provide Nasdaq and the American Stock Exchange with a $200 million subsidy package to build a new headquarters. B1.

Kosovo Health Care Collapse

NATIONAL A16-25
 
Elections Are Widely Seen As Referendum on Clinton
Americans are expected to trickle, if not stream, to the polls today in a midterm election that will inevitably be interpreted as a referendum on the fate of the President, whose tribulations distinguished the campaign season more than any raging national issue. Most strategists held firm with predictions of modest Republican gains in the House, where all 435 seats are up for grabs, a Republican gain of no more than a few seats in the Senate and no appreciable shift in the Republicans' domination of governor's offices. A1
 
Fewer than half of all eligible voters are expected to visit the polls; some political analysts say the number could plummet to about one-third. A1
 
National political parties have been steadily pumping money into critical state races, in part because whoever controls the statehouses and governors' mansions will have a hand in redrawing Congressional districts after the 2000 census. A24
 
Senator Carol Moseley-Braun of Illinois stuck close to her hometown, playing to her Democratic political base in an eleventh-hour effort to keep her job. Her opponent is State Senator Peter Fitzgerald. A23
 
Boston Leads Urban Comeback
A resurgence in Boston is seen by many urban experts as spearheading a hopeful trend among aging northern cities that have experienced decades of decay. For the first time in more than five years, for example, new office towers are going up in downtown Boston. A1
 
Military Faces Recruiting Crisis
The military faces a crisis in recruiting that has been building for some time and, many commanders fear, could very well get worse. The Pentagon said that the Army and the Navy had each failed to reach their goals in signing up recruits. A16

The nation's most famously liberal city, Berkeley, Calif., is trying to fight drug dealing and disperse entrenched camps of the homeless in its shopping district. A16

A tenacious Auschwitz survivor who went on to sue the Germans for compensation for his work as a slave laborer, then devoted his life to building a spirited movement of Holocaust survivors, he was 85. B11

HEADLINE: Iraq's Audacious Defiance

 BODY:
Emboldened by its past successes in curtailing United Nations arms inspections, Iraq has now virtually banned all monitoring efforts. Before Saddam Hussein will let this vital work resume, he unreasonably demands that the Security Council guarantee an early end to international economic sanctions against Iraq. Such a commitment would relieve Baghdad of its obligation to prove it has eliminated all illegal biological, chemical and nuclear weapons and missiles that can deliver them.
This contempt for Security Council resolutions has spurred even previously equivocal council members like Russia and France to condemn Baghdad's decision and demand that Iraq comply in full with all resolutions. This show of unity is important, and welcome. But experience suggests that resolutions alone will not be enough to make Iraq live up to its obligations. Washington, together with whatever partners it can mobilize, must once again be prepared to enforce the council's demands with military action. 
 Since August, Iraq has prohibited U.N. investigators from carrying out surprise inspections of new locations where they believed weapons ingredients or documentary evidence might be hidden. That seriously undermined the inspection program, but at least previously identified sites were still visited by inspectors and kept under surveillance by cameras and chemical detection devices. Now even those routine inspection visits have been barred.
For the moment, Iraq is not interfering with technicians who maintain video cameras and replace batteries at locations where these devices have been installed. But maintaining this equipment is much less important than the physical inspections by trained specialists.
Until early this year Washington consistently backed the U.N. inspection program with the threat to use force, the only language that seems to move Mr. Hussein. But White House resolve weakened last spring and Washington responded meekly when Iraq halted surprise inspections in August.
Whenever Mr. Hussein senses hesitation he moves to gain advantage, and Washington is now dealing with the predictable consequence of its desire to avoid another confrontation with Iraq. The threat of Iraqi chemical and biological weapons is too grave to treat exclusively as a diplomatic matter, as the White House now seems belatedly to recognize. If diplomacy backed by the threat of force does not budge Mr. Hussein, military action itself may be needed.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: THE ELECTORATE;
Bored, Dispirited, Disgusted, Most Won't Vote

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: OTTAWA, Ill., Nov. 1

 BODY:
Since casting a ballot for Harry S. Truman in 1948, Harold Hiles, a World War II veteran, has always deemed it an honor and a duty to vote.
But on this Election Day, he is staying home. 
 "Don't want any part of it," said Mr. Hiles, 76, over a piece of apple pie on Sunday morning, as church bells pealed in this small Midwestern city. "Clinton, Starr, the whole bunch of them. Who do you believe anymore? Who can you respect? People are just losing faith."
For all the handicapping about the races between Democrats and Republicans on Tuesday, there is little doubt what most Americans will effectively choose: none of the above.
It is a virtual certainty that fewer than half of all eligible voters will visit the polls on Tuesday; some political analysts say the number could plummet to about one-third.
While grousing about politicians is a time-honored American tradition, would-have-been-voters say this season's campaigners have wallowed in far more than the usual level of muck -- vicious name-calling, transparent pandering and, of course, the lascivious details about President Clinton's sexual behavior.
"It just seems like politics are spinning out of control," said Jerry Hanck, a 60-year-old liquor salesman who will be sitting out the election. "There are bad actors on both sides."
It was in this old river town 140 years ago that 10,000 people turned out at Washington Square for the first debate between Stephen Douglas and Abraham Lincoln, a discussion that focused on constitutional principles and the most fundamental of human rights issues, slavery.
It does not escape notice here that the last national election of the 20th century seems to be driven by sound bites, attack ads and sex talk that brings an embarrassed blush even to a crusty old Navy man like Mr. Hiles.
But gauging the sensibilities of voters is tricky, especially when it comes to Mr. Clinton's affair with a former White House intern.
Mr. Hiles, a retired glass factory worker and union member, would surely fall in the approval column in polls on the President's job rating. "He's been a wonderful President," Mr. Hiles said.
And yet Mr. Hiles said he would boycott the ballot box on Tuesday largely because he disapproves of Mr. Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, and the President's failure to tell the whole truth about the affair.
It was a sentiment that surfaced frequently among nonvoters, mostly among Democrats. These were not people who intended to bolt to the Republican side. They had simply become dispirited.
"Democrats just feel kind of embarrassed right now," said Connie Jolley, 29, a restaurant manager. Ms. Jolley, who described herself as "a majorly Democratic" voter in most years, plans to go to the polls on Tuesday, but only to vote on a local referendum.
She intends to skip the races for governor and Congress, saying that she could not bring herself to vote for the Republicans, but did not believe the Democrats had earned her vote.
Compared to voters, nonvoters are younger, less educated, have lower incomes and tend to support Democratic candidates for the House of Representatives, according to the latest New York Times/CBS poll.
The poll, taken Oct. 26 to Oct. 28, found that 32 percent of nonvoters are under age 30, compared with just 13 percent of voters. Nearly two-thirds of nonvoters have never attended college, whereas 43 percent of voters have not attended college. Forty percent of nonvoters have households incomes of less than $30,000 a year, compared to 24 percent of likely voters.
In races for the House of Representatives, 49 percent of nonvoters favored Democratic candidates and 27 percent favored Republicans. The likely voters, meanwhile, were evenly split between the two parties.
The extent of political apathy this year will not be fully measured until the votes are counted, but at least two studies suggest an increase.
Four years ago in a Times/CBS News poll, a third of voters said they were paying a lot of attention to campaigns in their state, and 20 percent said they were paying little or no attention. This year, the Times/ CBS News poll shows interest in the campaigns slightly down, with less than 3 in 10 voters saying they were paying a lot of attention, and about a quarter saying they were paying little or no attention.
And a report released on Friday by the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, a nonpartisan research institution in Washington, found that turnout was likely to be between 36 percent to 38 percent of eligible voters, down from the 38.8 percent who voted in 1994.
No one can yet accurately measure how much of the expected decline can be attributed to disgust with the Lewinsky scandal, or for that matter, the Starr investigation.
The conventional wisdom predicting a lower turnout in November is generally based on the relatively low turnout in this year's primary elections. But Thomas Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution in Washington, cautioned that turnout was difficult to predict. Indeed, he said some political analysts were expecting something of a surge in voting by blacks, who have been among Mr. Clinton's most loyal defenders. He added that union members, whatever their feeling about the Lewinsky affair, were unlikely to sit out the election, given strong get-out-the vote efforts by labor leaders.
The 11th Congressional District here, which sweeps north and east across Illinois farmland to the industrial city of Joliet, has swung between Democrats and Republicans. It last changed hands in 1994, when Jerry Weller, a Republican, took office. Mr. Weller is widely expected to win re-election against his Democratic opponent, Gary Mueller.
"People feel like, 'What's the sense?' " said Mike Malles, a 33-year-old house painter, who skipped past the political news to the movie reviews in the Sunday newspaper.
"The noise is just too loud," said Mr. Malles, who usually votes. "There's so much hype. A lot of people just want to pull back."
Mudslinging and scandal are surely not the only things keeping voters from the polls. Many people say they simply do not find politics interesting enough to spend much time dwelling on the issues.
When Melissa Reynolds, a 19-year-old college student, asked, "What are we voting for?" she was not posing a rhetorical question.
She was unaware that Tuesday was Election Day. "I don't get into that stuff," said Miss Reynolds, who plans to be a grammar school teacher.
With the economy in relatively good shape, many Americans see no reason to demand sharp political change. Others simply see the actions of political leaders as increasingly irrelevant to their daily lives.
Dedra Phillips, who works as a quality analyst for a cookie company, said she was enjoying some prosperity. A nonvoter, she said politicians should leave her alone. And she plans to return the favor.
"Times are good for me because I make them that way," said Ms. Phillips, 28, who pushed a stroller that held her two young children. "It has nothing to do with politicians."
Diana Harden, a 33-year-old custodian, said she would stay away from the polls as a gesture of protest against politicians who she claimed operated on a different standard than ordinary Americans.
"They think they're better than the people who pay their salaries," said Ms. Harden, who does not normally vote.
Susan Harnisch, a 47-year-old teacher at a prison, said she would skip the voting booth because politicians had skipped the issues most relevant to people.
"They're wasting time on this investigation -- censure him, throw him out, let him go, whatever -- but let's get on with it," said Ms. Harnisch, who usually splits her ticket.
She blamed Republicans for dwelling on Kenneth W. Starr's investigation of Mr. Clinton, but said the President, by his example, "has made it much harder for the average person who wants to go out and do the right thing."
But more than anything else, she said, she was annoyed by politicians who focus on "hot-button" issues like gun control and abortion, while ignoring the complicated matters that come up in everyday life.
"Why don't they talk about things that hit home -- medical expenses, credit card debt, men who don't pay child support," said Ms. Harnisch. "I'm not voting because it just doesn't seem to get through to them."

HEADLINE: Power Line Makes Use Of a Miracle Of Physics

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE 

 BODY:
After 87 years of alternating exuberance and disappointment, and a decade after a famous conclave of physicists at which the key to success seemed to be within reach, the world's first superconducting power line is about to become a reality.
A superconducting line is one that will conduct huge electrical currents with far less resistance than that of a line made of metal wire, and that therefore conserves energy. 
 The first large-capacity superconducting line, to begin operation by mid-2000 in Detroit, will be only 400 feet long. But it will use only 250 pounds of a new kind of superconducting wire to carry as much current as the 18,000 pounds of copper wire the line will replace.
Experts say the line will demonstrate the practicability of large-scale superconducting power transmission and will be the first of many such lines. In announcing a contract providing for Federal support for the project, Energy Secretary Bill Richardson predicted two weeks ago that power lines like this one, exploiting the special properties of "high-temperature superconductors," could eventually save the nation $6 billion a year. Another benefit is that the electricity industry could sharply reduce the pollution created by generating plants.
Lengths of the same superconducting cable up to 50 yards long have already been successfully tested, said Dr. Paul M. Grant, an expert in superconductivity at the Electric Power Research Institute in Palo Alto, Calif.
The new power line will be built by a consortium that includes the American Superconductor Company of Westborough, Mass., which will supply superconducting wire; Pirelli Cables and Systems of Milan, Italy, which will assemble the wire into a power line; the Lotepro Corporation of Valhalla, N.Y., which will supply refrigeration equipment to keep liquid nitrogen circulating through the line, and the Electric Power Research Institute.
The cost of the line, intended to serve an urban redevelopment project in Detroit, is estimated to be $5.5 million, $2.75 million of which will be paid by the Department of Energy.
Superconductivity was discovered in 1911 by a Dutch physicist, Haike Kamerlingh Onnes, when he used liquid helium at a temperature of minus 452 degrees Fahrenheit to chill metallic mercury. He found that at that temperature mercury loses all resistance to electric current.
The physics of superconductivity is complex, and despite the success of at least one theory, some questions remain. In general, a superconductor undergoes changes when sufficiently cooled that affect its "conduction electrons," the normally free electrons that wander through a metal and can carry an electric current.
In the simplest type of superconductivity, these electrons condense into pairs correlated with each other; the result is a kind of electronic fluid that conducts electricity without resistance.
Many metals were found to become superconductors when chilled with liquid helium, but liquid helium is too expensive and difficult to keep cold to be a practical coolant for large-scale superconducting power transmission. Despite this, inventors have envisioned giant superconducting storage rings that could provide huge amounts of power instantaneously for city power grids, or to power military beam weapons for use against ballistic missiles. Visionaries also sketched designs for magnetically levitated trains riding on fields generated by superconducting magnets.
But of all the possibilities, the one that beckoned most seductively was the dream of a superconducting power line -- one that could reduce transmission losses to practically zero, saving huge amounts of otherwise wasted energy.
Since 1911, several superconducting alloys, especially those based on the metal niobium, have found applications in superconducting magnets used for clinical diagnosis and in machines that accelerate subnuclear particles for scientific investigations of the nature of matter.
But hopes for building a superconducting power line remained unfulfilled. The main problem was that liquid helium is expensive and has to be constantly cooled by powerful refrigerators as it boils away. Engineers wished for some material that would become superconductive at much higher temperatures than that of liquid helium, perhaps even room temperature, or at least at the temperature of liquid nitrogen, which is minus 320 degrees Fahrenheit.
Scientists had all but given up hope of finding such a substance, but in 1986, two physicists working at I.B.M.'s Zurich Research Laboratory in Switzerland, Dr. Georg Bednorz and Dr. K. Alex Muller, made a momentous discovery, for which they were awarded a Nobel Prize a year later.
They found that a new class of compounds called copper-oxide perovskites (incorporating thin layers of copper and oxygen atoms) became superconductive at temperatures well above that of liquid nitrogen. Within weeks of their discovery, scores of other scientists turned up independent evidence of high-temperature superconductivity, and on the night of March 18, 1987, physicists packed a New York City hotel for a conference later dubbed the "Woodstock of Physics." At the meeting, scientists presented 51 reports of new superconductivity experiments, and riotous optimism dominated the proceedings.
But experimenters soon realized that copper oxide perovskites had a long way to go before they could be used for transmitting large electric currents. In some formulations, large currents destroyed superconductivity. It was also found that many high-temperature superconductors were so brittle that they could not be bent or fabricated into wire without breaking.
Another problem was "creep." In high-temperature superconductors, the current they carry induces a magnetic field outside them. This field then penetrates the superconductor as a lattice of "vortex lines" that define the superconductor's electronic behavior. As long as these lattices remain fixed in place (or "pinned," as scientists call it), superconductivity is maintained. But if the lattices creep out of place, superconductivity ceases.
Solving these problems took theoretical and experimental research that spanned a decade after the 1986 "Woodstock." But as the euphoria faded, real progress ensued.
American Superconductor drew technology from many sources, acquiring dozens of patents and licenses that finally enabled the company to produce a superconducting material suitable for a power line.
John Howe, a vice president of the company, identified the superconductor it is using for the Detroit line as BSCCO-2223, a finely powdered mixture of bismuth, strontium, calcium and copper oxide, to which a dash of lead is added. (The numbers in the formula denote the proportions of the elements in the compound.)
"We buy the powders commercially, mix them, pack them into silver tubes, and then extrude the tubes through dies to make microfilaments containing the superconductor," Mr. Howe said. "Then we bundle the filaments into wires, which we send to Pirelli for fabrication into cables."
The Pirelli company winds the wires helically around a channel in which the cold liquid nitrogen flows, and then encases the superconducting wire with layers of thermal and electrical insulation. For the Detroit project, Pirelli expects to manufacture the line in Italy.
The resulting line does not eliminate electrical resistance completely, Mr. Howe said. Where one fiber is in contact with another, the superconductive electric current is interrupted. It must take the form of ordinary current as it passes through the silver cladding enclosing the BSCCO (pronounced "bisco") superconductor, since the silver cladding is not a superconductor. Still, he said, the capacity of the line will be three times as large as that of a copper line.
Nine of the present four-inch-diameter copper power lines connecting a key transformer station with the distribution grid in Detroit will be replaced by three superconducting lines chilled with liquid nitrogen circulating through the cable cores.
One of the advantages of this, Mr. Howe said, is that dispersing the waste heat produced by a power line is a much less serious problem for a superconducting line than for a conventional copper line. This means that trenches dug for new lines can be narrower than those for ordinary conductors, and this will reduce the right of way utility companies must acquire.
Each superconducting four-inch cable will carry 2,400 amps of current at 2,400 volts.
Dr. Grant of the Electric Power Research Institute, who spent most of his career at I.B.M. as a solid-state physicist, said that it might be a long time before such lines were used over long distances. But superconductors can greatly reduce power bottlenecks within congested cities, he said.
A major use that may come soon will be in transformers, Dr. Grant predicted. A superconducting transformer will contain no oil to catch fire or spill causing toxic pollution, and would be a boon for utilities.
Once again, optimism pervades the community of scientists and engineers working on applications of superconductivity.
The contract to build the new Detroit power line, Secretary Richardson said, opens "the gateway to the electricity superhighway of the future" that will "transform the power delivery systems of the world."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 4, 1998, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Science Times yesterday about plans to build a superconducting power line in Detroit misstated the nature of the achievement for which Dr. K. Alex Muller and Dr. Georg Bednorz received the 1987 Nobel Prize in Physics. Their prize was awarded for their discovery of a new class of superconducting substances, which conduct electricity without resistance at temperatures much warmer than liquid helium, minus 452 degrees Fahrenheit -- not for discovering a substance that becomes superconducting at liquid nitrogen temperatures of minus 320 degrees.
(Five months after the discovery that won Dr. Muller and Dr. Bednorz a Nobel prize, another team, led by Dr. Ching-Wu Chu and Dr. W. K. Wu of the University of Houston, compounded the first member in this class of substances to become a superconductor at liquid nitrogen temperatures.)

HEADLINE: Nasdaq and Amex Close to Deal To Move to Single Times Sq. Site

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
New York City and state officials are close to a deal to provide Nasdaq and the American Stock Exchange with a $200 million subsidy package to build a new joint headquarters, probably in a skyscraper a block from Times Square, people involved with the talks said yesterday.
Under the terms of an agreement that was still being completed last night, the American Exchange, which is based in lower Manhattan, and Nasdaq, which is based in Washington, would build a new trading floor and a combined headquarters in New York. In turn, city and state officials would provide about $180 million in tax breaks and investment tax credits and $20 million to $25 million in cash for the project. 
 City and state officials and real estate executives say the markets will probably move to a 40-story skyscraper that a developer, Douglas Durst, plans to build on land between 42d and 43d Streets, from the middle of the block east to the Avenue of the Americas. Next door, Nasdaq is already erecting the largest sign in Times Square, a $15 million multimedia kaleidoscope, on the side of Mr. Durst's 48-story Conde Nast building, which is on Broadway between 42d and 43d Streets.
Should the markets move to the Times Square area, it would help solidify the emergence of midtown as another center of international finance. The move would also add to the growth of the Times Square area as an arena of pulsating signs, live theaters, giant media and entertainment companies, investment banks, MTV studios, restaurants and T-shirt shops.
Real estate and financial executives say the midtown location would be in keeping with efforts by Frank G. Zarb, chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, which owns Nasdaq and Amex, to build a world financial market that would rival the New York Stock Exchange.
He acquired the American Exchange last week and has made a bid to acquire the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, which would presumably also move to New York should the bid be accepted.
"If Nasdaq moves to Times Square, it's clear they are looking to climb onto the world stage," said Ross Moskowitz, a real estate lawyer with Stroock & Stroock & Lavan. "A move to an internationally recognized location reinforces a trend: stock ownership is no longer limited to a few and now requires mass marketing."
If the markets cannot strike a deal with Mr. Durst, Nasdaq and Amex could transfer the $200 million benefit package to a second site at Battery Park City, people involved in the talks said. Another developer, World Financial Properties, has offered to build a tower for the markets there. Their first choice, though, is the Durst site in Times Square, city and state officials and real estate executives said.
Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, declined comment, as did Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation.
"We are talking to the city about an offer," Michael Jones, chief administrative officer of the National Association of Securities Dealers, said last night. "We have also received an offer from New Jersey. We are reviewing both."
Two people involved with the negotiations said a deal "was very close." A City Hall official said last night, "We expect to have a deal within a few days."
At first glance, Nasdaq and Amex might seem to be alien to Times Square. But in recent years, corporate law firms, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the investment firm, and Reuters, the giant British financial information services company, have found their way to the district.
Other financial markets are looking for new homes.
City and state officials are trying to complete a similar but even more expensive deal with the New York Stock Exchange, which, like Nasdaq, has threatened to move to New Jersey.
Government officials and executives at the exchange are wrestling over the size of the public subsidies for what is described as a $1.1 billion project on a block across the street from the market's historic home on Wall Street. At least initially, the New York Stock Exchange sought more than $400 million in cash and $300 million in tax breaks, people on both sides of the negotiations have said.
Fearing that the loss of the exchange would undercut a downtown revival, city officials have secured a tentative agreement with the owners of the block, where they want the exchange to build offices and new trading floors.
But it would probably cost about $300 million to acquire the property, which is known as the J. P. Morgan site. In the negotiations, the exchange has said the cost of land should be borne by the city and the state.
Negotiators for the exchange have tried to arrange larger state subsidies by continually raising the specter of moving across the Hudson River to Jersey City.
Late last month, Gualberto Medina, the New Jersey Secretary of Commerce, said he had increased the value of an incentive package he was offering the exchange.
The New York Stock Exchange also has expressed interest in the same vacant lot at Battery Park City that Nasdaq has considered.
"We'd like to see the New York Stock Exchange stay in the downtown area," Mr. Gargano said. "We have made it clear that we will be competitive with whatever New Jersey is offering. At the same time, we have to use state dollars prudently. There are others who are going to come to us in the future."

A picture caption yesterday about a possible deal to provide Nasdaq and the American Stock Exchange a subsidy for a new headquarters near Times Square misstated the location in some copies. As noted in the related article, the site is at the northwest corner of 42d Street and the Avenue of the Americas, not the southeast.
