SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1494 words

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK STATE -- THE DEFEAT;
D'Amato Fails, Finally, To Confound Rivals

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
For most of his 18 years in Washington, Alfonse M. D'Amato has been the Senator who never quite fit in. He was a conservative from a state of moderates and liberals, a machine-bred politician in an institution sprinkled heavily with Ivy League-trained debaters, a colorful showman whose predecessors and colleagues, from Herbert H. Lehman to Daniel Patrick Moynihan, were more muted and highbrow.
But until yesterday, Mr. D'Amato, a Republican, had confounded his enemies time and again with sheer wiliness, energy and gall. Once the outsider, he had become the consummate Senate inside player. Dogged by ethics investigations, he had turned inquisitor into President Clinton's Whitewater dealings. Dismissed by his critics as a clown, he had learned to champion the hopes and resentments of suburban and upstate voters who had carried him to victory three times before. 
 Yesterday, those voters failed to answer his call one last time, heeding instead the message of his Democratic challenger, Representative Charles E. Schumer, that Mr. D'Amato could not be trusted, had been in office for too long and had embarrassed himself too many times.
At Republican headquarters at the Hilton Hotel and Towers in Manhattan last night, news of Mr. D'Amato's loss dampened the victory celebrations for Gov. George E. Pataki. Even late in the evening, some party loyalists insisted that Mr. D'Amato might still pull it off, as he did in 1992, while others fretted that upstate New York would be hurt by the Schumer victory.
Trying to silence boos at the mention of Mr. Schumer's name last night, Mr. D'Amato told supporters in his concession speech: "He is our Senator and we want him to be as effective as he can for all the people of this great state. Now remember that, that is the key -- doing the business of the people."
Surveys of voters leaving their polling places show that Mr. D'Amato lost support almost across the board from 1992, but particularly among Jewish voters, despite his heavy campaigning in Jewish neighborhoods in the campaign's final weeks. It also appeared that Mr. Schumer did a better job of holding on to Democratic voters than Robert Abrams did in 1992, when a quarter of Democrats voted for Mr. D'Amato.
Mr. D'Amato, 61, lost in large part, political analysts said, because Mr. Schumer was the toughest candidate he had ever faced. Mr. Schumer, a nine-term Democrat from Brooklyn, did not match Mr. D'Amato in spending -- he had spent $14 million on the campaign by mid-October while Mr. D'Amato had spent $20 million -- but he was much better financed than Mr. Abrams was in 1992. He had also deftly positioned himself as a moderate who could appeal to independent voters and centrists from both parties and tirelessly countered each of Mr. D'Amato's attacks.
But clearly, part of Mr. D'Amato's problem was Mr. D'Amato. Years of investigations into his ethics and his numerous high-profile gaffes, like using a Yiddish vulgarism to describe Mr. Schumer and then denying it, had made him dangerously unpopular with a large segment of voters. Several political analysts also suggested that bringing together Holocaust survivors to criticize his rival's record on Jewish issues hurt the Senator considerably more than Mr. Schumer, who is Jewish.
Even Mr. D'Amato's advisers were so convinced about the negativeness of his image that they kept him from speaking in his own television commercials and relied heavily on more popular surrogates, like Gov. George E. Pataki, to carry his campaign message.
But the cartoonish image of Mr. D'Amato that voters saw during this campaign did not do complete justice to his personality and style. New York's junior senator is a man often defined by paradoxes. His bitterest rivals reviled his hardball campaign tactics, then carefully studied and mimicked them. Democrats called him sleazy, yet found that he was true to his word when they did business with him. He could be profane and loutish in public, but gentle, even tender, in private. He was brutally vindictive toward his enemies, but doggedly loyal to friends.
Though a fundamentally conservative politician who staunchly opposed abortion and gun control and consistently advocated tax cuts and harsh criminal penalties, Mr. D'Amato has always found ways to moderate his image. No ideologue, he was guided by a pragmatic philosophy born of the place that nurtured his politics, Nassau County.
The grandchild of Italian immigrants, Mr. D'Amato was born in Brooklyn but brought up in Island Park, in the heart of middle-class Long Island. After he helped put himself through Syracuse University and Law School by working as a janitor, no Manhattan law firm would hire him. He returned home, getting a job as a lawyer for Nassau County government. Those experiences forever shaped his political views.
From his early years in government on, he strove to articulate the fears of middle-class homeowners infuriated by property taxes and worried about losing economic ground and the anger of small business owners beleaguered by regulations. He echoed the resentments of working-class parents toward the "liberal elites" who seemed to control their schools, their newspapers, their banks and government offices.
Perhaps better than anyone in the Senate, Mr. D'Amato understood that to these voters, Congress was a distant and abstract place. So he constantly searched for people -- breast cancer patients denied insurance benefits, Holocaust survivors trying to reclaim stolen assets -- whose gut-wrenching cases he could champion.
Win or lose, he invoked their stories as evidence that he was a fighter for regular citizens.
A man whose first job came through the patronage system, he ran his Senate office like a Nassau County ward heeler, returning calls from almost any elected official, honoring the requests of big-city mayors and small-town supervisors alike when they asked for help -- and expecting their support in return.
"I hate him," said Frances Werner, the former chairwoman of the Queens Republican committee whom Mr. D'Amato helped to oust. "But when he says he'll do something, he comes through."
At times, Mr. D'Amato tried to break out from his image as "Senator Pothole," embracing larger issues, such as banking law or Israeli policy. But history may remember him best for his missteps, from croaking "Old MacDonald had some pork" during a 1994 Senate debate to using broken English to mock Lance Ito, the judge in O. J. Simpson's criminal trial, during a 1995 radio interview.
What also defined Mr. D'Amato for many voters was his brass-knuckles political style. When he ran for the Senate for the first time in 1980, he did not shy away from reminding voters that the four-term Republican incumbent, Senator Jacob K. Javits, was 76 years old and in failing health. In each election since then, he has lambasted his opponents as liberals, as well as "wimp" in the case of Mr. Abrams in 1992, and the Yiddish insult in the case of Mr. Schumer this year.
Democrats, and many Republicans, argued that many of the people he helped over 18 years were campaign contributors, particularly financial services companies regulated by the Senate Banking Committee -- of which he is the chairman. In 1991, the Senate Ethics Committee faulted him for allowing his brother, Armand, to use his Senate office and stationery to help a client.
But the Democrats also privately conceded that they admired the ways he fudged or fine-tuned his political positions to pick off Democratic voters while holding down his conservative base. He embraced some centrist positions, but on one issue, his opposition to abortion, he remained firm, though that was out of step with the thinking of most New Yorkers.
Fighting for breast cancer research money won over many women angry with his opposition to abortion. Pushing to reduce automated teller machine fees helped counter assertions that he was too friendly to big banks. Advocating civil rights for homosexuals balanced accusations that he was an extreme right-winger.
Perhaps the oddest paradox of his long career was that this year, as he sat atop one of the most potent political organizations in the country, Mr. D'Amato had to depend on high-profile surrogates, like Mr. Pataki, to woo back voters who had grown weary of him. In a testament to his success in delivering for New York City over the years, Mr. D'Amato even managed to bring Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and former Mayor Edward I. Koch -- despite their long history of bickering -- to campaign together for him.
On Monday, as he stumped with Mr. D'Amato in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, Mr. Koch was asked if this year's race was as close as in 1992, when Mr. D'Amato won by a single percentage point. "Closer," replied Mr. Koch, a look of worry crossing his face.
But Mr. D'Amato, pugnacious to the end, cut Mr. Koch off. "We're in better shape than we were in '92," he said, then turned away.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: THE NATION -- GOVERNORS;
George W. Bush Is Re-elected in Texas; His Brother Jeb Is Victorious in Florida

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas was re-elected yesterday, and his brother Jeb was elected governor of Florida, meaning that brothers will be serving simultaneously as governor for only the second time.
In the governor's race with the highest stakes, Lieut. Gov. Gray Davis, a Democrat, defeated State Attorney General Dan Lungren to win in California, the most-populous state. But Republicans will still be governor of the next eight most populous states. 
 In the South, Democrats reversed a decades-long trend toward Republican control of governorships, ousting Republican Governors in South Carolina and Alabama and retaining a hotly contested seat in Georgia.
Jeb Bush's victory in Florida over Lieut. Gov. Kenneth H. MacKay Jr. was a gain for Republicans in the region. Gov. Lawton Chiles, a Democrat, is retiring. In Texas, George W. Bush won easily over Gary Mauro, the state Land Commissioner, and this could pave the way for a run for the Presidency in 2000.
Altogether, 36 governorships were at stake, 24 now held by Republicans, 11 by Democrats and 1 by an independent, Angus King of Maine, who was handily re-elected. Nationwide, going into the election, 32 Governors were Republicans and 17 were Democrats. This is the largest spread Republicans have enjoyed in the state capitals since World War II.
This year's elections are especially important because the Governors elected last night will preside over the redistricting of state legislatures and Congressional seats that will occur after the 2000 Census.
In South Carolina, one of the most conservative and normally most Republican states in the country, Jim Hodges, a former state legislator, defeated the Republican Governor, David Beasley. In Alabama, Lieut. Gov. Don Siegelman beat Gov. Fob James. In both cases, gambling was an issue. Mr. Hodges favored the legalization of video poker in South Carolina, and Mr. Siegelman advocated a lottery in Alabama to raise money for education.
In Georgia, Roy Barnes, a state Representative, held the seat being vacated by the Democratic Governor, Zell Miller. Mr. Barnes defeated Guy W. Millner, a Republican businessman who was making his second straight run for the office.
Democrats also won a close race in Maryland, where Gov. Parris N. Glendening was re-elected.
Republican Governors were re-elected in New York, Connecticut, Arkansas, Arizona, Kansas, Michigan, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Dakota, Tennessee, Wisconsin and Wyoming.
Democrats were re-elected in New Hampshire and Vermont.
In the Midwest, seats changed hands in Iowa and Nebraska, where Governors are retiring. In Iowa, State Senator Tom Vilsack, a Democrat, was elected to replace the Republican Governor, Terry E. Branstad. In Nebraska, Mayor Mike Johanns of Lincoln, a Republican, was elected to replace Gov. Ben Nelson, a Democrat.
Republicans were elected in Ohio, Idaho and New Mexico. The new Governor of Ohio is Bob Taft, the son and grandson of Senators. In Idaho, Senator Dirk Kempthorne was elected Governor.
The race was tight in Minnesota, where the Democratic Attorney General, Hubert H. Humphrey 3d, the son of the former Vice President, was in a three-way contest with Mayor Norm Coleman of St. Paul, a Republican, and Jesse Ventura, a former professional wrestler, who ran as an independent. Another close race was in Massachusetts, where Acting Gov. Argeo Paul Cellucci, a Republican, was challenged by Attorney General Scott Harshbarger.
The only time that brothers have been governors at the same time, the National Governors' Association said, was from 1967 to 1971, when Nelson A. Rockefeller was Governor of New York and his brother Winthrop was Governor of Arkansas.
Four years ago, when George W. Bush was first elected, Jeb Bush lost to Governor Chiles. In Miami last night, to the wild cheering of hundreds of supporters in a hotel ballroom, former President George Bush and his wife, Barbara, both beaming with pride, came on stage to introduce their son.
"May I introduce to you the next governor of Florida, Jeb Bush," was all the former President said. His son thanked, in order, God, his family, his supporters and "the best parents in the world."
The Clinton years have been political disasters for Democrats in the state capitals.
When Mr. Clinton took office in January 1993, Democrats held the governorships of 30 states. Republicans held 18, and 2 Governors were independents. But in 1993, Democratic Governors were ousted in New Jersey and Virginia.
Eleven more governorships were taken over in the 1994 Republican sweep. And Republicans picked up three more in 1996, including the governorship of Arkansas, where Jim Guy Tucker, a Democrat, resigned after he was indicted and was replaced by a Republican.
As a consequence, going into this year's election, Republicans were governors of eight of the nine most populous states in the country, all but Florida.
The turnabout has been especially striking in the Rocky Mountains and the Great Plains. Fifteen years ago, only 2 states in this 14-state region, North and South Dakota, had Republican Governors. Now, 11 of the Governors in the region are Republicans.
Of the 36 governors' races on the ballot yesterday, 25 involved incumbents: 17 Republicans, 7 Democrats and Governor King of Maine. Of the 11 Governors who are retiring, mostly because their states have two-term limits, 6 are Republicans and 5 are Democrats.
On a national level, the main effect of yesterday's elections for governor may be felt in the states that are likely to gain and lose Congressional seats as a result of the 2000 Census. The gainers are expected to include California, Arizona, Georgia, Texas, Colorado and Florida. States that may lose seats include Connecticut, Illinois, Michigan, Ohio, Oklahoma and Wisconsin.
The issues in this year's races for governor were mostly similar to those in Congressional contests. Republicans advocated lower taxes and smaller government. Democrats stressed the need for better health and education programs.
But local issues also cropped up. In South Carolina, the candidates battled over whether to legalize gambling in the form of video poker. In Alabama, there was a fight over whether to create a state lottery to raise money for education.
In Hawaii, the main issue was a statewide recession, a result largely of the sagging economies in Japan and elsewhere in Asia. In Maryland, by contrast, the economy is strong, and the campaign debate turned to other matters, like the state's financing of two new football stadiums.
In Minnesota, the candidates for governor scrapped over the legal fees due lawyers who represented the state in the suit it settled with the major tobacco companies. Laws against hate crimes and concealed weapons have been big issues in the New Mexico race.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: THE NATION -- THE HOUSE;
Embattled Democrats Pull Through as Republicans Appear to Fall Short of Predictions

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Republicans in the House seemed to be falling short last night of the gains they had predicted, as one embattled Democrat after another won re-election in the face of the yearlong scandal over President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.
The first returns from battleground states in the South and the Midwest suggested that the House election would amount to a virtual endorsement of the status quo, a result that would leave Republicans with little mandate to push ahead with the impeachment of Mr. Clinton. 
 While Republicans were likely to retain control of the House, Democrats considered it a victory that they were able to stave off sharp losses and contain the Republican majority. Since World War II, the average loss for the President's party in midterm elections has been 27 House seats.
"If we break even or even pick up a seat, it would be a historic reversal of what usually happens," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader.
Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the chief Republican strategist who just two weeks ago held out the possibility that House Republicans could gain as many as 40 seats, told supporters in suburban Atlanta that his party would continue to control the House. "This will be the first time in 70 years that Republicans will have kept control of the House for a third time," he said.
By midevening, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, said cautiously, "It's too early to be disappointed," and added, "We knew all these races were going to be close."
Most House incumbents in both parties easily coasted to another term in a year marked by voter content with the economy and no overriding national issues.
With so few members of Congress facing strong challenges, control of the House came down to several dozen fiercely fought contests scattered across the country. By midevening, not one incumbent had lost.
More than any overriding national theme, local issues and personalities and campaign financing helped decide many races. Only a few House candidates raised the possibility of the President's impeachment or his relationship with Ms. Lewinsky as a driving issue, although Republicans in the last few days of the campaign ran television advertisements invoking the scandal in several conservative districts.
Most of the turnover in the House was expected in the 34 seats left open by retirements.
In Kentucky, the two parties swapped control of two House seats that became vacant when Representatives Jim Bunning, a Republican, and Scotty Baesler, a Democrat, faced each other in a race for the Senate seat being vacated by Wendell H. Ford, a Democrat who is retiring. Former State Representative Ernie Fletcher, a Republican, picked up Mr. Baesler's seat while Ken Lucas, a Democrat, proved conservative enough to win Mr. Bunning's district.
Representative Anne Northup, a freshman close to the House Republican leadership, won re-election. Her opponent, Chris Gorman, had been one of the handful of Democrats who ran advertisements seeking to wield the Republicans' handling of the impeachment inquiry against his opponent.
In Indiana, Representative Julia Carson, a Democratic freshman who had been considered endangered, defeated her Republican challenger, Gary Hofmeiser, despite a slow campaign start because of health problems.
In North Carolina, three Democratic Representatives that the Republicans had hoped to topple held on to their seats -- Melvin Watt, David E. Price and Bob Etheridge. But Robin Hayes, a Republican, defeated Mike Taylor, a Democrat, for the open seat of Representative W. G. (Bill) Hefner, a Democrat who is retiring.
Other Democrats that Republicans had considered vulnerable also prevailed, among them Representative Corrine Brown of Florida, John F. Tierney of Massachusetts, John Spratt of South Carolina, Maurice Hinchey of New York and Frank Pallone of New Jersey.
The results promise another two years of policy stalemate, with Republicans, who have a fragile 11-seat majority, lacking the seats to pursue a new conservative agenda.
The two parties opened the year expecting a relatively placid midterm election with voters soothed by the good economy.
Leery of shaking the mood of content, House Republicans ran largely on their past accomplishments. They put forward no new agenda like the Contract With America, which propelled them into the majority in 1994 on a far-reaching conservative domestic policy agenda.
The Democrats, by contrast, hoped to make inroads with an agenda of issues blocked by the Republicans, from anti-tobacco legislation to regulation of health maintenance organizations, money for school construction and overhaul of the campaign finance system. But they found that they were all but drowned out by Washington's preoccupation with Mr. Clinton's troubles.
Ever since the President told the nation in August, after months of denials, that he had had an "inappropriate relationship" with Ms. Lewinsky, Democrats feared that they would suffer a rout, with Clinton-haters inspired to vote and disillusioned Democrats staying home.
But the political mood seemed to shift again after the Republican-controlled House released reams of salacious testimony that the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr had gathered about Mr. Clinton's relationship with Ms. Lewinsky, and voted to open a formal impeachment inquiry into the President. Detecting signs of a backlash against the Republicans, many political analysts said they had overplayed their hand.
Later this month the House Judiciary Committee moves to center stage once again as it opens its formal impeachment inquiry into Mr. Clinton. But the standoff in last night's elections could revive talk of censure and leave Republicans searching for a quick way to bring the inquiry to an end.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- NORTHEAST;
MASSACHUSETTS

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
The close fight for governor, between Acting Gov. Argeo Paul Cellucci, a Republican, and Attorney General Scott Harshbarger, a Democrat, grew so contentious that commentators described their final debate as a "brawl."
Mr. Cellucci, a fiscal conservative who supports abortion rights, was seeking his first full term. He was Lieutenant Governor when he succeeded Gov. William Weld, who resigned last year. 
 Although Democrats hold a 3-to-1 edge in voter registration, a strong economy helped Mr. Cellucci against Mr. Harshbarger, who is known for a tough approach to the tobacco companies and opposition to casino gambling.
Mr. Cellucci ran on a record of tax cuts and budget surpluses. Mr. Harshbarger, calling education his top priority, had a less-than-united party behind him.
In the Sixth Congressional District, the Democratic incumbent, John F. Tierney, and Peter G. Torkildsen, a Republican, went head-to-head for the third time. Mr. Tierney wrested the seat from the moderate Republican in 1996, after narrowly losing two years earlier. Mr. Tierney held a comfortable lead in polls this time around.
Voters were also to decide whether to provide public financing of political campaigns. A late poll found strong support.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK STATE -- THE GOVERNOR;
Pataki Wins Election to a Second Term by a Hefty Margin

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
George Elmer Pataki swept to a second term as Governor of New York yesterday, defeating his weak and splintered opposition by one of the largest margins in history, a victory so resounding that it is certain to raise his national profile.
Mr. Pataki's triumph capped a remarkable transformation from a little-known State Senator waging an uphill fight for governor in 1994, to a Governor who has shifted the state markedly rightward on crime, welfare and taxes, and has made himself its most popular political figure. Four years ago, he narrowly defeated Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, with considerable help from Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. This year, it was the Senator who, in an ultimately unsuccessful bid for a fourth term, turned to Mr. Pataki for help, and the Governor spent more energy in the final weeks stumping for his onetime patron than for himself. 
 With 96 percent of the voting precincts reporting, Mr.Pataki, a Republican who was also the candidate of the Conservative Party, had 54 percent of the vote, to 33 percent for his Democratic challenger, Peter F. Vallone, the New York City Council Speaker, who was also nominated by the newly founded Working Families Party.
B. Thomas Golisano, the Independence Party candidate making his second run for the office, was a distant third, with 8 percent, and Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, the Liberal Party nominee, trailed with 2 percent.
The 24-year-old split in New York's State Legislature appeared to hold fast, with Republicans easily retaining control of the State Senate, and Democrats keeping a strong hold on the Assembly.
The polls indicated that the Liberal Party had survived the near-death experience of nominating Ms. McCaughey Ross, then watching her husband, the financier Wilbur L. Ross, withdraw much of her financial backing. She appeared to have topped the 50,000 votes a party needs in a gubernatorial election to maintain an automatic place on New York ballots for the next four years.
Despite Mr. Pataki's triumph, the Republican ticket's Election Night crowd was remarkably subdued, mindful of Mr. D'Amato's defeat. The Governor appeared at 9:50 P.M., less than an hour after the polls closed, to declare victory before a crowd of supporters at the New York Hilton Hotel on the Avenue of the Americas.
"We said we were going to change this state and put in place new policies that would free the spirit of the people of New York from an oppressive government," he said. "Well, it's four years later, and let me tell you something, this is a better state than it was four years ago. We have kept our word in making this a safer state, making this a healthier state, making this a state with more environmental opportunities for our children and the children of the next generation."
Mr. Vallone gave his concession speech at 9:30 P.M., just half an hour after the polls closed, before a surprisingly upbeat group of supporters at the New York Marriott East Side hotel.
"This is really not cause for sorrow or complaint," Mr. Vallone said, flanked by his family, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and former Mayor David N. Dinkins. "We knew from the start that this was going to be an uphill race. The odds were long. The campaign dollars were always a little short. But there was a need to be filled, an obligation to be met."
The campaign did not present much of a test for Mr. Pataki, who campaigned sparingly, ignored his opponents and refused to debate them. And in the end, he won a smaller percentage of the vote than did Mr. D'Amato's opponent, Representative Charles E. Schumer.
But the defeat of Mr. D'Amato leaves his former protege, the Governor, as the undisputed leader of the State Republican Party and clearly the most powerful figure in state politics.
In the last month, as polls showed him running away with this race, Mr. Pataki and his aides grew so elated that they began to talk openly about the prospect of his running for national office in 2000. Like the last Republican elected New York's Governor, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Mr. Pataki might be favored by moderate Republicans, but is widely considered a dark horse, especially with the larger body of conservative Republican voters.
In New York this year, as in much of the country, the election season lacked defining issues or ideological chasms. There was none of the economic unrest that animates some contests, and local fights were overshadowed by President Clinton's troubles, though they did not cut clearly one way or another with voters. In such an atmosphere, voters were content mostly to return incumbents to office, even if it meant ignoring party lines and splitting their tickets.
The Governor was headed for the third-largest winning margin in a gubernatorial race in state history, in both percentage terms and in raw votes, and the largest ever by a Republican. The biggest margins were set by Mr. Cuomo in 1986 and 1990; he won each time by 32 percent, and 1.4 million and 1.3 million votes, respectively.
The Governor came nowhere near outpolling Mr. Vallone in the city, as some of his advisers had hoped, but the breadth of his victory was still remarkable. Mr. Pataki led Mr. Vallone two to one in the downstate suburbs, and more than three to one upstate. And voter polls showed that one-fourth of the people who voted for Mr. Schumer also voted for Mr. Pataki.
The Governor carried 58 of the state's 62 counties -- all but Brooklyn, Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens.
Mr. Pataki has said little about what he would do in a second term, beyond continuing to cut taxes and toughen criminal penalties, but the magnitude of his victory could allow him to claim a mandate for whatever his second-term agenda may hold. If the economy slows, however, Mr. Pataki's plans could be overtaken by budget woes, precisely the opposite of the circumstances that he has enjoyed for the last four years, as the economic expansion and Wall Street boom allowed the Governor to do what he promised and more, simultaneously cutting taxes and raising spending.
Mr. Pataki's victory brings to statewide politics a new face, that of Mary O. Donohue, his running mate for lieutenant governor. Ms. Donohue, a former judge and prosecutor from the Albany area, takes on a purely ceremonial post, but would become governor if her boss were elected to national office.
And the election may mark the end of the political career of Ms. McCaughey Ross, the Republican-turned-Democrat whose brief, odd sojourn in politics had alienated her from both major parties.
In one of the race's many subplots, Mr. Golisano's showing was close to capturing for the four-year-old Independence Party the third position on the ballot for the next four years. Positions are assigned in order of gubernatorial vote, and Mr. Golisano was running close to the number of votes that Mr. Pataki garnered on the line of the Conservative Party, which has been listed third since the early 1970's.
Mr. Pataki took office in 1995 determined to cut not only taxes but also state spending on health care, education, mass transit and other areas, a quest that won him a legion of enemies and made him widely unpopular.
But in 1996, he began his political resurrection by forging an alliance of some of his harshest critics, including labor unions and environmentalists, in support of his $1.75 billion environmental bond act. The campaign for the measure was, as much as anything else, a campaign for Mr. Pataki, one that raised his popularity and softened his image.
Voters approved the environmental act.
By last year, Mr. Pataki was raising spending on popular programs, and he was widely seen as unassailable. The two men considered his strongest potential challengers, Mr. Schumer and State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, decided not to challenge him.
That left Mr. Vallone, virtually unknown outside New York City, as the leading candidate for the Democratic nomination. Not since 1966 had the Democrats nominated someone of so little stature for governor.
During the Democratic primary campaign, the mercurial Ms. McCaughey Ross drew much of the attention, and after she finished second to Mr. Vallone, she continued running for governor on the Liberal Party line.
Meanwhile, Mr. Golisano's ever-present advertisements drowned out Mr. Vallone's own meager media campaign. And he and Ms. McCaughey Ross both threatened to fragment whatever anti-Pataki vote there was.
But ultimately, those were little more than distractions from Mr. Vallone's deeper problems: the Governor was too popular, the voters were too complacent, Mr. Vallone was too uninspired a campaigner, and he had too little money to prevent a rout. In the most expensive gubernatorial race in New York State's history -- and one of the most costly in any state -- Mr. Pataki spent $20 million, Mr. Golisano may have matched that total, and Mr. Vallone spent just $6 million.
Mr. Vallone has faced speculation all year that his true aim in this race was to position himself to run for mayor of New York City in 2001, but yesterday, as he has all along, he declined to discuss that subject. "We'll talk about that in the next millennium," he said.

LENGTH: 1103 words

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: THE NATION -- THE SENATE;
Democrats Boxer and Schumer Cruise, Although Republicans Retain Control

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

 BODY:
Republicans retained solid control of the Senate tonight, but struggled to pick up gains that would help advance their legislative agenda or a possible impeachment trial of President Clinton next year.
Democrats and Republicans were fighting to a draw in races around the country, defying expectations that low voter turnout might doom Democratic prospects. 
 Lauch Faircloth of North Carolina, the Republican incumbent, fell to a multimillionaire trial lawyer, John Edwards, and in New York, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato conceded to his Democratic challenger, Representative Charles E. Schumer. On the West Coast, two Democratic incumbents, Barbara Boxer of California and Patty Murray of Washington, won comfortably after pulling away from strong challenges in the campaign's closing days.
But in Illinois, the Democratic incumbent, Carol Moseley-Braun, was trailing State Senator Peter Fitzgerald.
"This was a status quo election," Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said on CNN's "Larry King Live." "The old saying that all politics is local is really true in this election."
But Mr. Faircloth was near tears in a concession speech to supporters. "I feel like I've let you down because we should have won."
Democrats were jubilant as results streamed in from across the nation, even as they conceded the possibility that Republicans could pad their majority if cliffhanger races in the West and Midwest went to Republicans.
"We could still end up losing one or two seats," said Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, vice chairman of the Senate Democratic re-election committee, "but the practical result of the election, even if there are modest losses, is the effort to remove President Clinton, for all practical purposes, has ended."
The Democratic incumbents Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin and Harry Reid of Nevada were still fighting for their political lives. And the race in Kentucky between two Congressmen, Scotty Baesler, a Democrat, and Jim Bunning, a Republican, was still neck and neck. But one of the lions of the old Democratic South, Senator Ernest F. Hollings, held off a spirited challenge from Representative Bob Inglis.
Of the 34 Senate seats on the ballot, 18 were held by Democrats and 16 by Republicans. But Democrats had far more vulnerable Senators.
As expected, most incumbents, like Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, retained their seats, a sign of voter satisfaction with the hardy economy and a paucity of well-financed, competitive challengers.
Three Democrats and two Republicans are retiring. Typically, open seats are easier for an opposing party to take over.
Democrats and Republicans swapped two of those open seats. In Ohio, George V. Voinovich, the Republican Governor, handily turned back Mary Boyle, a former Cuyahoga County commissioner, to take the seat of the retiring Senator John Glenn.
In Indiana, Evan Bayh, the popular former Democratic Governor, easily outpaced Paul Helmke, the mayor of Fort Wayne, to replace Daniel R. Coats, a Republican.
Democrats retained the seat of Senator Dale Bumpers of Arkansas, who is retiring, as former Representative Blanche Lambert Lincoln defeated the Republican State Senator Fay Boozman. In the fourth open seat, Representative Michael D. Crapo of Idaho, a Republican, easily won election to succeed Senator Dirk Kempthorne, who stepped down to run for governor.
In a year where no overpowering national issue emerged, many Democratic candidates spoke about preserving Social Security and boosting education while many Republicans discussed tax cuts and shifting power from Washington to local governments.
In the waning days of the campaign, Republicans launched a $10 million television advertising campaign that aimed to energize their voter base by exploiting President Clinton's sex scandal.
Democrats gleefully seized on the advertisements as a desperate last-minute gamble that would backfire with voters, who in public opinion polls have voiced disapproval of the Republican-led impeachment inquiry into Mr. Clinton.
Republicans have controlled both the House and Senate since the landslide midterm elections of 1994. Republicans held sway in the Senate from 1980 to 1986, briefly interrupting what had been largely unbroken Democratic dominance of the upper chamber since the late 1930's.
The Republicans' 55 seats in the current Senate are the most the party has held since the 56 of 1930 and 1931.
On the basis of historical precedent alone, Senate Democrats were resigned this year to losing at least a few seats. Since World War II, the President's party has gained seats in a midterm election only three times.
Early in the campaign season, Republicans had held out hope of reaching 60 votes, the magic number they needed to cut off Democratic-led debates and force a vote on an issue. Senator Thomas A. Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, has repeatedly used filibusters to stifle Republican initiatives.
It would also bring the Republicans closer to the two-thirds majority, or 67 votes, needed to override a presidential veto or to approve a treaty. If the impeachment proceedings under way in the House reached the Senate, 67 votes would be needed to convict Mr. Clinton and remove him from office.
But achieving even 60 votes has proved elusive for both parties in the last two decades. Since 1975, only the Democrats have held more than 60 seats, and that was for just one session, in 1977.
By midsummer, Mr. Lott had publicly all but ruled out reaching 60 votes, scaling back projections to one to three seats. However, even modest gains like those would help Republicans break legislative logjams over issues that have lacked a solid conservative edge. For two years in a row, Republicans have fallen three votes short of overriding Mr. Clinton's veto of legislation that would have banned a controversial procedure that opponents call partial-birth abortion. Any Republican gains in the Senate would fuel momentum for conservatives to provide dependable anti-abortion votes.
In addition, Senate Republicans twice this year fell one vote short of cutting off a Democratic filibuster on a proposal to require the Government to push ahead with a national defense against long-range missiles as soon as technologically feasible. If armed with a wider majority next year, Republicans are certain to offer the measure again, even though the military's Joint Chiefs of Staff oppose it.
Tonight, though, even those modest gains, and what extra advantage they bring with them, appeared in doubt.

HEADLINE: From Boston to New York, Cities Are Changing

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Boston Leading a Renewal of Old Northern Cities" (front page, Nov. 3): Rather than serving as a national model, the conversion of Boston's once vital neighborhoods into polluted and gridlocked "urban entertainment zones" designed for the amusement of suburban interlopers and gawking tourists and their cars is a catastrophe in the making. 
 A more desirable model of urban development would include a sound industrial policy centered around Boston Harbor's commerce, biotech research and high-tech manufacturing; public-transit projects. and mixed-income housing construction.
Randomly dividing Boston into auto-centric megaplex attractions is an irreversible civic disaster. Worse yet, this misbegotten venture has been rammed down Boston citizens' throats without open debate -- a sad statement for a city that once served as the cradle of the American Revolution.
 
PETER CATALANO
Boston, Nov. 3, 1998

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: AROUND THE REGION -- CONNECTICUT;
Rowland Wins Overwhelming Re-election

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut, a Republican, rode an economic recovery and a listless opposition to a landslide re-election today, overwhelming United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly in every region of the state, including her own Congressional district.
The Governor, who has grown more moderate with each year in office, said he was "humbled by the outcome," then used his victory speech to reach across party lines. "We are fiscally conservative, but we are aggressively inclusive," he told supporters at a balloon-decked ballroom in his hometown of Waterbury. "This tent that we call the Republican Party is large enough to include anyone that wants to be in a partnership with moving this state ahead and bringing us into the next century." 
 With 90 percent of 811 precincts reporting, the vote was:
 
Rowland 538,743 (63%)
Kennelly 302,002 (35%)
Mr. Rowland said his landslide was a mandate to continue pursuing his agenda of lower taxes and less government. "The outcome of this election has nothing to do with anything Congresswoman Kennelly did wrong," he said. "The outcome of this election is a testament to what we've done right for the last four years. The best campaign ad is job performance."
After less than 10 percent of the vote had been counted, Mrs. Kennelly conceded the race. She drew cheers speaking to supporters at the Arch Street Tavern in her hometown of Hartford when she referred to the more moderate stands that Mr. Rowland took during the campaign, and urged him to remain the Governor he had been for the last year.
"Governor Rowland," she said, "you promised in your campaign that you would put education as a priority. You promised that open land was important to you. You promised all the things I've lived for. And I say to you, Governor: Keep those promises."
Today was the first time since 1944 that Connecticut re-elected a Republican Governor. The breadth of Mr. Rowland's victory was especially impressive because Connecticut had historically voted Democratic. Now, 40 percent of the state's registered voters are unaffiliated, 35 percent are Democrats and 25 percent are Republican.
With poll after poll showing Mr. Rowland swamping Mrs. Kennelly, the campaign had all but disappeared from public view in recent weeks, as Mr. Rowland tried to sit on his lead and Mrs. Kennelly sought to avoid questions about her lackluster campaign. As Mr. Rowland voted at a Hartford school today, clumps of supporters for the two candidates began chanting and elections officers struggled to separate them. "This is the most activity we've had in a year," he quipped.
Mr. Rowland, who at 41 is the nation's youngest governor, is a schmoozer who thrives under the television lights. Mrs. Kennelly, 62, did not seem comfortable with the demands of a modern campaign, and admitted frankly that she preferred the comfort of Capitol Hill, where she has represented the First District for eight terms.
As she conceded, Mrs. Kennelly alternately smiled and looked grave as she thanked her family and listed the issues that she said caused her to embark on such an uphill journey, including the protection of children, patients and the environment.
"I considered it a privilege for being allowed to be the standard bearer of the Democratic party," she said. "A real privilege. And I tried to do the best job possible, and I tried to speak for the families of Connecticut.
"I brought those issues into the light, where they belong."
Democrats once had great hope for Mrs. Kennelly, who is a daughter of John M. Bailey, a former Democratic National Committee chairman, and is the widow of James J. Kennelly, a former Speaker of the State House of Representatives. So much suspense had built up about her potential run that in September 1997, she made her announcement at the Old State House by tearing aside the shroud on a royal-blue sign that said simply, "Yes!"
Signs of trouble appeared quickly, though, as even Democratic audiences found Mrs. Kennelly to be an uninspiring and confusing speaker. A small but powerful group of Democratic leaders had convinced her to run, then did little to help her as her campaign faltered.
Mr. Rowland, whose own polls had shown him to be vulnerable on education and other issues just a year ago, used this winter's session of the State Legislature to methodically saw planks off Mrs. Kennelly's platform. He began advertising on television in January, building a rosy reputation, while Mrs. Kennelly stayed off the campaign trail, saying she was raising money. The icing on Mr. Rowland's cake was an income-tax rebate that began arriving in mailboxes in July, helping to salve voter anger at his failure to win repeal of the state income tax, which was the signature promise of his 1994 campaign.
This year's campaign was notable for the dearth of promises or attacks. Mr. Rowland talked up the recovering economy, which he called "the Connecticut comeback," and said he would continue to push for tax cuts, but offered few specifics.
About the only drama left as Election Day approached was how much of Mr. Rowland's luster would rub off on other Republicans. Two statewide Democratic incumbents won re-election -- Attorney General Richard Blumenthal over his Republican challenger, Santa Mendoza; and Comptroller Nancy Wyman, over Christopher Scalzo. Treasurer Paul Silvester, a Republican, was in a tight race with Denise Nappier. Susan Bysiecwicz, a Democrat, won election as Secretary of State over Ben F. Andrews Jr., a Republican.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: AROUND THE REGION -- THE CONGRESS;
Incumbents Prevail in 12 of 13 Districts Amid Very Low Voter Turnout

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Democrats regained a one-seat majority in New Jersey's Congressional delegation today, as Rush Holt capitalized on Republican Representative Mike Pappas's vocal support of Independent Counsel Kenneth Starr to win a narrow victory in the 12th District.
Mr. Holt, a physicist from Pennigton, hammered away at Mr. Pappas for his outspoken criticism of President Clinton in the wake of the Monica Lewinsky scandal. After public opinion polls showed that Mr. Clinton's support remained strong in New Jersey despite the Independent Counsel's investigation, Mr. Holt's campaign aired an assortment of radio and television ads featuring Mr. Pappas singing Mr. Starr's praises on the floor of the Congress, to the tune of "Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star." 
 The contest was so close that the Associated Press projected Mr. Pappas the winner at 10:10 P.M., when the election returns gave him a 16,000 vote lead with 88 percent of all precincts reporting. But that projection was withdrawn 40 minutes later, after the Mercer County Clerk's office acknowledged that it had mistakenly transposed as many as 9,000 of Mr. Holt's votes to Mr. Pappas's vote totals. Mr. Holt made his acceptance speech at 10:52 P.M. and could notresist making a quip about the ballot-counting mix-up.
"This election is about issues that hit close to home: education, addition," he said with a laugh.
It was the only New Jersey seat to change hands yesterday, leaving Democrats with a 7 to 6 seat advantage. Political analysts said a stable economy and a disinterested electorate helped incumbents in most districts.
Although many political analysts had anticipated that voter turnout would be depressed by President Clinton's sex scandal, and that a disproportionate number of Democrats might not vote, Democrats in New Jersey still recaptured all six of their seats. The state's only member of the House Judiciary Committee, Steven R. Rothman, a Democrat, won re-election, despite being a target of the Republican National Committee.
Mr. Rothman, a freshman, has never publicly stated whether he will vote to impeach Mr. Clinton. But his Republican challenger, Steven Lonegan, called for Mr. Clinton's resignation early in the campaign and pressed Mr. Rothman to do the same.
During the last month of the contest, House Speaker Newt Gingrich visited the district to raise money and promote Mr. Lonegan's platform of tax reform, fiscal restraint and conservative social values.
Frank Pallone, a Democrat, also won a close re-election race in the Sixth District, after late campaign visits from Hillary Rodham Clinton helped him edge out two well-financed challengers.
Walter Fields, a Democratic strategist, said the slim majority would give New Jersey Democrats a psychological boost.
"This shows that the Democratic party is alive and well in New Jersey, contrary to what some people have said," Mr. Fields said.
 
Twelfth District
A Clinton Critic Loses His Seat
Mr. Holt, 49, will become the first Democrat to win a Congressional seat in the 12th District.
Mr. Pappas, a partner in a family-owned insurance firm, stressed his political experience and focused on issues such as Social Security, tax reform and preserving New Jersey's open space from suburban sprawl. He said the race would not even have been close if Mr. Holt had not received money from the national Democratic Committee.
With 99 percent of the precincts reporting at midnight, the vote was:
 
Holt 89,630 (46%)
Pappas 102,315 (52%)
In proclaiming victory, Mr. Holt said he would now move to focus on core issues which would improve the everyday lives of New Jersey residents.
 
Sixth District
Race Gauges Effects Of 'Soft Money'
The Sixth District race was noteworthy because of the personal enmity among its candidates. But on a national level, many analysts monitored the race to gauge the influence of so-called issue-advocacy campaign money.
With 100 percent of the vote in at midnight, the vote was:
 
Pallone 77,722 (57%)
Ferguson 55,011 (40%)
Frank Pallone Jr., a five-term Democratic incumbent, was first confronted by a local nemesis, Carl J. Mayer, of Princeton, the Green Party's candidate, who lost the Democratic primary in the 12th District. Mr. Mayer was reported to have been so angered by Mr. Pallone's lack of support that he decided to challenge Mr. Pallone in the Sixth District general election, even though Mr. Mayer lives outside its boundaries.
Mr. Mayer survived a court challenge to his candidacy in the Sixth District, which includes parts of Monmouth and Middlesex Counties, and was expected to draw votes from Mr. Pallone.
In the waning days of the campaign, Mr. Pallone was also hard pressed to fend off Michael Ferguson, a Republican, whose campaign received a boost from several pro-business groups that ran ads critical of Mr. Pallone's voting record on Social Security.
Mr. Pallone said the ads distorted his record, and charged that the group financing the ads, Americans for Job Security, was actually a front for insurance companies seeking to derail his plans for reform of health maintenance organizations.
Mr. Pallone said he was shocked by the amount that insurance companies spent to defeat him, estimating it between $3 million and $4 million, and said he viewed their expensive opposition as a measure of the importance of insurance reform.
"More than anything else, I consider this a mandate for H.M.O. reform," Mr. Pallone said yesterday in his victory speech. "I hope they spend 8 or 10 million next time around."

LENGTH: 2000 words

HEADLINE: The O.E.D. Adds the Web to Its Lexicon

BYLINE: By MARGALIT FOX 

 BODY:
FILED carefully away in the offices of the Oxford English Dictionary are millions of handwritten index cards, many dating back to James Murray, the master lexicographer who presided over the dictionary's first edition at the turn of the century. For decades these cards, which document the appearance in English literature of words from abacination to zumbador, were the raw material from which the dictionary was made.
The cards, six million or seven million at last count, are still used in the continuing work of revising and updating the dictionary. But they now compete for office space with a dozen Sun Microsystems servers, 80 Sun workstations and a battery of PC's running Windows NT. The dictionary's lexicographers, in turn, are assisted by a team of systems engineers. 
 In the last few years, the O.E.D., the esteemed lexicon that conjures up images of paper, ink and a heady dust, has gradually entered the silicon age.
"We're still straddling the electronic world and the paper world," said Royalynn O'Connor, the on-line product director for Oxford University Press, which publishes the O.E.D.
First there was a CD-ROM, which was released in 1992 and contained the entire second edition of the dictionary. Then came a home page on the Web (www.oed.com), featuring history, newsletters and a Word of the Day. Now the O.E.D. is undertaking its most ambitious electronic project to date: next year, the entire dictionary is scheduled to be placed on the Internet as a searchable database. And with the recent publication of the best-selling book "The Professor and the Madman," by Simon Winchester, about a highly regarded contributor to the O.E.D. who also happened to be a deranged murderer, public interest in the dictionary is keen, Ms. O'Connor said.
But before the O.E.D. can be put on line, it must overcome a host of technical challenges, some common to all electronic dictionaries, others resulting from the singular and unwieldy nature of the O.E.D. itself.
In short, the dictionary's editors and technicians must take a 20-volume, 22,000-page reference work containing some three-quarters of a million entries and turn it into an electronic database that can be searched rapidly by machine and be read comfortably on a 15-inch computer monitor.
The dictionary's staff is currently field-testing a prototype of its on-line edition with invited groups of scholars, researchers and librarians around the United States. In January, Ms. O'Connor said, an outside contractor will be hired, after bids are submitted, to create the on-line edition and its search engine according to Oxford's minutely detailed specifications.
"Most publishers let their vendors design," said Ms. O'Connor, whose office is in New York. "We're designing it first because it's so critical and so complex."
The idea of on-line publication grew out of a major revision to the dictionary that has been under way since the early 1990's. The O.E.D.'s first edition, shepherded by James Murray, was published in 10 volumes between 1884 and 1928. In the years that followed, various supplements were issued. In 1989, Oxford published the second edition, which comprised the first edition, the supplements and about 5,000 new words, in 20 volumes.
Now, besides adding contemporary words (Ruthian, hyperlink), editors are revising the entire content of Mr. Murray's dictionary for the first time, updating Edwardian-era definitions, adding new bibliographic citations and correcting etymologies, based on advances in linguistic research. Work on the revised edition, which is expected to run to at least 30 volumes, is scheduled to last until 2010.
The incentive to go on line was twofold, Ms. O'Connor said. "One is, we are making discoveries about the English language that it would be very unfair to ask people to wait until 2010 to read."
The other motivation was economic. Throughout its history, the dictionary has never been profitable; the current revision alone is budgeted at $55 million. "There's some sense of, 'Can we get a return before 2010?' " Ms. O'Connor said. "We have to pay the lexicographers."
The on-line edition, which is scheduled to be available to the public by the end of 1999, will be accessible for a fee through the O.E.D.'s home page. It will consist at first of the dictionary's second edition, plus some revised entries and new words. As the revisions to the dictionary progress, new entries will be added quarterly, complementing but not replacing the earlier ones.
"This is one of the things we get loud and clear from our market research," Ms. O'Connor said. "Say a new entry comes up for 'restaurant.' People still want to see what the old entry was."
For every electronic dictionary, there are two paramount considerations: it should be easy to search and easy to read. Open the O.E.D. to any page. Each entry contains certain standard elements: the word itself, its variant spellings and etymology and -- the dictionary's defining characteristic -- citations of the word as it has been used in English literature through the centuries. In the on-line O.E.D., users must be able to search for each of these elements independently. Someone researching words with Basque in their pedigree, for example, should be able to summon up on line a list that includes anchovy, jingo and jai alai.
The text of the O.E.D. has actually existed in electronic form since the late 1980's, when it was put into Oxford's computers, a task that took 120 typists a year and a half. (The profusion of special characters in the dictionary made it impossible to scan using optical-character recognition.) The text was then tagged using SGML, a markup language designed to encode and organize large documents.
Some institutions, including academic libraries and the Bloomberg News Service, purchased copies of the SGML text on magnetic tape, added their own search engines and offered the result to users as a computerized O.E.D. "In the past few years, universities have been in essence publishing the O.E.D. on line," Ms. O'Connor said. "The problem with it is the cross-references don't work. There isn't the kind of consistency Oxford University Press would want."
To make their dictionary fully searchable, the O.E.D.'s editors must standardize a tangle of inconsistencies left over from Mr. Murray's day. Suppose you want to search for words quoted from "Treasure Island." The dictionary currently renders the book's title as Treasure Island, Treasure Isl., Treasure Is., Treas. Isl. and Treasure I. Until those entries are standardized, a search engine cannot easily retrieve them all together.
"We have a fairly large process of normalizing this bibliographical data," said John Simpson, the chief editor of the O.E.D., in a telephone interview from Oxford, England. "In the old days, it didn't really matter if you gave a different short title for a text in Volume 1 as you gave in Volume 11 because the reader knew what it meant. But now there's a requirement that people can search for what they want and get the appropriate matches."
Another challenge is representing the welter of special characters that appear in the dictionary text. There are more than 600 in all, including letters of the Greek alphabet, diacritical marks, mathematical symbols and the signs of the zodiac. (The CD-ROM came with special fonts that the user had to install, something the O.E.D. editors want to avoid for the Internet edition.)
Not only do these characters have to be legible and printable, they must be searchable as well. "Making sure you have a display that is configured so that it can be handled by that many computers operated by that many people in a consistent way is a huge task," said Kara Noble, director of electronic product development for Merriam-Webster, whose Collegiate Dictionary, 10th edition, is published on the Web (www.m-w.com/dictionary.htm). "It's easy for a schwa to look correct on my computer here in the office and totally different on your computer where you're sitting."
On the printed page, an O.E.D. entry is a crowded affair. But what readers can tolerate in a book will not always work on a computer monitor. As a result, the overall design of the O.E.D.'s screen display is crucial. "It's important that on first glance it has to look elegant, which isn't necessarily that first thing you think about with a dictionary," Mr. Simpson said. "The O.E.D. has a reputation for being elegant. It mustn't put the reader off by having so much information compacted together that it's difficult to read."
To unclutter the screen and reduce the need for scrolling, Oxford is experimenting with allowing features to be switched on and off within each entry. In an early version of the prototype, for example, small buttons labeled S and D represent a word's spelling and derivation, respectively. Call up the entry for the word merchant and click on the S, and up comes a list of variant spellings recorded over the centuries, including marchaund, marchande, mayrchand, maircheant, mairchantt and marchawn. The list can be hidden with another click. Clicking on D reveals the word's derivation, or etymology.
To streamline the display even more, the O.E.D. is shunning the electronic bells and whistles common to many Internet sites, like video streaming, audio clips and even illustrations. "There won't be a multimedia aspect to this," Ms. O'Connor said. "Because the entries are so complex, we're really aiming for something very simple."
As the specifications for the on-line edition are being finalized, the huge task of revising the century-old printed dictionary continues. As in Mr. Murray's time, the O.E.D. maintains a stable of outside "readers" in England and the United States who scour libraries -- and these days, literature databases as well -- for bibliographic citations. In many cases, their labor has uncovered far earlier citations for words than were previously known. (Mr. Simpson was delighted to report that "market-basket," first cited in 1807 in the O.E.D.'s second edition, has been antedated to 1585.)
Today, the readers send in their findings by modem, using what Mr. Simpson calls "the electronic equivalent of index cards" -- specially prepared database shells installed on their laptop computers. As in the past, lay people are also encouraged to contribute. And while some of these lay lexicographers still send in quotations the old-fashioned way, using pen and paper or even mailing in pasted-up pages torn from books (not recommended), many more, Ms. O'Connor said, now transmit their findings via E-mail or the guest book section of the O.E.D. Web site. The site maintains a list of words for which editors need additional citations (glatt kosher before 1973, grandkid before 1948).
There is still no decision on how much it will cost to use the O.E.D. on line and what kind of access first-time browsers will get, Ms. O'Connor said. "Is it free one weekend?" she wondered aloud. "Is it free on Sunday? Can you use it for two weeks? Can you look up 30 words? We have to decide, and that's one of the fun things about the Web -- you can do all of those things. It's a fun way to give away information without giving away the whole store."
As the O.E.D. lumbers genteelly into the new millennium, it is heartening to note that however vital its computers have become, they can never fully replace the work of its pencil-wielding, flesh-and-blood staff. "An awful lot of it will remain having to be done by the individual editors," Mr. Simpson said. "The actual defining, for example. You can't ask a computer to define for us."
And the O.E.D.'s file cards, too, seem assured of a place in the 21st-century life of the dictionary. "It's actually quite efficient to use the index cards," Mr. Simpson said.
As he spoke, he riffled through a small batch on his desk containing words beginning with the letter M. "You can put them into little piles," he said. "I wouldn't want to denigrate them."

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- WEST;
ARIZONA

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
Gov. Jane Dee Hull, the Republican incumbent, cruised to her first full term, despite the faction of state Republicans who felt that she was not conservative enough. Ms. Hull, a former junior high school teacher, state legislator and secretary of state, became Governor in September 1997, when Gov. Fife Symington was convicted of financial fraud. Her Democratic opponent, Paul Johnson, the former Mayor of Phoenix, sparked little interest in his tax-cut plans.
In the Senate race, John McCain, the Republican incumbent known for his efforts on campaign finance reform, his leadership on tobacco legislation and his potential as a Presidential candidate, crushed his Democratic opponent, Ed Ranger, a political novice. Mr. Ranger, a lawyer who graduated from law schools both in the United States and Mexico and in 1994 set up a law firm in Mexico to counsel American companies doing business there, had an uphill fight to build a political base in Arizona, which he returned to only recently. 
 Arizona voters approved a plan to give substantial public money to political candidates who voluntarily limit their spending and raise certain small contributions.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- NORTHEAST;
CONNECTICUT

 BODY:
Proving his enduring popularity among Connecticut voters, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat, won a fourth term by a landslide.
During the campaign, Republicans hoped that the incumbent, a close friend of President Clinton, would be hurt by the Monica Lewinsky sex scandal. But Mr. Dodd strongly criticized Mr. Clinton over his relationship with Ms. Lewinsky, and the Republicans' strategy lost steam. 
 It was the Republican candidate, Gary A. Franks, whose effort was crippled by scandal. Mr. Franks was dogged by questions over delinquent loans and was unable to raise money.
Gov. John G. Rowland, a 41-year-old Republican, swept back into office on a wave of voter enthusiasm over the state's robust economy. His challenger, Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, 62, a nine-term congresswoman, could not match Mr. Rowland's buoyant campaign style.
But Mr. Rowland's popularity was not strong enough to help carry Republican candidates to office in two key Congressional races. A Democrat, John B. Larson, a former state senator, beat a Republican candidate, Kevin O'Connor. And a Republican challenger, Mark D. Nielsen, was unable to unseat Representative John H. Maloney, a Democrat.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- SOUTH;
TENNESSEE

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
As expected, Don Sundquist, the Republican incumbent, easily won another term as governor, a job he came to in 1994 after 12 years in the House, where he served on the Ways and Means Committee. Governor Sundquist was so heavily favored that it was hard to find a challenger, and even when John Jay Hooker, who had the Democratic nomination in 1966 and 1970, stepped up for a third shot, it was never an all-out campaign.
Mr. Hooker, a Nashville lawyer, was an unusual candidate who stayed clear of Vice President Al Gore's Tennessee appearances because of a decadelong feud with Mr. Gore. 
 Although Mr. Hooker, whose Minnie Pearl fried-chicken franchise failed in the 1970's, tried to focus the race on campaign finance, he remained better known for suing state agencies and announcing that he wanted to hold his fund-raiser in the governor's mansion.
Gov. Sundquist emphasized his record on welfare reform and improved programs for children.
His easy re-election was mirrored in the races for Congress, where Incumbents prevailed in all nine districts. None of the races were close, and two were uncontested.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- MIDWEST;
ILLINOIS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

 BODY:
Carol Moseley-Braun, the nation's first black female Senator, was defeated by Peter Fitzgerald, a wealthy conservative Republican who attacked her for "six years of scandal and controversy."
Hillary Rodham Clinton frequently visited Illinois in an effort to help Ms. Moseley-Braun, but the Democratic Senator could not overcome criticism of her 1996 visit with the Nigerian dictator Sani Abacha. 
 Mr. Fitzgerald bombarded voters with television commercials criticizing the trip to Nigeria and highlighting allegations that Ms. Moseley-Braun and a former campaign manager had spent $281,000 in 1992 campaign money on vacations, cars and jewelry. Mr. Fitzgerald, a state senator, spent large amounts of his own money on the campaign.
Those who voted for Mr. Fitzgerald often mentioned ethical standards as the issue that mattered most to them; Ms. Moseley-Braun's supporters often cited Social Security as the issue most important to them.
Republicans held onto the governor's office. Voters chose George H. Ryan, the Secretary of State, over Representative Glenn Poshard, a Democrat from downstate Illinois, to replace Gov. Jim Edgar, a Republican who is retiring after eight years in office.
In the hottest House race, Representative Lane Evans, a Democrat, held onto his seat in the Rock Island-Moline area. With strong support from labor and environmental groups, he defeated the Republican candidate, Mark Baker, a former television newsman who also ran against Mr. Evans in 1996.
Democrats retained Mr. Poshard's seat in the 19th District, as David Phelps defeated Brent Winters, the Republican candidate.

RHODE ISLAND

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
Governor Lincoln C. Almond, the Republican incumbent, beat Myrth York, the challenger, in a civil, almost boring, rematch that lacked any galvanizing issue.
In the 1994 election, when the big issue was gambling -- Mr. Almond was adamantly opposed, Ms. York less so -- he won 47 percent of the vote and she got 44 percent. The rest went to the Cool Moose Party candidate, Robert Healey Jr., who was back for the rematch. 
This time, the race was not quite as tight between Governor Almond and Ms. York. Governor Almond, who lacks natural political ease, ran on his success in bolstering what had been a weak state economy, and portrayed Ms. York, a former state senator, as too liberal. Ms. York argued that the economy could, and should, be much better.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- WEST;
HAWAII

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

 BODY:
Backed by a strong union showing, the incumbent Democrat, Ben Cayetano, narrowly defeated his Republican challenger, Linda Lingle, the Mayor of Maui. Ms. Lingle was trying to become Hawaii's first elected Republican governor since it became a state 39 years ago. A struggling economy that was being dragged down by the crisis in Asia nearly allowed her to succeed.
Both Neil Abercrombie and Patsy Mink, the state's Democratic House members, won re-election, as did its Democratic Senator, Daniel K. Inouye. 
 By 2 to 1, voters also approved an initiative allowing the state legislature to ban same-sex marriages. The effort was spurred by a 1993 State Supreme Court ruling that could have opened the way for marriages of people of the same sex to be recognized.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- WEST;
CALIFORNIA

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN JR. 

 BODY:
Democrats swept powerfully through the nation's most populous state, seizing the governorship and other statewide offices, retaining a Senate seat and gaining a major advantage when California's huge House delegation, making up about an eighth of the House of Representatives, goes through redistricting after the 2000 census.
It has been 16 years since California had a Democratic governor. The last one was Edmund G. Brown Jr. The next will be Mr. Brown's former chief of staff in Sacramento, Lieut. Gov. Gray Davis. 
 Mr. Davis overcame a reputation for dullness with a sure-footed campaign that highlighted his political moderation. He defeated the staunchly conservative Republican candidate, Attorney General Dan Lungren.
Meanwhile, the incumbent Democratic Senator, Barbara Boxer, managed to defeat the Republican State Treasurer, Matt Fong.
The pair of victories is of monumental importance to the Democrats as they prepare for the Presidential election two years from now. President Clinton, Hillary Rodham Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and other Administration officials had campaigned hard in the state.
Proposition 5, an initiative that would allow expansion of Indian gambling operations, was approved by voters but might face a court challenge. Proposition 9, which would have undone provisions involving the deregulation of electricity, was defeated. Both ballot measures sparked enormous advertising campaigns; more than $70 million was spent on the gambling initiative alone.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- WEST;
WASHINGTON

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
Patty Murray, a Democrat who made a nationwide name for herself in 1992 campaigning as the "mom in tennis shoes," won a second term in a tough race against Representative Linda Smith, a Republican who had backing from the Christian right.
In the third woman-versus-woman Senate race in history, Ms. Smith was known for down-to-earth sound bites, like when she spoke of "fighting against leches in the workplace who hit on young women," a reference to President Clinton. 
 Ms. Smith paid a price for her longstanding support for campaign finance reform: the Republican organization gave her little money, and she was noticeably outspent early in the campaign.
Washington voters approved Initiative 200, an anti-affirmative action measure, modeled on California's, that will ban racial or gender preferences in government hiring, contracting or college admissions.
As in other states, Washington voters rejected a proposed ban on a type of late-term abortion. And, one year after vetoing a broader plan some thought might leave the door open to legalizing other drugs, voters approved a ballot initiative allowing the medical use of marijuana.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- NORTHEAST;
WEST VIRGINIA

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

 BODY:
West Virginia confirmed its status as a loyal Democratic state, re-electing three Democratic incumbents who faced either token or no Republican opposition. Representative Alan Mollohan and Nick Joe Rahall easily beat Libertarian candidates.
Representative Robert Wise, an eight-term incumbent, drew a Republican challenger. But the candidate, Sally Anne Kay, did not raise any money, broadcast any commercials or show up for scheduled debates with Mr. Wise. Still she garnered 21 percent of the vote, to Mr. Wise's 73 percent. Joe Whelan, the Libertarian, had 14 percent.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- MIDWEST;
OHIO

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
The Taft name is gold in Ohio, where Secretary of State Bob Taft, the Republican candidate for governor, defeated former Attorney General Lee Fisher. Eight years ago, Mr. Taft, the great-grandson of President William Howard Taft, ceded the Republican nomination for governor to George Voinovich, then Mayor of Cleveland. But this year, with Governor Voinovich barred by law from re-election and pursuing the Senate seat vacated by John Glenn, Mr. Taft had a clear shot at the governorship.
Mr. Fisher, a Cleveland lawyer and great-grandson of a sheet-metal worker who emigrated from Russia, campaigned as a people's candidate who planned to slash property taxes. 
 In the Senate, Governor Voinovich won a seat from the Democrats, sweeping to victory against Mary Boyle, a former majority whip in the State House of Representatives. School financing was a big issue in Ohio, where voters last spring overwhelmingly rejected a Voinovich-backed proposal to raise the state sales tax for education. Ms. Boyle charged that Governor Voinovich had let the schools decline.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- SOUTH;
TEXAS

BYLINE: By GINGER THOMPSON 

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush, a Republican who campaigned hard among Hispanic voters, was re-elected by a landslide, the first Texas governor to win consecutive terms in 25 years.
Images of the Governor -- speaking in Spanish about good schools and safe neighborhoods -- filled Texas airwaves. Polls showed that the strategy paid off big, with Mr. Bush winning more than 40 percent of the Hispanic vote. That kind of showing will likely elevate Mr. Bush's standing among potential Republican candidates for President. The Hispanic population, which will soon be the largest minority group in America, is an important target for both parties in 2000. 
 Mr. Bush's opponent, Garry Mauro, the state's Land Commissioner and executive director of the Texas Democratic Party, had challenged Mr. Bush to "let us know if he's going to be a full-time Governor."
Republicans were counting on Governor Bush's popularity to sweep several other Texas candidates into office. Rudy Izzard, a dentist and former San Angelo Mayor, ran a strong but unsuccessful Republican campaign against Representative Charles Stenholm. The 10-term Democratic incumbent was re-elected to his seat.
Mr. Stenholm's campaign, which raised twice as much money as his challenger's, emphasized the Congressman's conservative views and his political independence. But in an increasingly Republican district, he struggled until Election Day to stay in office.
Representative Martin Frost, another 10-term Democratic incumbent, also fought off a challenge. Mr. Frost, the chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, spent as much time fighting for his own seat as he did fighting for Democrats across the country.
His Republican opponent, Shawn Terry, 31, a management consultant, accused the Congressman of distorting his record to appear conservative. Mr. Frost attacked his challenger as too young and inexperienced.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- WEST;
NEVADA

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
It took most of the night, but Senator Harry Reid, a Democrat, emerged as the victor in a close fight against Representative John Ensign. When the count was complete, Mr. Reid's victory margin was fewer than 500 votes.
The Senator, who won a third term, outpolled his Republican challenger in Las Vegas. Mr. Ensign did better in rural localities and in the Reno area. 
 Mr. Ensign was no stranger to close races. He had been about to concede his race for the House four years ago when late returns pushed him ahead of the incumbent by about 1,500 votes.
In the governor's race, Kenny Guinn, a former state school superintendent and president of the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, defeated Jan Laverty Jones, the Mayor of Las Vegas.
Mr. Guinn had received early financial backing from the state's gambling industry. But after he became locked in a surprisingly tough primary battle, the casino industry also contributed to Ms. Jones's campaign.

After an eight-year absence, Republicans captured the governor's mansion as Mike Johanns, the two-term Mayor of Lincoln, easily beat Bill Hoppner, a former aide to Senator Bob Kerrey.
