HEADLINE: Glenn E. Nielson, 95, Builder Of Oil and Asphalt Business

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Glenn E. Nielson, who built a petroleum and asphalt empire from a single leased oilfield and a closed oil refinery it served in Cody, Wyo., died on Oct. 19 at his home in Cody, according to Margaret Ruth Bullock, his daughter. He was 95.
Mr. Nielson found partners to help him buy what was then called the Park Refinery Company in 1938, a year after its owner had asked him to try to find a buyer. He then cajoled friends and local financiers into giving him enough cash to run the operation. By 1952, he had transformed it into the Husky Oil Company, a publicly traded company with production in Canada and seven states and refineries churning out gasoline and asphalt. 
 Mr. Nielson went on to gain the nickname Mr. Asphalt for his tireless efforts to expand use of the paving material in the United States and Canada and a leading spokesman for regional oil companies in the industry's trade organizations.
In 1966, he gained broader recognition as chairman of the Business-Industry Political Action Committee, a business lobbying group set up in 1963 to counter the influence of the Committee on Political Education, then the political action arm of organized labor.
Husky had become Canada's largest producer of heavy oil from the huge crude deposits in Saskatchewan and Alberta by 1977, when it became the target of a bitter takeover battle pitting the Occidental Petroleum Company against Petro-Canada, which was owned by the Canadian Government.
A third company, the Alberta Gas Trunk Line Company, finally gained control in 1979 when Mr. Nielson sold his family's 20 percent stake for more than $100 million. Mr. Nielson then retired to concentrate on ranching and a range of philanthropic and Mormon activities that maintained his place as one of Wyoming's most prominent citizens.
Mr. Nielson was born on May 26, 1903, in Aetna, Alberta, the son of James and Margaret Nielson, and grew up in Cardston, a Mormon farming center in Alberta 15 miles north of the Montana border. Mr. Nielson graduated from Raymond Agricultural College in Alberta in 1921 and then worked on his father's ranch before going on Mormon missions in England and California from 1924 to 1927.
He borrowed heavily to become a wheat farmer and rancher in 1929 but returned to school when prices plunged, working as a janitor while completing a bachelor's degree in agriculture and economics at the University of Alberta. After moving to Montana in 1935, he worked as a ranch hand, truck driver, power-line rigger and oil salesman before investing in the oil business.
Mr. Nielson married Olive Wood in Cardston in 1928. In addition to Mrs. Bullock, of Cody, he is survived by his wife; two other daughters, Joanne Livingston of Atherton, Calif., and Anne Marie Hales of Cheyenne, Wyo.; two sons, Glenn W. and James E. Nielson, both of Cody, 35 grandchildren and 68 great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Stability in Financial Markets Weakens Treasury Note Sales

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The United States bond market suffered the biggest decline in almost a month yesterday, driving yields to an eight-week high, as signs of stability in world financial markets sapped demand at the Treasury's $12 billion note sale.
"It's a double whammy," said Michael Mullaney, who helps oversee more than $1 billion at Boston Partners Asset Management. "There's a ton of paper hitting the street and stocks look like they're stabilizing -- the flight to quality is not there." 
 The 30-year bond fell 1 23/32 , to 102 20/32 . Its yield, which rises when prices fall, increased to 5.32 percent from 5.21, the highest since Sept. 8. Yields on two-year notes rose 18 basis points, to 4.42 percent, the highest since Sept. 29.
Bonds had rallied throughout September as investors sought the world's safest securities after Japan's recession worsened, Russia devalued its currency and stock markets around the globe tumbled.
That rally faltered after 30-year Treasury yields touched a three-decade low of 4.69 percent on Oct. 5, and have since lost 10 points, or $100 per $1,000 bond. Some investors swapped safer Treasuries for riskier securities, betting they had seen the worst of a global economic slowdown and selling in world stock markets.
The Treasury's $12 billion in 10-year notes was met with poor demand, as the Government failed to draw investor interest for a second day in its quarterly refunding of older securities.
"Some of the global turmoil is less urgent than it was a few weeks ago," said Joshua Feinman, global markets economist at the Bankers Trust Corporation. Adding to the stability in world markets are expectations that Congress is less likely to impeach President Clinton after a stronger-than-expected Democratic showing in Congressional elections. Political instability can erode confidence in financial markets.
"The election was basically status quo, but the end result is that Clinton will probably continue to be our leader," said David Horner, a senior fixed-income strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company.
At the same time, many investors and traders are declining to make purchases at this week's sale of $38 billion of notes and bills at the Treasury's quarterly refunding.
The Treasury sold the 10-year notes yesterday at a yield of 4.825 percent, above estimates of 4.771 percent prior to the sale. Demand for the securities was below the average for the 10 previous 10-year note sales.

HEADLINE: Fed Survey Finds Economy's Growth Slowing

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The economy was growing at a slower pace and inflation was benign at the start of the fourth quarter, the Federal Reserve's latest survey of regional conditions showed.
"The pace of economic expansion moderated in September and October, amid signs of slowing in some sectors," the Fed said today in its latest report, known as the beige book. "Virtually all districts reported that businesses and consumers remained cautious about the economic outlook," the report said. 
 While manufacturing "continued at relatively high levels," most of the Fed's districts reported "signs of softening" in factory activity.
"Three-quarters of the districts indicated that economic turmoil abroad, especially in East Asia, was at least partially responsible for softening demand," the report said.
Earlier this week, an industry report showed that manufacturing in October put in its weakest performance in more than two and a half years.
The National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index fell to 48.3 last month from 49.4 in September -- the lowest since a 47.3 in March 1996 -- as orders, output and exports slowed. The index has held at less than 50 since June, a sign of a decline in manufacturing and slower economic growth.
The Fed's regional outlook is based on reports from its 12 district banks. It is published eight times each year. The latest edition was compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. Information was collected before Oct. 26.
The report will help form the basis for discussion on interest rate targets at the Nov. 17 meeting of the Fed's policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee.
Amid turbulence in world financial markets, the Fed cut the overnight bank lending rate by a quarter percentage point at its last session on Sept. 29. In a rare between-meeting move on Oct. 15, the Fed also lowered the overnight rate and the discount rate by a quarter-point. Many analysts expect the Fed to continue to lower rates until it is satisfied that the markets have stabilized.
By changing the interest rates it controls, the Fed's actions translate into lower or higher borrowing costs on everything from credit cards to mortgages and business loans -- and influence economic activity, though often with a lag of many months.
In today's report, the Fed also suggested that inflation was not a problem: "Upward pressure on wages and prices remained generally subdued, according to most district reports."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Beige Book Shows Some Weakening Conditions"
A roundup of regional economic conditions in recent months for the Federal Reserve's 12 districts, according to the beige book report issued by the Fed yesterday.
 
Minneapolis -- The economy remained strong with construction a source of strength for the region. Labor demand high.
 
Chicago -- Retailers were cautious about the holiday season as consumer spending was slow. Lenders tightened standards on certain loans.
 
San Francisco -- Manufacturing activity was flat in recent weeks. Businesses faced tighter terms as general economic uncertainty made lenders more cautious.
 
Cleveland -- Economic activity remained strong over all. The industrial sector has softened; labor shortages were reported.
 
Boston -- Economic conditions were mixed. Retailers reported moderate to strong sales growth. Prices were steady; demand for labor was strong.
 
New York - Prospects for job and income losses on Wall Street appear to have dampened consumer confidence. Labor demand was strong.
 
Philadelphia -- Economic activity was steady, as were retail sales. Manufacturers reported a slight decline in demand.
 
Richmond -- The economy advanced at a moderate pace in recent weeks. Service companies were solid while manufacturing remained sluggish.
 
Atlanta -- Factory activity and production were weak. Construction remained strong. Labor demand was high and wages were steady.
 
St. Louis -- The economy operated at high levels. Housing and construction were strong; commercial and industrial lending increased.
 
Kansas City -- Corn and soybean yields came in below expectations. Factory activity was sluggish, but retail sales were firm.
 
Dallas -- Manufacturing and energy industry activity declined, while agricultural conditions remained difficult. Retail sales remained strong.
(Source: Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Shares Rise, Fade, Recover, With Dow Gaining 76.99

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Apparently buoyed by election results, stock prices jumped early yesterday but then faded after investors showed little enthusiasm for an offering of Government bonds.
The Dow Jones industrial average, up as much as 148 points at one stage, barely managed to stay in positive territory during an afternoon swoon before moving up again in the final hour to finish with a gain of 76.99 points, or nine-tenths of a percent, to 8,783.14. Indexes made up of smaller companies, however, did better. 
 Most analysts seemed to agree that electoral inroads by Democrats -- rare for a Presidential party in midterm elections -- diminished the chances of a market-rattling impeachment process that could result in President Clinton's removal from office.
"There's a feeling that the risk of a nasty impeachment proceeding has gone down a lot," said Alfred E. Goldman, chief market strategist at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis. "If Republicans had had a successful election, I think Newt Gingrich et al. would have been encouraged to press the impeachment."
A similar note was struck by Lisa Cullen, a strategist at Merrill Lynch.
"I guess it's good news for stocks because it looks like the Republicans won't be able to muster the firepower to impeach Clinton," she said.
Despite the afternoon selloff, which also coincided with release of a Federal survey showing the economy lost momentum in September and October, most stocks posted gains, with indexes dominated by technology and smaller-capitalization stocks faring best.
Various positive forces have converged in recent weeks to encourage stock investors, including signs of stabilization in Brazil, a seemingly serious attack by Japan on its banking problems, a big financial replenishment for the International Monetary Fund and some reassuring inflation and other reports from Washington.
Stocks climbed smartly in all major overseas markets yesterday, with main gauges up 4.12 percent in Japan and 1.96 percent in Brazil. Mexican stocks were up 3.39 percent, Germany's 3.59 percent, France's 2.80 percent, Britain's 2.16 percent and Hong Kong's 1.45 percent.
Wall Street, some analysts suggested, might have benefited early in the session by demand from foreign investors who generally may not have realized that impeachment fever had already diminished here before the election.
J. P. Morgan and American Express, both with significant exposure to overseas turmoil, accounted by themselves for 59 percent of the Dow's rise. Morgan soared 7 5/8, to 101 3/4, nearly 30 points higher than four weeks ago, amid speculation that it might be acquired. American Express climbed 3 9/16 , to 94.
Barton Biggs, chief global strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, on Monday raised his recommended allocation to Japanese stocks on the ground that the depressed economy there had stabilized enough to appeal to investors looking for bargains.
United States Steel, which announced it was cutting operations at its Fairless Works outside Philadelphia by 70 percent because of a flood of imports, rose 1 5/16 , to 26 11/16 , lifting its gain over the last week to 21 percent. Inland and AK Steel each rose more than 5 percent.
Drug stocks slumped as Dura Pharmaceuticals, down 2 5/8, to 9 3/4, failed to win Government approval for its asthma inhaler and was downgraded by Merrill Lynch. Warner-Lambert and Pfizer lost 3 3/4 and 3 1/4, respectively.
Southwest Airlines, a low-cost carrier, gained 7/16 , to 21 9/16 , on word that it plans to begin flights into the New York City area.
Once again, investors focused heavily on smaller companies, with the Nasdaq composite index rising 35.14 points, or 1.96 percent, to 1,823.57, and the Russell 2000 index up 5.40 points, or 1.39 percent, to 392.96.
"We have probably only started the next phase of the outperformance of the small-cap market," said Robert C. Elliott, senior executive vice president of the Bessemer Trust Company. He noted that earnings gains of small- and medium-sized companies had now exceeded those of big companies for three straight quarters.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 7.83 points, or seven-tenths of a percent, to 1,118.67, but more than twice as many issues rose as fell -- 333 to 154.
Still, many analysts expressed skepticism that stock prices were headed much higher. "We've got some fundamental profit problems," said Michael Fenollosa, an economist at John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance.
On the New York Stock Exchange, 2,062 stocks rose yesterday and 1,027 fell, with new highs swamping new lows, 82 to 14. Volume rose to 861.2 million shares from 704.3 million on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Deflation is frightening, but toothless, for 90's Americans.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
DEFLATION is scary. The last time prices nose-dived throughout the economy was during the Great Depression. Then Government stood by helplessly as wages and prices plummeted and over a quarter of the labor force stood desperately in unemployment lines.
No wonder, then, that investors cringe at the word. Yet Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, recently warned "that deflation from the Far East is heading our way." Many analysts now echo the deflation theme. Charles W. McMillion, chief economist of MBG Information Services, wrote last week in The New Republic that deflation "could happen again soon." 
 But predictions of deflation amount to little more than blather. The experts who dwell on deflation can point to no data that show prices are generally falling. Nor can they point to evidence that across-the-board price cutting is likely to break out in the future. Most important, deflation has not reached the all-important sinews of labor markets.
Predictions of deflation miss the key difference between today and the 1930's: a Federal Reserve no longer asleep at the monetary switch.
First, the data. This year, as in most other years, prices in some individual industries are falling. Energy prices have dropped almost 10 percent the last year. Commodity prices have dropped by about 20 percent the last year. The prices of raw materials, clothes and other imported goods have also declined, partly in response to the economic collapse of Southeast Asia.
But other prices are more than making up for the slack. Producer prices, excluding energy and food, are rising about 1 percent a year. Consumer prices are rising by about 2 percent a year. These rates are small. But they are nowhere near negative.
Look to the labor market, which drives the formation of prices. Over the last year, wages and salaries have been rising about 4 percent a year. Nothing in economic logic or history suggests that wages will suddenly reverse course. Indeed, even if recession strikes, wages will almost certainly continue to rise, as they have in every recent downturn.
And if wages do not fall, prices will almost certainly not fall either. Labor costs typically account for two-thirds of the cost of producing goods and services. In general, wages and prices move up and down together. They can move in opposite directions, however, in times of rapid gains in productivity. If, say, workers are given the tools to churn out 5 percent more each hour, then the extra output would yield enough new revenue to allow the company to pay workers 5 percent more even without raising prices. The company could even cut prices a few percent and still have enough extra revenue to pass along to workers as higher wages.
But productivity is now rising by less than 2 percent a year. That provides no room for prices to fall if wages continue to rise anywhere near their current 4 percent clip. As Prof. Martin S. Feldstein of Harvard points out, "Only in the extreme case of the economy falling into a deep depression like that of the 1930's would the level of prices actually begin a sustained decline."
Nor are prices falling in any other industrialized economy except Japan. Throughout Europe, prices are rising very slowly. In developing countries, inflation rules nearly everywhere outside of China. Even in the decimated economies of Indonesia, South Korea and Thailand, prices are rising rapidly.
So why the frenzy over deflation? Robert Solow, Nobel laureate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, attributes some of the chatter about deflation to analytical confusion. In virtually every industrialized country, the official task of the central bank is to achieve price stability, or roughly zero inflation. At least since the reign of Paul A. Volcker in the 1980's, Fed chairmen have been measured by their ability to get inflation down. With prices rising by only 2 percent a year, Mr. Greenspan has come close to victory.
But Mr. Solow observes, "if average prices are not changing, then, to a rough approximation, half the prices must be falling, while the other half must be rising" in order to keep the price index relatively level. To invoke the specter of specific price cuts for oil, apparel and computers as harbingers of deflation is, by this argument, to confuse economics with algebra.
The United States has not experienced deflation since the 1930's. But though economic historians continue to debate the underlying cause of the Great Depression, they do not dispute the simple proposition that deflation was then, and will almost certainly be in the future, a monetary event. Translation: prices can only continue to fall if people are given fewer and fewer dollars to spend on good and services. This is the flip side of the commonplace proposition that inflation can rage only if people are given more and more dollars to spend by the Fed. In the 1930's, the Fed committed the fatal mistake of sitting back while banks closed and the supply of money shriveled.
It is inconceivable that the Fed would make the same mistake today. If, as Mr. Greenspan fears, deflation forces drift ashore from Asia, the Fed has an ironclad remedy. It needs only to step on the monetary pedal, as it has already begun to do cautiously by lowering interest rates.
There are lots of economic forces to fear. Recession. Inequality. Productivity slowdown. In each case, living standards are at risk and government cannot perfectly anticipate what to do and when to act. But deflation isn't worth fretting about unless you believe that the United States will suffer a once-in-a-century catastrophe and the Fed will play dumb.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Hard Money for a Softer Europe;
Leftist Politics Complicates the Job of the Euro's Banker

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Wim Duisenberg will not acquire his full powers for another eight weeks, but he is already enduring his baptism by fire.
As president of the new European Central Bank, Mr. Duisenberg is in charge of setting into operation Europe's single currency, the euro, on Jan. 4. But just when the historic project seemed set for a remarkably smooth start, the ground underneath him has shifted. 
 Even as the new bank is preoccupied with projecting its hard-nosed credibility in world financial markets, Germany's new left-of-center Government is badgering it almost daily to open up the monetary spigots and generate more jobs.
Indeed, Mr. Duisenberg suddenly finds himself playing with a rulebook developed by players who are not around anymore. After years of belt-tightening, a new raft of center-left governments are increasingly eager to lift spending and let their budget deficits nose upward once again.
In a major ideological shift, Germany's new Government, under Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, now exhorts the bank almost daily to reduce interest rates and help stimulate growth.
Germany's new Finance Minister, Oskar Lafontaine, passionately argues that the country's high unemployment stems directly from the austere monetary policies of the Bundesbank, which serves as the model for the European Central Bank.
"Just look at America," Mr. Lafontaine said, referring to the Federal Reserve chairman. "Alan Greenspan has shown that you can simultaneously achieve inflation-free growth and growth in employment."
And Christa Muller, an influential Government adviser who is married to Mr. Lafontaine, said: "The policies of the European Central Bank and the Bundesbank are not sacrosanct. They must be subjected to a certain control."
To be sure, the new bank's independence and its duties are legally enshrined in the 1992 Maastricht Treaty, which laid the ground rules for the euro.
But the political landscape has changed enormously since European leaders signed the treaty. Most countries now have left-of-center governments, and Germany's change in power eliminates the most formidable champion of hard-money policies.
It was Germany, under then-Chancellor Helmut Kohl, that enshrined the new bank's political independence. It was Germany, often to the fury of France, that insisted the bank focus almost entirely on keeping prices stable rather than on promoting economic growth or jobs. And it was Germany that demanded harsh penalties for countries that run high budget deficits.
Indeed, many European economists believe that the gospel of fiscal austerity is losing force. Under the Stability and Growth Pact signed last year by all 11 nations adopting the euro, countries that run high deficits or have mountains of acquired debt are subject to huge penalties.
Yet countries like Italy, which has twice as much debt as the rules allow, are expected to increase Government spending next year. Last month, Prime Minister Romano Prodi of Italy was forced to step down because he could not muster enough support for his proposed budget cuts.
And Italy is not alone. "You're clearly seeing a shift left in European governments that is triggering a greater willingness to increase spending," said Kermit L. Schoenholtz, global economist for Salomon Smith Barney In London.
"I think it is fair to say that the rules of the game have been changed already," said Friedrich Heinemann, senior economist for the Institute for European Economic Research in Mannheim. "Until now, an important element of the credibility of the Stability and Growth Pact was Germany's tough position. With Lafontaine now in the Government, the pact has already lost some of its credibility."
At a news conference on Tuesday, Mr. Duisenberg brushed aside demands for a policy change. "It's normal for the political side to give suggestions or opinions," he said, "but it would be abnormal if these suggestions were listened to."
A towering man with a shock of white hair and piercing blue eyes, Mr. Duisenberg established his credentials as an anti-inflation hawk as president of the Dutch central bank. There, he locked his own monetary policy to the Bundesbank's. He argues that the only real way to promote job creation is by deregulating the economy.
Indeed, a growing number of experts believe that outspoken pressure from Mr. Lafontaine and other European leaders will merely force Mr. Duisenberg to adopt an even tougher line just to demonstrate his independence.
"Lafontaine would do well to study the example of Bob Rubin, which is to know when to shut up," said Rudiger Dornbush, an economist at M.I.T., referring to United States Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. "The European Central Bank has to show its independence, and if it is pushed, it will have to shove back extra hard."
But there may be other pressures. Mr. Greenspan has already cut American interest rates in the hope of pre-empting a severe downturn. That has put pressure on Europe and Mr. Duisenberg because it caused the dollar to sink in value against European currencies.
That makes European exports more expensive in many foreign markets and is expected to severely dent European growth in 1999.
Senior German advisers to Mr. Lafontaine have seized on the American moves as a vindication of their own arguments.
"The only question we have raised is whether there is maneuvering room for monetary policy to do something expansionary," said Heiner Flassbeck, Mr. Lafontaine's senior adviser on international economic issues. "This is exactly the question that Alan Greenspan has posed hundreds of times, and he has answered the question by reducing interest rates."
Until January, the formal power of monetary policy will continue to lie with the 11 national central banks. But in practice, the countries are already following a common European policy --and that policy is closely modeled on the Bundesbank.
Indeed, the European Central Bank is governed by a board that includes the presidents of each country's national bank. Most decisions require a majority vote.
As a result, Mr. Lafontaine and Mr. Schroder have exchanged most of their barbs with officials at the Bundesbank. On Thursday, Mr. Lafontaine and Mr. Flassbeck plan to take their case directly to the Bundesbank's concrete fortress in Frankfurt, where members of the executive board will hold their monthly meeting.
But economists say the issues in Europe are more complicated than those in the United States.
Even without pressure from Germany, many countries were already reducing interest rates in preparation for the euro. Rates must be almost equal in all member countries because every country will have the same risk of inflation and currency devaluation.
As a result, countries with historically higher inflation have been systematically cutting rates for several months to bring them in line with those of Germany and France. Ireland, Spain, Italy and Portugal have all slashed their rates several times, and more cuts are expected before the end of the year.
The Bundesbank's basic overnight interest rate, now at 3.3 percent, is already considerably lower than that of the United States. Many economists worry that cutting rates could lead some countries to overheat, igniting inflation.
But amid increasing signs that European growth may slow to less than 2 percent next year, Chancellor Schroder has joined Mr. Lafontaine in putting pressure on both the Bundesbank and the European Central Bank.
"It doesn't only have responsibility for monetary stability but also for economic growth in a sensible way," Mr. Schroder said on Saturday, noting new Government estimates that the German economy will expand only about 2.3 percent in 1999.
"That's damn little, too little for a big offensive on the labor market that is supported solely by economic growth," Mr. Schroder said.
Mr. Lafontaine and other officials have also tweaked the central bankers for their secretiveness and their refusal to reveal the minutes of board meetings. Christian Noe, State Secretary at the Finance Ministry, recently accused the Bundesbank -- and by extenstion, the European Central Bank -- of indulging in "pre-democratic" behavior.
"This isn't the Vatican we're talking about," said one government official, who insisted on anonymity. "No one is questioning the independence of the central bank. We're just raising questions of public interest."
But Europe's central bankers have been far from amused. Jean-Claude Trichet, head of the Bank of France, warned that political leaders risked jeopardizing the euro's credibility.
"Any suggestion that central banks were on the way to losing their independence would affect savers' confidence both in Europe and worldwide," Mr. Trichet said on Monday in Paris.
Jurgen Stark, the Bundesbank's deputy governor, said last weekend that he was already worried about growing budget deficits in Europe.
"Excessive deficits are damaging," Mr. Stark said in a television interview. "The European Central Bank could be forced to react with interest-rate increases."
Politics aside, a growing number of economists believe that Mr. Duisenberg will eventually be driven by economic pressure to reduce rates slightly -- to perhaps 3 percent.
But that may not satisfy people like Mr. Lafontaine, and Mr. Duisenberg has made it clear he has no intention of deviating from his basic concern about price stability.
"The leaders today are different from the ones that signed the Maastricht Treaty, but the fact remains that we still have the treaty," said Mr. Heinemann of the Institute for European Economic Research. "The fact that we have a new Government in Germany doesn't change one letter in the treaty."

HEADLINE: October Sales Of Vehicles Still Surprising

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The strength of car and truck sales in October continued to surprise Wall Street analysts and auto industry executives as more figures were released today. October turned out to be one of the strongest months in history and puts the industry on track for its best year in a decade.
"I was looking for strong numbers, and these are stronger than I expected," said David Healy, an auto analyst for Burnham Securities in New York. Mr. Healy noted that the stronger sales came about even as incentives began tapering off from the high levels of last spring and summer. 
 With almost every vehicle manufacturer tallying higher sales this October compared with the month a year earlier, total vehicle sales in the United States for the month totaled 1,368,567 cars and light trucks, a 9.8 percent increase compared with sales in October 1997. Car sales rose 7.1 percent, to 712,407 units; truck sales increased 12.9 percent, to 656,160 vehicles. That put the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for light vehicles at 16.6 million cars and light trucks for October, just shy of June of this year, when the rate was the highest since August 1987, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.
The General Motors Corporation surprised analysts in making a quicker comeback than expected from last summer's 54-day strike. Instead of increasing sales by 2 percent, as analysts had predicted, G.M. reported today that its sales increased 6 percent in October compared with those in the month a year earlier, to 408,655 cars and light trucks. G.M. light-truck sales totaled 180,212 vehicles, up 6.4 percent, even without the full production of the 1999 models of its large pickup trucks, the Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra, which are in their introduction phase after being redesigned. G.M.'s full-size sport utility vehicles, including the Chevrolet Tahoe and GMC Yukon, and front-wheel-drive minivans, sold as the Chevrolet Venture, Oldsmobile Silhouette and Pontiac Montana, had their best October sales in history. Small trucks also had large sales increases. G.M. car sales rose 6.3 percent, to 228,443, on the strength of its midsized line and large cars from Buick and Pontiac. "It looks like G.M.'s recovery from the strike is moving better than they hoped," Mr. Healy said.
For the year, G.M. sales are off about 4 percent. Truck sales are 5 percent higher; car sales are 10 percent lower. Because other auto makers, particularly the Chrysler Corporation, which reported earlier in the week that its October sales increased 20 percent, and foreign brands were turning in stronger-than-expected sales numbers, G.M. came in just shy of its goal for 30 percent market share in October.
In addition, G.M. recognized that it was losing sales because its inventory of vehicles in dealer showrooms remained off about 20 percent from levels in the month a year earlier, said Donald R. DeVeaux, G.M.'s director of North American market analysis. The inventory shortages were most noticeable at G.M.'s largest divisions, Chevrolet and Pontiac, and in their highest-selling models, like the Chevrolet Cavalier and Pontiac Grand Am.
In the meantime, G.M. plants were running at full capacity and the auto maker planned to build 1.5 million cars and trucks in the fourth quarter, more than any fourth quarter in a decade. At the Ford Motor Company, sales of Ford, Mercury, Lincoln and Jaguar vehicles rose 2.1 percent, to 333,522 cars and trucks, on target with analysts' projections but higher than Ford expected at the start of the month. Light-truck sales increased 10.1 percent, to 202,741 vehicles, on the strength of the Ford F-Series pickup, Explorer, Expedition and Lincoln Navigator sport utilities. Car sales declined 8.2 percent, to 130,781 vehicles, because of lower fleet sales. Like G.M., Ford, based on October's strong sales performance, will build 1.1 million cars and trucks -- 25,000 more than originally planned -- in the fourth quarter.
"The industry blew past what we thought it would be," said Michael C. DiGiovanni, G.M.'s chief forecaster, in an interview. "We dodged the bullet of the Asian financial crisis. Now the rest of the economic fundamentals look strong."
Mr. DiGiovanni noted lower interest rates and new products combined with favorable demographics, such as aging baby boomers buying luxury vehicles and Generation X'ers forming households and buying vehicles to meet their needs, bode well for the industry's near future.
"Internally, we're looking at 1999 and wondering if it will be a better year than we thought," he said.
Mr. Healy agreed, noting recent interest rate cuts and future ones would soon show up in car loan rates, "a plus factor for next year's vehicle sales."
"These sales might subside a bit but, barring 20 percent interest rates or $2-a-gallon gasoline, we're not looking for a collapse in sales or a recession," he said.

HEADLINE: French Youths Strike for the Right to Study Hard

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: CHELLES, France, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Thousands of the 2.3 million high-school students in France plan to resume protests against poor study conditions with a demonstration in Paris on Thursday. But at the Lycee Gaston Bachelard in this Paris suburb students are torn about how hard they should keep pushing.
"We've got some promises on paper," said Abdenbi Benammar, 20, a student leader, referring to promised remedies for shortages of teachers and shortcomings in the curriculum made by the Ministry of Education after last month's national protests. "But until we actually see changes made we should keep up the pressure." 
 Sarah Devannes, a classmate, disagreed. "We achieved a lot of things," she said. "We got six teachers' assistants who'll be here in January, and if we continue the strike too long, we'll start losing support."
Discussions like this are going on in schools all over the country after a two-week October vacation that followed some of the biggest school protests since 1995. Then it was university students who were on strike. They wanted better classrooms and study conditions, more teachers, smaller classes and curriculums designed to help them compete for jobs in an economy where many graduates find no jobs waiting for them when they get out of school.
In France these days, with unemployment at 11.7 percent, students are now striking for the right to study harder to be better prepared for the job market.
That is only one of many things about French schools that might amaze Americans. Even in troubled neighborhoods, schools have no metal detectors at the door because guns in France are strictly controlled.
"I've been in teaching for 19 years, and I've never seen a knife flashed in all that time, though I've worked in some pretty tough schools," said Daniel Bach, the principal at the Lycee Bachelard, where 2,000 students from all racial and ethnic groups prepare for the "bac," the baccalaureate diploma that qualifies them to study at university.
Looking at the school, a visitor might ask what there was to strike about. In a neighborhood of single-family houses and gardens next to a housing project, the school has big picture windows and wide, spotlessly clean corridors in four-story buildings organized around a central courtyard where students gather during breaks.
The openness turns out to be one of the problems. "Kids from the neighborhood can come in and sell hashish and other stuff," Mr. Benammar said. "We used to have draftees doing alternative service who helped with administrative work and insured security, but the draft ended this year and we don't have them any more."
So one of the student demands, here as at other schools around the country, was for more supervisory workers and better safety. The Education Minister, Claude Allegre, promised to increase school staffs with part-time students as part of the Socialist Government's national youth employment program.
Another complaint of students here was academic schedules that had scheduled some of them right out of lunch, a problem Mr. Bach laid to computer foul-ups that have since been solved. He discusses problems like these regularly with student representatives who, like Mr. Benammar, tend to be older than their American counterparts.
Students commonly repeat years before passing the national examination thresholds to higher levels of education, and the examinations, particularly for the "bac," are so rigorous that there is little stigma attached to staying back a year or more to prepare for them.
"One of the strains on the system is that nowadays 60 to 65 percent of all students want to go on to university," Mr. Bach said. "It used to be 30 percent. So it's no longer just an elite that wants to continue."
In a country where until a decade or so ago schools were run by a huge bureaucracy centralized in Paris, and providing education is still seen by almost everybody as a state responsibility, students are as apt as their parents to take to the streets to demand solutions to their problems.
Last month, the high-school protests in Paris turned violent when unemployed youths joined student marches and started breaking windows, looting stores and setting cars on fire in scenes reminiscent of the student revolution in the Latin Quarter in 1968.
But the violence this time was an aberration, agreed these students, who seem more preoccupied with fitting into today's global economy and their increasingly competitive society than with changing it.
When Mr. Allegre responded to last month's strikes by promising to lighten the weekly class workload, which keeps many students on the campus here from 8:15 A.M. to 5:15 P.M., at least some of them thought he had missed the point.
"If they cut back the workload too much, we could find that we aren't prepared when we get to university," Miss Devannes said. "They could assume we know math we haven't even studied, and then how would we cope with our courses?"
What exactly the relief in the study load that Mr. Allegre promised would mean was not clear to Muriel Navarro, a history and geography teacher who meets regularly with student representatives more concerned with passing tests than avoiding work.
Remedial study programs are unknown in the state university system, which leaves students to figure out their own deficiencies and make up for them, if necessary.
At the high-school level, according to Mr. Bach (whose ancestors came from Germany, though he says he has not had the time to research whether they were related to Johann Sebastian), it is up to professors and students together to meet diploma requirements.
Worry about that was one of the reasons students at this school decided to strike, he said, after they got back to school in September from summer vacation and found that they were short of 4 teachers out of 170. That meant that some students were unable to sign up for required courses in life sciences and mathematics.
"I had asked the district administration for a replacement for the math teacher last June, when she asked for maternity leave," Mr. Bach said. "But I didn't get one."
Now that Mr. Allegre has promised to recruit 3,000 new substitute teachers in answer to the strikers' demands, Mr. Bach thinks he will get replacements for the ones he is missing. But he says it will be up to them and their students to figure out how to get through the required syllabus by the end of the year.

HEADLINE: U.S. Enlists Russians to Spot Nuclear Smuggling

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
In an effort to prevent nuclear weapons and materials from being smuggled out of Russia, the United States announced plans yesterday to train Russian customs agents in identifying and arresting smugglers.
"The cold war is over, but the weapons are still around," said Rick Galbraith, a policy coordinator at the United States Customs Service in Washington. "The Russians were really good at keeping track of their nuclear weapons." 
 But the economic collapse of Russia has made its cache of weapons and materials more vulnerable to smugglers "who know people who know people who haven't been paid," he said.
Plans include training Russian customs agents at the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, the United States Energy Department's "nuclear reservation" in Pasco, Wash. Thirty Russian agents are scheduled to spend two weeks there before the end of this year, learning how to detect nuclear materials and track smugglers. All expenses, including travel, will be covered by the United States.
There are plans to train other Russian agents at subsequent sessions at the Washington reservation. The United States is also planning to give the Russian customs service three X-ray detection vans for use at its borders. The vans, which cost a total of $750,000, can detect nuclear material.
"We want to make their customs people aware of what to look for," said Bonnie Brigman, the manager of the Customs Service's 30-month-old radiation detection program. "We'll be using actual radioactive sources so they can see the way the detection equipment responds."
Customs officials say they have not yet worked out the costs of the program. But the benefit of controlling nuclear materials and weapons of mass destruction in order to keep them from terrorists or unfriendly countries is incalculable, Mr. Galbraith said.
"We had a meeting of the minds," he said, referring to the cooperative agreement between the two countries, which stems from the September meeting of President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin in Moscow. "But we have better financing."
But the real question is "are we doing enough?" said Michael O'Hanlon, a foreign-policy expert and senior fellow at the Brookings Institute, a Washington think tank. Though he praised the cooperative customs-services plan, it is, he said, too little, too late. "We should be protecting nuclear materials at their point of origin," he said. "We shouldn't wait until they reach the borders. We know from drug trafficking that border inspections are not enough."
The United States should be considering "much more radical" plans to control weapons of mass destruction and keep impoverished Russian employees -- from scientists to customs inspectors -- from being tempted to sell them. If necessary, he said, the United States should itself pay Russian employees in return for safeguarding its nuclear materials.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: CONGRESS -- THE PRESIDENT;
Hiding Smiles, White House Aides Say It's Time to Return to Work

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Out of the exhaustion, relief and controlled euphoria, a White House post-election strategy emerged of putting on a visible show of attending to the nation's business while letting Republicans engage in noisy political bloodletting.
This is a time to remain largely silent, senior officials concluded after the extent of Republican losses in Tuesday's voting became clear. If others want to emphasize that voters have shown that they are fed up with talk of sex, scandal and impeachment, top Administration officials are happy to get out of the way. 
 "Obviously, there is no intention to gloat," said one senior White House official who insisted on anonymity. "Impeachment is still serious business. The worst thing the White House could do is imitate the Republicans and overplay our hand. We're just going to sit back for a few days."
There was a careful effort by senior White House officials not to convey a sense of giddiness about Tuesday's election results, which some Clinton loyalists were suggesting should be read as a vote of acquittal on all charges against the President by his ultimate jury, the electorate.
Officials insisted that Tuesday's voting would have no impact on how the President approached the impeachment inquiry pending in the House. Aides said it was up to Republicans to make the next move, after they sort out the implications of their poor showing.
"Back to work," was the refrain from the President on down.
Mr. Clinton convened a meeting of his senior economic advisers to discuss revamping Social Security, an issue that Democrats played to their advantage during the campaign. At the start of the meeting, Mr. Clinton said the election's message was that the American people wanted elected officials to address pocketbook issues like Social Security, health care, education, the minimum wage.
"I think the American people basically said to all of us, all of us, 'We sent you there to work for us and we want you to find a way to do it, to address the challenges we face and to bring this country together and move this country forward,' " Mr. Clinton said. "I think that was the loud, clear, completely unambiguous message of the election."
Mr. Clinton would not bite on an impeachment question dangled before him.
"That's in the hands of Congress and the American people," he said. "I've said that before; I'll say it again. I have nothing else to say about that."
Beneath their sober demeanor, the President's top aides and advisers were having difficulty concealing their pleasure at the unexpected Republican losses.
"This was a reaffirmation of what we knew before the election," said James Carville, an outside adviser who helped to turn the election into a referendum on Speaker Newt Gingrich as much as on the President's private morality. "The public knew where the Republicans wanted to take them -- down the road of scandal and impeachment -- and they clearly said they didn't want to go with them. That's the real point."
Clinton aides involved in scandal control would say only that they hoped Republicans would read the results as a public order to conclude quickly the impeachment inquiry scheduled to begin before the House Judiciary Committee this month.
Republican leaders said the inquiry would continue as planned, but there was a recognition that voters interviewed at the polls expressed a clear preference for ending the matter quickly.
Jim Nicholson, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, suggested that the inquiry might be accelerated in the wake of Tuesday's voting but that no decision had been made on how to proceed.
Mr. Nicholson acknowledged that the results were heartening for the White House, saying, "I would expect the President is probably feeling pretty chipper this morning."
No one who has worked for Mr. Clinton for any period of time is under the illusion that one election -- even one as surprising and favorable as this one -- will end the President's problems at home or abroad.
In addition to impeachment, the President must still cope with the threat from Iraq, the follow-through to the Israeli-Palestinian talks, Kosovo and the continuing global economic crisis. On domestic matters, even though the Republicans have been weakened, there is still no bipartisan consensus on Social Security revision, tax policy, education spending, tobacco legislation or health care.
And despite the good fortunes of Democratic candidates from California to New York, Mr. Clinton still does not enjoy the trust of a majority of the electorate. Exit polls indicated that while about 60 percent of the public approved of the job he was doing as President, an equal number did not approve of his personal morality or behavior.
"After all the ups and downs of the past six years," said Rahm Emanuel, a senior White House political adviser for six years until leaving last month, "nobody is acting giddy or ebullient today. The White House staff is a very sober, very serious, very battle-tested group. They've seen good and they've seen bad, and they know impeachment is a very serious matter."
Although White House denizens were disciplined about not interpreting the election results, the one race they could not help talking about was the contest for Minnesota governor, won by a former professional wrestler, Jesse (The Body) Ventura.
John Podesta, the scrawny White House chief of staff, said that henceforth his nickname would no longer be Skippy, but rather John (The Body) Podesta.
And the President, asked at the Social Security meeting about Mr. Ventura's election, said, "I think that you're going to have a lot of politicians spending time in gyms now."

HEADLINE: RUSSIA CANNOT PAY ITS FOREIGN DEBTS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The Russian Government said today for the first time that it will not pay its foreign debts next year, and will seek to renegotiate the loans.
Today's announcement is just the latest in a litany of familiar setbacks here that includes a collapsing currency, a yawning budget deficit and a deteriorating economy. 
 But today the Government also acknowledged another startling indicator of its troubles: last month it had a meager two-week to three-week supply of food. The Government said it has taken steps to restock its national cupboard, including an appeal to the United States and Europe for food and financing.
Russia's attempt to renegotiate its loans from foreign lenders and countries is an important test of its ability to maintain some credibility with the West. A Russian default on foreign loans would make it that much harder for many years to come for a cash-starved Russia to receive credits.
Russia owes about $3 billion this year in foreign loans and another $17 billion is due next year. The debt includes government-backed credits to Russia, payments due to the International Monetary Fund, loans coming due that were made to the old Soviet Union, as well as more recent borrowings from private banks and long-term bonds sold to Western investors.
At first Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov held open the possibility that the Government would find a way to pay its debts.
But the Primakov team soon found itself overwhelmed by the economic crisis. Seeded with Communists, social democrats and free market supporters, the coalition Government has produce a program of only vague economic measures.
Mr. Primakov's failure to make tough decisions to close the budget deficit and advance market reform has cost it, at least temporarily, the support of the I.M.F.
The fund has criticized Mr. Primakov's most recent plan as a step backward from economic reform, making it virtually impossible that the Kremlin will receive the next $4.3 billion disbursement in assistance before the end of the year.
And without Western aid, the Government's cash crunch has become that much worse.
"There is no chance of receiving money from the West," said Sergei Kiriyenko, the former Prime Minister who was ousted by Mr. Yeltsin last August. "And as a result Russia will not be able to pay all of its foreign debt next year."
Today Yuri Maslyukov, a Communist who was given responsibility for economic policy under Mr. Primakov, acknowledged as much.
"We must pay $17.5 billion next year," Mr. Maslyukov said. "This year we have to pay only $3.5 billion. But both tasks are extraordinary ones for our weakened economy."
Mr. Maslyukov said Russia had two possible responses. It could take draconian steps to pay off the debts at the expense of clamorous Russian industries, interest groups and needy Russians.
"Or we should come to terms with our creditors, reach an agreement with them that they will restructure our debt," Mr. Maslyukov said. "We will be tackling the second task."
Still, like much of the Government's economic program, Mr. Maslyukov was short on details today. At a news conference he did not say which types of loans the Government would try to renegotiate or what terms they would seek. Generally, the restructuring of loans involves deferring principal payments, lowering interest rates and lengthening the term of the loan.
He also did not say if Russia would simply default if it failed to come to terms with its lenders. The choice is not an easy one, for the Russian Government must continue its payments to the I.M.F. to maintain its good standing with the fund.
Mr. Kiriyenko suggested today that the Government should begin talks on renegotiating former Soviet debt.
But Mr. Kiriyenko clearly has a dim view of Mr. Primakov's ability to direct economic policy. He said the Government's most recent set of economic measures was a profile in political cowardice that was aimed primarily at papering over divisions within its own ranks.
Mr. Maslyukov, not surprisingly, put it differently. He said the Government was merely trying to cope with the mess that Mr. Kiriyenko and Russia's market reformers left behind.
But even Mr. Maslyukov acknowledged that the combination of state intervention, subsidies and printing of money that the current Government had proposed did not constitute a strategy.
"This is not a program," he said. "We are speaking of measures that must be taken today and tomorrow."

HEADLINE: In America;
The Landscape Shifts

BYLINE: By Bob Herbert 

 BODY:
Some unsolicited advice for the Republican Party: Give up on the politics of meanness. It's killing you.
And for the Democrats: Forget about running away from blacks and Hispanics. You hide from those constituencies at your peril. 
 And for politicians from both parties: The voters want you to conduct yourselves with a little dignity. So stop the name-calling and the lying and the frat-boy behavior. Grow up.
The post-Clinton era is fast approaching, and the public is in the mood for straight arrows. So the likes of Al D'Amato and Carol Moseley-Braun are being shown the door, and quieter types -- Charles Schumer in New York, for one, and the aptly named Gray Davis in California -- are receiving warm welcomes.
I'm sure Newt Gingrich doesn't get it. He's been all over television since Tuesday night trying somehow to blame his party's poor showing on the media's obsession with the Lewinsky scandal. Never mind that the Speaker himself is the driving force behind the effort to impeach the President, or that he was the one who authorized the G.O.P.'s desperate last-minute advertising blitz designed to capitalize on the scandal.
The whole thing has backfired. Public sentiment has been clear from the beginning: Do not impeach the President. But Mr. Gingrich suffers from the handicap of being tone-deaf while battling against a President with perfect political pitch.
"My view is that impeachment will not happen," Mr. Schumer said yesterday. "My sense is that while Newt Gingrich and Trent Lott would not admit it publicly because they have the extreme right looking over their shoulder, they are both astute politicians and they realize they made a mistake, and they are going to find a graceful way to come to a denouement."
In other words, a deal. The irony is that Mr. Gingrich, having miscalculated so badly, now has to worry about being bounced from his post as Speaker by angry Republican colleagues.
As for the Democrats, when the going got tough they started looking for the minorities. It wasn't too long ago that an awful lot of Democratic politicians were trying to shake off what they saw as the stigma of the party's association with blacks and Hispanics, especially blacks. They acted as if soccer moms cast the only votes that counted.
How successful was this strategy? Well, the next thing you knew both houses of Congress and most of the nation's governorships were in the hands of the Republicans.
When Bill Clinton's troubles threatened to make matters worse, black and Hispanic voters started looking a lot more attractive. Suddenly they were being courted again.
Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist Poll, summed up the matter nicely: "When Democrats get their clocks cleaned, it's because they're not getting the turnout in urban areas."
It's early, but we may be at the start of a significant political advance. The Democrats, less liberal than a few years ago, are regrouping. They are talking again about unifying disparate constituencies around issues that resonate widely -- education, jobs, Social Security, health care. A stronger economy, which tends to ease the hostility between groups, makes that kind of goal easier to accomplish.
"The average American doesn't like divisiveness," said Mr. Schumer. "And they are tired of this idea where people on each side of the aisle yell at each other all day long and nothing gets done."
In his acceptance speech, Mr. Schumer said: "Now, as we enter the 21st century and face ever-increasing global competition, competition that can make or break America, we cannot afford division, whether it's between race, sexual orientation, geographic region or ideology."
The Republican Party, on a roll for awhile, is threatened by all of those divisions and nobody sees a way out. The mindless intolerance of the far right is a plague that serves as a perpetual check on the power of the party's more progressive forces, which are the forces with the widest appeal. The most successful Republicans are the big state governors who have escaped the right-wing plague, at least for the time being.
But in Congress Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Lott have been unable to get their act together. Which has been a godsend for the Democrats.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Essay;
No Third Term!

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the wake of their midterm triumph, the permanent campaigners in the White House must be thinking: Will nobody rid us of this troublesome 22d Amendment? Why should superpopular Bill Clinton be denied the chance to run for a third term?
That was some shellacking the G.O.P. took this week. Let us count the lessons: 
 1. Not all politics is local. This was an election nationalized by the Impeachment Issue, no matter what exit pollsters report. Despite hand wringing predictions of rampant apathy and turnoff, midterm turnout was 38 percent of the voting-age public. That is as high as the controversial Agnew-driven campaign of 1970.
There is no blinking away the fact that this was a referendum on Clinton conduct. This year, core voters of both parties as well as swing voters were motivated by the fear or hope of removing the President. The difference in most close races that Democrats won was sympathy for Clinton. Which means:
2. The majority of Americans who care enough to vote do not believe that lying under oath about sexual matters -- by itself -- justifies removing this President from office. The minority can grumble about how the Clinton example undermines the judicial system, or argue that good times should not justify bad acts, but the majority rules. Which means:
3. If the President is to be called to account, Congress and the Independent Counsel must come up with significant new evidence of a pattern of abuse of power. The unwritten rule at Justice is that no indictments should be brought before an election, a custom that Ken Starr followed. If he has other cases or criminal information that will reveal abuse of power or tampering with witnesses, this month is the time to indict. If the Supreme Court thinks that government lawyers cannot act as personal attorneys, this is the time to force Bruce Lindsey to talk.
The House Judiciary Committee will proceed in an orderly way, breaking down previous stonewalling, but it must present new evidence of wrongdoing beyond Monica. (A Clinton-appointed judge has in effect O.K.'d Clinton fund-raising from Chinese intelligence sources, and Clinton Justice is happy not to appeal his egregious ruling. That travesty bears a close Judiciary look.)
4. The religious right would be wise to let economic conservatives take the G.O.P. wheel. The statehouse victories of the Bush Boys in Texas and Florida and George Pataki in New York suggest that tax cuts and attention to local schools butter more political parsnips than an aggressive assertion of traditional values.
Swing voters are evidently not troubled by swingers. There's a respected place for moralists and religionists in the Republican vehicle; their principled resistance to the corrupting gambling epidemic will, I hope, shame G.O.P. fat cats greedy for casino bucks. But if races in 2000 are to be won, social conservatives cannot be in the driver's seat.
5. The flip side of women voters' condoning Clinton's conduct with a subordinated tut-tut is the practical end of sexual harassment law as we know it. Paradoxically, nobody will have done more than Bill Clinton for the macho predator, or will ruin more cases for trial lawyers out to blackmail corporate executives.
6. Idealism lives. The Democratic victory that did my heart good was the squeaker won by Senator Russell Feingold in Wisconsin. That new Don Quixote demonstrated how a campaign finance reformer could win by running against soft money and practicing what he preached.
Feingold's example gave new life to fund-raising reform, which should be handled both retrospectively though investigation of the Asian connection and prospectively through legislation next year. His Republican partner on this issue, Senator John McCain -- with his 70 percent blowout victory in Arizona -- now becomes the dark horse to challenge front-runner Bush.
Finally, 7. The pendulum of politics swings faster than ever. Remember how Clinton soared in '93, collapsed in '94, came back in '96, crashed this summer, came back this fall? Do you really think that pattern will fail to repeat next spring?
Hence, loathed Melancholy; cheer up, droopy right-wingers. Regroup around new leaders, challenge the President to veto your tax cuts, and watch your heads -- here comes that pendulum back again.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK STATE -- THE SENATOR-ELECT;
Looking Jubilant, if Bleary-Eyed, Schumer Sets His Priorities for the Senate

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
Still exultant from his victory in the bruising Senate race, Representative Charles E. Schumer said yesterday that education, health care and campaign finance reform would be among his top priorities in Washington next year, and he vowed to keep his family in Brooklyn because he did not want to lose touch with his constituents.
In the first of several days in which Mr. Schumer plans to crisscross the state thanking voters, the nine-term Democratic Congressman greeted commuters near his home in Park Slope, held a lengthy news conference in Manhattan, made a surprise appearance at a teachers' union meeting and read the top-10 list on "Late Show With David Letterman." 
 Looking exuberant, even if his eyes were a bit bloodshot from weariness, Mr. Schumer called his 9 percentage point victory over Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato "a humbling and awesome experience" and said he was looking forward to relaxing this weekend with his wife, Iris, and two daughters, Alison and Jessica.
Asked if he planned to move his family to Washington, Mr. Schumer, 47, said no, partly because they love their Park Slope home and partly because he was worried about becoming disconnected from New Yorkers and their concerns. He said he plans to continue sharing a Washington apartment with three other members of Congress while commuting home on weekends.
"One of the nice things, I think, I hope, I pray, about being Senator is that I can sort of keep my same life style," he said. "I learned a lesson a while back. The Congress members who live in Washington lose touch with the struggles and the dreams of our citizens far more quickly than those who live back in their districts."
Mr. D'Amato, a Republican in his third term, held a brief news conference yesterday morning in the parking lot of the Hilton Hotel and Towers in Manhattan, where he spent the night. The Senator, 61, said he had not made up his mind about what he plans to do once he leaves office.
"It's been a great honor," Mr. D'Amato said, "it's been a great privilege, it's been a great thrill to be Senator from this great state. I've tried to make a difference and I think we have accomplished a lot."
Mr. Schumer began his morning with a spate of television interviews, after which he walked Alison, who is 7, to her bus stop, trailed by a gaggle of photographers, reporters and two New York City police detectives serving as bodyguards.
At a meeting of the United Federation of Teachers in lower Manhattan, Mr. Schumer got a standing ovation from several hundred teachers when he chided Mr. D'Amato for having attacked the teacher's union early in the campaign.
"I think we have taught a lesson or two to those who would kick around teachers," he said.
In the late afternoon, Mr. Schumer taped a segment for Mr. Letterman's show titled, "Top 10 Things on Chuck Schumer's To-Do List." No. 8: "Learn how to say 'Pataki' without giggling." No. 3: "Endorse new Starbucks beverage line: The Chuck-accino."
And No. 1: "Change my name to Chucky (The Body) Ventura," a reference to the former professional wrestler, Jesse (The Body) Ventura, who was elected Governor of Minnesota on Tuesday.
During a 40-minute session with reporters, Mr. Schumer was asked whether he thought Tuesday's election, in which the Democrats picked up several House seats, amounted to a referendum on President Clinton and the Monica Lewinsky scandal.
"I think there was a feeling among New Yorkers and among Americans that there were some in Congress, particularly on the Republican side, that would rather spend time debating the Lewinsky affair than debating education and debating H.M.O.'s, and I think that hurt the Republican Party," he replied.
Mr. Schumer, along with a minority of members of the House Judiciary Committee, voted against bringing impeachment proceedings against the President. He said yesterday that he had not decided what he would do if the House votes to impeach the President -- which, after Tuesday's elections, is considered less likely to happen. An impeachment vote in the House would send the issue to the Senate, which would serve as the jury over the President's fate.
Mr. Schumer said he had six priorities for his first year in the Senate: improving public schools and making all college tuition deductible; bringing jobs to upstate communities; improving health insurance; bolstering the Social Security system; expanding gun control, and revamping the nation's campaign finance system.
The New York Senate race was the most expensive in the country this year, with Mr. Schumer having spent $13 million and Mr. D'Amato $20 million by mid-October. Asked if he regretted the campaign's high price tag, Mr. Schumer said: "No. I won."
"But I regret that the system is the way it is," he continued. "The way to deal with the system is not to unilaterally disarm, but rather to change the system so that one side doesn't have all these big megaweapons and the other side doesn't have any."
Mr. Schumer said he spoke yesterday morning to Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Republicans who supported Mr. D'Amato, to discuss state and city issues. He said he plans to meet with Mr. Pataki in the coming week to discuss ways of strengthening the upstate economy.
Mr. Schumer said he wished the campaign could have been more positive in tone. But he said he thought that in the final days of the race, voters had heard his message on education, Social Security and other issues.
"The best way to combat the cynicism of young people, and everybody in America, is to actually pass things that make people's lives better," he said. "And that's what I'm going to do."

HEADLINE: THE 1998 ELECTIONS: THE STATES -- INITIATIVES;
From Same-Sex Marriages To Gambling, Voters Speak

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 4

 BODY:
In a vote expected to have national reverberations, Washington State residents dealt a stinging defeat to state-sponsored affirmative action. Voters in five Western states gave a resounding yes to the medical use of marijuana, while Alaska and Hawaii voters said a clear no to the idea of same-sex marriages.
Massachusetts and Arizona voters approved public financing of political campaigns, while Colorado and Washington rejected proposals to criminalize late-term abortions. And Oregon, becoming the first state to do away with polling places altogether, will conduct elections entirely by mail. 
 These were some of the highlights of votes on more than 200 initiatives and proposed constitutional amendments that were on state ballots on Tuesday. Supporters hail such initiatives as popular democracy in action, but critics call them a potentially dangerous subversion of representative government. Whatever its merits or flaws, the initiative process was very much in action on Tuesday in 16 states, perhaps most notably here in Washington, where voters also made theirs the first state in the nation to require annual minimum-wage increases linked to the inflation rate, and in California, where voters contended with a dozen major questions.
In California, a proposal to raise cigarette taxes by 50 cents a pack and dedicate the money to early childhood and prenatal care programs, bitterly opposed by the tobacco industry, had passed by such a thin margin that it was probably headed for a recount. And in a battle that became the most expensive fight ever waged over a state initiative, the voters ignored an advertising campaign by Nevada casinos and broadly backed the expansion of casino gambling on Indian tribal lands in California. They also passed an initiative to spend $9.2 billion on measures to reduce crowding in the state's public schools and to repair aging classrooms.
In all, voters nationwide passed 37 of the 61 initiatives and popular referendums before them, a higher percentage of yes votes than in any other election this decade. Some of the big winning issues were medical marijuana, campaign-finance reform and gambling, while the big losers included doctor-assisted suicide, tax credits for private school tuition, a late-term abortion procedure that opponents call partial birth abortion, and same-sex marriages.
"The voters addressed the tough issues that elected officials have been unwilling to deal with, as well as voted down those reforms they weren't ready for," said M. Dane Waters, the president and founder of the Initiative and Referendum Institute, a nonpartisan group that tracks the votes and generally supports the initiative process.
But others said that many of the measures that passed were misleading to the voters, and that on no issue was there more debate about the meaning of the initiative than on Washington state's Proposition 200, which passed with 58 percent of the vote and will ban many state-supported forms of affirmative action originally enacted to remedy discrimination.
Voters on Tuesday were asked whether government should be "prohibited from discriminating or granting preferential treatment based on race, sex, color, ethnicity or national origin" in public employment, education and contracting.
They said yes by a wide margin, making Washington the second state, after California, to put such language into law.
"It means that America is taking a great step forward to looking beyond race and minimizing its importance, rather than dwelling on it and magnifying its importance," said John Carlson, chairman of the group sponsoring the initiative. "It also, I think, will hasten the transition of affirmative action from a program based on race and ethnicity and occasionally gender to a program that is based on people's circumstances."
But the vote, far from clarifying the issue, is certain to spark lawsuits, as supporters of affirmative action argue that programs intended to provide equal opportunity for racial minorities or women do not constitute preferential treatment. They also point to polls indicating that while people endorse the language in measures like Proposition 200, which was taken from the Civil Rights Act of 1964, they will say no when asked whether they wish to eliminate affirmative action.
In any event, the vote in Washington is clearly a boost to opponents of affirmative action and is likely to spur efforts to get similar measures on the ballots in other states.
Gay rights measures were defeated in several states. Colorado residents rejected a proposal to grant homosexuals civil rights protection against discrimination. Hawaii voters gave the Legislature authorization to overturn a court ruling and ban same-sex marriages, while Alaskans voted 2 to 1 in favor of a constitutional amendment that defines marriage as a union between one man and one woman.
Voters in South Portland, Me., passed an ordinance to ban discrimination based on sexual orientation, but in three other cities -- Fayetteville, Ark.; Fort Collins, Colo.; and Ogunquit, Me. -- such measures were defeated. The issue was especially charged in Fort Collins, which is near Laramie, Wyo., the city where Matthew Shepard, a gay man, was beaten and tied to a fence. Mr. Shepard was transferred to a hospital in Fort Collins, where he died.
"We recognize that the struggle for full equality is a long-term one," said Kerry Lobel, executive director of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force. "And win or lose in Hawaii and Alaska, we will continue to fight for full equality, including the freedom to marry, until we succeed."
The battle over California's proposed cigarette tax remained remarkably close this evening; with all the precincts reporting, 3,550,483 people voted for the tax, while 3,537,278 voted against it. A recount was almost certain in what has been dubbed the "Marlboro vs. Meat head" battle, pitting tobacco companies against a coalition led by Rob Reiner, the actor whose character in the "All in the Family" television series was nicknamed Meathead.
In other votes, Michigan residents rejected a proposal to legalize doctor-assisted suicide, and South Carolinians chose to remove a 103-year-old passage in their Constitution that forbids marriage between a white and a black. The United States Supreme Court has already found it to be unenforceable.
In Iowa, voters agreed to add the phrase "and women" to the constitutional guarantee that all men "are, by nature, free and equal, and have certain inalienable rights." Floridians voted solidly to let counties impose waiting periods on firearms sold at gun shows. And voters in Massachusetts and California rejected efforts to block deregulation of the electric utility industry.
In what is perhaps a reflection of Americans' positive perceptions about the economy, voters approved a record total of $20 billion in bond measures for schools and infrastructure projects like water and sewer line improvements. Sports stadiums in Denver, San Diego and Cincinnati were also approved.
In one of the more unusual local issues to make it to the ballot box, voters in Newport, Me., rejected an ordinance that would have punished women for publicly displaying their breasts.
The dispute began when a woman in that town got into the habit of mowing her lawn without a shirt, prompting complaints by her neighbor to the local authorities that she was violating decency laws. Maine law prohibits display of genitals or commission of sex acts in public, but town officials ruled that breasts were not genitals and that lawn mowing was not a sexual act, so they said they could not charge the woman with breaking any law. That prompted the irate neighbor to get enough signatures to put the measure on the ballot, but it failed.

Area for Slot Machines Widened
 KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Voters in Missouri decided on Tuesday to legalize slot machines on casinos floating in artificial basins, with 55 percent of the 1.54 million people who voted on it backing the measure.
Such gambling was previously restricted to riverboat casinos on the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers.
