HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
From Garage for 'Taxi' on TV to Condos

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
Amid a streetscape of brownstones in the historic district of the West Village, a seven-story condominium building is rising where a taxi garage once stood, at the corner of Charles and Hudson Streets.
When completed by this spring, the structure will have 22 apartments, most of them two- and three-bedroom units, including penthouses. There will also be one unit with one bedroom, and one with four. 
 The apartments are to range in size from 880 to 2,400 square feet and in price from $395,000 to $1.1 million. The building, at 534 Hudson Street, will also contain 11,000 square feet of ground-level retail space and an equal amount of medical office space on the second floor.
The $20 million project, called the Kimberley, is being developed by the Stillman Organization of Manhattan and the property's owner, Sligo Realty and Service Corporation of the Bronx, which is owned by Gerald W. Cunningham. Another of Mr. Cunningham's companies owned and operated the taxi garage on the site, which served as the exterior setting for the television series "Taxi."
In the late 1980's, Sligo began securing some approvals to redevelop the property, including receiving permission from the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission in 1987. Then, the real estate recession hit and Sligo shelved its plans.
But last year, with Manhattan's housing market booming, the company sought a development partner and hammered out an agreement with the Stillman Organization, pushing the project forward, said Marc J. Freud, a principal with the RAK Group, a real estate services concern that negotiated the transaction on behalf of both companies.
Under the agreement, signed in September, the partners jointly own the site and Stillman will develop the project. They will share the proceeds of the sale of the condominiums, and Sligo will retain ownership of the commercial space, Mr. Freud said.
Over the summer, Stillman, which builds high-end single-family homes and condominium apartments in the New York metropolitan area, demolished the old garage, and in September, with all approvals and permits in hand, started constructing the condominium building. Financing is coming from the developer's own equity and a $12.5 million construction loan from China Trust Bank.
Robert Stillman, vice president at the Stillman Organization, said his company became involved with the project because it offered the chance "to develop a prime site in the West Village, where available land is scarce and the demand for housing is high and the supply is low."
One indication of that is the pace of sales at the condominium building nearing completion at 99 Jane Street. Since sales opened in May, 68 of the 84 two- to four-bedroom units have been sold for $495,000 to $965,000, according to the developer, the Rockrose Development Corporation.
There are at least three other projects, with about 60 apartments, under way, with more planned. Most of the activity is in an area west of Washington Street to West Street, which is outside the Greenwich Village Historic District. Because that area lacks the barriers to development, like height restrictions, that accompany historic-district designation, some local residents are worried that the neighborhood, known for its brownstones, loft warehouses and river views, will become crowded with tall, bulky buildings.
Community Board 2 and the Federation to Preserve the Greenwich Village Waterfront are asking that the landmarks commission create a waterfront historic district to help protect the neighborhood's character, said Ben Green, executive director of the federation, which is made up of civic and business groups.
The developers of the Kimberley, which is in the historic district, are following terms of existing approvals from the commission regarding the building's design and height. It will rise seven stories and be clad in reddish-brown brick with cast-stone details "to blend with the neighborhood," said Debra S. Kossar of Kossar & Garry Architects of Manhattan, which designed the project. The penthouse floor will be set back to lessen its visibility from the street.
The partners have made interior modifications. Among them is the elimination, for economic reasons, of a proposed underground public garage that had drawn opposition from the community board and local residents because of the additional traffic it would have brought. The original number and mix of apartments, which comprised 40 studio and one-bedroom units, was also changed to the current scale and configuration.
Larger apartments in the West Village are in short supply, said Andrew J. Gerringer, a senior vice president at Douglas Elliman, a Manhattan brokerage and the exclusive selling agent for the Kimberley. "And, with rental prices out of control and mortgage interest rates at a historic low," more people may be encouraged to buy, he said.
The price for the apartments at the Kimberley is expected to average $450 a square foot, which is on par with the area, Mr. Stillman said. A typical 1,400-square-foot two-bedroom unit will cost about $630,000.
All the apartments have fireplaces and separate bedroom suites; many have balconies or private terraces. Amenities include a concierge, a landscaped rear terrace on the third floor and private storage cubicles. Monthly maintenance fees, excluding taxes, will be $407 to $1,077.
Mr. Stillman said he was under contract to buy tax certificates under New York City's 421a tax certificate program, which would phase in property taxes over 10 years, making the apartments more competitive. Without the abatement, for example, taxes on a two-bedroom unit would be $614 a month; with the abatement, they would be $50.
Sales are expected to start in January, with occupancy to begin in June.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Growth in Jobs SlowedSharply Last Month

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
The United States economy is still expanding, but much more slowly than in the first half of the year.
The Labor Department -- reporting on October a day ahead of schedule after some data were accidentally posted on a department Internet site -- said that employers added just 116,000 workers to their payrolls last month, the unemployment rate held steady at 4.6 percent and the hourly pay of most workers inched up slightly. 
 Though the department also said that it had badly underestimated job growth in September -- revising its initial estimate to 157,000 jobs from 59,000 -- the labor market looked weaker in October than forecasters had expected. Gains in the services and construction sectors were offset by deep cuts by manufacturers that are bearing the brunt of global economic turmoil.
"The markets for at least two weeks have been sending a very clear message that the economy is slowing but will not lapse into recession," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany. "The jobs data are very consistent with that message."
After digesting the details of the report, which was officially released in full at 1:30 P.M., stock investors focused on the positive implications; the Dow Jones industrial average ended the day up 132.33 points.
The good news is that the labor market, still very tight by any historical measure, is not getting any tighter, leaving the door open, at least in principle, to further interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. At the same time, the job market has not unraveled. Job security and income growth are crucial to consumer spending, currently the economy's sole source of strength.
"The pattern is the same as for the past few months," said Tom Nardone, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "Payroll growth is tailing off, but not as dramatically as we feared."
Adjusting for the effect of the strike against the General Motors Corporation during the summer, which cut employment in July and bolstered it in August, payrolls have risen an average of 148,000 a month in the last three months compared with an average of 247,000 a month in the first seven months of the year. That is the slowest pace in the last three years.
The dichotomy between the industrial sector and the rest of the economy, evident since the Asian crisis first hit last winter, widened further in October. While the sprawling services sector added 154,000 jobs and construction payrolls expanded by 19,000, manufacturers cut employment by 52,000 jobs.
The biggest losses were in clothing and textiles, which lost 18,000 jobs, and in electronics, which lost 12,000. But there were many smaller declines scattered across industries from machinery to metals. Within manufacturing, Detroit was the only bright spot: Auto makers, which are still scrambling to keep up with strong demand and to rebuild inventories depleted by the G.M. strike, added 7,000 workers.
Nearly 200,000 manufacturing jobs have disappeared since March, an important reason that consumers have begun to get nervous about the global economic outlook. John A. Challenger, whose outplacement firm, Challenger, Gray & Christmas, tracks layoff announcements, said that the cuts could be attributed largely to mergers, cost pressures and low oil prices.
Companies announced -- though did not yet carry out -- 73,000 job cuts in September and 91,000 in October, many in the oil, metals, electronics and telecommunications sectors. Last month, the three biggest cutbacks were announced by the Halliburton Company and Schlumberger Ltd., two oil-services companies, and the Bell Atlantic Corporation.
"These were kinds of numbers we were seeing in 1993 at the peak of the downsizing wave," Mr. Challenger said. His layoff figures had been running as little as 20,000 a month as recently as last fall.
Hiring in the services sector picked up last month, though the pace did not match that of earlier this year. Computer and other business services, which had been down in September, added 58,000 jobs. Work at temporary-help companies rose by 21,000 positions, but the levels were still below the peak set in June.
As businesses turned to outsiders for advice, computer, engineering and management services kept hiring; employment grew by 13,000. And so did financial-services companies, which added 18,000 jobs, a large part in mortgage banking, after no growth in September.
"We'd create more jobs if we could find the workers," said Bill Dunkelberg, chief economist of the Federation of Independent Business. That organization's monthly survey of small businesses, which was also released yesterday, shows that 32 percent of its members still had openings that they could not fill.
Total hours worked, a rough indicator of the growth of the nation's gross domestic product, edged up two-tenths of 1 percent, suggesting that output as well as employment expanded in October. In an anomaly -- given the sharp drop in employment -- total hours worked rose in manufacturing as well.
Hourly earnings, meanwhile, barely edged up, rising by a penny, to $12.89. If the numbers are to be believed, wage inflation is slowing. The 12-month increases, which peaked at 4.4 percent in June, were down to 3.6 percent.
Most economists, however, consider this series less reliable than the Labor Department's broader employment cost index, which indicates that wage inflation rose during the summer.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Early Report Roils Markets, But Stocks Post Gains
The premature release by the Labor Department of sensitive job figures caused a rally in the bond market, whipsawing traders who had bet on bond declines ahead of the Government's auction of $10 billion in 30-year Treasuries. They had hoped to distribute the new supply of bonds before the release of the job report that had been scheduled for today. The rally later retreated, and the yield on the 30-year bond finished at 5.34 percent, up from 5.32 percent. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, down as much as 68 points in late morning, rebounded smartly, setting the pace for other gauges with a gain of 132.33 points, or 1.51 percent, to 8,915.47. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 15.18 points, or 1.36 percent, to 1,133.85. The Nasdaq rose 13.53 points, or seven-tenths of a percent. Page C9.
 
The New York Stock Exchange loosened the curbs on computer trading that take effect when the market shifts quickly. C10.

California became the first state to require cars, minivans and nearly all sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks to meet identical and much more stringent emissions rules, despite strong objections by auto makers. C2.

Steelmakers asked the Clinton Administration to cut off the import of extremely low-cost steel, much of it originating from the economically distressed countries of Brazil, Russia and South Korea that depend on America's huge market. After a slew of European interest-rate reductions, the Bank of England ordered a larger-than-expected cut in a key rate, half a percentage point, to 6.75 percent. It was the second reduction in a month, reflecting heightened anxiety over slower economic growth both in Britain and abroad. C3.

HEADLINE: California to Toughen Its Emissions Standards

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Despite strong objections from Detroit's Big Three auto makers, environmental regulators in California voted tonight to require cars, minivans and nearly all sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks to meet identical and much more stringent emissions rules.
Tonight's vote makes California the first state to impose car emissions standards on so-called light trucks, a category that includes sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks. Regulated as work vehicles, light trucks have been allowed until now to emit up to three times as much pollution per mile as cars. 
 The Environmental Protection Agency is working on new emissions rules that, like the new California regulations, would start with the 2004 model year.
Auto makers and environmentalists lobbied California regulators with particular zeal because the E.P.A. is widely expected to follow the outlines of California's models, although possibly with slightly higher limits on some emissions because the rest of the country tends to have cleaner air.
The California Air Resources Board, which regulates the state's air quality, not only approved a staff proposal for stricter standards but actually made it even tougher by eliminating a clause that would have allowed diesel-powered cars and light trucks to meet less strict rules.
All of Detroit's Big Three and several foreign auto makers are working on fuel-efficient diesel engines for their sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks so they can meet Federal fuel-economy regulations while continuing to make these vehicles bigger and bigger.
Requiring diesel vehicles to meet the same rules as gasoline-powered vehicles "makes it extremely difficult to market a diesel vehicle in California," said Richard Varenchik, a spokesman for the air resources board.
Detroit's Big Three auto makers -- the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation -- had agreed with state regulators that minivans, midsized sport utility vehicles like the Jeep Cherokee and midsized pickups like the Ford Ranger should start to meet car pollution standards. They objected strongly but unsuccessfully to the California regulators' decision to apply car pollution standards as well to full-sized pickup trucks like the Dodge Ram and full-sized sport utility vehicles like the Cadillac Escalade and Chevrolet Tahoe.
These big vehicles have much larger engines that are designed to haul heavy loads and pull trailers, and tend to pollute more than cars.
Auto makers here were dismayed by tonight's unanimous decision by the air board's 11 members.
"Make no mistake, this is going to be really difficult," said Sara Tatchio, a spokeswoman for Ford. Full-sized sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks sold in California may become less powerful, with less capacity to haul freight or trailers, as a result of today's decision, she said.
Regulators calculated that the cost of complying with the new rules would be $96 to $304 for each vehicle, but the auto makers warned that the cost could be far higher for full-sized sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks. The very largest pickup trucks, as well as four-wheel-drive Chevrolet Suburbans and even bigger sport utility vehicles that Ford will introduce next year, will qualify for less stringent rules.
The new rules do not require any further regulatory or legislative action before taking effect, but could be challenged in court, although auto makers have historically avoided doing so. It takes two to five years to make significant alterations in automobile designs, so auto makers can seldom afford to wait for the result of a lengthy court battle before beginning to make the changes.
Today's vote will force drastic reductions in pollution from full-sized sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks. The new rules will require, for example, that cars only emit a quarter of their current output of nitrogen oxides, which are thought to be an important contributor to smog. By requiring full-sized sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks to meet the new car standards, instead of continuing to be allowed to emit three times as much, California is asking that nitrogen oxide emissions from these vehicles be cut to one-twelfth of their current levels.
Cars and light trucks already produce far less pollution per mile now than they did in the 1950's. But this improvement has been partly undone because there are more vehicles and they are driven farther.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Clinton Pressed for Curbs on Steel Imports

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
President Clinton came face-to-face today with the political costs of the world economic crisis, meeting with steel executives and union leaders who are demanding that Washington cut off the import of extremely low-cost steel -- much of it from Brazil, Russia and South Korea.
Steel imports into the United States have surged by more than 75 percent in recent months, and the United Steelworkers of America, a union the White House cannot afford to antagonize after it helped mobilize Democratic votes on Tuesday, has been insisting for months that the Administration take action. 
 Almost all the country's major steelmakers, which have staged a remarkable comeback in recent years, are now starting to cut production, and some have begun layoffs as prices for steel decline to some of the lowest levels in six years.
But Mr. Clinton, as one of his economic aides said the other day, has "no good options." Any move to limit the flow of low-cost steel here runs the risk of undercutting the recovery of some nations that are hardest hit by the economic crisis. Moreover, this would increase costs for auto makers, construction companies and other manufacturers -- potentially making their goods less competitive.
So in long meetings and dinners with Commerce Secretary William M. Daley and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, among others, the union officials and top executives -- who rarely find themselves on the same side of a bargaining table -- have been engaged in a detailed debate over Mr. Clinton's choices.
The most likely option is that the President would put pressure on producing countries to reduce steel exports to the United States, a step Japanese officials say they are already taking. At the White House meeting this evening, Mr. Clinton indicated he would take up the issue this month, during an Asian trip.
Eventually, Washington could raise tariffs on imported steel. But it could only impose those "anti-dumping duties" if the United States International Trade Commission found that the imported steel was being sold here at unfairly low prices, causing injury to American companies. Such duties were recently imposed on stainless steel coil plate imported from Taiwan, South Africa, Italy, Canada and South Korea.
But in the broader complaint by the steel industry, the case may not be clear-cut. Foreign officials insist that some of the price cuts did not result from dumping, but were made possible by the sharp devaluation of Asian and Russian currencies. That exchange-rate advantage makes all goods imported from those countries less expensive in the United States.
In fact, the surge in exports from the hardest-hit countries is exactly what the International Monetary Fund has tacitly been seeking as a way to increase foreign-currency reserves and rescue faltering economies. Export increases are factored into the I.M.F.'s recovery plans for several nations, especially Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia.
Mr. Clinton acknowledged the problem at a meeting with steel officials last month, noting that "the yen got too weak, and it led, for example, to the breathtaking imports of Japanese steel, which hurt a lot of our industry, people and workers." But aides said that after further study, they found the problem to be immensely complicated -- and that every proposed solution carried a significant cost. "If you take measures to protect the steel industry, it hurts the auto industry," a White House official said recently. "Eventually, that hurts sales and other workers."
The industry argues that the damage is already starting. Weirton Steel, the seventh-largest producer, has said recently that it is laying off 300 workers, or nearly 9 percent of its hourly work force, and that it may have to dismiss more people.
The Clinton Administration needs the steelworkers. Vice President Al Gore has been wooing the industry's leaders, who are suspicious of the Administration's free-trade policies, and opposed the effort to expand the President's right to negotiate trade agreements on a "fast track" basis. Arguments on that are likely to be revived next year.
One measure of the political resonance of the issue came in the attendance at tonight's session in the Cabinet Room. In addition to Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore, those who joined the meeting included Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, Secretary Rubin, Secretary Daley and the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky. The steel industry officials included Curtis H. Barnette, chief executive of Bethlehem Steel, Paul Wilhelm of U.S. Steel, and George Becker, president of the United Steelworkers.
Mr. Becker has insisted on quotas limiting the import of foreign steel; the industry officials have not publicly joined him in calling for that action. But all of them, a participant in the meeting said, pressed for quick action. Mr. Clinton made no commitments.

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
Labor Fight Becoming a Falk-Stern Clash

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
Keith Glass recalled the time a few years ago when David Falk was talking about how Michael Jordan needed to be financially rewarded by the Chicago Bulls. As a low-profile agent who represents a much more modest clientele than the agent Falk, Glass finally interjected.
"After a while I couldn't take it," Glass said. "I mean, I'm the anti-David. I represent different kinds of players. He was talking about Michael getting paid. I told him I have a Michael, too. Michael Peplowski. That's the player I'm worried about." 
 Now that David Stern, the National Basketball Association commissioner, has accused Falk of trying to detonate an agreement between owners and players that would end the league's lockout, Falk's power and potential influence have become an issue in the negotiations.
Stern's claim, that Falk is looking out for his prominent clients while ignoring the N.B.A.'s eroding middle class, was seen by the union as an attempt to form a chasm between the Jordans and the Peplowskis.
After saying he didn't take Stern's comments personally Wednesday, Falk shot back yesterday.
"This is a wake-up call for the players, because this is exactly what the league did three years ago and the players fell for it three years ago," Falk said. "They fell for the fact that the league was saying the agents were only trying to protect the top 30 or 40 players.
"If the mass of players listens to that tired saw David Stern is using again, they're going to be even more disadvantaged than they were three years ago."
Replied Stern: "There is a deal on the table, and David Falk is trying to kill it. Is that for the betterment for mankind? I don't think so."
The salvos fired back and forth between the game's most powerful agent and its omnipotent commissioner have been indicative of recent negotiations: a lot of posturing and little progress. A union official said a meeting between the chief negotiators on both sides is scheduled for today in Manhattan; the union has told the N.B.A. it hopes to forward a new proposal to the league office by early next week.
It appears nothing will prevent the league from losing its fifth week of games to labor strife; after canceling the rest of November last week, league officials said that every week a deal was not signed would mean another week of games canceled.
Until headway is made through a bargaining session, the season is on hold. At the center of the talks is an escrow system proposed by the owners that would give money back to the teams if the players' share of income reached an agreed-upon threshold. Economic divide is regarded as the main issue. But there are egos involved, too.
"I don't run the union, but I certainly want to have influence because of my clients," Falk said.
"I'm like a congressman. And my district is Ewing, Jordan, etc. But I also have people in my district named Jaren Jackson and Rex Chapman, and I have to make sure the rules protect all of them. Ewing and Jordan are paying me enough lobbying fees to make sure the less-advantaged people in my district are taken care of."
Stern said in response: "If David has suddenly became a man of the people, then he should love the N.B.A. owners' proposal. I'll assume he will join me in applauding the proposal that benefits 80 percent of the constituents that he says he represents."
Glass and Falk, along with Mark Bartelstein and Arn Tellem, whom Stern also mentioned by name as being a divisive force in negotiations, met yesterday with the union's executive director, Billy Hunter. Also present were Patrick Ewing of the Knicks, the players association president, and union lawyers.
A union official said the meeting was planned before the week's charges and countercharges developed, but nonetheless it made for interesting subject matter beyond the economic issues.
"I don't agree with a lot of what David Falk believes," Glass said, "but this is clearly a campaign to drive a wedge between us."
Publicly, the league's 400-plus players have been unified, but there is a feeling of angst developing on both sides.
"It's too bad," Glass said, "but I don't see anything happening quick."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
FERTILIZER COMPANY SAYS IT WILL ELIMINATE 530 JOBS

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
IMC Global Inc., one of the world's largest fertilizer companies, said yesterday that it would cut 530 jobs, or about 5.9 percent of its work force, as part of a drive to reduce costs, increase profit and accelerate growth. IMC will immediately begin to cut 180 jobs, primarily at its phosphate operations and administrative offices, through a combination of dismissals and early retirement. An additional 350 positions will be cut in the next nine months as IMC shuts plants and mining operations in Florida and Louisiana. IMC, which had 1997 sales of about $3 billion, said the moves were part of a revamping started in September. IMC, based in Northbrook, Ill., had about 8,950 employees as of the end of last year.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1261 words

HEADLINE: U.N., Avoiding Talk of Force, Criticizes Iraq on Arms Team

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 5

 BODY:
The Security Council voted unanimously today to condemn Iraq and demand that President Saddam Hussein rescind his ban on cooperation with United Nations arms inspectors. But the Council stopped short of authorizing or even mentioning the use of force to back its demand.
The resolution, making formal the outrage first expressed by Council members on Saturday after Iraq effectively shut down the arms monitoring system, comes in the face of reports that the United States may be preparing for military action against Iraq. 
 President Clinton tonight called on Iraq to comply immediately with United Nations demands, saying its refusal was unacceptable. Mr. Clinton also emphasized that "all options are on the table" for the Administration, including military action.
American officials argue that they already have ample authority to attack Iraq under previous resolutions, and today the Clinton Administration moved ahead with preparations for air strikes, Administration and Western officials said. Page A8 .
But several Council members warned against that course.
Russia's representative, Sergey Lavrov, who said that his Government had been lobbying Iraq to change its policy, added that the only way out of the impasse was through diplomatic and political means. Nothing in today's measure "could be interpreted arbitrarily as a kind of permission to use force," he said.
"Any attempt to resolve the problem by using force," Mr. Lavrov went on, "would entail highly unpredictable and dangerous consequences both for the capacity of the United Nations to continue to monitor proscribed military activities in Iraq and for peace and stability in the region and in the Middle East as a whole."
Brazil's representative, Celso Luiz Nunes Amorim, said in an interview on Wednesday that there was a sense among a number of Council members that Iraq's noncompliance was not enough to provoke military action. "If they did some physical damage or expelled everybody, that would be different," he said.
But today the Brazilian and Russian representatives joined a stream of speakers expressing frustration and anger over Mr. Hussein's seemingly self-destructive move, given the diplomatic strides Iraq made earlier in the year. Several diplomats speculated that the Iraqi President may be more out of touch or under strain than outsiders thought.
The resolution comes under a section of the United Nations charter that makes it enforceable by military action. But there is typically a challenge to that view, especially when the resolution does not explicitly threaten military force.
 For a year Iraq has been stepping up pressure for the lifting of sanctions imposed after its invasion of Kuwait in August 1990, and the Council repeatedly said this would not happen until Baghdad answered all outstanding questions on its weapons programs. Last week the Iraqi leadership said it had run out of patience.
Alain Dejammet, the French representative, said that the only way to make progress "toward lifting sanctions from which the Iraqi people are suffering is for Iraq to rescind without delay the unjustifiable measures of Oct. 31."
France withdrew its charge d'affaires from Baghdad today to protest the Iraqi bans.
Iraq first cut back cooperation with arms inspectors on Aug. 5, then said on Saturday that it would end all dealings with the United Nations Special Commission, known as Unscom, while allowing the International Atomic Energy Agency to continue some of its work.
Today Unscom officials reviewed the status of their staff in Baghdad, where only maintenance work on monitoring equipment has been permitted. Charles Duelfer, deputy executive chairman of the commission, said in an interview that perhaps up to 20 of about 120 people might be withdrawn over the next few days. They would include a visiting team sent to observe Iraqi missile tests and some members of regular monitoring teams who are not needed since inspection and monitoring activities have been frozen.
The American threat is being taken seriously among Arab leaders, who have urged Baghdad to rethink its harsh stand against inspections. A letter from the Arab League to Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, President Hussein's spokesman on the inspection issue, urged the Iraqis to adopt a "flexible" position, the league's representative at the United Nations said today.
"We're very concerned about an escalation and the use of force to settle this problem," said the envoy, Hussein Hassouna. "It would be better to negotiate, to convince the Iraqis to cooperate." Mr. Hassouna said that Arab nations feared that the whole region could be unsettled by another battering of Iraq.
Today's resolution restates the Council's support for the Special Commission, which has been under constant attack by the Iraqi leadership, which wants it restructured and its chairman, Richard Butler, replaced.
But there has been little or no discussion in a week of debate about how to insure that meaningful inspections take place again if Iraq lifts its ban. During months of confrontations with Iraq, arms experts have seen the inspections panel, created both to disarm Iraq and to prevent it from rearming, get whittled down with each crisis.
Getting the inspectors back to work, these experts say, will require more than a return to the status quo before August, when spot inspections were barred.
The inspectors, from the United Nations Special Commission, will have to be strengthened, in this view. Despite American protests, these arms experts and some members of the Council say this strengthening does not appear to be high on the American agenda.
American diplomats insist that American policy has not changed. But comments in recent months from Administration officials in Washington reflect a preference for maintaining tight sanctions with the unified backing of the Security Council, rather than risking a rupture of the common front by forcing an intrusive policing of arms programs.
The common front has maintained tough sanctions on Iraq's oil sales, other aspects of its economy and such things as travel to the country.
But arms experts worry that without strict vigilance, Iraq would try to rebuild its arsenal. David Albright, president of the independent Institute for Science and International Security in Washington, said, "My sense is that the U.S. Government thinks that sanctions alone can do the job," of keeping Iraq isolated and preventing it from being a danger internationally. But in his view, full inspections are essential.
Mr. Albright, a former inspector in Iraq for the International Atomic Energy Agency, said the atomic energy agency and Unscom are at the critical juncture, between disarming Iraq and setting up a system of long-term monitoring to prevent President Hussein from rearming.
Noting Iraq's stepped-up interference with monitoring activities and its rejection of on-the-spot inspections, arms experts say the value of remote inspection systems seems to have diminished considerably. The remote inspections involve 135 video cameras in 20 locations and air, soil and water sensors and sniffers.
William Scott Ritter, an American specialist in Iraqi concealment methods who resigned from Unscom in August to protest what he said was a muzzling of inspectors, called the monitoring system "a joke." In an interview on Tuesday, he said that many cameras were placed haphazardly and hurriedly in stationary positions in storage areas or production plants, some watching machine tools.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Risking Life, Limb and Capital;
U.S. Companies Operate in Colombia, but Very Carefully

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia

 BODY:
The note was scrawled on a scrap of paper and thrust at a truck driver for a United States oil company stopped on a rebel-held highway to the eastern plains of Colombia recently. "Please do us the favor of coming to talk to us, so we can reach agreements allowing you to work without problems," the note said. "If you do not come, we will not be responsible for the consequences."
The company passed the extortion demand, penned in oddly formal, misspelled Spanish, to Colombian military intelligence. Executives at the multinational concern, who asked that the company not be identified, did not give in to insurgents, but ordered their drivers to skirt the area by taking other roads. 
 The company could alter its routes and still conduct business, said Enrique Urrea, head of a committee of security chiefs for United States multinationals operating in Colombia. "Not everybody can," he added.
A Colombian soft drink manufacturer, defying similar demands from the insurgents, had 54 of its trucks burned. In September, the rebels kidnapped three drivers and executed one to put pressure on the company. "If they give up a road, they lose a market," Mr. Urrea said. He asked that the company not be named, saying publicity could endanger the lives of the remaining hostages.
Though the new Government of Andres Pastrana seeks peace talks with the country's three rebel movements in an effort to end three decades of civil war, Colombia remains one of the riskiest places in the world to do business. Threats to foreigners come from random street crimes, kidnappers, extortion, vandalism and sudden roadblocks thrown up by rebel factions vying for power.
Half of all reported kidnappings in the world happen in Colombia; 806 occurred in the first half of this year and 1,693 last year, the Presidential Anti-Kidnapping Office says. More people are murdered in this nation of 36 million than in the entire United States, which has nearly eight times the population. In 1996, the last year for which figures are available, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported 19,645 homicides; in Colombia, there were 26,627.
While the central Government holds Bogota and the larger cities, the countryside is fragmenting into a collection of fiefs controlled by rebels or by right-wing paramilitaries that terrorize peasants, often in collusion with army officers and the police. Foreign businesses are particularly vulnerable to kidnappings and extortion and kickback demands from the rebels. Security costs, which average 4 percent of a company's operating costs in the rest of the developing world, can run up to 10 percent here, security experts and company executives say.
Despite the limitations and risks, a variety of United States companies have opened offices and factories in Colombia, particularly since the country acted in the early 1990's to lower trade barriers and otherwise open the economy to foreign investment. They include Occidental Petroleum, Procter & Gamble, Colgate-Palmolive, Kellogg, DuPont and Citigroup.
Some businesses have left, but those that stay in Colombia have learned to protect their interests. To discourage kidnappings, they employ Colombian executives and use local contractors. They hire such multinational security services as Control Risks Group and Defense Systems Ltd., both based in London; the Ackerman Group of Miami, and the Kroll-O'Gara Company, in New York, to tailor security packages for their executives, installations and trade secrets.
Insurance companies, sometimes working directly with protection services, often demand strict security precautions from United States executives in Colombia, said Joseph A. Finnin, head of the American Chamber of Commerce here. One insisted that not only an oil company president but also his wife use bodyguards and armored cars.
The security services also analyze the risks of doing business with a given Colombian company, perusing court records for potential legal or tax problems. Earlier this fall, Kroll-O'Gara bought a factory for making armored cars in Colombia, said Bruce Goslin, a managing director of the company's office in Miami.
Because of security worries, foreigners largely confine themselves to a small, safe piece of this grimy, bustling city. They take apartments on the upper floors instead of houses, and only in the priciest neighborhoods. They vary routes, switching vehicles and vetting maids, nannies and gardeners with a thoroughness J. Edgar Hoover might have envied. And they fly, rather than drive, if they must leave Bogota.
Oil companies pay a special war tax to the Government, and they contract with the Defense Ministry for special army platoons to protect oil exploration and production sites or dangerous highways. As threats to their business escalate, foreign companies are sharing security information and tightening their lines of communication with Colombia's military intelligence service.
Through the committee that Mr. Urrea heads, the chiefs of security for 65 of the largest companies in Colombia, most of them from the United States, are in constant contact through beepers that flash bulletins. Mr. Urrea heads security operations for Esso, the Colombian subsidiary of Exxon. On one recent day, his beeper warned of a strike by 700,000 civil servants that was paralyzing roads, telecommunications, hospitals and airports.
The Colombian military sends the committee daily intelligence reports and other information, while the police provide financial profiles of potential or actual employees. "If there's no information, there's no power," Mr. Urrea said.
For Armando Lara, a former F.B.I. officer who heads Latin American operations for Control Risks, that maxim was vividly illustrated a few years ago. Running late to a meeting with a military commander in charge of eastern Colombia, Mr. Lara flipped on the radio to hear that the commander had been killed when his car exploded a few minutes earlier. If Mr. Lara had known security was so volatile in the area, he would have avoided going there, he said.
But more information means maintaining close ties to military and police forces that have a record of chronic human rights abuses. According to Government investigators and human rights groups, army and police officers have colluded with the right-wing paramilitaries, which roam the countryside, terrorizing and massacring peasants.
Last summer, the 20th Intelligence Brigade, which supplied information to every branch of the military, was disbanded, with numerous officers facing criminal charges of running death squads and carrying out political assassinations. For more than a year, the State Department has been combing the human rights files of the Colombian Army, seeking units with clean records to receive aid to combat narcotics. But the human rights problems are so pervasive that only one unit has been cleared, and another had to be created fresh, culling officers and soldiers with unblemished records from scattered units.
Mr. Urrea said that most security chiefs working in the private sector are retired military officers like him who have access to the most senior officers in the Colombian military command.
"As far as I know, they are honest, but there are exceptional cases where a person, in his impotence before the situation we're living through, commits excesses and violates human rights," he said. " But that's the exception, not the rule."
Security chiefs and security firms have also been involved in negotiating ransoms, which are technically illegal in Colombia. In a famous case, Control Risks negotiated for the wife of a BASF chemical company executive, Alvaro Uribe Velez, the former governor of Antioquia province, said in an interview at the time. The hostage, Brigitte Schone, was eventually released when a German spy couple, Werner and Isabel Mauss, elbowed Control Risks aside and paid rebels a ransom of $1.5 million -- 10 times the amount the company had bargained the ransom down to. The case set off an international incident when the Mausses were briefly arrested trying to leave the country with the freed hostage, using false passports provided by the German Government. Control Risks declined to comment on the case.
(In the latest illustration of the shadowy ties that run Colombia, the Mausses emerged last summer as behind-the-scenes figures arranging peace talks in Germany between the rebels and Colombian business and church representatives.)
It is also illegal to pay extortion in Colombia. Most large United States companies do not surrender to extortion, Mr. Lara of Control Risks said, but added, "So many have a policy of subcontracting to Colombian firms, and Colombians feel, especially operating in rural areas, that they've got to pay to keep themselves safe."
The most costly threat to foreign businesses has been attacks on oil pipelines. The attacks have not ceased even as the Government prepares to open talks with the largest insurgent group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, in an effort to end the civil war, which last year claimed 2,183 lives, human rights groups say.
Nestor Martinez, Interior Minister in the new Government, acknowledged that lack of security is a serious hindrance to doing business in Colombia. "Of course, we have problems, like all other developing countries," he said, "but we're dealing with them, and we're beginning peace talks with the guerrillas."
Of the four major American oil companies working here-- Exxon, Amoco, Chevron and Occidental Petroleum -- perhaps no company has been more battered by the instability than Occidental. Oxy Colombia, as the company's local office is known, pumps 160,000 barrels a day of crude from its complex at Cano Limon, near the Venezuelan border.
So far this year, rebels have blown up the pipeline 61 times. Last year, rebels bombed the pipeline 64 times and started striking closer to home, at the wellheads.
The rebels collect a 10 percent commission from contractors hired to repair the pipeline and wellheads, said Robert Stewart, a spokesman for Occidental.
"We're getting clobbered," he acknowledged. "It used to be the guerrillas would do their attacks and run. They're not even scrambling anymore. Now, they sit around after, have a cup of coffee and wait for the army to show up."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 14, 1998, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Nov. 6 about the dangers of doing business in Colombia described the kidnapping of the wife of a BASF chemical company executive and negotiations on her behalf by Control Risks Group, a multinational security service. The former governor of Antioquia province said that the hostage, Brigitte Schone, was eventually released after Control Risks was elbowed aside by Werner and Isabel Mauss, a German couple, who paid a ransom of $1.5 million.
In fairness, The Times should have sought a response from Mr. and Mrs. Mauss, who deny this account. They have since said that they became involved in the incident after the Colombian Government sought German help in connection with peace negotiations with a rebel guerrilla movement. But the couple said that they had no role in the payment of any ransom and that the hostage-takers were common criminals, not anti-Government rebels.
The article also referred incorrectly to Mr. and Mrs. Mauss's detention. They were held in jail for nine months, not briefly arrested. All charges against them have been dropped.

HEADLINE: Pace of Consumer Credit Rose in September

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Borrowing by United States consumers rose in September at a pace that was faster than expected as credit card debt and personal loans accelerated, according to Federal Reserve figures released today.
Borrowing rose $8.4 billion, to $1.282 trillion, after rising $4.4 billion in August. Analysts had expected a September increase of $4.7 billion. 
 The September pace of borrowing is close to the monthly average for the last five years of $7.7 billion.
Still, the Government reported that consumers spent more than they earned in September, which may point to a further increase in borrowing in coming months, as consumer spending is holding up in advance of the holiday buying season.
Economists watch the consumer credit data to help them gauge changes in consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of the gross domestic product.
Revolving loans, which include credit cards, increased $3.1 billion in September after rising $2.2 billion in August. Auto loans rose $1.9 billion in September after increasing $3.8 billion in August. Other types of installment loans increased $3.4 billion after falling $1.4 billion in August.
Consumer credit rose at a 7.9 percent annual rate during September. That was up from the 4.2 percent pace of new borrowing in August. The credit increase in August was revised down from the Fed's earlier estimate of a gain of $4.6 billion.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Banks Grow Cautious On Scope of Aid to Brazil

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
With a $30 billion international rescue package for Brazil nearing completion, American banks, already battered by global financial turmoil, are sitting on the sidelines. Only a few weeks ago, some United States bankers, including those with the Chase Manhattan Corporation, talked openly about the possibility of bolstering the lending efforts of agencies like the International Monetary Fund by adding their own funds to any rescue package.
But banks now say they will wait for Brazil -- a far more important country to most of them than, for example, Indonesia, South Korea, or Russia -- to ask for more money before any is offered. 
 "The initiative for any private money will have to come from Brazil," said a senior American banker who requested anonymity. "I think Brazil will want to wait and see what the $30 billion credit line does to their costs in the sovereign debt markets before they make another move."
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin has argued in recent weeks that any aid to Brazil has to include money from the private sector -- lest banks and other investors benefit from a bailout without suffering for any undue risks they took in Brazil. For their part, bankers face the wrath of their shareholders and regulators if they throw good money after bad.
Lingering questions remain about the ability of the Brazilian President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, to invigorate the country's economy.
Under the circumstances, until Brazil's spending plans gain further momentum and the economic picture becomes clearer, investors are likely to remain cautious about the country. The United States banks are adopting a wait-and-see attitude.
"I believe there will be an agreement between Brazil and the I.M.F. sometime next week and immediately thereafter I believe the Brazilian Government plans a road show in the United States, Europe and Japan to discuss the country's economic programs," said William Rhodes, head of risk management for Citigroup.
A great deal is at stake for the United States financial institutions. Compared with exposure of $6.8 billion to Russia, and $44.6 billion to all Asian borrowers, United States banks had about $27.3 billion in loans and other financial exposure to Brazil as of June 30, according to Brown Brothers Harriman & Company. While more current aggregate figures are not available, the biggest United States banks in Brazil released updated information about their exposures at the end of September -- and most of them showed a sharp decline since June.
Chase has $3.8 billion in exposure to Brazil, down from $4.3 billion at the end of June; J. P. Morgan has $2.2 billion, down from $4 billion; BankAmerica has $3.3 billion, down from $3.9 billion, and BankBoston has less than $1 billion, down from $1.7 billion. Citigroup, recently formed by the merger of Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc., said it had $4.4 billion in Brazilian exposure in June but does not have more current figures. Both Citigroup and BankBoston also have large local operations in Brazil that make them the most heavily involved United States banks in the country.
"I think banks are steeling themselves for a currency devaluation," said Diane Glossman of Lehman Brothers Inc. "Mutual funds and investment banks also have a big stake in the outcome and to expect that it's appropriate for the banks to take on the responsibilities for all of these other investors is wrong."
"This is not 1982," Ms. Glossman added, referring to a time when banks were the only big investors in Latin America.
Unfortunately, any bailout package for Brazil -- with or without backing from the private sector -- may only prove to be a stopgap measure given the crushing debt schedule the country faces. Brazil has more than $150 billion in short-term debt with an average maturity of about eight months -- a huge amount of money for any country to pay back so quickly.
"If the question is $30 billion versus $35 billion, I don't think it will make a difference anyway," said Morris Goldstein, a former I.M.F. official and a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "It might look nice, but the debt payments confronting Brazil go well beyond anything $35 billion will do."
Brazil is also wrestling with having to pay interest rates of 40 percent to keep dollars from fleeing the country. While about $2 billion to $3 billion a week was being taken out of the country in recent weeks, analysts said that has now been offset by fresh funds coming in, meaning that the net capital flow is currently flat.
But the Government, with central bank reserves having dropped to about $40 billion from $70 billion over the last two months, cannot maintain sky-high interest rates indefinitely.
Ricardo Gallo, BankBoston's head of emerging markets trading and investment banking, said: "I think Brazil has about 30 to 60 days, given its current level of reserves, to work out its problems out. After that, the situation could get very bad."

HEADLINE: Disputed 'Lolita' Spinoff Is Dropped by Publisher

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
In an abrupt reversal that ends a tangled legal and literary confrontation, Farrar, Straus & Giroux said yesterday that it had canceled plans to publish a retelling of "Lolita" from the nymphet's point of view, in part because of copyright concerns by some of the publishing house's own writers.
The estate of Vladimir Nabokov filed suit in Federal court last month to block American and British publication of the book, "Lo's Diary," by Pia Pera, an Italian short-story writer, calling it a "rip-off" of the legally protected original, published in 1955. The new novel, in the form of a diary by Lolita giving her version of the scandalous love affair with her stepfather, has been published to mixed reviews in Italy and six other countries. 
 The lawsuit, which Farrar, Straus & Giroux contested and has now agreed to settle, raised far-reaching questions that lawyers said had never been resolved by the courts, including the degree to which a character in a copyrighted literary work can be reused by another author.
Ms. Pera, reached in Italy, said she deplored the decision but that she did not plan to sue.
Lawyers said it was not clear whether MacMillan, which had planned to bring out the book in Britain and was named as a co-defendant with Farrar, Straus in the lawsuit, intended to proceed with publication.
Roger W. Straus, president and chief executive of the publishing house, said he decided to cancel its planned publication next July despite objections from his editor in chief, Jonathan Galassi, in response to concerns by some of his writers that their creations could be appropriated through the same literary license claimed by Farrar, Straus.
The publishing house is now owned by Holtzbrinck, the German publishing conglomerate, but the decision against publication was made by Mr. Straus alone, all parties agreed.
Mr. Straus said he had been questioning his decision to publish "Lo's Diary" since the uproar began. " 'Is this good for literature or bad for literature?' is the question we have been asking ourselves," he said. "Are we standing up for writers and for literature by proceeding to publish Pia Pera or by acceding to the wishes of the Nabokov estate?"
In the end, he said, "I don't think it right for any publisher to feed off the reputation of a literary person." He declined to name any of the authors who had voiced concern about the planned publication.
The cancellation was welcomed by Peter L. Skolnik, a lawyer for Dmitri Nabokov, the sole heir and executor of his father's estate. "Dmitri is, of course, enormously pleased and joins me in thinking it is the right outcome for the right reasons," Mr. Skolnik said. He said the decision to sue had also been difficult because, given the history of controversy over "Lolita," "few writers have stood more for the right of free expression than Nabokov."
But the estate had to respond to what he called "esthetic and literary vampirism," Mr. Skolnick added. If the appropriation claimed by Farrar, Straus and Ms. Pera had been allowed to stand, he said, "the next author is free to say, 'Ahh, there's a good idea: I'll tell it from the perspective of a another character.' " Why would motion picture producers pay writers for their creations "if they could just change the perspective and get away with it?" he added.
Leon Friedman, a lawyer for Farrar, Straus who had been prepared to defend the book as a "fair use" and artistic transformation of Nabokov's work, called Mr. Straus's action "a literary decision."
From the Greek legend of "Pygmalion," which became a George Bernard Shaw play and then "My Fair Lady," literary characters and entire works have long been fodder for other writers but usually the works are out of copyright. "Lolita," published in the United States by Random House, is under copyright until the year 2030.
Ms. Pera, 42, reached at home in the Tuscan countryside near Lucca, said she had heard about the cancellation only hours before in a call from one of her editors. "I was disappointed," she said. "I thought they were going to fight for it. This way we will never know if we could have won."
"I feel what is at stake here are two fundamental rights clashing: property rights and the right of free expression," she said. "My book is on some kind of frontier between the two."
She said that if it were possible to secure publication by giving up any economic gain from her book, she would agree. She also said she did not intend to sue Farrar, Straus to enforce publication. The book, first published in Italy in 1995, later came out in Brazil, Spain, the Netherlands, Germany, Finland and Greece. It was also bought by a French publisher who later dropped it and turned out to be a cousin of Dmitri Nabokov, Ms. Pera said.
Mr. Skolnik said although the Nabokov estate did not sue those publishers at the time, legal action was still under consideration.
Mr. Straus's decision to cancel publication was strongly opposed by Mr. Galassi, editor in chief and executive vice president at Farrar, Straus, and by Ethan Nosowsky, the editor who worked with Mr. Galassi to prepare the manuscript for publication.
Mr. Straus said they had argued strenuously for publication but not acrimoniously. "It was an intellectual debate, not who shot John," he said.
He also said the case raised important questions that would remain unresolved, at least until another publisher came along to take up the book. "From a lawyer's point of view," Mr. Straus said, "it would have been a delicious case."

HEADLINE: Election Brings Hope

 BODY:

To the Editor:
People in the third world will celebrate the victory of Democrats in the midterm elections (editorial, Nov. 5). 
 With the global market in a recession, a strong United States President brings hope. The world needs a President like Franklin D. Roosevelt, who could start a New Deal-like program to rejuvenate the American and the world economies.
Moreover, the disputes that have outlived the cold-war era necessitate effective action from the United States.
With a President like Bill Clinton and a balanced Congress, there is a hope for the world.
 
SAQLAIN IMAM
Lahore, Pakistan, Nov. 5, 1998

HEADLINE: Closing Sweatshops

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The proposed agreement by human rights organizations and apparel manufacturers requires employers to pay the local minimum-wage rate or prevailing industry wage, whichever is higher, to workers (news article, Nov. 5). Labor unions have rightfully protested that such wage rates, determined by the brutal economic realities of supply and demand in poor countries, are not living wages. 
 Even minimum-wage rates in the United States are shamefully inadequate. The vibrant economy and the bull market have only widened the disparities in income between those at opposite ends of the pay scale. The success of big corporations has not been shared with their minimum-wage employees, without whose labor these companies could not survive.
 
MADALYN MARGOLES
New York, Nov. 6, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: A Financing Plan By Apple for New PC

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: CUPERTINO, Calif., Nov. 6

 BODY:
In a bid to pump up demand for its iMac personal computer, Apple Computer Inc. said this week that it would offer consumers a $29.99-a- month financing program to buy the iMac.
"For the price of three pizzas a month, you can own an iMac," Steve Jobs, Apple's co-founder and acting chief executive, said in a statement. 
 The iMac, which first became available in August, is the fastest-selling new product in Apple's history. It retails for around $1,300.
Apple said the financing program would require 67 monthly payments, which would total just under $1,992 when paid in full. The new plan, to be offered through participating Apple retailers and resellers, requires no money down for 120 days and charges an annual interest rate of 14.9 percent.
Apple's program will also allow customers to finance add-on products including printers, storage devices, scanners and software for the first 90 days after the purchase.
Analysts believe the initial success of the iMac has been at least partly fueled by huge pent-up demand among existing Apple Macintosh loyalists.
The financing program seems intended to expand the iMac's appeal to a wider audience, especially first-time computer buyers.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Lift Some Sanctions Against India and Pakistan

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
President Clinton will use his new authority granted by Congress to waive some sanctions on India and Pakistan because of their promises to stop nuclear testing, a senior American official said today.
The sanctions lifted are largely symbolic, but they are intended to encourage India and Pakistan to take further steps to end what is considered to be the world's most dangerous nuclear-arms race. 
 But with Pakistan teetering on economic default, the Administration will support an agreement, if one can be reached, between Islamabad and the International Monetary Fund, the official said, even though international lending comes under sanctions that are not being lifted.
This would be a single exception, the official emphasized, and would depend on Pakistan's adopting a "credible reform program" acceptable to the Fund.
Despite pressure from Washington and the other nuclear states that make up the United Nations Security Council, neither India nor Pakistan has promised to forgo deployment of nuclear weapons or to join a moratorium on the future production of fissile material for warheads. India is leaning toward the latter, because it already has a large stockpile of fissile material. But both countries have agreed to join negotiations on a fissile material cutoff in January.
After India began a round of nuclear tests on May 11, and Pakistan responded, Washington imposed sanctions under a law sponsored by Senator John Glenn of Ohio. But the Administration argued that the sanctions law gave it no flexibility to encourage better behavior by India or Pakistan, and Congress agreed. In an omnibus bill passed about two weeks ago, Mr. Clinton was given authority to waive some of the sanctions selectively, which he has decided to do, the official said.
In six rounds of discussions with the Indians and Pakistanis, "we've said that positive actions on their part in response to our nonproliferation concerns will be welcomed with positive responses on our part, and that's what we're trying to do," the official said.
At the United Nations in September, the leaders of both countries announced that they would put a moratorium on further nuclear tests and would comply with the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty by September 1999. They also agreed to work with the Americans to tighten their export controls on nuclear materials and products.
And they have also begun a dialogue, pressed by Washington, on nuclear issues and on Kashmir, the disputed territory that could be a flash point for war.
In response, Mr. Clinton will again allow India and Pakistan to take part in American investment and trade promotion programs.
Bans on sales of military equipment and hardware will remain, but Washington will resume military-to-military training programs, in part to keep its relations with the influential Pakistani military, which also runs the nuclear weapons program, as close as possible.
And India will continue to be denied access to American high-technology exports and so-called dual-use equipment that could also be used for nuclear or military purposes.
"No one wants to see Pakistan go under," the official said. "We're trying to respond to sensible steps with some of our own."

HEADLINE: When the Mind Is the Matter;
Mental Disability Cases Pose Painful Workplace Issues

BYLINE: By GEANNE ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
John Olson, an engineer at the General Electric Company, was hospitalized for depression for four months in 1991. Soon after he returned to his job at the company's astrospace unit, he was laid off in a widespread downsizing.
When a similar position at GE Astrospace, which ultimately became part of the Lockheed Martin Corporation, opened up a year later, Mr. Olson, still unemployed, applied. Although he was told, he said, that he would be recommended for the job, he did not get it. 
 Now, six years, three Federal court opinions and thousands of lawyers' hours later, Mr. Olson is finally set to go to trial. An appeals court ruled that he had a claim he was entitled to pursue -- not because he was mentally disabled under Federal law but because the company may have discriminated by treating him as if he were.
"It's a very stigmatizing thing," Mr. Olson said. "You don't want to let your co-workers know" about mental problems.
With his case scheduled for a jury trial in Federal District Court in Camden, N.J., in January, he said, he wants to make it easier "for other people who have been discriminated against for suffering from depression."
Mr. Olson's case shows just what a legal quagmire is taking shape. Until now, some plaintiffs like him have been caught in a no-win situation: they must show that they are qualified for the job in question, but when they do, courts often rule that they are not disabled.
"It's a horrific Catch-22," said Chai Feldblum, a law professor at Georgetown University Law Center who was instrumental in drafting the Americans With Disabilities Act.
But guidelines issued last year by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and a recent Supreme Court opinion could help employees escape that double bind and win more cases.
And there is an explosion of litigation. "It's one of the fastest-growing areas of employment law," said James J. McDonald Jr. of Fisher & Phillips in Newport Beach, Calif., who represents management in employment matters.
In 1992, the E.E.O.C. recorded 91 complaints of discrimination on the basis of emotional or psychiatric impairment, or 9.1 percent of all disability claims. By 1997, with the number of mental disability claims skyrocketing, that had jumped to 2,789, or 15.3 percent, making this, for the first time ever, the largest single category of claims. Complaints outnumbered those related to H.I.V., cancer, substance abuse, vision, hearing and diabetes-related disabilities combined. And preliminary numbers for the 1998 fiscal year show yet another increase.
Until now, said Susan Stefan, a professor at the University of Miami School of Law, many competent employees with mental illnesses like schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and depression had lost their cases because courts had found they were not disabled.
And Mr. Olson's lawyer, Stephen E. Klausner of Klausner, Hunter & Rosenberg in Somerville, N.J., noted: "If the patient is taking medication, you've got to make sure the dosage doesn't so adversely affect him or her that she can't do the work."
From 1992 through 1997, companies won 92 percent of all final court decisions under the Americans With Disabilities Act, said John Parry, director of the American Bar Association's Commission on Mental and Physical Disability Law. For mental disability cases, companies won even more often.
But in its new guidelines, the E.E.O.C. basically said that a mental problem could be labeled a disability even if it did not hurt a person's job performance. And the Supreme Court decision, which concerned H.I.V. discrimination, may increase employees' chances by leading courts to broaden their views of disabilities.
The new guidelines have also called attention to employees' rights and helped educate managers, said Peggy Mastroianni, associate legal counsel at the E.E.O.C. "Human resources departments now understand," she said, "that you can have a very productive worker who has a psychiatric illness -- that both things can be true."
But managing workers who appear to have mental problems is tricky business. When an employee engages in some bizarre behavior, "it can be a mine field" for employers, said Harriet E. Cooperman, head of the labor and employment law group at Weinberg & Green in Baltimore.
If a company takes any action, "it's subjecting itself to liability because the employee can turn around and claim that the employer perceives the employee as having a disability and is discriminating against the employee on that basis," Ms. Cooperman said. "Recognizing a problem and referring the employee to counseling or treatment or suggesting that they get help is the humanitarian thing to do," she said, but it can also expose the company to a lawsuit.
Thus, employee assistance programs are much more risky, said Mr. McDonald, the California lawyer. "It used to be that employers could set up programs to help employees deal with mental and emotional programs," he said. "But now we see in an increasing number of cases that E.A.P.'s are just another source of liability." His advice to employers: "Focus on the conduct, not on the condition. Don't try to play armchair psychiatrist."
And despite the success most companies have had in court, fending off discrimination claims based on mental disability is not easy. "Unlike a physical condition that is readily, medically diagnosable, a mental condition is often very amorphous," said Robert Bernstein, managing partner of the Newark office of Epstein, Becker & Green and a lawyer for GE Astrospace. A mental condition, he said, "is based on essentially the unverifiable statements of the person who suffers from the condition, so it becomes very difficult to rebut." He declined to comment on the merits of the Olson case.
Navigating a case through the system is costly. "These cases can cost more to fully litigate than the damages," Ms. Cooperman said, "with attorneys' fees sometimes in the hundreds of thousands of dollars." Plaintiffs can find lawyers to take cases on a contingency basis, as Mr. Olson did, and thus avoid big legal bills.
The GE Astrospace case is a vivid example of just how tortured litigating these cases can be. Mr. Olson filed a complaint with the E.E.O.C. after learning he had lost out on the job, but the agency found no reasonable basis for his claim.
Mr. Olson then filed a case in Federal court, citing what he said were violations of Federal and New Jersey workplace discrimination law. Again, he hit a roadblock. The court dismissed the case, finding that Mr. Olson was not disabled. But again, Mr. Olson did not walk away. Instead, he appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit and finally won the decision allowing his case to go forward.
The court also said that because New Jersey's law had a different definition of disability than did the Federal law, Mr. Olson had a potential state claim for discrimination on the basis of having a mental disability as well as for being regarded as mentally disabled.
Another concern for employers: under disability law, employers are required to provide reasonable accommodations to disabled employees. For a physical disability, the form this takes is often clear -- it might be a ramp for a person in a wheelchair. But with mental disabilities, accommodation is more complex. Requests for, say, an isolated cubicle or time off to calm down can be misunderstood by managers and resented by co-workers.
Accommodating employees is not necessarily a one-shot deal but can be a continuing obligation, as I.B.M. learned the hard way. Elizabeth Criado, who moved from New York State to take a position with the International Business Machines Corporation in San Juan, P.R., had been an award-winning marketing representative.
But after more than six years she was finding the pressure, including having a new manager, overwhelming. In mid-1994, at her new supervisor's suggestion and on the advice of her doctor, Ms. Criado, then 43, took a leave of absence for anxiety and depression. I.B.M. expected her to return on Aug. 1, but her doctor, she said, faxed the company a letter saying she needed more time.
In mid-August, I.B.M., which said it had never received the fax, sent its own letter -- dismissing her. Ms. Criado called and wrote the company to try to straighten out what she thought was a misunderstanding. But, she said, there was no reply.
"I had put so much of myself in my job," she said. "I had awards all over the place. I went from being Cinderella to the wicked witch overnight." Finally she sued, claiming discrimination on the basis of a mental disability.
I.B.M. lost. In June, the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit upheld a jury verdict of more than $500,000, finding that I.B.M.'s grant of a single, finite leave did not fulfill its obligation to accommodate. For Ms. Criado, who has not had a full-time job since, it was a bittersweet victory. "Between what I ended up paying in taxes and lawyers, I could have made more money working," she said. I.B.M. disagrees with the decision, saying it had done all it could to balance the needs of the employee with the business.
Jeffrey G. Huvelle, a partner at Covington & Burling in Washington, who handled I.B.M.'s appeal, said: "If an employee comes with a request, companies now have to be very careful in assessing the information the employee provides. In some cases, that means the company has to consult its own physician or have the person examined by its own physician to see if there is a way of accommodating the workplace demands. The disability law imposes a particular challenge to small companies that don't have in-house medical advice."
Employers may have to adjust their work standards case by case. "They are used to enforcing standards of attendance and conduct on a consistent basis, treating everyone alike," he said. "In part they do this to insure they're not treating people differently based on race, sex or age. But sometimes when an employee has a mental disability, the law now imposes an obligation to take that into account."
But under the law, an employee's needs cannot undercut the essence of the job itself. Thus, a waitress in Alabama who could not handle the stress of working busy nights and learning menu changes was found unqualified for the job and lost her case.
Still, managers should not brush off employee complaints of mental problems, said Christopher Collins, a lawyer at Proskauer Rose in New York. "It's vitally important that employers can point to a record at the end of the day that they took a request for accommodation seriously."
For those cases that do make it to a jury trial, depending on state law, there may be no cap on liability. With no limit to punitive damages in New Jersey, Mr. Klausner said, there's no telling what Mr. Olson could win.
