HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Autumn Rally Taking Stocks Back to Highs

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
The stock market has spoken. Its tidings: Happy days are here again.
As of yesterday's close, most broad market measures were either close to their summer highs or at them. The Dow Jones industrial average closed the week at 8,975.46, up 59.99 points for the day and 4.46 percent for the week. That places the Dow only 3.8 percent below its July 17 peak and up 19 percent from its Aug. 31 low. For the year, the Dow is up a respectable 13.49 percent. 
 Big-capitalization stocks that make up the Dow average are not the only ones moving up. The Wilshire 5000 index, the best approximation for the entire United States stock market, has shown an even better performance. It has jumped 21 percent from its Oct. 8 low, and is up 12.4 percent for the year. Yesterday, the Wilshire had a value of $11.5 trillion. In about one month, the value of the index has risen more than $2 trillion.
As of yesterday, the market has gone eight sessions without a down day, its second example of such durability in less than one month. But extended moves like these are unusual: to find a third example of such staying power requires a trip back to 1997.
What's fueling this move? Traders and strategists point to several disparate factors.
Most significant, perhaps, is a sea change in monetary policy not just domestically but around the world. Central banks, beginning with the Federal Reserve back in September and extending to Britain, Latin America and parts of Asia, have been reducing interest rates fairly aggressively. According to Jeffrey Applegate, chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers, since the September rate cut by the Fed, 27 central banks have done the same.
"In the last month and a half, the global policy outlook has improved," Mr. Applegate said. "Then this week we had a slew of data that was stock-market friendly. I think the fear trade is out of the market."
Lower interest rates are almost always a tonic for stock prices largely because they mean reduced borrowing costs -- offering the potential for higher profit margins -- for corporations. So it is not surprising that a cut in the discount rate -- the Fed's rate on loans made to banks -- has historically been followed by an average 12-month increase of 18 percent in the Standard & Poor's 500 index.
Stocks have been getting an additional lift from a giant increase in the money supply. According to Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y., the broadest measure of money supply, known as M-2, which includes currency in circulation, savings accounts and money market mutual funds, has grown by 2.5 percent in the last two months. The annualized rate for the last three months is 9.3 percent, the fastest annual expansion since 1987. "This tells me that there isn't a credit crunch," Mr. Shepherdson said. "And all this liquidity sloshing around has got to go somewhere."
An increase in the money supply comes basically from the Fed's providing reserves to the banking system, which banks use to lend. "New lending and investing power is created as money turnover speeds," said Robert H. Parks, an economist and investment consultant in Scarborough, N.Y. "It brings increased spending power that can go into stocks."
Another supply of money coming into stocks is from investors selling Treasury holdings in recent days. When Russia effectively defaulted in August, Treasuries became the darling of investors.
No more. The price of the 30-year bond has tumbled this week. Its yield, which rises as the price falls, ended at 5.38 percent, up from 5.15 percent a week earlier.
An interesting, if somewhat obscure, reason for the advance in equities may be the decline in stock volatility recently. Volatility -- basically the range from high to low in stocks during the trading day -- peaked on Oct. 15. Mr. Applegate notes that since 1948, the S.& P. 500 has risen an average 12 percent in the 12-month period after a peak in volatility.
"As long as the policy outlook continues to look good, then risk aversion should come down, volatility should come down and returns should come up," he said.
The jubliant stock market is, however, choosing to shrug off some troubling indicators. Corporate earnings, for example. While all the third-quarter announcements are not quite in, the period was a disappointment.
Even though many analysts have focused on the positive announcements, those were a distinct minority. John L. Manley Jr., equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, said that of 428 companies that have reported third-quarter results, fewer than 36 percent recorded a positive surprise. He defines a positive surprise as a company that reports a result greater than the consensus estimate on Wall Street one month before the quarter ended.
Neither do stocks seem to care that it is becoming increasingly likely that the Fed's policy-making committee will not cut rates when it meets on Nov. 17. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, said on Thursday that investors and lenders appeared to be less fearful than they had been. If the deep freeze in the credit markets is indeed beginning to thaw, as Mr. Greenspan seems to believe, another quick rate cut becomes less likely.
Some investors are calling this the John Glenn rally. After all, since Mr. Glenn blasted off from Cape Canaveral, the market has rallied nearly 10 percent. As long as he has been in orbit, so has the stock market.
Mr. Glenn returns to earth today. Investors clearly hope the stock market does not follow suit.

HEADLINE: The Speaker's Parting Gift

BYLINE: By Matt Salmon; Matt Salmon, a Republican, is a United States Representative from Arizona.

DATELINE: TEMPE, Ariz.

 BODY:
Two numbers symbolize why we need a new Speaker of the House in 1999: 8 dollars and 20 billion dollars. The first is the per-person annual tax cut passed this year; the second is the amount of money raided from the budget surplus to pay for so-called emergency spending.
For these reasons, Newt Gingrich was right to step aside and allow new leadership in the House for the 106th Congress. 
 This year we became the Seinfeld Congress, a Congress about nothing. We failed to put forth a clear agenda for America, instead opting to run out the clock. It seems that we were convinced that history guaranteed additions to our majority; the party out of the White House almost always makes large Congressional gains in a midterm election.
So we spent a good portion of the year naming roads, bridges and post offices. While President Clinton was building a bridge to the 21st century, the Republican Congress was busy naming it. And we spent more time trying to make Puerto Rico a state than we did discussing tax relief, fighting crime or reducing the size of the Government. When we ousted the the Democrats from power in 1994, it wasn't because they had failed to produce a 51st state.
Moreover, Republicans have lost their ability to negotiate with the President. Granted, Bill Clinton is a very skillful politician. But for the past three years, we have repeatedly been out-negotiated by the President, and the situation has been getting progressively worse, culminating in this year's omnibus spending package -- a legislative monstrosity if there ever was one. This final act of the 105th Congress utterly demoralized the voters who are our political base, and they decided to sit out on Election Day. After all, they sent us to Washington to reduce the size of the Government, not to increase it.
With yesterday's announcements that Bob Livingston of Louisiana, the chairman of the Appropriations Committee, will run for Speaker and that Steve Largent of Oklahoma will run to replace Dick Armey of Texas as majority leader, we see the bright promise of a rejuvenated Republican majority. With the Speaker's decision to step aside, others may now join them in these races. This is a sign of health in the party.
How can our new leadership shake the moniker of the do-nothing Congress? We must emphasize the issues that unite us: creating economic growth through tax relief, reducing the size and intrusiveness of the Government, and insuring the long-term solvency of Social Security. Members may still butt heads on social issues, but these differences could be managed if the party refused to buckle on the issues on which we agree.
The alternative is a continuation of the downward spiral of House Republicans into the next elections. That would not affect me directly. I pledged to Arizona voters that I would not seek a fourth consecutive term, so I will not be a candidate in 2000. But returning the House to the Democrats in two years would mean even higher taxes and an even bigger Government.
It is never easy to replace a leader who has brought you success in the past. Newt Gingrich spearheaded our Super Bowl victory in 1994; unfortunately, we haven't won enough games since then. I respect and admire Mr. Gingrich. His statesmanlike decision to pass the Republican leadership to a new generation is a wise and welcome one.

RUSSIA: CRITICIZED ON ECONOMIC RETREAT -- Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott attacked Russia's retreat from free-market economics and warned that financial decline could lead to "political drift, turmoil and even crack up" there. Help from the International Monetary Fund, Mr. Talbott said in a speech at Stanford University, "must wait until the Russian Government shows itself willing and able to make the difficult structural adjustments necessary for recovery and growth."' (Reuters) 

RUSSIA: THE TRUTH IS NOW THE WORD -- Pravda, once the official organ of the Soviet Communist Party, was forced by court order to change its name. The newspaper, whose name means "the truth," has now appeared on newsstands as Slovo, the word. The change resulted from a battle between editorial factions, one of which began publishing a new version of the paper in 1994 with the same name, in virtually the same typeface. (The old Pravda is shown at top above, with its competitor.) (Agence France-Presse)
 
GERMANY: U.S. LAWYER PRESSES SLAVE-LABOR CASE -- An American lawyer who has sued companies over slave labor in World War II demanded that the new Government include his group in talks about a compensation fund. The lawyer, Edward Fagan, said he would never agree to a Government-run fund. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)
 
YUGOSLAVIA: INSPECTORS' VISAS SOUGHT -- Richard C. Holbrooke, the United States special envoy, said in Berlin that President Slobodan Milosevic clearly agreed last month to allow United Nations war-crimes investigators access to Yugoslavia, including Kosovo. But Belgrade has refused to give the visas. (Reuters)
 
SPAIN: PINOCHET EXTRADITION REQUESTED -- The Government agreed to seek the extradition from Britain of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, a move that could send the general, the ex-dictator of Chile, to trial on a charge of genocide. The Chilean Government immediately recalled its ambassador, and the Spanish Foreign Minister, Abel Matutes, conceded that the case "inevitably has important political repercussions." (NYT)
 
TURKEY: NEW RULES ON THE BOSPORUS -- Turkey imposed new navigation rules for the Bosporus, moving to eliminate competitors in the race to carry Caspian Sea oil to world markets. Turkey, which says increased traffic would lead to collisions and oil spills, is seeking a pipeline to skirt the Bosporus. Turkey can stop traffic when currents are unfavorable, stop any ship on legal grounds and require increased use of local pilots. (AP)
 
ASIA
 
INDONESIA: SUPPORT FROM THE I.M.F. -- The lending agency approved a $960 million loan to the Government and urged it to speed the pace of banking reform and of refinancing corporate debt. But it also praised the direction of the economy. Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F.'s managing director, said, "Due to good policy implementation, the Indonesian economy is showing welcome signs of stabilization." (Reuters)
 
JAPAN: 4 SPY SATELLITES BY 2003 -- The Government announced it would launch four intelligence-gathering satellites, increasing its military abilities in ways that are widely expected to cause unease at home and regionally. The Cabinet approved the launchings by the spring of 2003. Japan became alarmed when North Korea launched a rocket over its territory in September. Nicholas D. Kristof (NYT)
 
CHINA: CONTROLS ON MIXED MARRIAGES -- Shanghai has moved to control the increasing number of marriages between residents and foreigners, BBC World News reported. Starting next month, the BBC said, Chinese in Shanghai who want to marry a foreigner have to register with city authorities, who will rule in a month on allowing or prohibiting marriages. Shanghai had 3,000 mixed marriages last year.
 
TAJIKISTAN: RESISTANCE TO WARLORD'S THREATS -- Tajik and former opposition groups joined forces to combat a warlord, Makhmud Khudoberdyev, who threatens to blow up a dam and flood large areas. Government troops and their allies retook control of Khudzhand, but still faced pockets of resistance. (Agence France-Presse)

The army confirmed that Israelis were removing soil from an Israeli-occupied zone, said the spokesman for the United Nations peacekeepers in Lebanon, Timur Goksel. (AP)

UNITED NATIONS: U.S. IS SPURNED AGAIN -- The United States was again denied a seat on a financial watchdog committee because it owes the United Nations more than $1 billion, despite having paid $197 million this week to avoid forfeiting its vote in the General Assembly. The United States, which was voted off the panel, the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions, in 1996, finished last in a field of four candidates. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

ARGENTINA: AFRICA WARNED ON WARMING -- Africa is more likely to suffer from global warming than other regions largely because of its limited ability to react to climate change, a United Nations committee predicted at a conference. The rest of the world will not be spared, either, the panel said, with the North and South Poles, as well as the Pacific and Caribbean, also badly affected. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

No. 1 Bookstore Chain To Buy Top Wholesaler
Barnes & Noble, the nation's largest bookseller, announced the $600 million purchase of Ingram Book Group, a leading wholesaler, in a deal that an organization of independent booksellers denounced as "devastating" and an authors group compared to a wedding of Godzilla and King Kong. 
 The deal, for $200 million in cash plus $400 million in stock, will give Barnes & Noble access to 11 distribution centers. Page A1.
 
Credit Growth Accelerates
Consumers picked up the pace of their borrowing in September. The Federal Reserve said outstanding credit grew at a 7.9 percent annual rate during the month, up from August's 4.2 percent rate and faster than the 5.2 percent average for the year so far. C3.
 
Market's Strength Is Widespread
The sharp run-up in the stock market over the last month, which has returned the Dow Jones industrial average to within striking distance of the 9,000 level, has given almost every major stock group big gains. The major exception is the utility sector. C3.
 
Accord on U.S. Food Aid for Russia
In a sign of Russia's economic desperation, Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov's aides put aside their pride and concluded an agreement with the United States for $625 million worth of grain, meat and other food assistance. Agriculture Department officials say the Russians will run out of wheat before their next harvest without aid. A4.
 
Rule Near on Child Safety Seats
After years of negotiations with manufacturers of cars and child safety seats, the Transportation Department plans to publish a rule next month that would establish a uniform system for installing child safety seats in new cars without using seat belts. A11.
 
U.S. Bankers Hesitate on Brazil
As institutions led by the International Monetary Fund prepare a $30 billion economic rescue package for Brazil, United States banks find themselves sitting on the sidelines. With questions lingering about the ability of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso to reinvigorate the Brazilian economy, American bankers say they will wait for Brazil to ask them for more money before any is offered. C2.
 
Sweepstakes Operator Is Accused
The Florida Attorney General accused American Family Publishers of preying on the elderly through deceptive magazine solicitations and by selling the names of the elderly and retired people who enter sweepstakes to operators of other contests. A7.
 
American Scales Back Growth Plans
American Airlines plans to slow its growth in 1999 by retiring 10 aircraft early and by deferring service on some new international routes, including to Moscow and Tokyo. C3.
 
Results Delayed at Lucas Varity
Lucas Varity delayed until today an announcement of whether shareholders voted to move its headquarters to the United States from Britain. The vote was too close to call as proxies were counted. C2.
 
Tough Choice for Astra Creditors
Astra International, Indonesia's largest auto maker, has offered its creditors the choice of cashing out and taking sizable losses or joining its debt-revamping plan. C2.
 
ABC Drops Stone-Produced Special
Citing the potential for confusion among viewers between "fact-based entertainment and hard news," ABC has dropped plans to broadcast a special, produced by the film maker Oliver Stone, about the theory that long-range missiles caused the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800. A12.

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
Talks Hit Stalemate And Break Off for Now

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
The chances of ending the National Basketball Association's labor conflict grew more bleak yesterday. Talks between the chief negotiators broke off indefinitely, another week of games was stricken from the schedule and the union's executive director, Billy Hunter, again accused the league of trying to shatter the players' solidarity.
Hunter and the union's negotiating team emerged from a one-hour meeting in Manhattan with Commissioner David Stern and his team, and they gave no indication when negotiations might resume. It was the first time that talks were suspended since Aug. 6, when the owners walked out of a meeting. 
 With both sides holding firm and no bargaining sessions planned, it appeared the lockout would push up against Stern's unofficial early-December deadline for reaching a deal.
In response to a question, Hunter said pressure on both sides was growing. "We're not going to take a bad deal," he said. "If it means we don't play until January or February, that's what it means."
Stern's deputy, Russ Granik, said: "Unfortunately, nothing has changed this week. We are still very, very far apart. We haven't moved closer at all."
Granik added: "As each day goes by, there are just huge dollars that are lost. It's hard for me to say there is a particular date as to when the window closes to make a deal, but I'm hoping we don't get to that point."
With Granik out of town to attend U.S.A. Basketball meetings early next week, negotiations between the league and the union could not take resume until late next week. That would most likely mean another week of games would be canceled, which would reduce the season to around 60 games.
Meanwhile, a participant in Wednesday's negotiating session said the union had offered mediation to help resolve the dispute, a tool Major League Baseball players and owners employed unsuccessfully in 1994. The league rejected the use of a mediator, the participant said.
League officials said they never received a new proposal that the players had promised. Hunter, who acknowledged that the union decided not to send a new proposal, accused Stern and the owners of using the next two weeks to lobby the players and exert pressure on the union to sign a deal.
"It's clear they're trying to split the players," Hunter said, adding that he knew of seven teams that had made contact with players to discuss the league's latest proposal. "They want to take a poll and see where our players stand."
On Wednesday, Stern lifted a four-month-old moratorium that prohibited team officials with knowledge of the negotiations from explaining the deal to players. The action does not constitute an unfair labor practice, the league contends, because it says it is for informational purposes only.
The move angered Hunter, and he has scheduled a meeting next week of the union's executive committee.
"We're not going to stand by and let the owners and league attempt to have unfettered access to our players and let them manipulate them without going back out there and clearing the record up," Hunter said.
Negotiations over the key economic issues continue to lag. Among them are the distribution of total revenue and the implementation of an escrow system. A week after both sides boasted that a framework had been agreed upon, talks have become so unproductive that a fifth week has been deleted from the season. That means games could not start earlier than Dec. 8.
Hunter said the following team officials were among those who had talked to players about the deal:
*Miami Heat: Micky Arison, owner, and Pat Riley, president and coach.
*Boston Celtics: Paul Gaston, owner, Rick Pitino, president and coach, and Chris Wallace, general manager.
*Milwaukee Bucks: George Karl, coach.
*Cleveland Cavaliers: Wayne Embry, general manager.
"From what we've heard, they're talking to the players about how good the deal is," Hunter said. "Our players know the difference between a good deal and a bad deal. We're confident about that. I'm just worried this will create a rift between management and players."
Asked why the union decided not to make changes in its most recent proposal, Hunter said, "Our position is, we're not going to show movement until they show movement."
Granik said: "The owners believe totally that they will not operate until we have a fair deal. And if that means missing the whole season, that's what it means. Obviously, it's not anything anybody wants to do."

HEADLINE: California Examines Brutal, Deadly Prisons

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: CORCORAN, Calif.

 BODY:
There was lots of celebrating in this cotton-growing town in the San Joaquin Valley when a maximum-security prison opened here 10 years ago.
It would bring jobs and economic growth to the stagnant farm belt, not to mention put more criminals away. But while the jobs came, the prison has, more than anything, brought Corcoran a bad name. 
 Months after it opened as part of a prison construction boom in California that coincided with a push for tough new sentencing laws, the State Prison at Corcoran began to develop a reputation as one of the deadliest, most abusive prisons in the biggest, most troubled prison system in the United States.
Now, state lawmakers and prison officials are examining why Corcoran, and by extension, the entire state prison system, veered out of control. From 1988 to late 1994, when whistle-blowers inside Corcoran went to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the prison's guards shot to death 7 inmates and wounded 43, more than in all other prisons in the country combined.
And while the shootings at Corcoran stopped when the Federal authorities moved in, they continued at other California prisons. At High Desert Prison, guards have killed 3 inmates and wounded 11 since that maximum-security institution opened three years ago.
"California correctional officers, on at least a few occasions, have shot and killed an inmate who was locked in a cell, in a fistfight with an inmate, with no weapons in sight," said State Senator John Vasconcellos, a Democrat from San Jose. "No other state has done that."
At the end of a series of recent legislative hearings on abuses at Corcoran, Mr. Vasconcellos called for a meeting of prison leaders from other states to review California's prison system, particularly its violent form of inmate control. But some wonder what took so long.
In October, five prison guards at Corcoran were indicted on state charges of conspiracy, accused of having an inmate rape another inmate in 1993.
In February, as part of a four-year Federal investigation into abuses at the prison, eight guards were indicted on civil rights charges, accused of staging gladiator-style fights among prisoners in exercise yards and shooting at the inmates when they did not stop fighting on command.
In 1995, a Federal judge ruled that treatment of prisoners at the maximum-security Pelican Bay Prison, at the northern tip of the state, was cruel and inhumane.
Also in 1995, 5 supervisors at Corcoran and 10 guards were accused by whistle-blowers of beating a busload of handcuffed, shackled prisoners who had been transferred to the prison. A local grand jury declined to indict the guards, but the Department of Corrections handed out punishments including dismissal and demotion. In September, a court overturned the disciplinary penalties on a technicality.
There is no one answer to why California became the model for how not to run prisons. But the troubles began when it embarked on the biggest, fastest prison construction boom in American history. When the building began in 1982, the state had 12 prisons and 31,000 inmates. Now, it has 33 prisons and 160,000 inmates.
The boom, prison officials say, was prompted by several tough-on-crime laws drafted by the Legislature, most famously the "three strikes" under Gov. Pete Wilson that mandated life terms for third felony convictions. As prisons were built, the Department of Corrections hired thousands of guards. Many had no law-enforcement experience beyond six weeks' training given by the state.
Like the system's critics, C. A. Terhune, who became director of the corrections department last year, said the system grew too large, too fast. But Mr. Terhune also blamed the state's entrenched prison gangs, which he called "second to none" in the country. Just as significant, he said, his department, with an annual budget of $4 billion, has the nation's largest prison population, but ranks near the bottom in the ratio of guards to inmates, 1 to 7.6.
"While California was building its prison system, there didn't seem to be a concurrent budgeting of resources," Mr. Terhune said. "It's only begun in this last year or so to really commence the process of staffing up."
The prisons' security housing units, or super-maximum prisons within the prisons, where most of the shootings have taken place, were built so that one or two guards with high-powered riles could watch over a yard with dozens of the most troublesome prisoners. Other states with super-maximum security units have nothing close to the same numbers of incidents of guards using lethal force. But in California, use of force was a major factor in the inmate control equation.
"The design, the staffing, and many of the factors that go into the program operations of the California prison system were based on having lethal force as a control mechanism," Mr. Terhune said. "It is a reality of life that we have to live with."
Mr. Terhune acknowledged that the department's policy on use of force had not been defined in writing and that it needed to be defined strictly and enforced the same way. Echoing the Correctional Peace Officers Union, the second-most-powerful union in the state after the teachers' union, he said the system's 27,000 prison guards needed reinforcements and more training.
"A lot of good things happened in these hearings," he said, "and I think one of the main ones is that a six-week academy is not sufficient."
Longtime critics of the California prison system remain skeptical of the department's willingness and ability to reform itself. Corey Weinstein, a doctor who directs the Corcoran Committee of California Prison Focus, a watchdog group based in San Francisco, said recent history suggested it would not happen.
'Only after abuses are exposed in the press do they act," Dr. Weinstein said. "Only when the public sector has forced them into acting have they acted."
Dr. Weinstein pointed to the catastrophe of the integrated prison yard policy, in which rival gang members imprisoned in security units were put in tiny, concrete recreation yards together to force them to get along.
In the mid 1980's, the policy backfired when guards began shooting and killing inmates to break up fights at the California Correctional Institute at Tehachapi. Still, officials continued the policy when Corcoran and Pelican Bay prisons were opened in 1988 and 1989, respectively.
Pelican Bay prison was built to house the "worst of the worst." It quickly became a place where prisoners claimed they were beaten, brutalized and tormented. In 1995, a Federal court agreed. In a class-action civil rights case, Judge Thelton Henderson of Federal District Court in San Francisco ruled that the prison caused "senseless suffering and sometimes wretched misery."
Like many critics of the system, Dr. Weinstein blames the prison guard union for some of the problems. The union, which has contributed more than $1 million to the campaigns of Governor Wilson and Attorney General Dan Lungren since 1992, has stymied investigations.
George Galaza, the warden at Corcoran, said the accusations of continued abuse and neglect at his prison were "lies."
"I wouldn't be sitting here if that was going on," said Mr. Galaza, who became warden of the 5,000-inmate prison in 1996. "With all the different agencies scrutinizing this place, if something was going on, I'd be behind bars if anything was going on."
Guards at Corcoran said they were tired of being made out to be the criminals, in a prison filled with some of the state's toughest inmates. Lieut. Rob Vella, who has been at Corcoran since it opened, said that even criticisms of the old integrated yard policy was simplistic.
"There are just so many facets to it," he said. "When we separate the gangs, the ones that used to get along start forming rivalries."
Lieut. Rob Dean, one of the group of guards accused of beating inmates getting off a bus in 1995, said the accusations were politically motivated. "If we were doing all the things they said, these guys wouldn't respect us," he said, as he watched a sagging, baggy line of prisoners file into the mess hall.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1353 words

HEADLINE: Fans' Hoop Dreams Tainted by N.B.A. Rift

BYLINE: By NICHOLE M. CHRISTIAN 

 BODY:
On a nippy November afternoon, when he would ordinarily be leaping toward the basketball rim trying to imitate the aerodynamic glide of his hero, Michael Jordan, 11-year-old Jonathan Figueroa grimaced at the mention of basketball.
Instead, Jonathan, who once aspired to be a point guard, was transforming the Goat Courts at 99th Street and Amsterdam Avenue -- one of New York City's most hallowed hoops grounds -- into an asphalt baseball field. And with repeated swings of his wooden bat, he tried to forget ever having loved Jordan or professional basketball, which he says is so "messed up" in a labor dispute that fans like him have been pushed to the sidelines. 
 "Basketball is dead," Jonathan declared, continuing to swipe the air with his bat. "The players only really care about getting a lot of money. I don't care if it ever comes back. It's all about baseball now."
By the calendar at least, basketball loyalists like Jonathan should be tethered to their televisions, trying to glimpse the latest moves, newest phenoms and hottest highlights of the National Basketball Association. But this season, a high-stakes labor battle between the N.B.A.'s more than 400 players and 29 team owners has already canceled 194 games in November and is threatening to call off the entire schedule.
The two sides are at odds over how best to divide basketball's billion dollar revenue base, and the owners have locked out the players. The players want 60 percent of that total; the owners are offering 50.
On the basketball courts and public playgrounds of New York City, which have launched legions of basketball dreamers -- and more than a few N.B.A. stars -- hard-core fans of all ages are directing sharp words at both the players and the owners. While almost no one is well versed or even particularly interested in the details of the day-to-day negotiations, many fans say they have heard enough to know this much: Basketball is disintegrating into a game of greed.
As in many urban areas across the country, basketball has long been more than just a sport in New York. It has also been a way for young people in poor neighborhoods to grasp at America's modern pastime: success, and the wealth that comes along with it. But as with other such pursuits, basketball has a heartbreaking trail of disappointments -- none better known in New York than that of Earl (the Goat) Manigault, for whom the Amsterdam courts are named. Manigault became a local legend for his ability to defy gravity on the court, but a heroin addiction spoiled his chances of pursuing a professional career.
So perhaps the N.B.A. impasse has a particularly sharp resonance on the city's concrete playgrounds, where those who sweat and dream of an N.B.A. career and its comforts feel betrayed by the few who have made it.
Players at the famed West Fourth Street court in Manhattan recently joked about the predicament of Kenny Anderson, a former point guard for the New Jersey Nets. Anderson said recently that he might have to sell one of his eight luxury cars now that he is unable to collect his $5.8 million salary from his new team, the Boston Celtics.
Anderson, who has homes in New York and Los Angeles and a fledgling entertainment company, has said that he spends $75,000 a year on the upkeep of his cars and is currently losing $76,000 for every game that he does not play.
"It's insulting," said Stephen Breslin, 15, a West Fourth Street regular. "They can go out and buy a whole bunch of cars and apartments and we're supposed to feel bad. Get real. Even the ones who make only a couple hundred thousand still have it better than most people out here. I don't have sympathy for either side."
Some basketball devotees have so distanced themselves from the N.B.A.'s troubles that they had to be reminded that the official start of the season came and went this week.
Last year, Eddo Smalls, 16, spent his time and money collecting memorabilia related to his favorite sports heroes at the time, the Orlando Magic guard Penny Hardaway and the Los Angeles Lakers center Shaquille O'Neal. But the two have now been dethroned by the likes of "Big Sexy Kevin Nash" and "Stone Cold Steve Austin," stars from the world of professional wrestling.
"Wrestling is the last pure sport," Eddo said. "They don't have big N.B.A egos. Everything they do is for the fans."
Officials at the N.B.A. say they are painfully aware of the damage the lockout has done to the public's perception of the game. "We know the lockout is not doing anything to endear us to fans," said Brian McIntyre, a spokesman for the league. "But we have an economic system that is not working and if left unaddressed would only get worse."
Mr. McIntyre said some teams lost so much money during last year's regular season because of player salaries and benefits that this year's lockout is actually saving money. Officials for the National Basketball Players Association did not return telephone calls to their office. But in the past the players have disputed the league's contention that many teams are losing money, saying that basketball's popularity is soaring and now is not the time for players to agree to a pay cut.
But like the reaction to the baseball strike of 1994-95 -- when fans vowed to turn their backs on the game but returned en masse by this year -- the complaints over the basketball dispute are likely to be fleeting.
Gregory Rose, a 27-year-old N.B.A. fan and a regular player on city courts, said he was mourning the loss of basketball. "I'm hurting," he said. "Right now, I'm supposed to be in front of my TV rooting for the Bulls."
And others, like Derek Pilgrim, 31, a friend of Mr. Rose's, said the team owners were at fault. "Blaming the players is crazy," he said. "Basketball is a business now. Players know their careers probably won't last 10, 20 years like they used to, so they have to look out for themselves just like the owners are doing."
At the Brownsville Recreation Center in Brooklyn, all the talk about salaries and sticking points was lost on the nearly three dozen children who gather each season in front of a 52-inch color television to watch N.B.A. games. So far this year, the children have had to settle for sitting in the gym and watching amateurs.
"I don't think it's fair," 12-year-old Rykeem Robinson said as he lay sprawled over the gym's bleachers, only half watching a loud, sweaty game of three-on-three. "On TV it's better than this. If the players weren't selfish, we could be watching a real game."
Since many of the children come from homes where cable television is an unlikely luxury, the recreation center's manager was planning to buy a cable television package this year so they could watch more of their favorite players, including Stephon Marbury, the Coney Island point guard who used to dunk in the center's full-court gym and now plays for the Minnesota Timberwolves.
The center, which is run by the city's Parks Department, also helped ignite the career of World B. Free, who played 13 N.B.A. seasons for various teams, including the Philadelphia 76ers, and was inducted into the New York City Basketball Hall of Fame last year.
To Greg Jackson, who manages the center and is also a former point guard for the Phoenix Suns, the dispute is sending a troubling message to children like Rykeem.
"Where is the loyalty to the game from the owners and the players these days?" asked Mr. Jackson, 47, who was drafted by the New York Knicks in 1974 and played for the Suns, earning $25,000 a year. "Every year these kids are loyal supporters, even though most of them can't afford to think about going to a game."
Once a year, Mr. Jackson said, the center finds the money, with help from the Parks Department and a local community organization, to sponsor a trip to a game. But rarely is he able to take more than 30 of the center's nearly 400 children. Even then, the children must settle for the New Jersey Nets, rather than their favorite team, the Knicks.
"Maybe they should stop being so loyal," he said. "Maybe the owners and the players would all learn a lesson then."

GRAPHIC: Photos: In DeWitt Clinton Park in Manhattan, Gregory Rose, second from left, and Derek Pilgrim, left, discuss the pain of life without N.B.A. games. Greg Jackson, a former professional player and the manager of a city recreation center, said the players and the team owners should have the same loyalty to the game as the young fans at the center. HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
USX-U.S. STEEL OFFERSEARLY RETIREMENT TO 540

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
USX-U.S. Steel Group Inc. offered early retirement yesterday to 540 managers and nonunion employees, or 12 percent of its salaried work force. The company, the biggest United States steelmaker, said it would take a fourth-quarter charge of less than $10 million to account for the buyouts. U.S. Steel's sales and earnings have been weakened in the last year. The company, a unit of the USX Corporation, made the offer to selected managers at its steel plants and to USX Engineers and Consultants Inc. employees.

HEADLINE: Food Crisis Forces Russia To Swallow Its Pride

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 6

 BODY:
The burning question for the Kremlin these days is not the future of capitalism, the lack of a national program or NATO's creeping to the East.
It is about food. 
 With winter fast approaching, this nation is locked in a primal struggle to feed its citizens and prevent them from freezing.
It is a race against time. Food reserves are dwindling. Remote cities have been left without heat. And the huge logistical task of moving grain, meat and fuel is well behind schedule.
It is a mark of Russia's anxiety that Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov's aides put aside its pride and concluded an agreement today to buy $625 million worth of grain, meat, milk, soybeans and other food from the United States.
According to Christopher Goldthwait, the senior official of the United States Department of Agriculture who helped negotiate the food accord, the Russians will run out of wheat before their next harvest without American aid.
"We project they will run short some time in the month of July," Mr. Goldthwait said in an interview.
Even now Russia is facing regional shortages. Russia's Agriculture Ministry has reported shortages in 22 of the nation's 89 regions.
Russia's disastrous harvest -- the worst in 45 years -- is just part of the reason. The tendency of the nation's regions to go their own way, lax government management and Russia's financial crisis have turned a difficult situation into a desperate one.
Many grain producing regions have been hoarding their supply. The collapse of the banking system and fuel shortages have also delayed the sale and distribution of what food is available to regions that do not produce grain.
"Distribution is a big problem," said Viktor F. Lishchenko, a leading agricultural specialist. "The nation is vast and many local governors practically do not let the grain out of their borders."
Quantity is not the only problem. The quality of Russia's store of grain is uneven, diminishing its value for making bread or raising livestock.
The decline in domestic food production has been aggravated by a sharp decline in imports, another consequence of the plummeting value of the nation's currency.
Before its financial crisis, Russia used to import more than 40 per cent of its food. But imports have fallen to a fraction of that and what foreign food is being shipped in is being sold at skyrocketing prices.
Russia's needy have been hit hard. Relief groups are besieged with reports of orphanages that have five rubles a day (about 30 cents) per child to buy food and prisons that spend even less on their inmates.
"We think the situation is critical," said Margarita Plonikova, Moscow representative of the International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies.
Even ordinary Russians have felt the pinch. Even before the financial crisis, the annual consumption of meat has declined to about 95 pounds a person, less than half of American levels. And since the crisis, Russia's pasta factories have been working overtime, a sign that Russians are changing their diet.
Food is not the only problem. The Russian Government is also struggling to keep its citizens supplied with heat and power. Russia's Fuel and Energy Ministry said this week that it had only received 3 per cent of what it was due to buy fuel for the nation's northern territories.
As the food crisis has grown, the Kremlin only begrudgingly recognized the seriousness of the situation. At first, it continued to allow farmers in the south of the country to export their grain.
Then aides to Mr. Primakov said that the nation did not need food aid, suggesting that talk about food assistance was a Western plot to dump agricultural surplus on Russia.
But as the Russians re-examined their stocks and confronted the difficulty of distributing food supplies, they began to document their shortages for their American counterparts. The Russians even urged that the first of the American shipments arrive before the end of the year.
Under today's accord, the United States will supply 3.1 million metric tons of food. That supply includes 1.5 million tons of wheat, which is being provided free.
Another 1.5 million tons of feed grain, meat, dry milk, soybeans, rice, corn and other commodities is being bought by Russia under extremely favorable terms: a 20-year loan at a nominal interest rate. The United States is also providing 100,000 tons of food to private relief groups for distribution to Russia's needy.
The Russians intend to sell much of the food at home at market rates. With corruption rampant in Russia, the United States wants to prevent Russian businessmen from raking off the profits.
It rejected the Russians' insistence that the revenue be used to support their agricultural sectors. Instead, the Russians are obliged to use the proceeds to pay pensions and finance other social programs.
The United States is footing the $260 million bill for sending the different shipments for Russia. Relief organizations, meanwhile, are mounting their own campaigns to buy and distribute food.
Still, American officials said that the food aid may not be sufficient and may need to be increased.
"This is a question that we have left open," Mr. Goldthwait said. "We will continue to assess whether there or not there is a need for additional commodities."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 10, 1998, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about United States food aid for Russia misstated the terms. Russia will get $625 million of food, much of it free. It is not buying food worth $625 million.

HEADLINE: A World of Celebration;
New York City: Kwanzaa

BYLINE: By Eric V. Copage; New York Times Magazine

 BODY:
Kwanzaa means "first fruits of the harvest" in Swahili. From Dec. 26 through New Year's Day, up to 18 million African-Americans will celebrate the richness of their African heritage by observing the holiday of Kwanzaa.
It is a reminder to live up to the high standards of the best of black culture -- tenacity, resourcefulness, joy and pride exhibited through action, not rhetoric -- throughout the year. My 11-year-old son, Evan, 8-year-old daughter, Siobhan, and I celebrate Kwanzaa in the typical way. On the first night we light the central candle of the kinara, the seven-branched candelabrum, and talk about the holiday's seven principles. First, Unity -- working together as a family, in the classroom, with other black people. On the second night, we light two candles and talk about Self-Determination, not letting others decide who or what you should be, and so on until the seventh day, when we light the candle of Faith. 
 I have a small Karamu, or feast, during which I might cook cornbread and greens the way my grandmother did, or peanut soup and Jolof rice, a reminder of my trip to Africa. I'll give my children simple gifts, usually books ("Her Stories," "The House of Dies Drear," by Virginia Hamilton), CD's of black jazz legends, or a family memento, such as a photograph of their great-grandmother.
More elaborate Karamus -- both public and private -- include dance and music, storytelling and foods from the African diaspora.
The holiday was created in 1966 by Dr. Maulana (Ron) Karenga, chairman of black studies at California State University in Long Beach. He blended philosophies and harvest festival rituals from sub-Saharan Africa to create Kwanzaa's seven symbols, such as the kinara, and its seven principles: Umoja (Unity), Kujichagulia (Self-Determination), Ujima (Collective Work and Responsibility), Ujamaa (Co-operative Economics), Nia (Purpose), Kuumba (Creativity), Imani (Faith).
There are many Kwanzaa celebrations in New York. On Dec. 27, under the blue whale in the hall of ocean life, the American Museum of Natural History will bring alive an African marketplace. Hours are noon to 5 P.M.; suggested donation, which buys admission to Kwanzaa events: $8 for adults, $4.50 for children (telephone: 212-769-5100).
From Dec. 11 to 14, a Kwanzaa Fest will be held in the concrete cavern of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. There will be food, dance, music and vendors, and African-American authors will sign their books. Admission: $10 for adults, $5 for children 6 to 12 (718-671-2811).

LENGTH: 225 words

HEADLINE: Hunger to Spare

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While I enjoyed and agreed with much of Dana Milbank's review of Janet Poppendieck's "Sweet Charity? Emergency Food and the End of Entitlement" (Oct. 18), I question some of the assertions of your reviewer. If Poppendieck says that food providers should stop feeding people and concentrate on lobbying the Congress, I cannot agree; there is an immediate, growing need for direct feeding programs. On the other hand, when the reviewer cites the continuation of emergency needs despite job growth, there is no mention of the fact that a lot of these new jobs are at the minimum wage, leaving the worker still dependent on food supplements from someone. The discussion of possible solutions is interesting, but it fails to focus on how the overall economic system itself (of which the food system is part) fails to deliver adequate food (or income) to the sixth of the nation that is below the poverty line. I would submit that an in-depth analysis of how food is produced and distributed in this country (and worldwide) would indicate that elimination of some of the injustices in that system might obviate the need for many of these emergency programs by either government or private charity. It is a longer and more complex story than the review (or, I have to assume, the book) tells.
 
Martin M. McLaughlin
Arlington, Va.

HEADLINE: The Patron Saint Of Paradox

BYLINE: By Paul Elie; Paul Elie is an editor at Farrar, Straus & Giroux. His last article for the magazine was about Pope John Paul II's relationship with the Jews.

 BODY:
When she died, a multitude came down to the old dwelling off the Bowery to pay their respects, the way people had come to Catholic Worker houses for soup ever since the Depression. There were Catholic Workers, social workers, migrant workers, the unemployed; addicts, alcoholics, anarchists; Protestants, Jews and agnostics; the devout and the strident and the curious, there to see what a saint looked like.
Dorothy Day died in 1980, at the age of 83. She was one of the greatest religious figures of the century, and one of the most paradoxical. She was a Catholic and she was an anarchist. She condemned poverty and she advocated it. She founded the Catholic Worker, a loose aggregation of "houses of hospitality," communal farms, newspapers and round-table discussions for "further clarification of thought" -- and called her memoirs "The Long Loneliness." The movement was wary of authority, yet revered her as its leader. She humbled herself before God and sat for a portrait by Richard Avedon. 
 "Don't call me a saint -- I don't want to be dismissed that easily," she once said, to no avail. A year ago, to mark what would have been her 100th birthday (today would have been her 101st), John Cardinal O'Connor of New York, a lifelong admirer, announced that he would take up the cause for her canonization. "If anybody in our time can be called a saint, she can," he said.
It was an honor, and it was another paradox. For the prospect that Dorothy Day might be declared a saint was welcomed by everybody except the Catholic Workers, the very people pledged to emulate her sanctity today.
The old-time Catholic Workers who were close to Day support the canonization effort wholeheartedly. But many Workers, especially the younger ones, see the church remaking a rebel for its own purposes, and find her synthesis of rock-ribbed Catholicism and radical politics impossible to attain today. They find it twisted that Dorothy Day, a pacifist who opposed even World War II, should be celebrated by Rear Adm. John J. O'Connor, retired, a former head chaplain to the United States Navy. They object to his notion that Day -- who became a Catholic after having an abortion -- could become a poster saint for the church's anti-abortion efforts. "People feel that Dorothy's too good for the church, and are afraid of what will happen once the church gets its mitts on her," says Robert Ellsberg, a former Catholic Worker, now the editor in chief of Orbis Books, a progressive Catholic press.
When Day's sainthood was first brought up 15 years ago, one of her nine granddaughters called the idea "sick." Then the high priest of the Catholic left weighed in. "Her spirit haunts us in the violated faces of the homeless in New York," wrote Daniel Berrigan. "Can you imagine her portrait, all gussied up, unfurled from above the high altar of St. Peter's?"
The conflict has since taken shape as a battle over property, with the Workers claiming squatter's rights to Day's legacy while the church exercises its power of eminent domain. Those in favor of sainthood depict her as "a loyal servant of the church Jesus had founded" (her words) who prayed the rosary on the barricades. Those opposed are afraid the Vatican's saint-making priests will evict her from the underworld of tenements, flophouses, rallies and jails and recast her as the Patron Saint of Soup Kitchens, a kindhearted woman who dabbled in anarchism on the side. "They're going to take the best of Dorothy and remove it, like a lobotomy," says Jeff Dietrich, a Catholic Worker in Los Angeles.
Saints, in the Catholic tradition, are holy people who call forth the devotion of the faithful, even after they are dead. Since becoming pope in 1978, John Paul II has canonized 280 saints, more than any previous pope. And the Vatican has simplified the process, reducing from four to two the number of miracles needed (say, the inexplicable cure of a person who prayed for the saint's aid) and doing away with the "devil's advocate," who argued against the prospective saint's cause.
Why so many saints? John Paul doubtless has a number of objectives. The new saints reflect the worldwide presence of the church and stand in contrast to the modern cult of the self. But mainly they embody John Paul's view of history. Whereas many popes have seen the church as above or outside of history, he sees the church in the thick of it. So he has made saints of people who made history, however controversially. Last month, for example, when he canonized Edith Stein, a Jewish philosopher who converted to Catholicism, became a nun, then was killed as a Jew at Auschwitz, he affirmed -- defying scruple -- in effect that the church was on the right side of history during the Holocaust, suffering with the Jewish people.
The ensuing controversy hung on whether Edith Stein died as a Catholic or as a Jew. The controversy over Day is different. Nobody would deny that she was a Catholic, and most people think she was a saint, even those who care little for the church. What complicates matters is that these people don't agree about what it was that made her saintly. The tussle over her legacy is no simple tug-of-war between the Catholic left and the Roman right. It involves a range of conceptions of what it means to be Catholic, and the one that prevails very likely will be the prevailing form of Catholicism in the next century.
Cardinal O'Connor went to Rome in September, taking a sheaf of recollections of Dorothy Day written by her old friends. Meanwhile, in flats and tumbledown farmhouses and "houses of hospitality," Catholic Workers are watching his every move. Their friend and foundress is their pearl of great price. Each day she passes further out of their hands and into those of the church. If they are a touch possessive, who can blame them?
Twice a year, the patrons of the Radical New York Walking Tour pause at St. Joseph House on East First Street to hear the story of Dorothy Day. Before she was a saint, Day was a bohemian in Greenwich Village, drinking all night and wandering into strange churches at dawn. She rallied for the masses, went to jail, married on the rebound, wrote a novel, fell in love and bore a child, all before she abruptly became a Catholic at age 30 in 1927. Her lover scorned her. So did her radical friends. One day in 1932 she returned home to find Peter Maurin, a French "troubadour of God," waiting for her. They founded the Catholic Worker there and then.
Day called her Catholic Worker column On Pilgrimage, and she crisscrossed the country by bus to visit Catholic Worker houses, taking her breviary, her diary and a jar of instant coffee. She went to Cuba to meet Castro and to Rome to fast in St. Peter's Square for peace, yet was so identified with the Lower East Side that people would invariably show up at St. Joseph House and expect her to greet them at the door.
The house still looks the way it did when Day was in charge, furnished with beat-up chairs and a cast-iron stove out of a Grimm tale. A pot of coffee brews perpetually. The movement names no leaders; in New York, the closest thing is Carmen Trotta, a musclebound 35-year-old man with thick brown hair.
He and I set out to join a few old-time Workers for further clarification of thought at a local bar. "In the old days," he says, "the Workers would stand on the corner selling copies of the paper until they had enough change for a drink. You'd have to sell an awful lot of papers today."
The Catholic Worker newspaper still costs a penny a copy. It is still a broad sheet full of articles about labor, politics and the life of faith, with a statement of "Aims and Means": yes to "personalism," manual labor and a green revolution, no to usury and bureaucracy. But the subject between the lines is change. While Day and Maurin aspired to "build a new society within the shell of the old," today a new society is being built in the shell of the old Lower East Side. Galleries and boutiques have replaced the junk shops and flophouses. The Workers used to serve 300 meals a day; now they serve half as many.
Some people have suggested that the Catholic Workers have outlived their mission in the Village, but they are there to stay, questioning change. How should they respond to gentrification -- by protesting, by homesteading or by founding a satellite house in the Bronx? Should they welcome Ivy League volunteers who want to pad their resumes, or insist on poverty as a way of life? These questions are usually answered through further clarification of thought. So Carmen Trotta spends many hours with the old-timers asking them what Dorothy would have done.
Yet Day's refusal to institutionalize the movement has left Catholic Worker houses elsewhere free to experiment. Unity Kitchen Committee in Syracuse offers "lavish hospitality" -- dinner with china, cutlery and fresh flowers -- as a response to Day's adage that "nothing is too good for the poor." Casa Juan Diego in Houston provides English classes, sanctuary for illegal aliens, first aid for battered women and coffins for the dead. After the Archdiocese of Los Angeles announced plans to build a new cathedral -- estimated cost, $163 million -- Catholic Workers broke into the old one and hung a banner out the bell tower: "We Reclaim the Church for the Poor."
So it is no great surprise that the Catholic Workers have as many ways of being Catholic as of serving soup. A house in California sponsored "a gay marriage" (the two men later "divorced"), and one in Denver held a mock Mass led by some Sisters of Loreto. "There are some crazy joints out there, some things that would turn a bishop's hair a little whiter," says Tom Cornell, an old Worker who now lives at Peter Maurin Farm in upstate New York.
How vital is the Catholic faith to the Catholic Worker's mission? Ann O'Connor of Unity Kitchen thinks the Worker must be more faithful to the church; Jeff Dietrich thinks the church must become more like the Worker, strengthening its "prophetic dimension" through street protests. And while Mark and Louise Zwick of Casa Juan Diego in Houston think prayer and worship are as vital as rice and beans (when supplies run low, they pray), the Workers at St. Francis of Assisi House in Chicago say that they are first and foremost anarchists.
The Catholic Worker is Catholic, but it is unsure how or why. Its members hold beliefs ranging from traditionalism to the radical fringe, with each deciding for himself or herself what the faith is. It is like the Catholic Church throughout the United States, that is, and the question -- in the movement, and in the church -- is whether this diversity is a form of strength or a kind of religious decadence.
Last January, the new Archbishop of Chicago shook up a group of lay leaders by declaring that "liberal Catholicism is an exhausted project." Curious, I paid him a visit one evening at his residence, a Victorian pile on the Gold Coast, the ritziest neighborhood in Chicago. Dusk was falling on the lake, and the house's 19 chimneys stood out against it like upraised fists at a rally.
Francis Cardinal George wears big glasses and walks with a limp. He showed me around the mansion, plainly ill at ease there ("this decor is early funeral parlor"), and we settled in the only small room in the place. His predecessor, Joseph Bernardin, stared down at us from his portrait.
The Cardinal declared his enthusiasm for the cause of Day, recalling the time she shocked his seminary class by criticizing President Kennedy. "It's the Catholic Worker now that I'm worried about," he told me. "At the end of her life she said, 'They've turned day into night,' and I fear she was right."
I asked him to explain his remark about "liberal Catholicism." He began by stressing that Day was no liberal. "She was an anarchist," he said. "Now, there's no reason why an anarchist can't be a saint. All kinds of people have been saints. But for all her anarchism, she said nothing about the structure of the church. No, she was an anarchist because she saw the state, the modern liberal nation-state, as a rival to God's church."
So who were the liberals? The Cardinal declined to name names. "Liberal Catholics are people who look to the culture to reform the church. Nowadays, if you're a feminist, say, you see the church as just one more sinful structure in need of reform. But remember, Dorothy Day did not turn her criticism of the social order on the church. Don't get me wrong. I don't mean that church leaders and even church structures aren't open to criticism. But if you call into question the entire Christian project, as the liberals do, you end up with nothing but a critique, and the air gets thinner and thinner and the church becomes a club for good causes. That's not what Dorothy Day was about."
I cast my eye around the Cardinal's house, which owes as much to the culture of Gilded Age Chicago as to the Catholic Church. Dorothy Day sought to make the rich poor and the poor holy. What did he make of this?
"Dorothy Day was a romantic of poverty -- she saw poverty as a sign of God's presence," he said. "Her view is important. It will always be important. But it will always be on the fringes of the church as a corrective, not as mainstream Catholicism. Anarchy is not mainstream Catholicism."
Cardinal George's view is what one would expect from a traditional Catholic churchman, celebrating a holy woman for her fidelity to the church. But it also reflects the assumptions of Catholic neoconservatives.
Day and Maurin initially opposed the New Deal, believing that charity was no business for "Holy Mother the State." So neocons and "theocons" (religious neocons) have invoked Day as an antiliberal spokeswoman, posthumously opposing the welfare state.
How can the court philosophers of the Republican Party claim a poor anarchist as one of their own? By way of the very paradox that led the poor anarchist to Catholicism in the first place. Day was drawn to the church when she realized that the huddled masses she loved were not Communists but Catholics. So it is for the neoconservatives. They see the church as the only organization that can persuade the masses to resist the liberal, vulgar, consumerist drift of American society. So Day must be held up as an ordinary, decent Catholic whom the people in the pews can emulate, even as they vote their pocketbooks.
Yet Day thought "policy" a dirty word. "For Catholic Workers, the soup line is the think tank and the seminar room," says Patrick Jordan, an editor of Commonweal and a former Catholic Worker. "That's where you make policy."
Nowhere is this more so than with abortion. When Day became pregnant in 1919, the father threatened to leave her unless she aborted the child. She did so, but he left her anyway. When she became pregnant again, this time by a man she loved, "I knew that I was going to have my baby baptized a Catholic, cost what it may," she said. It cost her her lover. Her conversion followed.
Today, while many, even most, Catholic Workers see abortion as an act of violence that must be resisted, they see the church's campaign against legal abortion as an attempt to enlist the state to enforce holiness. When USA Today reported Cardinal O'Connor's remark that Day might become "the patron saint of the pro-life movement," many Workers were alarmed. At a meeting in Nashua, N.H., an old Worker named Jack Cook rose in his chair and denounced the plan as "a form of spiritual abuse." He was applauded. "She could have, at any time, come out publicly and politically against abortion," Cook explained. "She did not.. . . When she spoke of abortion, it was in terms of forgiveness, not criminality."
Day's response to abortion is crucial to the canonization process because she is a role model for thousands of Catholic women in the United States, an American Mother Teresa. The two figures -- who met in India in 1970 -- are often cast as the two archetypes of contemporary Catholic activism: one a nun who stressed charity, the other a lay woman who called for justice. In a talk last year, though, the Jesuit priest Thomas Reese stressed what they had in common -- not as women but as devout Catholics who had devoted themselves to fixing the world rather than reforming the church. Father Reese went on to ask why so many Catholics are bent on the latter, why the conflicts among Catholics often seem like quarrels over a brand name, with the players so worked up over what it means to be Catholic that they lose sight of the holy.
The obvious reason is that the church stands in need of reform. But there are reasons behind the reasons. It may be that the Catholic leaders who would confront society -- the Mother Teresas and Dorothy Days -- are in short supply. The experts expatiate on the shortage of priests, but the real shortage is of authentic Catholic leaders of any kind -- of the saints among the living, that is.
Aug. 6 is the Feast of the Transfiguration, devoted to the Gospel episode in which Jesus blazed bright before two disciples' eyes. It is also the date the atomic bomb was dropped on Hiroshima, and pacifists grimly mark the day.
This August, a group of Catholic Workers fasted for three weeks on the sidewalk in front of the United Nations, urging an end to sanctions against Iraq. Aug. 6 was their 12th day, and the previous evening, Daniel Berrigan said Mass for them at St. Joseph House. He has said Mass there off and on for 30 years, and he, more than anybody, is seen there as Dorothy Day's successor, a Catholic striving to be holy. But Berrigan is not a leader. Since he fled the F.B.I. in 1970 after burning Federal draft files, he has held to the path of radical purity and apartness.
Berrigan rose from his seat to give the homily; draping a stole over his paisley shirt, he consecrated the Eucharist at the prep table in the back. Then the fasters, drawn and wasted, trudged toward him to receive Communion. They were among old-timers and college students, young Jesuits and aged nuns, married couples with their kids. Carmen Trotta ambled up to the altar, his hair cut military-short; he had organized a "demo" at the U.N. for the next day.
The Catholic Worker felt, just then, like an authentic community. Yet something -- someone -- was absent. Long after Day's death, her sanctity is preventing a successor from emerging to lead the movement. The Worker, like the church in general in this country, is so agonized over its structure and the integrity of its name that it scants the personal sanctity that could bind it together.
"Whatever I had read as a child about the saints had thrilled me," Day once wrote. "I could see the nobility of giving one's life for the sick, the maimed, the leper." But, she recalled, even as a child, she asked: "Why was so much done in remedying the evil instead of avoiding it in the first place? . . .Where were the saints to try to change the social order, not just to minister to the slaves, but to do away with slavery?"
The child responded by becoming a saint herself. As it happened, her sanctity demanded more than social change. It lay in her ability to reconcile opposed ideas and make the result seem the soul of fidelity. Robert Ellsberg has called her a Saint of Common Ground, around whom very different people can come together and try to be holy. But she just as well might be known as the Patron Saint of Paradox. Her life, with all its parts, was of a piece.
The only St. Dorothy, then, is the whole Dorothy Day. Even at its swiftest, the canonization process will extend well into the next century, as the saint-makers take depositions from people who knew her, draft a hagiography, judge any miracles and try to see whither the spirit bloweth. Meanwhile, there will be conflicts over what she did and what she meant. People will read her books and pray for her intercession. Some will give their lives to her work. Some will give a few Saturday mornings. The Catholic Workers will play devil's advocate; and if and when the banner bearing her likeness is unfurled at St. Peter's, the Catholic Church will be a little more like the Catholic Worker, if only because of all the further clarification of thought along the way.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 28; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 987 words

HEADLINE: On Language;
The E-Lancer Eats a Bagelwich

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
How are new words created? What's the logic behind neologisms? How can you, working at home, coin your own words for fun and profit?
Here is how you can amaze your friends and dismay your derogators by displaying your hidden ingenuity. The secret: knowing your combining forms. 
 Take -ware. This started out in the Sanskrit vasna, "price," and came to mean, in English, things of value -- "goods." We used this combining form for articles made of clay (earthenware) or a range of tools (hardware). Then, in 1960, as computers came on the scene, we had the need for a word to describe the programming needed to go with the hardware. Coinage: software, the opposite of "hard" with the combining form-ware. That was only the beginning: if a company promises new software and doesn't meet its deadline, the nonproduct is derided as vaporware.
Last month, in a harangue against gloom-and-doom economists wringing their hands about a global crisis, I had the need for a name for what ailed them. What's the combining form for an ailment? Often it's -itis, as in sinusitis. So I blazed away at those afflicted with global crisis-itis. Strictly a nonce coinage, but it fit the moment's vituperative need.
In the spring 1998 issue of American Speech, A Quarterly of Linguistic Usage, Adrienne Lehrer of the University of Arizona has an article about "Scapes, Holics and Thons: The Semantics of English Combining Forms." She describes how "source words" like Watergate get splintered, with a portion becoming a combining form, from Carter's Billygate to Reagan's Irangate to Clinton's Monicagate. In the same way alcoholic spawned workaholic and chocoholic, as -holic became a combining form meaning "hooked on."
Take a familiar word like sandwich, a culinary creation named after the fourth Earl of Sandwich in 1762. Say you are a bagel baker and you want to use your product instead of bread to purvey smoked salmon and cream cheese. You put up a sign: bagelwich. Everyone instantly knows you are pushing a sandwich made on a bagel. Across the street, a Francophile competitor puts up his own sign: croissantwich, and your customers desert you, mouths fixed for croissants stuffed with the filling of their choice.
Same with hamburger, originally chopped meat enjoyed by residents of Hamburg, Germany. Using the -burger combining form, we come up with cheeseburger and now veggieburger, with a score of variations in between. You get the meaning instantly with no explanation needed, even if you've never seen or heard the word before. Quick: what is a turkeyfurter? (It could be wurst: Would you like to wash one down with a vodkatini? You need no help to make the leap to these neologisms based on frankfurter and martini.)
Jargonauts (a play on Argonauts and an example of the -nauts combiner used by Reaganauts) like to use -speak as their combiner. The source word is George Orwell's newspeak, and it spawned everything from my Haigspeak (Al Haig's "Snakecheck that" and shades-of-gray nuancal) to the San Fernando Valley girls' Valspeak ("grody to the max").
Let's leave behind the -holics and -thons. (Just as a television marathon blends to telethon, an unending stream of faxes becomes a faxathon.) We can also skip the -scapes. (Landscape, the source word, led to coinages of seascape, moonscape, cityscape and Xeriscape, "parks created with little need for water.")
Turn to the fifth letter of the Roman alphabet for the combining form now most in vogue: I've been keeping a fair weather eye on the letter E.
"More of us will work as E-lancers," said Snigdha Prakash, an NPR reporter, in the course of an interview, defining the term as "free agents who are electronically linked to other soloists for specific projects, and move on when the work is done." These are the unaffiliated employed ("drifters," we used to call them), and the term is a rhyming play on freelancer, originally a mercenary soldier of the Middle Ages, now often a middle-aged soloist.
When electronic mail, coined in 1977, was shortened five years later to E-mail, it became the combining form of the Information Age, muscling aside its competition on the prefix menu, cyber- (from the Greek kybernan, "to govern").
Now we have E-text published in an E-zine (often shortened and pronounced "zeen"). You can buy an airline E-ticket with E-money or E-bucks (terms that have bankrupted cybercash), unless you want to use E-credit, a form of Internet dealing known as E-commerce or E-tailing. That last is a play on retailing and, as in E-lancer, the letter E does not stand only for "electronic."
Dr. Wayne Glowka, an editor of the Among the New Words section of American Speech, reports that E-gifts of E-bouquets are often given by members of the E-generation. (Want to subscribe? Send $35 to Duke University Press, Box 90660, Durham, N.C. 27708-0660. Sorry, I don't know how to do it electronically.)
All of this, plus generations of new terms as yet uncoined, will be sneered at as E-speak, a product -- just think of it -- of two combining forms, which I have just coined this instant unless some E-reader of my E-text beat me to it.
 
NOBODY'S PERFECT
In a smirking swipe at the use of "what is is" by the only President we have, a language maven noted that has there been was in the past perfect tense.
As Lise Nazarenko, a lecturer in English at the University of Vienna, noted: "Has there been is not in the past perfect tense, but rather in the present perfect tense. Past perfect would be had there been."
Perfect, in its most familiar sense, means "flawless"; in an earlier sense, it meant "complete." That sense of "finished" is what we use in grammar: a verb form expressing an action that is complete at the time of speaking or at the time spoken of. And since has is present and had is past,"has there been" is, as the entire Gotcha! Gang has gleefully pointed out, in the present perfect tense.

HEADLINE: SUNDAY: NOVEMBER 8, 1998: THE NATIONAL DEBT;
Depressing Displays

 BODY:
From its perch over the Hop Won Express restaurant on Sixth Avenue in New York City, between 42d and 43d Streets, the National Debt Clock has been bumming out pedestrians since 1986. It is a computerized billboard, consisting of 305 light bulbs, that keeps track of America's outstanding loans, adding an average of nearly $10,000 a second to a number that has topped $5 trillion.
 But in the second week of September the Debt Clock shut down. Why? Had the first budget surplus in years ended the debt crisis? Could we celebrate? 
 Nope. The man with the answers is Douglas Durst, president of the Durst Organization, a New York real-estate developer whose late father, Seymour Durst, put the clock up at his own expense to remind America of its fiscal recklessness. Durst says the clock went black simply because "the computer couldn't take it anymore -- the numbers were too high." But, he adds, "we're fixing it."
 The repair job falls to the Artkraft Strauss Sign Corporation, which originally built and installed the clock. Tama Starr, company president, says the clock's computer conked out at around $5.5 trillion. To fix it, Artkraft is installing a newer, more powerful computer, a modern desktop that can be controlled by either Artkraft or Durst. The Debt Clock should be up and bumming again by the end of the month.
